Disciplines - CS Revolution for MSPs'The secret of change is to focus all of your energy not on fighting the old, but on building the new.' — Socrates.  Unlocking Customer Success: The Six Essential Disciplines for MSP TransformationThe old models won't work in today’s hyper-competitive MSP landscape. You’ve felt the constant pressure to deliver more value, rise above commoditization, and move beyond merely fixing problems to becoming a trusted strategic partner for your clients. But this transformation doesn’t happen by chance; it demands intentionality, structure, and clarity. It requires a new way of thinking, powered by a disciplined methodology that puts customer success at its core.The journey from reactive vendor to proactive partner isn’t easy. But we’ve seen it work again and again. The MSPs winning today have adopted a structured approach to Customer Success, centred on six key disciplines that guide their actions and interactions. These disciplines form a robust framework to deliver measurable business outcomes, foster loyalty, drive differentiation, and elevate your MSP from commodity provider to indispensable partner.Have you ever tried to hit a golf ball straight down the fairway? If you have, you know there are at least four things you must get right:1. Choose the right club for the distance and lie, just as you must pick the right business goal to pursue with a client.2. Address the ball—stance, alignment, and posture, just as you must set up your team, data, and process to align with that goal.3. Grip the club correctly, just as you need a solid playbook and tools in your CS toolkit.4. Swing on the right path—follow through just as you must execute with discipline and rhythm.Miss any one of those, and your ball slices into the rough. In Customer Success, the stakes are even higher: you’re not hitting a ball by yourself, you’re orchestrating a team of CSMs, vCIOs, engineers and your client’s stakeholders. Every element—from goal?setting to follow?up—must work together, every time.This book will show you how to build that repeatable, integrated “swing” so you not only hit the ball, but drive measurable business impact for every client.
The Five Levels of Client GoalsRather than a generic “maturity” scale, we anchor our program in what clients want to achieve. The MSP's role and your CS approach must shift as they move from basic IT support to true innovation.1. Level 1: Technology Support Deliver reliable monitoring, backups, incident response and basic reporting—so clients feel confident that the lights stay on.2. Level 2: Technology Enablement Drive discrete projects and align tools—onboarding new applications, improving security posture—so clients can operate more smoothly.3. Level 3: Technology Modernization Standardize platforms, close gaps, and adopt best?in?class solutions—so clients know they’re protected and future?ready.4. Level 4: Business Transformation Leverage technology to streamline processes, boost productivity, and automate routine work, so clients can shift their teams to higher?value tasks.5. Level 5: Business Innovation Co?author strategic roadmaps, pilot emerging tech (AI, advanced analytics), and embed innovation into the culture, so clients gain a true competitive advantage.As clients progress through these five levels, your CS program must evolve: from different deliverables to deeper engagements, new playbooks, fresh metrics, and ultimately, a seat at the client’s strategy table.
Introducing the Six?Discipline CS MethodologyTo guide clients through those five levels—and to ensure you never leave any element to chance—we organize everything into six integrated disciplines. Think of them as the six facets of your “swing”:1. CS Strategy - Define how you’ll segment clients, package services, and allocate capacity so clients get the right experience for their goal level.2. CS Health - Choose and track a few metrics—adoption, engagement, satisfaction, service quality, and alignment—to know exactly where each client stands.3. CS Deliverables - Build the right artifacts—reports, assessments, budgets, strategic plans, roadmaps—that connect directly to client goals and CS Health.4. CS Process - Standardize your workflows—playbooks, triggers, preparation, delivery, follow?up—so every meeting and milestone is purposeful, consistent, and scalable.5. CS People - Staff and structure your team—roles, responsibilities, enablement, compensation, governance—around the goals and processes you’ve defined.6. CS Technology - Implement the tools and integrations that automate routine tasks, surface insights and keep everyone aligned on the same real?time data.These six disciplines don’t live in isolation—they form a hexagon of capability. Each client engagement is a cycle:? Annual strategy and goal?setting (Disciplines 1 & 6)? Quarterly health reviews and roadmap updates (Disciplines 2 & 3)? Weekly process execution and follow?up (Discipline 4)? Ongoing people enablement and tech tuning (Disciplines 5 & 6)In the following chapters, we’ll dive into each discipline—step by step—so you can master the art and science of Customer Success for MSPs, level by level.
1. Understanding Client Goals: The Foundation of All SuccessEvery successful Customer Success (CS) methodology begins with a clear understanding of your client’s business goals. After all, technology itself isn’t the end goal; it’s merely a means to achieving something bigger. Whether it’s seamless operations, modernization, process transformation, or market innovation, every client has unique objectives guiding their technology decisions.By deeply understanding these goals, you can tailor your approach and services to their strategic priorities. This alignment shifts your conversations from technical jargon about servers and bandwidth to strategic dialogue about growth, efficiency, and competitive advantage. It elevates your MSP from technical expert to strategic enabler.We’ve identified five distinct levels of client goals, ranging from basic operational support to business innovation. Whether clients simply want smooth-running systems or seek transformative market leadership, knowing exactly where they stand on this spectrum helps you deliver the right conversations, insights, and deliverables at the right time.2. Measuring the Right Things: Customer Success HealthOnce you understand what success looks like for your clients, measuring progress toward these goals becomes critical. This discipline defines clear, relevant metrics for client health beyond basic SLA reports and trouble tickets. Measuring customer health means tracking client experience, technology adoption, engagement, service quality, and service alignment. It’s about seeing the complete picture of how your client benefits from your services and pinpointing where they might encounter obstacles.Imagine knowing exactly which clients are thriving and which are at risk. Imagine proactively identifying when a client starts to disengage before they consider leaving. This insight allows you to intervene early, adjust your approach, and continuously improve the client’s journey. It’s not about numbers for numbers’ sake; it’s about information that empowers meaningful action.3. Delivering Tangible Value: Customer Success DeliverablesClients today crave more than just conversations; they need tangible evidence of the value you provide. This is where CS Deliverables come into play—clear, structured, consistent outputs such as reports, strategic assessments, budgets, action-oriented plans, and roadmaps.These deliverables aren’t just paperwork. They’re powerful tools that capture your strategic insights and recommendations, aligning your MSP’s activities with the client’s long-term business outcomes. Whether creating a multi-year technology budget, providing detailed compliance assessments, or delivering strategic innovation roadmaps, your deliverables clearly illustrate your value in terms that your client’s executives understand and appreciate.Strong deliverables become a regular part of client interactions, creating transparency, accountability, and trust. They shift the perception of your MSP from a reactive service provider to a proactive strategic advisor.4. Creating Consistency: Customer Success ProcessesConsistency is critical to scaling Customer Success effectively. Without clearly defined processes, every client interaction becomes unpredictable and inconsistent. Good intentions aren’t enough; MSPs must establish repeatable workflows that ensure disciplined execution across every client touchpoint.This discipline involves creating standardized playbooks for onboarding, quarterly business reviews (QBRs), strategic planning sessions, and crisis management. It means establishing clear triggers to initiate proactive engagements, preparing thoroughly before every client interaction, and always closing the loop with disciplined follow-up.When processes are clear and consistent, your team can operate with confidence. Clients feel understood, valued, and supported at every step. Over time, this consistency builds trust, reinforces your value, and positions your MSP as a dependable strategic partner, rather than just another vendor.5. Empowering Your Team: Customer Success PeopleBehind every excellent Customer Success methodology lies a dedicated, empowered team. Your team members, not the technology alone, drive your client’s experience. Defining roles is essential, providing the tools and training your people need, and incentivizing their performance in ways aligned with client success outcomes.This discipline means clarifying who handles what, from Technical Account Managers (TAMs) monitoring day-to-day service quality, to virtual Chief Information Officers (vCIOs) driving strategic alignment, to dedicated Customer Success Managers (CSMs) ensuring overall client health and engagement. Each role must be clearly defined, trained, and empowered to deliver on your customer success promise.When your team knows exactly their responsibilities and how their performance is measured, they’re positioned to deliver consistently excellent experiences. They become advocates for your clients, proactively solving problems and seeking opportunities to add strategic value.6. Leveraging Technology to Scale: Customer Success ToolsFinally, the right technology infrastructure must support your Customer Success strategy. While technology itself is never the whole solution, it’s essential for scaling your CS operations, improving efficiency, and enabling data-driven decisions.Leveraging technology means integrating platforms that help you manage client portfolios, track health metrics, automate reporting, and streamline processes. It includes tools to manage playbooks, document deliverables, and ensure consistent client experiences. Increasingly, it also means embracing AI-driven insights to identify risks, opportunities, and strategic recommendations proactively.With powerful technology supporting your team, your MSP can scale customer success without sacrificing quality. It frees your people to spend less time managing administrative details and more time engaging clients, solving strategic problems, and driving innovation.What Makes This Methodology Work?MSPs often appear identical on the surface—offering similar services, technologies, and even organizational charts—but the subtle nuances make massive operational and strategic differences. What works for a small shop with one technician moonlighting as AM, TAM, and vCIO won’t translate to a larger MSP with defined CS roles across a matrixed team.Our methodology works because it acknowledges these differences. It’s not a one-size-fits-all approach—it’s a modular system powered by MSP Archetypes. Whether you're an owner-operator wearing every hat, a team with a dedicated Account Manager, or a mature CS organization with vCIOs, vCISOs, and strategic teams, this methodology adapts to you.We’ve also embedded Client Archetypes, which help tailor CS engagement based on the client's technology maturity and business appetite, ranging from support-focused to innovation-driven organizations.This methodology is robust because:? It leverages best practices already in use by leading Managed Service Providers (MSPs)—then orchestrates them into a single, adoptable system.? It supports a gradual path to execution excellence, allowing you to start small and evolve at your own pace.It drives alignment between business goals and technical deliverables, making customer success a measurable, strategic function.When applied consistently, the methodology delivers predictability, scalability, and genuine business impact for both MSP and client. Methodology Design AssumptionsCustomer Success isn’t one-size-fits-all. If we ignore the messy, real-world dynamics of how MSPs and clients operate, any methodology will collapse under the weight of theory. These assumptions ground the framework in truth: MSPs are diverse, clients evolve at different paces, and success is built through alignment, not abstraction. By designing for reality, not fantasy, we ensure this system works whether you're a solo operator managing five clients or a CS leader scaling strategic outcomes across hundreds. These principles don’t just shape the methodology—they protect it from becoming shelfware.1. MSP Archetypes Are Real - MSPs vary in terms of size, structure, and maturity. Our methodology assumes you might be a one-person CS team or a matrixed organization, and it adapts accordingly.2. Client Archetypes Shape Engagement - We design around client maturity and appetite for technology: Supporters, Enablers, Modernizers, Transformers, and Innovators.3. Commitment to Service Excellence - The MSP is committed to becoming its clients’ most valuable partner, not just a vendor.4. Client Success Drives MSP Success - Success is no longer just about uptime, but about delivering measurable business impact and proving your strategic value.5. Innovation is a Shared Responsibility - MSPs and clients share the responsibility of evolving; products, services, and delivery models must keep pace with market shifts.6. The CS Role Is Multifaceted - CS isn’t one person—it’s a set of roles (AM, vCIO, vCISO, vCTO, TAM) united by a shared purpose: enabling, aligning, and innovating.7. People Are Wired to Solve Problems - Our system empowers the people closest to the client to identify and solve real business problems.8. Data-Informed Engagement Wins - Gut Feel and Goodwill Aren't Enough. Data—about health, adoption, engagement, and outcomes—must guide action. Methodology Design RequirementsA methodology is only as robust as it is practical. These design requirements serve as the guardrails that transform strategic intent into daily execution. They ensure the system is scalable, data-driven, and AI-native from day one—because time, not willpower, is the real enemy of Customer Success. By reducing friction, embedding habits, and aligning people to outcomes, we create a framework that works in motion, not just theory. This isn’t about adding work; it’s about architecting a system that does the job with you. When every team, tool, and touchpoint reinforces the same goal—client success—you deliver not just value, but also a unified approach. You compound it.1. AI First - The most significant barrier of CS is the requirement of time to understand clients, prepare meetings, create follow-ups, all of which can be supported by well-designed AI2. Make It Easier - Reduce friction. Use tools, templates, and workflows that minimize overhead and maximize outcomes.3. Think Holistically About the Business - See the client’s full context, including strategy, operations, risk, and goals, and map technology for business purposes.4. Be Process-Driven - Utilize standardized processes and playbooks to ensure consistency and scalability, tailored to each client segment.5. Establish Habits - Anchor CS in recurring cadences: QBRs, strategic planning, roadmap reviews, etc.6. Promote Continuous Innovation - Always seek better ways to serve clients—productize improvements, refine playbooks, launch new value.7. Instill Constructive Accountability - Define what “winning” looks like. Align teams to measurable client outcomes and shared ownership.8. Build a Measurement Culture - Measure what matters—client health, adoption, engagement, experience—and act on insights.9. Proactively Pursue Alignment - Utilize strategy, data, and cadence to keep everyone focused on shared goals, rather than just reactive tasks.10. Encourage Effective Communication Create clear channels, templates, and structures to promote client collaboration and internal alignment.11. Leverage Technology - Use CS tools that support visibility, repeatability, and decision-making across all teams and clients.Reading Tips for 'Customer Success Methodology for MSPs'Read This Through Your LensThis methodology isn’t just for one role—it’s a system designed to serve every player in the client success game. Whether you’re a growth-minded MSP, a frontline operator, or a forward-thinking client, how you engage with this material will vary. So read it through your lens:MSP ClientsAmbitious Clients of MSPsIf you want more than “keeping the lights on,” this is your playbook. Learn how high-performing clients collaborate with MSPs to turn technology into a growth engine—and a moat.Executive StakeholdersYou're shaping the direction of your company. This methodology demonstrates how the best leverage their MSP as a strategic growth partner—not just for technical execution, but for insights, innovation, and a competitive edge.Internal Champions You’re on the ground, executing plans and keeping operations running. This will help you understand how to extract more value from your MSP relationship, align on goals, and drive tangible business outcomes faster.MSP RolesOwner-OperatorYou’re wearing multiple hats. This system gives you the structure to deliver consistency today and confidently scale tomorrow. Think of it as your franchise model for strategic service delivery.COOYou make it all work. This is your blueprint for operationalizing CS across functions, instilling habits, assigning accountability, and driving measurable outcomes at scale.Service TeamsYou’re closest to the action. This methodology shows how your work impacts CS health, retention, and client perception—so execution becomes strategic, not just technical.Sales TeamsCS isn't just post-sale—it's your growth pipeline. Use QBRs, roadmap outcomes, and health data insights to identify upsell, renewal, and cross-sell opportunities rooted in real client value.Customer Success RolesAccount Manager (AM)You're the voice of the relationship. Utilize structured playbooks and health metrics to deliver a consistent client experience, enhance retention, and identify needs before they become issues.Technical Account Manager (TAM)You keep the technical trains running on time. This framework ties your service delivery to business outcomes, giving your work greater visibility and strategic weight.Virtual CIO (vCIO)You own the roadmap. This is your toolkit for moving clients from transformation support—using structured planning, goal alignment, and measurable impact.Virtual CISO (vCISO)Security is your domain. This methodology demonstrates how to integrate risk and compliance into the broader CS motion, ensuring security isn’t just a checkbox—it’s a driver of trust and informed decision-making.Virtual CTO (vCTO)You're the innovator. This system can be used to embed future-proofing into the client relationship, connecting technology trends to business advantage.
Bringing It All Together: The Power of a Structured ApproachThese six disciplines—understanding client goals, measuring customer satisfaction (CS) health, creating value-driven deliverables, standardizing processes, empowering your team, and leveraging technology—work together as an integrated system. Each discipline supports and enhances the others, creating a comprehensive methodology that transforms your MSP into an indispensable strategic partner.Imagine the power of aligning every client interaction around clearly defined business objectives. Imagine having real-time visibility into client health, enabling you to take proactive action. Picture the confidence your team gains from consistent processes, clear roles, and strong supporting technology. Think of your strategic conversations, guided by structured deliverables that clearly communicate your value.MSPs who adopt this disciplined approach don’t just survive—they thrive. They build lasting, loyal relationships with their clients, differentiate themselves in crowded markets, and position themselves for sustainable growth.This isn’t just theory. It’s the reality for MSPs who’ve embraced the Customer Success revolution.
?? Client Business Goals
Client Business GoalsThe Foundation of Customer SuccessThe 5 Levels of Client Business Goals1.1. Technology Support1.2. Technology Enablement1.3. Technology Modernization (Where most MSPs operate today)1.4. Business Transformation1.5. Business Innovation
The Foundation of Customer SuccessAt the heart of a modern Customer Success strategy for MSPs lies one crucial question: “What are our clients trying to achieve with technology?”Answering this question is the starting point for every high-impact CS program. Even the most polished deliverables, processes, or tools risk missing the mark if they fail to reflect the client’s business priorities.Clearly defined business goals help MSPs:? Align technology initiatives with business outcomes? Tailor CS activities to each client’s maturity and strategic appetite? Measure value based on business impact, not just service delivered? Standardize engagement across the portfolio? Inform segmentation, role definitions, and service levelsEach goal level reflects a unique combination of where the client is today (maturity) and what they’re ready for (appetite). Together, these determine how the MSP should engage—stabilizing infrastructure or co-planning innovation.The Client Business Goal model provides a clear path from support and enablement toward modernization, transformation, and innovation, ensuring every CS motion is aligned with client readiness and strategic ambition.
The 5 Levels of Client Business Goals 1.1. Technology SupportFocus: Reliable, well-managed infrastructureClient Need: “Just keep things running.”At this level, clients have low maturity and low appetite. They rely on the MSP for stability, uptime, and issue resolution. Engagement is reactive and measured through SLAs, ticketing, and service quality.Typical Roles: Owner/Founder, Field Technician, Helpdesk1.2. Technology EnablementFocus: Stabilizing operations and delivering foundational projectsClient Need: “Help us manage IT better.”Clients begin adopting core tools and delivery structures. The MSP introduces onboarding playbooks, standard deliverables, and visible risk mitigation. Appetite grows, but maturity is still forming.Typical Roles: Service Delivery Manager, Technical Account Manager1.3. Technology Modernization (Where most MSPs operate today)Focus: Aligning IT environments to best practices and security standardsClient Need: “Ensure we’re up to date and secure.”Clients expect lifecycle planning, stack standardization, and structured cadence (QBRs, budgets, reports). Both maturity and appetite are developing. Strategic roles like vCIO begin to shape forward-looking planning.Typical Roles: Account Manager, vCIO1.4. Business TransformationFocus: Driving operational efficiency and strategic improvementClient Need: “Help us work smarter.”Clients have high maturity and an increasing appetite. The MSP supports process optimization, cross-departmental collaboration, and business-aligned initiatives. Technology becomes a means of measurable improvement.Typical Roles: Strategic Business Advisor, vCISO1.5. Business InnovationFocus: Enabling growth, differentiation, and strategic changeClient Need: “Help us grow and innovate.”Clients are high in both maturity and appetite. They treat technology as a driver of competitive advantage. The MSP co-plans strategic initiatives (e.g., AI, BI, transformation labs) with executive stakeholders. Services are tailored to departments and OKRs.Typical Roles: vCXO, SME Consultants (AI, BI, ISO, ERP)
?? 1. Technology Support
1. Technology Support Technology Support is the foundational Client Business Goal for MSPs, focused on delivering operational stability, visibility, and security in fragmented or reactive environments. Clients at this level are typically low maturity and low appetite, seeking to reduce risk, downtime, and support noise without yet engaging in strategic planning. This goal reflects a Low Impact / Low Engagement quadrant: the client wants IT to “just work” but is not yet investing in change.The MSP’s role is to stabilize the environment through monitoring, ticketing, reporting, and service delivery, driven by standard operating procedures (SOPs). This creates the first measurable proof of value and opens the door to future CS activities. By integrating basic elements of Health, Delivery, Process, People, and Strategy—even in minimal form—this level transforms firefighting into structured, trustworthy service that builds the foundation for growth, modernization, and future engagement.Strategic planning is minimal, but early segmentation and visibility practices can prepare the client for the next phase of enablement.OverviewWhat is the objective?Why is it important?As an MSP, why do I need to do this?What is the Customer impact?Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: Technology Support Is the Entry Point to Strategic ValueConcept #2: Support-Centric Clients Require Confidence, Not ComplexityConcept #3: Technology Support Clients Can Be High Risk—If MisreadConcept #4: The Role of CS Is to Create Visibility, Not UrgencyConcept #5: This Stage Defines the CS Baseline—and the Roadmap to ProgressImplementation Process1. Track Minimum Viable CS Health Metrics2. Deliver Consistent, Foundational Outputs3. Execute a Minimal CS Rhythm4. Assign Practical Roles and Responsibilities5. Calibrate Strategy Inputs to Segment D StandardsAppendixHow does it connect to the other parts?Product Links / Tooling SupportBest Practice IndicatorsExample Client Profile
OverviewWhat is the objective?To ensure clients have a reliable, well-managed, and visible IT infrastructure. The focus is on stabilization, visibility, and foundational readiness—helping clients reduce noise, resolve risks, and operate securely with minimal disruption.Why is it important?This is the foundation level of Customer Success:? Without operational stability, no strategic initiative can be sustained.? Enables trust, transparency, and early reporting habits.? Forming the first measurable proof of value between MSP and the client.As an MSP, why do I need to do this?? Positions the MSP as a trusted operator, not just a reactive provider? Makes performance visible and reportable? Opens the door for further CS initiatives once core systems are stable? Often enables a shift from firefighting to proactive task executionWhat is the Customer impact?At this stage, clients experience the MSP primarily as a reactive support function, rather than a strategic partner. They receive technical reliability, but little guidance or forward planning.? Impact: Low business impact – Services reduce operational noise (e.g., downtime, tickets) but don’t yet connect to outcomes like productivity, collaboration, or growth.Engagement: Low strategic engagement – Interactions are infrequent, typically issue-driven, and focused on support rather than planning or business value.Client mindset: “Just keep things running.”This quadrant—Low Impact / Low Engagement—is typical for:? New clients are in onboarding or rescue mode.? Long-time clients without strategic renewal.? Cost-sensitive clients who equate IT with utilities, rather than viewing it as a means of enablement.At this stage, even basic Discovery is often skipped, and strategic intake has yet to begin. These clients need early wins, not long decks.
Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: Technology Support Is the Entry Point to Strategic ValueTechnology Support is where most MSP-client relationships begin. It is the foundation layer of the Client Business Goal model—the starting point for any strategic co-planning or roadmap work.Clients operating at this level often:? Expect a reactive or ticket-based service? Focus on stability, uptime, and basic infrastructure? View the MSP as a technical responder rather than a business partnerThis mode of engagement aligns closely with Segment D clients, characterized by low engagement and low impact. The client’s immediate need is reliable support, not transformation or enablement. For MSPs, the objective is not to force strategy too early, but to stabilize operations and build trust.Concept #2: Support-Centric Clients Require Confidence, Not ComplexityAt the Technology Support level, clients are often in a reactive posture:? They may have legacy systems, minimal internal IT expertise, or a limited appetite for change? Their KPIs revolve around uptime, issue resolution, and responsiveness? Strategic initiatives may be perceived as disruptive or prematureThe goal at this stage is to deliver a consistent service experience with:? Clear escalation paths and SLA alignment? Basic lifecycle visibility (e.g., hardware refresh reminders)? Lightweight, support-relevant assessments or reviewsThese clients don’t need a vCIO—they need service and field technicians who can translate issues into patterns, stabilize workflows, and introduce maturity concepts over time in a gentle manner. However, in most MSPs at this level, the Customer Success function is not absent—it is typically owned by the owner or founder, who acts as the de facto strategic leader (or pseudo-vice chief information officer, or VCIO).This means that, although there is no dedicated vCIO role, someone still needs to maintain a minimum CS rhythm—typically annually—encompassing Discovery, Assessment, Annual Meeting, Initiative creation, and early strategic guidance.Concept #3: Technology Support Clients Can Be High Risk—If MisreadWhile these clients appear stable, they often lack:? Documentation and process discipline? Visibility into asset lifecycle or risk exposure? Strategic planning habitsThis makes them high-risk for reactive churn. A service outage or poor ticket experience can undermine the entire relationship because there is no broader strategic context to mitigate its impact.That’s why Customer Success at this level should still include:? Simple Health Metrics: Are We Resolving? Are they responsive? Are we showing up regularly?? Lightweight Discovery: What has changed in the client’s business? Are there early signs of appetite?? Segment-aware cadence: Annual reviews may suffice—but only if they happen.The goal is not to over-serve or overwhelm, but to consistently execute the basics and prepare for eventual maturity.Concept #4: The Role of CS Is to Create Visibility, Not UrgencyIn Technology Support relationships, urgency must be earned. These clients often don’t yet see the value of assessments, budgets, or roadmaps. That’s okay. The role of Customer Success here is to observe and document:? Where are the gaps in alignment or readiness?? What risks are being tolerated?? What pain could be solved by scalable solutions?Initiatives, when introduced, should be small, tangible, and directly linked to pain reduction (e.g., reducing ticket volume, solving recurring issues, consolidating vendor sprawl). The first step toward strategic CS is earning the right to propose.Concept #5: This Stage Defines the CS Baseline—and the Roadmap to ProgressTechnology Support is not a failure—it’s a phase. It represents where many clients naturally begin. The key is to:? Recognize their position in the maturity/appetite matrix? Align delivery cadence and expectations accordingly? Establish a system of record for Health, Adoption, and Engagement signals—even if they're limitedThis creates the baseline from which the client can grow. When Health indicators begin to shift (e.g., increasing responsiveness, openness to lifecycle discussions), the MSP can propose a discovery-driven transition toward lifecycle services, basic initiatives, and eventually roadmap collaboration.In most cases, the owner or founder is responsible for executing this progression. They must manage the entire early CS cycle—from Discovery to Assessment to Annual Meeting and Initiative definition—alongside their other executive duties.Assessments are not mandatory at this stage, but recommended, especially when the MSP wants to make clear that an initiative idea stems from client-acknowledged needs, not just internal recommendations.This creates a bottleneck not on the client side, but on the MSP side: lack of time, structure, and delegation often means these tasks are delayed or skipped. As a result, clients don’t experience the visibility, education, and strategic impression necessary to build an appetite.At this level, only a few small, pain-reduction initiatives are likely to emerge, and they are typically operational (e.g., reduce ticket noise, replace outdated hardware).Technology Support isn’t a dead end—it’s the front door to strategic partnership, if navigated with patience, structure, and consistency. Recognizing that the bottleneck is often internal is crucial for designing more effective early-CS support structures.
Implementation Process1. Track Minimum Viable CS Health MetricsIntroduce lightweight, foundational CS Health tracking. These clients don’t require advanced analytics—but a consistent signal baseline helps stabilize operations and anticipate future engagement.? 2.1 Client Experience - Use NPS or CSAT from support tickets to gauge satisfaction. Feedback loops should be simple and tied to issue resolution quality.? 2.2 Engagement - Measure incident/ticket volumes and frequency of structured meetings (even if annual). Avoid misinterpreting high ticket noise as high engagement.? 2.3 Technology Adoption - Track only essential coverage: monitored backups, antivirus, patching, and basic M365 usage. Avoid deep adoption scoring at this stage.? 2.4 Service Quality - Use SLA compliance (response + resolution times) and first-call resolution rate. These provide key indicators of reliability and service consistency.? 2.5 Service Level Alignment - Verify whether support activity matches the defined scope. Are we doing work outside contracted services? Are patching or backup expectations aligned?2. Deliver Consistent, Foundational OutputsStandardize the minimum required deliverables that help shift the client from reactive firefighting to visible, reliable service:? 3.1 Reports - Focus on monthly or quarterly Ticket Summaries, Backup Status, and Asset Lifecycle Reports. Ensure these are shared in a consistent format, even without a dedicated meeting.? Blueprints 3.2–3.5 (Proposal, Budget, Strategy, Roadmap) are not recommended at this stage. They may be introduced later through 4.4 Meeting or 4.5 Initiatives if maturity improves.3. Execute a Minimal CS RhythmAvoid overwhelming the client with strategic motions. Instead, adopt a minimal, cadence-based structure that introduces process without requiring buy-in for full engagement:? 4.1 Scheduling/Trigger - Define one annual strategic meeting, triggered by contract anniversary or renewal cycle. Monthly reporting may be shared asynchronously. Even this minimal cadence forms the backbone of early Customer Success rhythm.? 4.2 Discovery Intake (Business Discovery) - Introduce a lightweight Discovery conversation prior to the annual meeting. This is not an in-depth consultation—it is designed to ask basic business-context questions (e.g., recent changes, growth concerns, pain points). It helps detect early appetite signals and clarifies whether future initiatives may emerge.? 4.3 Meeting - Hold an Annual Check-in Meeting, even if it remains tactical. Use it to:? Confirm support expectations? Review simple performance reports? Highlight low-effort improvements (e.g., backup gaps, asset lifecycle risks)? 4.4 Assessment Intake (optional) - Introduce only if appetite is evident. Use a basic intake to define recurring technical or operational challenges. Assessment formats should be lightweight and pain-driven.? 4.5 Initiatives Limit to 1–2 operational pain-reduction initiatives per year. These may include:? Reducing ticket noise? Streamlining recurring support workflows? Replacing unsupported or unreliable hardware Initiatives should be owned by the MSP, but based on observations surfaced during Discovery and the Annual Meeting.4. Assign Practical Roles and ResponsibilitiesAt this stage, there are no dedicated strategic roles. Roles must be scoped narrowly to maintain delivery discipline while preparing the MSP for scale:? 5.1 Roles & 5.2 Responsibilities -The Owner/Founder acts as the TAM/vCIO proxy, owning:? Discovery conversations? The Annual Check-in Meeting? Initiative proposal and scope communication To prevent growth bottlenecks, this must be treated as a repeatable annual leadership task, not an ad hoc engagement.? Helpdesk / Field Tech / NOC/SOC teams are responsible for:? Consistent ticket resolution? Backup and asset status tracking? Visibility reporting? These teams should aim for regular, structured updates, not only ad hoc interventions. Their observations often form the trigger points for Discovery and Initiative suggestions.? The Owner/Founder must carve out dedicated time each year to ensure this rhythm occurs. Without at least Discovery and Meeting once annually, clients may stagnate at this level indefinitely. This responsibility should be treated as a leadership discipline, not an afterthought.? 5.3 Enablement - Provide entry-level enablement on:? Identifying recurring technical pain patterns? Communicating asset or coverage gaps to the Owner for follow-up? 5.4 Compensation - Strategic contributions are not expected or rewarded at this level. Should be aligned with:? SLA adherence? First-response resolution? Consistent reporting activity? 5.5 Governance - No formal governance exists. However, the Owner/Founder should review CS Health signals quarterly to:? Track segment fit? Catch missed meetings or reports? Adjust initiative scope or cadence based on ticket or Discovery input5. Calibrate Strategy Inputs to Segment D StandardsAvoid over-engineering the strategic framework. Focus on consistency, visibility, and readiness assessment—not transformation.? 1.1 Segmentation - Tag these clients as Segment D. Use Low Touch engagement and a cost-driven investment model (1–2% MRR guideline). Do not force lifecycle initiatives.? 1.2 Engagement Strategy - Apply semi-annual or annual cadences, asynchronous updates, and no proposal cycles. Ownership resides with support staff and the Owner.? 1.3 CS Playbooks - Deploy a Segment D playbook that defines:? Report formats? Annual meeting flow? Minimum initiative definition criteria? 1.4 Roadmaps -  Not applicable at this level unless an initiative emerges organically from a support trend. No proactive roadmap construction.? 1.5 Standardization - Ensure all outputs (Ticket Reports, Asset Snapshots, Backup Summaries) follow standardized Segment D templates. This enables early benchmarking and trend analysis.
AppendixHow does it connect to the other parts?? 1. Customer Success Strategy - Strategic planning is minimal. Clients at this level may be grouped into Segment D (Low Touch) and represent a Cost Driver–style investment model, characterized by a 1% allocation of Monthly Recurring Revenue (MRR), although this is only an example and not a fixed rule.? 2. Customer Success Health - At this stage, CS Health focuses on operational indicators, including SLA compliance, ticket trends, backup status, and CSAT. These metrics help MSPs monitor identity, surface recurring issues, and track growth in readiness and further maturity.? 3. Customer Success Delivery - Delivery is centred on operational reports and visibility tools, such as asset inventories, ticket summaries, and technology health assessments. These deliverables validate that core IT services are being delivered consistently and effectively.? 4. Customer Success Process - Processes are largely reactive or maintenance-driven. Typical triggers include incidents, renewals, or policy checks. Execution follows standard operating procedures (SOPs) for backup verification, patching, and incident reporting, ensuring baseline performance.? 6. Customer Success Team - Primary roles include Owner/Founder acting as Technical Account Manager (TAM), Helpdesk Support, Service/Field Technicians, and Security Operations Center (SOC)/Network Operations Center (NOC) staff. These roles are responsible for maintaining stability, monitoring systems, and reporting issues; no dedicated strategic roles have been engaged yet.Product Links / Tooling Support? LMx Client Health can track indicators like:? SLA response & resolution time? Ticket volume & aging? CSAT / NPS? Basic asset coverage & M365 usage? These inputs contribute to a health score that signals whether a client is ready to move beyond stabilization.onBest Practice IndicatorsAttributeTypical ProfileEnvironmentUnmanaged or fragmented systems, limited documentationRisk ExposureBackup unmonitored, outdated hardware, no proactive review cycleCS Role InvolvedOwner/Founder =TAM, Helpdesk Support, Service/Field Technicians, SOC/NOCDeliverablesBackup, Ticket, Asset Reports; Technology AssessmentEngagement CadenceMonthly or ad hoc reporting cyclesBusiness Goal Quote“Just keep things running.”CS FocusVisibility, reliability, risk reductionExample Client ProfileThe environment is non-standard with disparate vendors. Devices are out of warranty or beyond their lifecycle. Documentation is limited or offline. Backup is manual or unmonitored. The client wants IT to stop being a pain point, but lacks a clear plan and a long-term vision. They operate in firefighting mode and view IT as a cost, not a business enabler.
?? 2. Technology Enablement
2. Technology Enablement Technology Enablement is the first Client Business Goal where the MSP transitions from reactive support to proactive service delivery. Clients at this level typically exhibit low to medium maturity and a low appetite—their environments are partially aligned, but they’re not yet seeking full-scale change. This places them in a Low Business Impact / Medium–High Engagement quadrant: the client wants IT to “just work,” and is increasingly engaged in structured delivery, but not yet ready for strategic planning.The MSP’s role is to standardize and align services, reduce friction, and deliver structured projects, such as BCDR, stack alignment, or onboarding improvements. Planning begins to formalize—discovery, assessment, and cadence emerge—but most engagement remains operational. Done well, this stage creates the conditions for future modernization by building repeatable success, clear documentation, and increasing trust in the MSP’s structured delivery.OverviewWhat is the objective?Why is it important?As an MSP, why do I need to do this?What is the Customer impact?Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: Technology Enablement Is the First Step Toward Outcome-Focused ServiceConcept #2: Enablement Priorities Are Practical, Not StrategicConcept #3: Technology Enablement Is the Launch Point for Initiative-Based EngagementConcept #4: Enablement-Level Clients Need CS Structure, Not ComplexityConcept #5: Technology Enablement Matures the Relationship and Prepares for Strategic PlanningImplementation Process1. Define Segment and Cadence Expectations2. Track and Align Customer Success Health Signals3. Execute Cadence-Based CS Process4. Assign Roles and Enablement5. Use Strategy as a Framing Tool6. Prepare for Transition to ModernizationAppendixHow does it connect to the other parts?Product Links / Tooling SupportBest Practice IndicatorsExample Client Profile
OverviewWhat is the objective?To help clients better manage IT operations by aligning the tech stack, improving service quality, and delivering structured projects. The focus is on enabling productivity through stable, integrated tools and processes, supported by proactive MSP involvement.Why is it important?? Lays the groundwork for scalable, supportable IT environments? Moves the client from reactive firefighting toward structured service delivery? Enables deeper reporting, more consistent outcomes, and improved tech adoption? Sets the stage for modernization, automation, and long-term planningAs an MSP, why do I need to do this?The MSP evolves from ad-hoc support to structured service delivery. This includes delivering planned projects, aligning service execution with a standardized tech stack, and eliminating chaos through process and platform consistency.A dedicated TAM or Service Delivery Manager replaces the Owner/Founder as the Customer Success lead, removing key-person risk and introducing coordinated delivery across Helpdesk, Projects, and Account Management.However, while these roles are dedicated, they often bring a strong technical foundation but lack strategic and business orientation. As a result, Discovery and Assessment conversations at this stage tend to focus on systems and infrastructure rather than the client’s business context, goals, or appetite for transformation. This limits the MSP’s ability to elevate the conversation and ignite strategic engagement.To address this, TAMs and SDMs must be supported with playbooks, question sets, and coaching that introduce business-centric framing—even in operational conversations. Appetite is not unlocked through tools alone—it grows when clients feel their business is understood.From a segmentation perspective, these clients are typically in Segment C. Their maturity is increasing, often signalled by a decline in firefighting and improved service consistency. However, their appetite remains low: they are responsive to recommendations but rarely initiate requests or ask forward-looking questions. Instead, they’re engaging just enough to approve fixes and appreciate reliability.This is why strategic CS cadence is so important: the Bi-Annual Strategic Meeting, preceded by structured Discovery and optionally by an Assessment, gives the client a lens into their progress—and creates space to reframe operational wins into business value.The MSP evolves from ad-hoc support to structured service delivery. This includes delivering planned projects, aligning service execution with a standardized tech stack, and eliminating chaos through process and platform consistency.What is the Customer impact?Clients begin to experience more structured and predictable service. IT becomes less of a distraction and more of a utility: tickets decline, recurring issues are resolved, and confidence builds.They appreciate that “someone is finally managing IT”—but they aren’t yet leaning in. Their engagement is reactive: they approve projects, attend reviews occasionally, and respond to issues, but they rarely initiate change or ask strategic questions.The value they see is technology-first: stability, fewer surprises, and better documentation. Conversations are still focused on operational improvements, rather than long-term outcomes.Early discovery or assessment discussions may begin, but typically remain shallow or MSP-led, focusing on stack gaps, service hygiene, or tool adoption.These clients live in the Low Business Impact / Medium–High Engagement quadrant. They show up, they appreciate structure, but they haven’t yet connected IT to business enablement or transformation.
Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: Technology Enablement Is the First Step Toward Outcome-Focused ServiceClients at the Technology Enablement stage have moved past a purely reactive mindset. They no longer define value only by ticket resolution or uptime. Instead, they begin to ask:? Are our tools being used effectively?? Can we mitigate recurring issues by optimizing the configuration?? What should we standardize or automate?This stage reflects a shift from Service Consumption to Service Utilization. Clients are often still operational, but they are ready to address recurring friction, stabilize their stack, and optimize for internal efficiency.These clients typically fall into Segment C or early Segment B, showing signs of engagement and growth potential, but are still limited by budget, mindset, or technical maturity.Concept #2: Enablement Priorities Are Practical, Not StrategicTechnology Enablement isn’t about innovation—it’s about getting the current tools to work better for the client’s business context. Typical priorities include:? Increasing adoption of existing platforms (e.g., Teams, SharePoint, RMM tools)? Improving onboarding and access management processes? Streamlining ticket handling through automation or training? Reducing alert fatigue or recurring issues through root cause initiativesAt this level, clients don’t need a roadmap—they need lightweight assessments, tailored guidance, and help identifying clear wins from their existing stack. Success looks like:? Fewer repeat tickets? Better end-user satisfaction? Clear internal owners for IT-dependent workflowsConcept #3: Technology Enablement Is the Launch Point for Initiative-Based EngagementEnablement opens the door to proactive planning—not by forcing big strategies, but by creating space for small, scoped, and meaningful initiatives. Examples include:? A backup validation process? MFA deployment for remaining users? A printer standardization or refresh planThese initiatives begin to introduce structure:? They are discussed and approved in light cadence (Segment-aware QBRs or Lifecycle Reviews)? They may lead to formal proposals or budget items? They start to link technical actions to business benefits (e.g., reduced downtime, improved onboarding)In this way, Enablement becomes the first proving ground for the MSP’s strategic credibility.Concept #4: Enablement-Level Clients Need CS Structure, Not ComplexityAt this stage, clients still value simplicity. They may resist long meetings, layered roadmaps, or multi-step scoring models. That’s why the CS Process must be:? Cadence-aware, but lightweight? Outcome-focused, not tool-driven? Enabled with templates that clarify next steps, not overwhelmThe MSP’s job is to:? Make adoption and alignment visible (via clear Discovery + Assessment)? Recommend manageable actions (1–3 key initiatives at a time)? Track and follow up through Governance and CS HealthThis builds client confidence and sets the stage for broader conversations in future quarters.Even with a formal cadence, many Enablement-stage clients will not voice business needs unless prompted. That’s why Assessments, while optional, are strongly recommended—they help shift ownership of initiatives toward the client by showing that improvement areas were identified collaboratively. Without this, most initiatives tend to feel MSP-driven, thereby reducing their strategic weight.To succeed, Discovery and Assessment should include business-context questions, not just technical gaps. This shift enables clients to articulate their goals, connect IT to outcomes, and transition from a consumption-based approach to one that fosters collaboration.Concept #5: Technology Enablement Matures the Relationship and Prepares for Strategic PlanningClients in the Enablement stage are not yet strategic co-planners, but they’re no longer passive consumers. They are emerging collaborators, and the MSP’s role is to:? Recognize their readiness? Deliver structured wins? Use those wins to justify the next level of partnershipClient maturity at this stage is not just about reduced tickets—it’s about operational readiness to adopt strategic building blocks. Readiness signals include:? No fires present—daily operations are stable? Openness to Stack Alignment investments? Willingness to implement foundational security (identity, endpoint, threat protection)? Interest in up-to-date hardware and cloud migration? Adoption of modern backup/resiliency solutions? Support for remote work, enablement, and collaboration? Progress on cyber risk management and insurability pathwaysWhen these indicators are present, the MSP can shift from operational alignment to long-term enablement, with cadence, structure, and business context framing as the bridge.
Implementation Process1. Define Segment and Cadence ExpectationsClients at the Technology Enablement level typically fall into Segment C: Mid-Touch. They require structured delivery but limited strategic depth. Cadence should be standardized to:? Monthly reporting (automated or shared via structured reports)? Quarterly service reviews? Bi-Annual Strategic Meeting with optional Assessment supportUse 1.1 Segmentation and 1.2 Engagement Strategy to:? Confirm this client is a match for Segment C? Establish a minimum engagement rhythm? Assign ownership to the Service Delivery Manager (SDM) or Technical Account Manager (TAM)2. Track and Align Customer Success Health SignalsEnablement-stage clients must show signs of increasing maturity and operational alignment. CS Health focus areas include:? 2.2 Engagement: Are clients attending meetings, responding to follow-ups, and engaging in reviews?? 2.3 Technology Adoption: Are key tools deployed and in use (e.g., Teams, BCDR tools, M365)?? 2.4 Service Quality: Is SLA adherence consistent? Are repeat issues being reduced?? 2.5 Service Level Alignment: Are we delivering the right services at the right frequency?These indicators guide the MSP’s assessment of whether Enablement is successful or whether adjustments are needed.3. Execute Cadence-Based CS Process? 4.1 Scheduling/Trigger: Use contract milestones or quarterly intervals to schedule structured check-ins and project planning reviews.? 4.2 Discovery Intake: Begin asking business-context questions that reveal appetite, friction points, and department-specific pain (not just stack alignment).? 4.3 Assessment Intake: Optional but recommended—especially for larger clients or those showing signs of increased initiative engagement. Helps surface and justify initiatives.? 4.4 Meeting: Quarterly reviews should now include simple project outcomes, stack alignment scores, and adoption metrics. Begin to surface initiative opportunities for planning.? 4.5 Initiatives: Document 2–3 tangible initiatives per quarter. Focus on hygiene, compliance, or risk mitigation. Position them in light cadence reviews and summarize with proposals or budgets.4. Assign Roles and Enablement? 5.1 Roles:? SDM becomes the primary delivery coordinator? TAM manages discovery and initiative documentation? Technical leads and support staff execute projects and resolve escalations? 5.2 Responsibilities:? SDMs own meeting execution and cadence? TAMs own initiative framing and communication? Project team members execute scoped work? 5.3 Enablement:? Provide templates for project tracking, Discovery formats, and initiative briefs? Train SDMs and TAMs on asking business-aligned questions, not just technical ones? 5.4 Compensation:? Link to ticket reduction, project delivery rates, and CS Health metrics (Engagement & Quality)? 5.5 Governance:? Informal but recurring—monthly CS Health review, quarterly delivery check-ins by leadership5. Use Strategy as a Framing ToolEnablement is where CS Strategy starts to take root. Use:? 1.3 Playbooks to guide how projects are selected, executed, and reported? 1.4 Roadmaps to lightly structure project timelines for discussion, even if they are not yet full strategic plans? 1.5 Standardization to ensure the same Discovery questions, Assessment formats, and initiative templates are used across Enablement clientsThis discipline-level integration ensures that MSP delivery is predictable, scalable, and increasingly tied to outcomes, even if strategic planning remains limited.6. Prepare for Transition to ModernizationBy the end of Enablement:? Fires should be rare? The stack should be aligned or in progress? Clients should begin initiating small changes or asking, "What's next?"When these signs emerge, use Discovery + Assessment + Bi-Annual Meeting to re-segment the client and recommend transitioning to Technology Modernization. Align this transition with CS Health indicators and initiative success metrics to ensure readiness.
AppendixHow does it connect to the other parts?? 1. Customer Success Strategy - Clients typically fall into Segment C – Mid-Touch. They receive standardized but recurring engagements and are on the path toward modernization and strategic planning.? 2. Metrics include project delivery status, SLA consistency, incident frequency, ticket closure rate, and service coverage across the aligned stack.? 3. Customer Success Delivery - Key deliverables include stack alignment reports, infrastructure budgets, ticket trend summaries, backup and disaster recovery (DR) alignment reports, and related operational outputs. Project proposals and Statements of Work (SOWs) begin to take shape.? 4. Customer Success Process - Recurring engagement rhythms (monthly or quarterly) drive service reviews. There is no strategic lead on the client side—an office manager or an overwhelmed team member may be the point of contact.They want IT to be stable, predictable, and less frustrating—but they’re not thinking long-term. There is little executive involvement, and a limited vision beyond “making things work better.”Maturity is low to medium: some progress, but still vulnerable to inconsistency. Appetite is low: clients are receptive to improvements but don’t initiate them.The MSP drives the relationship, delivering visible value through standardization and structured projects. The foundation is being laid for modernization, but business transformation still feels like a distant step.
?? 3. Technology Modernization
3. Technology ModernizationTechnology Modernization is where MSP-client relationships begin to evolve from structured delivery into structured transformation. At this level, clients show readiness to modernize their stack, adopt cloud-first platforms, and embrace lifecycle-driven decisions. The MSP shifts from firefighting and tactical delivery to roadmap-driven execution. Engagement becomes more strategic, but is still primarily technology-focused. Strategic planning is introduced, and clients begin to co-own the decision-making process. This phase sets the foundation for cross-functional impact and long-term business alignment.OverviewWhat is the objective?Why is it important?As an MSP, why do I need to do this?What is the Customer impact?Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: Technology Modernization Marks the Transition from Reactive Fixes to Lifecycle PlanningConcept #2: Modernization Requires Cross-Role Orchestration and Process MaturityConcept #3: Modernization Relies on Clear Scoring, Prioritization, and Proposal StrategyConcept #4: Modernization Prepares Clients for Strategic Enablement—If Managed ProperlyConcept #5: Modernization Clients Require Segment-Calibrated Support and Strategic FramingImplementation Process1. Confirm Segment and Strategic Rhythm (1.1 Segmentation, 1.2 Engagement Strategy)2. Operationalize CS Health Signals (2.x Customer Success Health)3. Implement Structured CS Process (4.x Customer Success Process)4. Execute Modernization-Aligned CS Delivery (3.x Customer Success Delivery)5. Assign Roles and Strategic Responsibilities (5.x People Discipline)6. Frame Modernization with Strategy Integration (1.3–1.5 Strategy Discipline)AppendixHow does it connect to the other parts?Product Links / Tooling SupportBest Practice IndicatorsExample Client Profile
OverviewWhat is the objective?To guide clients through structured modernization of their IT environment—including cloud adoption, stack consolidation, and platform lifecycle upgrades—while building repeatable planning, budgeting, and execution rhythms. This phase marks the transition from “running IT” to intentionally transforming it.Why is it important?Technology Modernization marks the shift from structured delivery to structured transformation. Clients at this stage aren’t yet driving innovation, but they are leaning into structured improvement. They’re investing in stack alignment, security, and lifecycle upgrades, and they’re becoming more open to planning.This unlocks:? Better risk control through lifecycle and security planning? More efficient operations via consolidation and modernization? Higher platform adoption and internal enablement? Early strategic engagement through roadmaps and budget planningFrom an MSP perspective, this phase introduces scalable rhythms—like discovery  ? assessment (typically recommended, but not mandatory) ? roadmap ? proposal ? execution—even when full executive appetite is not yet present.These clients often live in the “Moderate and growing Business Impact / High Engagement” quadrant. They’re not driving top-down innovation, but they’re attending meetings, responding to proposals, and implementing the plan.As an MSP, why do I need to do this?? Strategic value is primarily framed around technology maturity and operational improvement: infrastructure health, cloud adoption, SaaS utilization, and lifecycle upgrades.? Clients are typically in Segment B—characterized by Moderate and growing maturity, as well as high appetite.? This is the stage where dedicated Account Managers and vCIOs are actively engaged. QBRs (Quarterly Business Reviews) and monthly tactical meetings are in place, providing rhythm and accountability.? These process elements and strategy mechanisms (1.2 Engagement Strategy, 1.3 Playbooks) work in concert to deliver planned value.What is the Customer impact?? Clients feel they’re gaining control, with fewer outages, increased stability, and clearer plans.? They begin to think in quarters, not just fire drills. This is often the first time they’re co-owning roadmap reviews or budget planning.? Business leadership may remain at arm’s length, but operational stakeholders are engaged and responsive.? Value is still primarily driven by technology, with improvements in availability, standardization, or security.? These clients care deeply about being modern, compliant, and efficient, but they require ongoing coaching to connect IT to business outcomes effectively.
Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: Technology Modernization Marks the Transition from Reactive Fixes to Lifecycle PlanningAt the Modernization stage, clients are no longer just trying to make existing tools work—they are ready to replace, consolidate, or restructure their technology environment in service of long-term business outcomes.These clients are:? Replacing outdated infrastructure or unsupported platforms? Standardizing tools across locations or departments? Seeking to reduce complexity, cost, or operational risk? Asking questions like: “What should we be using instead of this?” or “How can we future-proof our setup?”This posture reflects a shift into Segment B behaviour: appetite is high, maturity is moderate, and clients seek strategic clarity, not just execution support. Clients at this stage are Ready for Modernization and Technology Adoption, including:? Stack Alignment Parity achieved? Unified Communications Strategy improvements? Deeper Remote Work and Collaboration enablement? Roadmapping and Goal Setting practices? Cloud Adoption Readiness or in progress? Security Foundations in place? Data Loss Prevention (DLP) strategies under consideration? Asset Lifecycle Management program implemented? vCTO-level guidance readinessConcept #2: Modernization Requires Cross-Role Orchestration and Process MaturityTechnology Modernization isn’t one project—it’s a coordinated initiative layer, often spanning multiple proposals, timelines, and departments. To succeed, it requires:? TAMs to identify recurring technical or lifecycle triggers (e.g. aging assets, ticket patterns)? vCIOs to structure modernization into initiative groups and link them to roadmap planning? CSMs or AMs to manage pacing, client readiness, and stakeholder alignmentAt this level, Customer Success Health depends on coordinated execution:? Is Adoption improving as systems are replaced?? Is Engagement sustained through longer delivery timelines?? Are Service Quality and Alignment scores holding up through change?Modernization exposes all weak points in your CS system—unless well-enabled and governed.Concept #3: Modernization Relies on Clear Scoring, Prioritization, and Proposal StrategyModernization is typically triggered by a recommended—but not mandatory assessment that reveals risk, fragmentation, or inefficiency. These findings should be:? Translated into scored initiatives, using compliance or readiness indicators? Prioritized using segmentation logic and business context? Framed within a Proposal–Roadmap–Budget planning cycleFor example:? A client may receive a Lifecycle Assessment showing that 70% of endpoints are end-of-life and scattered across platforms? The MSP scores the modernization impact and proposes a two-phase refresh, with aligned budgets and milestones? Over the next 6–12 months, the initiative is tracked via Governance checkpoints and validated via CS Health metricsThis structure ensures that modernization is not just a reactive clean-up—it’s a planned, measured transformation.Concept #4: Modernization Prepares Clients for Strategic Enablement—If Managed ProperlyWhile modernization work is technical, its success depends on:? Consistent meeting cadence to manage transitions and approvals? Visible initiative tracking with outcomes linked to business goals? Alignment between delivery rhythm and client readinessIf rushed or poorly communicated, modernization can overwhelm clients. If well-managed, it becomes a strategic trust accelerator that prepares the client for higher-value engagements, such as lifecycle planning, playbook adoption (7.3), and goal alignment frameworks (e.g., OKRs).This prepares the transition to a process-led QBR cadence (4.4) and full CS Strategy orchestration (1.1–1.3).Done right, modernization clears the runway for the next stage of CS maturity.Concept #5: Modernization Clients Require Segment-Calibrated Support and Strategic FramingClients in this stage may still feel Segment B (high impact, low engagement)—meaning they have real needs, but inconsistent executive attention or planning discipline. CS leaders must:? Use Enablement to coach internal teams on modernization messaging and pacing? Use Engagement Strategy to manage stakeholder drift and maintain rhythm? Use Governance to monitor initiative follow-through and update Health scores accordinglyThe CS job is to frame modernization not just as “cleanup,” but as a transformation layer—one that sets the stage for business enablement, cross-functional planning, and innovation.Modernization is the bridge between operational efficiency and strategic partnership. If supported by structure, cadence, and transparency, it becomes the most compelling justification for transitioning the client into complete lifecycle management.
Implementation Process1. Confirm Segment and Strategic Rhythm (1.1 Segmentation, 1.2 Engagement Strategy)Clients at the Modernization level are typically Segment B: high appetite, moderate and rising maturity. These clients are open to structured transformation but still require guidance on prioritization and planning. Confirm:? Engagement strategy includes Quarterly Strategic Roadmap Reviews and Monthly Tactical Meetings? Segment B cadence is mapped to a proactive AM/vCIO rhythm with role clarity and cadence accountability2. Operationalize CS Health Signals (2.x Customer Success Health)Technology Modernization requires elevated CS Health tracking:? 2.1 Client Experience (CX): Use feedback from project delivery and strategic reviews? 2.2 Engagement: Track initiative participation, roadmap sessions, and QBR attendance? 2.3 Technology Adoption: Use assessments to score stack alignment, lifecycle status, and SaaS utilization? 2.4 Service Quality: Validate execution quality through SLA metrics, issue reduction, and governance inputs? 2.5 Service Level Alignment: Ensure platform rollout and initiative execution match roadmap scope and CS Playbook guidelines3. Implement Structured CS Process (4.x Customer Success Process)? 4.1 Scheduling/Trigger: Define a repeatable planning rhythm linked to quarterly reviews and initiative cycles? 4.2 Discovery Intake: Conduct structured Discovery every 6–12 months to assess readiness, departmental needs, and risk posture? 4.3 Assessment Intake: Run modernization-focused assessments to reveal technical debt, lifecycle gaps, or misalignments? 4.4 Meeting: QBRs evolve to roadmap-oriented reviews with initiative scoring, client readiness validation, and proposal follow-up? 4.5 Initiatives: Structure all modernization efforts (e.g., BCDR, remote work enablement, DLP) into roadmap-synchronized initiative cards; group initiatives thematically for visibility and scoring4. Execute Modernization-Aligned CS Delivery (3.x Customer Success Delivery)? 3.1 Reports: Provide roadmap and initiative status, ticket patterns, SaaS usage summaries? 3.2 Proposal: All initiatives must link to a Proposal with defined outcomes and investment scope? 3.3 Budget: Consolidate project costs into structured budgets with client sign-off? 3.4 Strategy: Document initiative prioritization in a strategic framework; publish in client-facing format if appetite supports it? 3.5 Roadmap: Maintain an evolving, living roadmap tied to initiative outcomes, review cadence, and health progression5. Assign Roles and Strategic Responsibilities (5.x People Discipline)? 5.1 Roles:? vCIO: Initiative framing, roadmap management? AM: Cadence execution, stakeholder coordination? PM: Project delivery, milestone tracking? 5.2 Responsibilities:? AM owns the operational cycle (meetings, feedback)? vCIO drives roadmap and modernization design? 5.3 Enablement: Train all roles on initiative tracking, roadmap navigation, and lifecycle-based proposals? 5.4 Compensation: Tie incentives to roadmap completion rates, health improvement metrics, and client initiative success? 5.5 Governance: Conduct quarterly governance reviews of initiative execution, cadence consistency, and roadmap progress6. Frame Modernization with Strategy Integration (1.3–1.5 Strategy Discipline)? 1.3 Playbooks: Standardize initiative types by segment (e.g., SaaS adoption, cloud migration, endpoint refresh)? 1.4 Roadmaps: Establish client-visible roadmaps with milestones tied to assessments and budget alignment? 1.5 Standardization: Ensure initiative scoring, proposals, and roadmap visuals follow consistent formats for comparability and internal reportingModernization is the moment where structure becomes scalable. Done well, this implementation process creates alignment, earns trust, and prepares both MSP and client for the transition to Business Transformation.
