OverviewWhat is the objective?To define the appropriate frequency, format, and depth of Customer Success engagement for each client segment, based on their maturity, appetite, and Client Business Goal level. The Engagement Strategy turns segmentation into action. It ensures that the right conversations happen with the right people at the right time, and at the correct depth—driving strategic outcomes, not just service check-ins.Why is it important?Without a clear engagement strategy, MSPs risk either over-serving or under-serving clients, leading to wasted effort, missed expectations, or disengagement. Strategic engagement ensures CS isn’t just reactive—it’s a planned, proactive experience aligned to both client and MSP goals.It drives:? Predictable delivery of value? Increased initiative, momentum, and acceptance? Better internal resource planning and CS team efficiency? Higher client trust, satisfaction, and retentionAs an MSP, why do I need to do this? Because your most strategic initiatives—and your best relationships—depend on consistency. Engagement Strategy creates the strategic context for Customer Success, connecting initiatives, services, OpEx, and CapEx to business outcomes over time.Without this rhythm, CS becomes reactive and fragmented. With it, MSPs can:? Prevent engagement drop-offs in lower-tier clients? Scale high-touch conversations without increasing overhead? Deliver the correct format at the right time, using defined playbooks? Maintain strong forward visibility to support staffing and delivery planningWhat is the Customer impact?Clients receive the right kind of interaction, at the right time, with the right level of strategic input. When engagement is predictable and tailored to their maturity and appetite, clients see the MSP as a leader, not a vendor.But when engagements are inconsistent or mismatched:? Meetings get skipped or reduced to technical updates? Strategic initiatives lose support? Executive trust declinesA structured engagement strategy builds confidence, continuity, and accountability.
Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: Engagement Strategy Is the CS Operating Rhythm Engagement Strategy defines how often and how deeply each segment is engaged. It is not a calendar of meetings, but a strategic framework that governs the flow of value:? Inputs: Discovery, Assessments, Roadmaps? Outputs: Meetings, Reports, Budgets, Initiatives? Coordination: Playbooks, roles, and timingIt is also the scheduling backbone of CS Health. If rhythm breaks down—meetings missed, initiatives stall, cadence slips—Engagement scores in CS Health decline. The Engagement Strategy ensures that those signals are not random but structured and traceable.Concept #2: Choose Your Engagement Investment ModelEvery MSP, whether consciously or not, invests a percentage of effort into Customer Success. Engagement Strategy makes this investment visible and intentional.Start by defining how much of your time or margin you want to invest in CS—commonly 1% to 9% of MRR per client. Then, shape your segment-specific strategy around:? Cadence (weekly, monthly, quarterly)? Format (live, virtual, async, hybrid)? Roles (vCIO, CSM, TAM, Strategic Advisor)? Meeting Types (roadmap, budgeting, QBR)This ensures Segment A clients receive full strategic attention, while Segment D clients get lightweight, scalable guidance. This model replaces the old “Engagement Investment Model” by embedding it into a living framework. It also aligns with CS Health expectations, enabling Governance to judge performance segment by segment.Concept #3: Ad Hoc vs. Proactive Time AllocationMost CS effort falls into two categories: planned (strategic, proactive) or ad hoc (reactive, issue-driven). A well-formed Engagement Strategy includes a defined ratio—e.g., 60% planned / 40% ad hoc.This balance prevents teams from being consumed by reactive work. It also clarifies:? How much time is available for roadmap reviews, QBRs, and budgeting? How to allocate resources across segments? How to forecast CS capacity needsOver time, mature MSPs should aim to increase the proactive percentage, as this drives strategic execution, reduces firefighting, and improves CS Health.Concept $4: Hourly Rate as a CS Planning MetricTo align CS time investment with financial reality, calculate your internal hourly cost of CS (e.g., $75 per hour). Then apply your MRR-based percentage allocation (e.g., 5% of a $2,000/month client equals $100/month or approximately $1,200/year).Divide this budget by your hourly cost to estimate available CS time. For example:? $1,200/year ÷ $75/hr = 16 hours/year That’s ~4 quarterly meetings or eight touchpoints—enough for roadmap delivery, budget review, and a few follow-ups.This method ensures that strategic engagement is grounded in resource and financial capacity. It also gives you a basis for CS staffing decisions.Concept #5: Engagement Strategy ≠ Playbook What’s the Difference?? The Engagement Strategy defines when and why to engage a client, including cadence, role, meeting type, and depth, based on the segment.? Playbooks define the process for executing each engagement, including agenda, preparation, structure, documentation, and follow-up.You need both. Strategy sets the rhythm; playbooks deliver the value.How It Works TogetherExample:? Strategy: “Segment B gets quarterly roadmap reviews with a vCIO.”? Playbook: “Here’s the template, prep questions, and follow-up structure for a roadmap review.”Playbooks ensure strategic engagement is consistent, measurable, and aligned with CS Health outcomes, including Engagement, Alignment, and Service Quality.Time Allocation Formula (Linking Strategy to Capacity)To make playbook execution scalable, align it with your CS investment using this formula:5% ? 50% ? 40% = Strategic Playbook Time? 5% = % of MRR invested in CS? 50% = Portion reserved for planned (vs. ad hoc) CS work? 40% = Time spent on strategic engagements delivered via playbooksExample: For a $2,000/month client:? $100/month CS budget = $1,200/year? 50% planned = $600 ? 40% = $240/year for strategic playbook time? At $75/hr internal cost ? ~3.2 hours/year for structured engagementsThis anchors your Engagement Strategy to real delivery capacity.Why It MattersWithout a strategy, CS becomes reactive. Without playbooks, it becomes inconsistent. This formula ensures that:? You don’t overpromise what your team can’t deliver? Playbook usage is resourced correctly? CS performance is measurable and scalable
Concept #6 - How many CS, vCIOs do you need? (3 scenarios)Your Engagement Strategy directly determines your CS staffing model. Given the same client base, different strategies require different FTE allocations.Example (100 clients):? High-Touch Strategy (Segment A-focused):? Quarterly meetings + monthly check-ins = ~20 hours/client/year? ~2,000 total hours ? Requires ~1.25–1.5 FTE? Balanced Strategy (Mix of B and C):? ~10–12 hours/client/year ? ~1,000–1,200 total hours? Requires ~0.75 FTE? Tech-Touch Strategy (Segment D-focused):? ~4 hours/client/year ? 400 total hours? Covered by 0.25–0.5 FTE + automationThis concept ties strategy to real-world delivery: CS isn’t just a philosophy—it’s a workload. Matching strategy to headcount ensures you don’t burn out your team or under-serve key accounts.Concept #7: Challenge: Capability MismanagementExplanation: A common mistake is building your Customer Success plans around the ideal service experience without first ensuring you have the right people, skills, or industry expertise to deliver it. True capability isn’t just about headcount; it’s about whether your team has the expertise (e.g., vCIOs, AMs, technical specialists) and vertical understanding needed for each client segment and playbook you want to deliver.Many MSPs commit to services (such as advanced QBRs or industry-specific playbooks) before they’ve mapped whether their staff has the necessary training, experience, or sufficient hours to perform these tasks effectively. If your team isn’t enabled for the service, the result is broken promises, inconsistent client experiences, and staff burnout.Practical Example: Imagine you want to deliver quarterly strategic meetings (QBRs) to all your Segment B and Segment C clients.? You have 30 clients in Segment B and 40 in Segment C.? Each QBR requires a vCIO (2 hours of preparation + 2 hours of delivery = 4 hours per client per quarter).Calculation:? Total QBR hours per year: (30 Segment B + 40 Segment C) ? 4 hours ? 4 quarters = 1,120 hours/year? You currently have only one vCIO with 1,400 hours of availability per year.Now, suppose you also want that same vCIO to run roadmap reviews for Segment A (8 clients, 6 hours per quarter each):? 8 ? 6 ? 4 = 192 hours/yearCombined demand: 1,120 + 192 = 1,312 hours/year (leaving only 88 hours for all other work, meetings, training, or vacation).What happens? If the vCIO is also expected to cover other responsibilities (or if you want to launch new vertical-specific services), you quickly hit a wall. Result: Some QBRs are rushed, postponed, or of low quality; some industry-specific playbooks are never launched, resulting in client inconsistency.Takeaway: Before promising new or advanced CS services, map your real people capability by segment and service type. If you don’t have enough capacity or the right vertical expertise, either upskill your team, reduce CS commitments, or focus your strategy on segments where you can consistently deliver value.Concept #8: Challenge: Capacity MisalignmentExplanation: Most MSPs underestimate the actual time it takes to deliver the CS activities they promise to clients. It’s easy to include QBRs, monthly check-ins, or frequent roadmap reviews in your playbook, but if you don’t align those promises with your team’s actual available hours (and segment distribution), you risk creating overwork and burnout. Capacity planning is essential to avoid overcommitting and underdelivering.Practical Example (with numbers): Suppose your recommended annual CS capacity per segment looks like this:SegmentMRR RangeTotal Annual Hours per ClientMeetings/FormatTotal ClientsTotal Segment HoursSegment A$10,000+30 hours3x QBR + monthly7210Segment B$5k–$10k20 hours2x QBR + monthly18360Segment C$2.5k–$5k10 hours1x QBR + virtual40400Segment D<$2.5k5 hoursVirtual/Ad hoc60300Total1251,270Your total available CS team hours for the year: 1,000.Problem: You have a capacity gap:? Required hours: 1,270? Available hours: 1,000? Shortfall: 270 hoursHow to solve it?? Option 1: Move the segment boundaries upward.? Shift Segment A threshold from $ 10,000+ to $ 12,000+ ? now only five clients qualify as Segment A.? Shift B from $5k+ to $7k+ ? now only 12 clients qualify as B.? The rest move down to C or D, which are less time-intensive.? Option 2: Reduce the average annual hours per segment (e.g., deliver QBRs less frequently or move more C and D clients to ad hoc or virtual touchpoints).? Option 3: Lower your overall CS investment (e.g., from 7% of MRR to 5%), and adjust hours accordingly.Example Table After Adjusting Segment Boundaries:SegmentNew Client CountTotal Annual Hours per ClientNew Total Segment HoursSegment A530150Segment B1220240Segment C4510450Segment D635315Total1251,155Now, the required hours = 1,155 — still tight, but closer to the 1,000-hour limit.Takeaway: If your actual CS team capacity doesn’t match your playbook and segment design, you must adjust either segment boundaries or the level of planned engagement. This keeps your promises deliverable and your team healthy, so only your most strategic clients receive frequent high-touch service, and the rest receive a level of engagement you can sustain.Concept #9: Managing the “Defense Loop”The Defense Loop is a customer success philosophy focused on defending revenue, margin, and incident stability for transactional and cost-sensitive D-segment clients. It aims to make risk visible, align on minimum standards, and assure executives of protection and predictability.Customer Success Defense LoopHere's how to manage the Defense Loop:? Phases:? Risk Visibility: Help clients identify and rank business risks by unifying asset lifecycle, security, and process exceptions in a living register.? Stability Alignment: Agree on the technology stack and service baseline to maintain business stability. This involves setting standards, defining change windows, establishing escalation paths, and sequencing fixes in 30-60-90-day cadences.? Value Assurance: Provide executives with confidence in protected continuity and predictable spending through quarterly assurance briefs, forecasting risks and costs, and running continuity drills.? Operating Rhythm:? Monthly: Automatically intake risks, conduct stability checks, and send a one-page assurance summary.? Quarterly: Deliver the assurance summary during the Quarterly Business Review (QBR) slot, refresh Service Level Objectives (SLOs), and update the 90-day plan.? Triggers: Spikes in incident rates, increasing exception age, or two consecutive months above the cost-to-serve target.? KPI Link to Outcomes:? GRR (Gross Recurring Revenue): Executives renew when risk is visible, standards are in place, and confidence is high.? Margin: Fewer incidents and approved change patterns reduce effort.? Incident Control: Aligned baselines and decision Service Level Agreements (SLAs) reduce noise and recurrences.? Fit with Maturity Model: The Defense Loop can be adapted for different maturity levels, from a light, PSA-based foundation to a strategic partner model with advanced risk scoring, prevention logging, and board-ready reporting.? Connection to the Growth Loop: The Defense Loop protects the existing client base, while the Growth Loop expands value. Defense artifacts, such as risk visibility, stability alignment, and value assurance, can be used in Growth conversations to drive roadmap items, reduce incidents, unlock adoption, and build executive trust.? Positioning for any Managed Service Provider (MSP): Frame the approach as running "two loops: Growth to create value, Defense to protect it." For D accounts, prioritize stability and predictability. As trust grows, migrate clients to higher segments and introduce the Growth Loop. Use client-centric language like "operations," "continuity," "predictability," and "confidence."
Implementation ProcessThe Implementation Process turns your engagement philosophy into a working plan. It helps you define, allocate, and validate Customer Success efforts based on both segmentation and operational capacity.Step 1. Define Your Engagement Strategy ModelStart by determining how much of your recurring revenue (MRR) you are willing to allocate to Customer Success for each segment. This decision determines the scale and type of engagement you can realistically offer across your portfolio.? High-touch strategy: 6–9% of MRR (for top-tier, strategic clients)? Balanced strategy: 3–6% of MRR (for mid-tier, growing clients)? Lean/Tech-touch strategy: 1–3% of MRR (for operational or low-touch clients)Why it matters: Selecting your CS investment model upfront ensures you don’t overpromise (e.g., quarterly QBRs for every client) and that you allocate time and resources proportionally to client value and potential.How to do it:1. Multiply the chosen % by each client’s MRR (or by segment average) to set the annual Customer Success budget per client.? Example: For a $5,000/month Segment B client at 6% investment: $5,000 ? 12 ? 6% = $3,600/year CS budget.2. Convert that annual CS budget into available Customer Success hours:? Divide by your internal average hourly rate for CS team members (e.g., $75/hour): $3,600 / $75 = 48 hours per year for this client.3. Sum these calculations across each segment to set your overall capacity, and check that the total is feasible for your current team size.4. Use this time budget to:? Set meeting cadence (how often, what type)? Define the number of planned vs. ad-hoc touchpoints? Assign roles and responsibilities by segment (e.g., vCIO for A, TAM for D)Practical Example Table:SegmentTypical MRRCS Investment %Annual BudgetInternal RateAvailable HoursSegment A$10,0008%$9,600$10096Segment B$5,0006%$3,600$7548Segment C$3,0004%$1,440$7519Segment D$1,5002%$360$755Defining your CS investment model in this structured way enables you to turn ambition into action, so you can set realistic, segment-specific engagement plans that align with both your business goals and your team’s actual capacity.Step 2. Allocate Time by Segment and Activity TypeBreak that time into planned (proactive) vs ad hoc (reactive) categories:? e.g., 60% proactive = roadmap planning, budgeting, QBRs? 40% reactive = initiative support, escalations, unexpected issuesUse this to define touchpoints and playbook frequency per segment. For example:? Segment A: 16 hrs/year ? four strategic meetings, four follow-ups? Segment B: 10 hrs/year ? two meetings + async reviews? Segment C: 6 hrs/year ? QBR + budget session? Segment D: 2–3 hrs/year ? CS Health check-ins, triggered follow-upsStep 3. Validate Capacity Against CS HeadcountAdd up the total time across all clients. Then compare against your CS team's available capacity:FTE ? 1,680 hours/year (or 140/month)This shows whether your Engagement Strategy is realistically deliverable. If not, adjust:? Reduce cadence or touchpoint depth? Automate lower-tier interactions? Shift delivery from vCIOs to TAMs/CSMs? Reassign roles or delay hiringStep 4. Monitor and Refine Over TimeAs CS Health trends emerge or client goals evolve, reallocate time and effort:? Strategic clients moving up? Shift toward more high-touch.? Low-value clients stagnating? Move toward automation.Your Engagement Strategy should evolve quarterly, just like roadmaps and segmentation.
AppendixHow does it connect to the Client Business Goal levels?The engagement strategy evolves as the client’s maturity and appetite increase. Different Client Business Goal levels reflect different readiness to engage and different expectations.LevelRole of Engagement Strategy1.1 Technology SupportReactive or ad-hoc check-ins; meetings triggered by issues or service changes.1.2 Technology EnablementBasic cadence introduced (e.g., annual or semi-annual check-ins); focus on stability and onboarding.1.3 Technology ModernizationRegular, structured meetings to track progress on modernization and roadmap execution.1.4 Business TransformationQuarterly or monthly meetings; review business impact and coordinate cross-departmental initiatives.1.5 Business InnovationStrategic, multi-stakeholder engagements aligned to OKRs, innovation programs, and executive-level planning.How does it connect to the other parts?? Client Business Goal – Engagement depth and rhythm evolve with the client’s maturity and appetite. High-Goal clients require more frequent, strategic interactions, while lower-Goal clients benefit from an operational cadence.? CS Health – Engagement frequency and stakeholder participation are key health indicators. Health trends may also trigger adjusted cadences.? CS Delivery – Meetings, Reports, and Budgets are delivered on cadence, powered by Engagement Strategy.? CS Process – Cadence, preparation, and follow-up workflows are structured according to the engagement strategy.? CS People – Determines which roles (e.g., vCIO, CSM, TAM) are involved at each engagement level. Role clarity ensures consistency across segments.? CS Strategy – Engagement Strategy operationalizes the segmentation model. It transforms Client Business Goal and MRR into time, attention, and leadership effort.Product Links / Tooling SupportNo dedicated LMx product feature currently supports Engagement Strategy holistically, but engagement strategy is enabled and informed by:? LMx Meeting module: For scheduling, tracking, and documenting meetings across segments? Client Health Score: Engagement frequency and stakeholder involvement are key input metrics? Segmentation: Determines default cadence, meeting types, and owner roles per client tier? Playbooks / SOPs: Drive repeatable engagement structures per segment (e.g., quarterly business review vs. annual planning)Comparison of 7.2 Engagement Strategy and 7.3 CS PlaybookAspect7.2 Engagement Strategy7.3 CS PlaybookWhat is it?A strategic framework that defines how often, what type, and at what level of depth each client segment should be engaged.The CS team uses a tactical, step-by-step methodology or workflow to execute each engagement. It describes what to do, when to do it, and how to do it.Primary FocusDetermines when and what type of engagement should happen. (e.g., QBR annually, onboarding once, roadmap review monthly, etc.)Defines how a specific type of engagement is executed. (e.g., how to run a QBR, what materials are needed, how to follow up)LevelStrategic – built around segmentation and CS strategyOperational / Tactical – applied at the client interaction levelKey Questions Answered- What types of engagement exist?- How often should they occur per segment?- Who owns each meeting type?- What format should be used (in-person, virtual)?- What happens before, during, and after the engagement?- What templates, tools, or materials are used?- How is the meeting structured and documented?Example“Segment A clients receive an annual vCxO strategic planning session and quarterly roadmap reviews with a CSM.”“The Roadmap Review playbook includes: pre-meeting checklist, agenda template, meeting notes structure, and follow-up action plan.”How they connectEngagement Strategy dictates the type and cadence of playbooks required per segment.CS Playbooks execute the engagements defined by the strategy in a standardized, repeatable format.
?? 1.3 CS Playbooks
1.3 CS PlaybooksOverviewWhat is the objective?Why is it important?As an MSP, why do I need to do this?What is the Customer impact?Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: Playbooks Are WorkflowsConcept #2: Not All Playbooks Are MeetingsConcept #3: CS Playbooks Should Match Client SegmentConcept #4: Great Playbooks Make the Team Look GreatConcept #5: Strategy and Execution Are a Matched SetConcept #6: Trigger – Meeting Prep CycleConcept #7: Quarterly Example – A Playbook in ActionImplementation Process – Turning Capabilities Into Repeatable ActionStep 1: Map What Your Team Can Deliver (Capabilities)Step 2: Identify Opportunity Areas (Client-Centric Themes)Step 3: Match to Industry and Vertical CompetencyStep 4: Align to Roles and Execution OwnersStep 5: Define Topics by Cadence and SegmentStep 6: Validate Team CapacityFinal Output: A Playbook Strategy That DeliversAppendixHow does it connect to the Client Business Goal levels?How does it connect to the other parts?Product Links / Tooling SupportComparison of 7.2 Engagement Strategy and 7.3 CS Playbook
OverviewWhat is the objective?To define standardized, repeatable processes for delivering Customer Success activities across client segments, ensuring consistency, efficiency, and alignment with business goals. Playbooks are the tactical execution layer of Customer Success Strategy. They bring cadence, content, and coordination to life, executing the engagement rhythms defined by the Engagement Strategy.Why is it important?Without documented playbooks, CS delivery becomes ad-hoc, inconsistent, and reliant on individual memory or discretion. The Engagement Strategy determines the frequency and type of interaction for each segment (e.g., a quarterly roadmap review for Segment B). Playbooks ensure that interaction actually happens with quality, structure, and accountability. Together, they ensure MSPs can deliver value at scale without sacrificing precision.As an MSP, why do I need to do this?Because success doesn’t happen by chance—it happens by design. You can’t just decide to be strategic—you need to operationalize it. Playbooks are how Engagement Strategy becomes real: not just “when and why” you meet, but exactly “how” to run those sessions and follow up. Without this, even the best segmentation or cadence plans fall flat.What is the Customer impact?Clients experience a delivery model that feels professional, thoughtful, and aligned with their goals. Engagement Strategy ensures the proper conversation happens at the right time; Playbooks ensure that the conversation is structured, prepared, and followed through. Together, they create:? Predictable, high-quality experiences—clients know what to expect and when? Momentum across meetings—each interaction drives the next step in the roadmap? Alignment between vision and execution—strategic goals translate into consistent workflows? Confidence in the MSP’s leadership—clients feel guided, not just supportedWhen strategy defines the "why" and playbooks deliver the "how," clients experience Customer Success that is both relevant and reliable.
Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: Playbooks Are Workflows Each playbook defines a process, from trigger to outcome. A great playbook includes:? Purpose of the engagement (e.g., align roadmap, review budget)? Triggering event (e.g., quarterly cadence, Health Score drop)? Preparation checklist (data, reports, notes)? Agenda or conversation structure? Roles and responsibilities (who leads, who attends)? Follow-up steps and timelinesPlaybooks operationalize CS Health workflows—ensuring that Health Score signals (e.g., low Engagement, missed initiatives, misaligned service levels) result in consistent, team-wide responses. They turn insights into action.Expanded with a Practical Example:A playbook is not just a checklist—it’s a complete, step-by-step system, from trigger to outcome, designed for repeatable execution.Practical Example: Segment A Annual Planning Playbook Suppose you have a high-value Segment A client. Their annual playbook might look like this:StepToolDescriptionTime BudgetTriggerAuto SchedulerAnnual planning meeting scheduled 1 year in advance0.5 hrPrepDiscovery Tool, Assessment Tool, Binder GeneratorCollect client data, generate questions and an assessment report, and print a prep binder.2.5 hrsMeeting 1Printed Binder, Note Tool90-min CEO session—capture business goals, SWOT, current state1.5 hrsFollow-UpMeeting Minutes, Action Item ToolSummarize actions, decisions, and schedule the next meeting0.5 hrMeeting 2Client SWOT/Goals/Initiative DocsReview and confirm priorities, set next steps1.5 hrsBudgetingBudget ToolDraft and review the budget for initiatives1.5 hrsFinalizationSOW GeneratorFinalize SOW, save to system, send to client1 hrTotal planned time for one annual cycle: ~7.5 hours Multiply by the number of clients: 10 Segment A clients = 75 hours/yearThis practical approach shows why you can’t run “Segment A” playbooks for every account—the math is straightforward, and the process is explicit.Concept #2: Not All Playbooks Are Meetings While many playbooks support meetings (e.g., QBR, Roadmap Review), others are structured:? Initiative follow-up and proposal delivery? Onboarding and renewal cycles? Risk response and Health Score recovery? Budget planning and stakeholder approvalPlaybooks provide the standard operating procedure for restoring or advancing CS Health. For example, a low Service Quality score should trigger a remediation playbook. A strong Adoption trend may trigger a strategic upsell or roadmap refresh.Concept #3: CS Playbooks Should Match Client Segment Not all playbooks belong everywhere. Your Segmentation and Engagement Strategy determines which workflows apply where, and with how much effort.Match the playbook’s scope and complexity to the client’s Business Goal Level and CS Investment Strategy:? Segment A – Full pre-meeting prep, multi-stakeholder agendas, strategy alignment, initiative planning.? Segment B – Formal prep and delivery using a leaner version of Segment A’s process.? Segment C – Semi-structured workflows that cover essentials and build consistency.? Segment D – Lightweight, templated, and potentially asynchronous playbooks focused on operational continuity.The goal is consistency without over-servicing. Playbooks help you scale the right level of structure—no more, no less.They also ensure that Health metrics are interpreted in context. For example, a “low Engagement” signal in Segment D does not mean the same thing as in Segment A, and your playbooks should reflect that nuance.Expanded with a Practical Example:The more strategic the client, the more complex and involved the playbook.Practical Example: Segment Comparison TableSegmentPlaybook StructurePlanned HoursExample ActivitiesA3-Meeting Annual Cycle + Budget & SOW7–10Strategic Discovery, CEO sessions, SOWB2-Meeting Annual Cycle4–6Discovery, Planning, Budget ReviewCSingle Meeting + Virtual/Async Touchpoints2–3Roadmap Review, Key Initiative EmailDAsynchronous, Email Only1–2Automated Report, Quick Survey, EmailSo, if you have 20 clients in Segment C, you should expect 40–60 hours/year on C-segment playbooks.Concept #4: Great Playbooks Make the Team Look Great Playbooks are internal tools that power external confidence. A junior TAM with a great playbook can run a roadmap session like a seasoned vCIO. A new hire can onboard clients like a pro. The best playbooks:? Reduce reliance on tribal knowledge? Make team roles clearer? Improve handoff quality? Support accountabilityThey also improve the reliability of CS Health scoring. When execution is standardized through playbooks, Health data becomes trustworthy and consistent across accounts, enabling better forecasting, planning, and governance.Expanded with a Practical Example:Playbooks give even less-experienced team members the tools to deliver high-quality outcomes.Practical Example:? Scenario: New TAM joins and is assigned to a Segment B client.? With Playbook: Follows the “2-Meeting Annual Cycle” template—preps with binder, runs Discovery questions, logs meeting notes, triggers follow-up template.? Result: Consistent client experience, no gaps, same value as vCIO could deliver.? Without Playbook: Meetings become ad-hoc, key topics get missed, follow-up slips, and trust declines.Impact:? Playbooks reduce mistakes, shorten the ramp-up time, and make CS Health scoring more reliable (e.g., eliminating “missed QBR” errors).Concept #5: Strategy and Execution Are a Matched SetEngagement Strategy defines the when, why, and who of CS delivery. CS Playbooks define the how.They must work in tandem:? Engagement Strategy says, “Segment B clients receive quarterly Roadmap Reviews.”? The Playbook says, “Here’s how to run a Roadmap Review—from prep to follow-up.”And Scheduling/Trigger supports both by making sure it happens at the right time. Together, this trio creates a CS engine that is:? Strategically aligned? Operationally repeatable? Executed on time? Measured and informed by CS Health, ensuring that all parts of the delivery system are tied back to the actual outcomes and behaviours they generateExpanded with a Practical Example:A playbook only works if it’s executed as designed, at the cadence set in Engagement Strategy.Practical Example:? Engagement Strategy: Segment B gets two strategic meetings per year.? Playbook:  “Annual Planning Cycle” is triggered twice for each Segment B client.? Calculation: 20 Segment B clients ? 2 cycles ? 3 hours (prep + meeting + follow-up) = 120 hours/year? Check: If your team has only an 80-hour capacity for Segment B, either the cadence or playbook depth must be adjusted.Summary Table: Annual Playbook Workload Planning ExampleSegmentClientsHours per ClientTotal HoursA10880B20480C40280D60160Total130300This calculation helps you see at a glance whether your CS playbook plan is realistic for your team size.Concept #6: Trigger – Meeting Prep CycleA playbook is essentially a repeatable client interaction cycle—not just a meeting, but any structured engagement, including in-person meetings, video calls, phone calls, or even asynchronous communications like email summaries and action items.1. Trigger of the Interaction: The process begins with a trigger—this might be a recurring cadence (quarterly review, renewal), a key event (risk alert, assessment result), or a scheduled milestone. Triggers ensure that every interaction happens for a reason, not just “because it’s time.”2. Preparation for the Interaction: Collect relevant information (Discovery responses, assessment results, previous decisions), prepare documents, create the agenda, and set expectations with the client.3. Executing the Interaction: Run the engagement according to a clear and structured approach. This could be a meeting, a video call, or even a planned email exchange—whatever the client context requires. The agenda drives focus, outcomes, and alignment with client goals.4. Follow-Up: Document action items, decisions, and next steps. Follow-up can be a summary email, a shared task list, or scheduling the next interaction. If anything is unclear or missing, the process loops back to the preparation stage.5. Statement of Work / Output: Each cycle ends with a tangible deliverable—this could be a new roadmap, an updated Statement of Work, a contract amendment, or a project launch.Key point of the cycle: If follow-up reveals missing info or open items, the playbook loops back to preparation, ensuring no tasks are lost and every engagement drives to closure.Practical example:? For a Segment A client, a quarterly review cycle might start with a risk assessment (trigger), proceed to prep (collecting SWOT and business goals), then a video call or onsite meeting (executing), followed by a summary and a new Statement of Work sent via email.Concept #7: Quarterly Example – A Playbook in ActionWhy is this concept important? A playbook is not just a checklist—it’s a structured, repeatable cycle of client interactions, each with clear goals and outputs. Quarterly Business Reviews (QBRs) are popular among MSPs because they provide a regular, visible, value-driven rhythm—but it matters which client segments you apply this to.This example is for a $10,000+ MRR Range Segment A – VIP Touch client, where the goal is to establish a strategic partnership, foster frequent high-touch engagement, and engage in multi-level business conversations. Across the year, you typically have three QBRs, but the first client-facing interaction is an Annual Planning Meeting (to set the year’s direction), and the third QBR serves as a major wrap-up or milestone review.Practical example – Quarterly playbook for a Segment A client:PhaseKey Actions & OutputsTriggerAuto-scheduled quarterly reviewPreparationPrepare IT strategy review, compliance report, productivity report, discovery questions, tech reportClient Facing #1Annual Planning Meeting: deep dive on business goals, SWOT, and tech state for the upcoming yearFollow UpMeeting summary, action items, decisionsClient Facing #2Discuss discovery questions, tech report, and present executive reportCS DeliverablesQBR report, IT strategy review, executive report, discovery questions, tech report—each formally deliveredCommercialIn parallel or after: quotes, project scopeClient Facing #3QBR—review project scope and quotesSOW / OutputStatement of Work (SOW)—for new projects or roadmap stepsWhy does it matter?The QBR example is relevant because most MSPs recognize the concept of regular reviews, even if these are implemented very differently from one company to the next. In this Segment A – VIP Touch playbook example, you see how a structured quarterly cadence follows an annual planning meeting, with each step having clear preparation, follow-up, and commercial outputs, such as Statements of Work (SOWs) or quotes. The model demonstrates how a playbook can systematize client interactions, ensure consistency, and provide a visible, repeatable value delivery rhythm, regardless of the segment or exact meeting frequency.
Implementation Process – Turning Capabilities Into Repeatable ActionThe implementation process for Playbooks transforms your strategic customer service (CS) intentions into executable workflows. It connects what your team can deliver, where opportunities lie, and how each client segment should be served—consistently, confidently, and at scale.This process ensures that playbooks don’t just exist—they get used, adapted, and improved across your entire client base, with clear role ownership and measurable outcomes.Step 1: Map What Your Team Can Deliver (Capabilities)Begin by documenting your internal customer service capabilities. These are the real-world services and planning activities that your team can confidently deliver to a client.Examples:? Technology Roadmapping? Cybersecurity Reviews? Budget and Forecast Planning? Digital Transformation SWOT? Cloud Strategy or AI/Automation AssessmentsThis becomes your Capability Library, which defines the building blocks of your CS playbooks.Step 2: Identify Opportunity Areas (Client-Centric Themes)Review your client base and identify where you can add value or expand relationships:? What services are underutilized or unknown?? Which clients have untapped budgets or latent appetite?? Where can you extend coverage (sites, users, projects)?Build playbooks around common cross-sell, up-sell, or initiative triggers—using Discovery or CS Health signals (e.g., high Adoption or low Service Quality) to initiate action.Step 3: Match to Industry and Vertical CompetencyClients expect tailored insights, not generic templates. Classify your capabilities and playbooks by industry verticals where you have genuine expertise.For example:? Healthcare: compliance frameworks, EHR integrations? Construction: mobile workforce optimization, field service tools? Professional Services: secure collaboration, client-facing digital enablementThis ensures your playbooks speak the client’s language—and make your team look sharp and informed.Step 4: Align to Roles and Execution OwnersDefine who in your team owns which playbooks. Map playbook delivery to specific roles, based on complexity, strategic weight, and segment:? vCIO / Strategic Advisor ? Segment A & B strategic playbooks? CSM / TAM ? Segment B & C delivery playbooks? Service Desk / Coordinator ? Segment D operational or async playbooksClarity here supports CS People planning and avoids overloading senior staff with repetitive tasks that can be delegated.Step 5: Define Topics by Cadence and SegmentNow build your Engagement Calendar: which playbooks are used at what rhythm and for which segments.Example – Segment A:? Annual: Strategic IT Plan, Full Cybersecurity Assessment, Growth Alignment? Quarterly: Roadmap Review, Threat Landscape, Initiative Planning? Monthly: Performance Optimization, Stack Alignment? Ad Hoc: M&A Support, Facility Expansion, Strategic ProcurementEach segment’s playbook suite should reflect its maturity, appetite, and budget contribution.Step 6: Validate Team CapacityPlaybooks create work. Make sure your team can execute.? Use the Engagement Strategy time allocation formula (e.g., 5% ? 50% ? 40%) to calculate the number of hours per year available for playbook-driven engagements.? Match this to the CS roles assigned to you.? Adjust your cadence or playbook complexity if you are operating at or above capacity.This ensures your CS Playbook library is not only powerful but usable and sustainable.Final Output: A Playbook Strategy That DeliversBy completing this process, you end up with:? A documented list of your CS capabilities? A mapped set of playbooks per vertical and client segment? Clear role ownership? A time-budgeted execution plan that fits your CS investment modelPlaybooks aren’t just documents—they’re a system for delivering repeatable value. This Strategy Decision Process ensures that the system is built around what you’re good at, what your clients need, and what your team can deliver.

Client Business Goal – Playbooks evolve in tandem with the client’s maturity level, transitioning from technical tasks to strategic planning frameworks.? CS Health – Health scores can trigger or prioritize specific playbooks (e.g., a low customer experience (CX) score initiates a relationship recovery playbook).? CS Delivery – Playbooks define how and when deliverables are created, presented, and followed up.? CS Process – The operational layer: each playbook defines a process from trigger to outcome, including preparation, delivery, and follow-up.? CS People – Roles and responsibilities are embedded into each playbook step, ensuring team clarity and accountability.? CS Strategy – Segmentation and SOPs dictate which playbooks apply to which clients, and how often they’re executed.Product Links / Tooling SupportCurrently, there is no dedicated LMx feature that directly supports playbook authoring or execution. However, playbook planning is informed by:? Client Segmentation: Determines playbook applicability and cadence? Meeting and Assessment modules: Core actions inside many playbooks? Client Health Score: May influence playbook triggers or escalation paths? Future Opportunity: Potential integration with workflow automation tools and QuoterX (for initiative follow-through)Comparison of 7.2 Engagement Strategy and 7.3 CS PlaybookAspect7.2 Engagement Strategy7.3 CS PlaybookWhat is it?A strategic framework that defines how often, what type, and at what level of depth each client segment should be engaged.The CS team uses a tactical, step-by-step methodology or workflow to execute each engagement. It describes what to do, when to do it, and how to do it.Primary FocusDetermines when and what type of engagement should happen. (e.g., QBR annually, onboarding once, roadmap review monthly, etc.)Defines how a specific type of engagement is executed. ?? 1.4 Service Catalog
1.4 Service Catalog (Ongoing / Project)OverviewWhat is the objective?Why is it important?As an MSP, why do I need to do this?What is the Customer impact?Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: “What’s in the Box?” – Make Services Visible and UnderstandableConcept #2: Gaps and Gains – Use the Catalog to Spot OpportunitiesConcept #3: Segment-Driven Service MappingConcept #4: From Services to Initiatives—Catalog as a LaunchpadConcept #5: Catalogs and Assessments on the growth loopImplementation ProcessStructuring the Catalog for Scalable ImpactStep 1: Define the Catalog Structure by Service Type and SegmentStep 2: Map Services to Customer Success TouchpointsStep 3: Align the Catalog to Segmentation and Engagement StrategyStep 4: Integrate the Catalog with Playbooks and GovernanceFinal Output: A Dynamic, Role-Integrated, Client-Facing CatalogAppendixHow does it connect to the Client Business Goal levels?How does it connect to the other parts?Product Links / Tooling Support
OverviewWhat is the objective?To document, standardize, and map the MSP’s service offerings—both ongoing and project-based—into a structured catalog that aligns with segment tiers, Client Business Goal levels, and the overall Customer Success lifecycle.The catalog supports clarity, consistency, and scalability by mapping services to client segments and business goals. It provides the foundation for proposal generation, roadmap planning, and initiative tracking.Why is it important?Because without a structured service catalog, the Customer Success methodology can’t scale. Services become invisible, misunderstood, or inconsistently delivered, leading to client confusion, missed opportunities, and internal inefficiencies. A well-structured catalog:? Clarifies what the MSP delivers, at which level, and why? Makes services comparable, plannable, and improvable? Reduces ambiguity in delivery and accelerates the sales-to-service handoff? Allows proactive service evolution as client needs mature.As an MSP, why do I need to do this?? Enables consistent delivery across roles and client segments? Clarifies which services are available at which tiers and why? Reduces rework in proposal creation and initiative scoping? Highlights gaps in the current portfolio versus market demand or client needs? Supports operational planning through better visibility into service capacity and scope? Strengthens internal alignment across CS, Sales, Operations, and FinanceWhat is the Customer impact?? Provides visibility into what they’re receiving today—and what’s possible next.? Builds trust through clearly defined scope, ownership, and timing? Helps clients plan strategically by linking services to their business goals? Encourages service adoption by removing ambiguity? Supports better budgeting and project planning by clarifying expectations? Drives more productive conversations by shifting from ad hoc asks to structured options
Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: “What’s in the Box?” – Make Services Visible and UnderstandableMSPs often sell value, but clients hear “IT stuff.” The service catalog is enhanced by transforming abstract services into tangible, understandable components. It answers a fundamental client question: “What am I paying for, and what else do you do?” By clearly listing and describing ongoing and project-based services, the MSP makes its work visible and removes friction in conversations around scope, expectations, and upgrades.This visibility also helps internal MSP teams stay aligned. When proposals, roadmaps, and budget items all pull from the same catalog, everyone’s speaking the same language. It reduces the chance of over-promising, under-delivering, or missing a service the client needs but doesn’t know how to ask for.It also standardizes service-level inputs that directly impact CS Health, especially in the Alignment and Service Level Fit categories. A visible catalog makes it easier to assess whether the client is receiving the right services based on their business goals, and where mismatches are driving low Health scores.Explanation: The Service Catalog must break down your offering into clearly defined, understandable categories and items, so clients know exactly what they are getting and you can demonstrate real value. This transparency is crucial for aligning client expectations, improving internal handoffs, and enabling consultative sales.Practical Example:? Service Category: Managed IT Services? Service: Server & Network Administration? Service Items:? Server OS Administration? Network Monitoring? Incident & Problem Management? Configuration Backup? Availability & Capacity Management? Operations Management? Patch Rollback/Testing? Network Documentation? Firmware Management? Service Category: Cybersecurity Services? Service: Vulnerability & Pen-Testing? Service Items:? External Vulnerability Scanning? Internal Vulnerability Scanning? Penetration Testing? Remediation SupportHow it looks for a client: When a client receives a proposal or a QBR summary, instead of vague terms like “security service,” they see a concrete, checklist-style breakdown: “Your current agreement includes network monitoring, incident management, and external vulnerability scanning. However, you do not currently have regular penetration testing or remediation support in place.”Concept #2: Gaps and Gains – Use the Catalog to Spot OpportunitiesA good catalog isn’t just a list—it’s a strategic lens. When paired with client segmentation and maturity, it becomes a powerful tool to identify gaps in delivery and opportunities for growth. For example, if a Level 3 client hasn’t adopted any alignment services or roadmap planning, the catalog helps flag these as potential next steps. It lets MSPs say: “Others at your stage typically engage in X—shall we explore?”By linking catalog items to Client Business Goal levels, the MSP can tailor conversations, drive upsell without being pushy, and guide the client journey in a way that feels proactive, not salesy. This builds trust and positions the MSP as an advisor, rather than just a vendor offering a list of services.More importantly, it connects the CS Health system to structured planning. Catalog adoption—or the lack of it—can serve as a measurable signal of Adoption readiness, misalignment, or Engagement drop-off.Explanation: A well-structured catalog enables you to instantly identify which services a client is already using and which are missing, based on their maturity, industry, or current business challenges. This enables proactive recommendations and explicit conversations about what’s next.Practical Example: Scenario: During a business discovery session with a financial services client, you learn that their competitors in the insurance industry have adopted Public/Hybrid Cloud Management to handle compliance, scalability, and rapid innovation. Your client expresses interest in exploring this further.How it works:? You run an assessment covering relevant service items:? Cloud Security Posture Management? Workload Migration & Testing? Hybrid Network Integration? Regulatory Compliance Monitoring? The assessment shows your client is missing “Workload Migration & Testing” and “Cloud Security Posture Management.”? Based on the gap, you propose an initiative: “We recommend a Cloud Readiness Assessment and Pilot Migration project, which would help you catch up with industry peers and meet compliance standards. The scope, timeline, and outcomes are already standardized in our catalog—so we can move fast and with clear expectations.”Concept #3: Segment-Driven Service MappingDifferent clients need different things, even if the service behind the scenes is the same. The service catalog enables MSPs to tailor the presentation of services according to the segment. A Level 1 client might only need to know that they have secure backups. A Level 5 client wants to see how “data governance, backup, and compliance policy review” aligns with OKRs. Same engine—different dashboard.This mapping supports scalable personalization. You don’t need 50 different services—you need the ability to present and prioritize your services differently depending on the client’s maturity, appetite, and strategic posture. The catalog is how you organize the mess into something modular, understandable, and value-driven.This tailored presentation also enables more accurate CS Health diagnostics. When services are framed to match segment expectations, the Engagement and Alignment scores reflect proper fit, not noise from miscommunication or scope confusion.Explanation: Service catalogs enable you to map each item to the client’s segment and business goals, providing a customized, value-based presentation for every client.Practical Example Table – Digital Workplace & Collaboration:Service CategoryServiceService ItemGoal Level (Example)Description / Use CaseDigital Workplace & CollaborationMessaging & CommunicationTeams Enablement1.2–1.3 (Enablement)Roll out company-wide instant messaging to support hybrid workDigital Workplace & CollaborationFile Sharing & CollaborationSharePoint/OneDrive Setup1.3–1.4 (Modernization)Enable cloud-based file sharing and department collaborationDigital Workplace & CollaborationIdentity & Access ManagementSSO/MFA Deployment1.2–1.5 (All Levels)Strengthen security, support remote access, and enable SSO for SaaS appsDigital Workplace & CollaborationAnalytics & DashboardsPower BI Implementation1.5 (Innovation)Deliver business intelligence dashboards for executive decision-makingConcept #4: From Services to Initiatives—Catalog as a LaunchpadThe service catalog is more than just documentation—it’s an operational engine. Every service should map to an initiative type or proposal category. This turns the catalog into a launchpad for Discovery follow-ups, Assessment remediations, or Roadmap items. When something appears in a Discovery conversation, such as poor MFA adoption, you can quickly tie it back to a cataloged initiative: “We have a 3-week rollout for that.”This alignment means that services aren’t just things you talk about; they’re things you do. When clients see that every assessment risk or roadmap idea has a corresponding, scoped service offering, confidence increases—and so does project acceptance.When clients see that every assessment risk or roadmap idea has a corresponding, scoped service offering, confidence increases—and so does project acceptance. It also closes the loop in the CS Health system, reinforcing Adoption scores and making Execution follow-through measurable.Explanation: A well-structured service catalog doesn’t just describe what you offer—it connects every service and service item to a standardized initiative or project template, complete with scope, duration, and pricing logic. This means as soon as a client’s need or risk is identified (via Discovery or Assessment), you can instantly generate a ready-to-propose project with clear value, timeline, and investment.Practical Example with Calculation:Let’s say your client’s assessment reveals a gap: they lack modern Endpoint Detection & Response (EDR) across their 75 devices. Your service catalog lists “EDR Upgrade” as a standard offering, and behind it is a fixed-scope initiative:? Initiative: EDR Upgrade Project? Scope:? Deploy the EDR agent on 75 endpoints? Configure policies? Test and verify the deployment? Provide staff training? Update documentation? Pricing Calculation:? Base setup fee: $1,500? Per device fee: $75 ? 75 devices = $5,625? Total fixed price: $1,500 + $5,625 = $7,125? Duration: 2 weeks? Deliverables: Completed rollout, handover documentation, staff training sessionHow it works in practice:? During a QBR or after a technology assessment, you see that EDR is missing.? You propose the "EDR Upgrade" project from the catalog, using the pre-defined scope and calculation: “This initiative will take 2 weeks and is priced at $7,125, covering all 75 devices with training and documentation.”? The client gets clarity, confidence, and a clear path to remediation—no custom scoping needed, no vague estimates.Why it matters: This approach lets you move at speed, present initiatives with real business value, and eliminate surprises on both sides. Every project in your catalog becomes a launchpad for measurable action, and your pipeline becomes both more predictable and more strategic.Concept #5: Catalogs and Assessments on the growth loopThe service catalog is not only for sales or onboarding—it drives every stage of the client journey, as visualized by the Bowtie & Growth Loop. Assessments are always done against a catalog, not in isolation, to identify what the client is missing and what the logical next step should be.Practical Example (based on the image):? During acquisition (the left side of the bowtie), a prospect’s needs are compared to your Service Catalog.? Example: “During onboarding, you receive a Stack Assessment, which benchmarks your current environment against our Managed IT Services and Cybersecurity Services. Missing items are highlighted.”? During expansion (right side of the bowtie), growth opportunities are identified by reassessing the client against the Project Catalog.? Example: “After 12 months, a Project Assessment is performed to explore which business initiatives—like a SharePoint deployment, a compliance project, or a new BI dashboard—would create the most value. Each of these projects has a ready-made scope and outcome in your catalog.”Why this matters: This approach ensures that all recommendations are tied to predefined, value-based services and that assessments are not open-ended or ad hoc, but are always targeted at moving the client forward in a structured and scalable way.
Implementation ProcessStructuring the Catalog for Scalable ImpactThe Implementation Process transforms your service list into a structured, segment-aware Customer Success engine. Rather than viewing the catalog as documentation, this process positions it as a strategic foundation—linking every service to a specific point in the client journey, from Discovery to Roadmap execution.This process ensures that services are:? Visible to both clients and internal teams? Aligned to maturity and appetite? Deliverable in a consistent, measurable format? Ready for proposal, roadmap, and initiative integrationStep 1: Define the Catalog Structure by Service Type and SegmentBegin by categorizing all offerings into two delivery modes:? Ongoing Services (recurring activities tied to reliability, compliance, and infrastructure stability)? Project Services (scoped initiatives linked to transformation, modernization, or enablement)Then tag each service by:? Client Segment (A–D)? Client Business Goal level (1-5)? Service Category (e.g., Managed IT Services, Cybersecurity Services, Professional Services & Consulting)This ensures each client sees a tailored service experience aligned with their maturity and appetite, and each CS team knows what they’re expected to deliver at each stage.Practical Example:Ongoing Services (recurring services): Service Category: Managed IT Services Service: Server & Network Administration Service Items:? Server OS Administration — Client Business Goal 1.1, Segment D? Network Monitoring — Client Business Goal 1.1, Segment D? Incident & Problem Management — Client Business Goal 1.1, Segment D? Configuration Backup — Client Business Goal 1.1, Segment D? Availability & Capacity Management — Client Business Goal 1.1, Segment DProject Services (project-based implementations): Service Category: Managed IT Services Service: Server & Network Administration Implementation Service Items:? Server Setup & Configuration — Client Business Goal 1.1, Segment D? Network Infrastructure Deployment — Client Business Goal 1.1, Segment D? Initial Security Hardening — Client Business Goal 1.1, Segment DAll segments (Segments A–D) and Client Business Goal levels (1.1–1.5) are assigned, so lower segments and less mature clients receive only the foundational ongoing services, while higher segments have access to more complex project-based implementations.Step 2: Map Services to Customer Success TouchpointsLink each service to a corresponding CS Process activity to drive integration:? Business Discovery: Services flagged as cross-sell or friction-resolvers? Assessment: Services mapped to remediation or maturity milestones? Initiatives: Services structured into initiative templates for execution? Proposal: Services formatted for quoting and client-facing scoping? Budge: Services linked to cost expectations by segment and cadenceThis allows MSPs to scale playbook usage, reduce proposal rework, and improve roadmap clarity—all using a shared catalog.Example:During a Business Discovery session with a financial services client, it becomes clear that they require a new service: Public and Hybrid Cloud Management.Assessment:Performed assessments reveal gaps in Cloud Security Posture Management and Workload Migration & Testing.Based on these findings, an Initiative is proposed: "Cloud Readiness Assessment and Pilot Migration."The Proposal and Budget are then generated from this initiative, leveraging pre-built project templates within the catalog. This ensures a fast, accurate, and standardized offering that aligns directly with the client’s needs.Step 3: Align the Catalog to Segmentation and Engagement StrategyEach segment deserves a different catalog view and delivery intensity:? Segment D: Focus on foundational services (e.g., backups, patching, monitoring). Use templated language and lightweight delivery expectations.? Segment C: Emphasize enablement services (e.g., stack alignment, BCDR setup and configuration). Use semi-structured proposal templates and standard Statement of Work (SOW) templates.? Segment B: Highlight modernization services (e.g., cloud migration, lifecycle upgrades, policy alignment). Prioritize initiative mapping and proposal-readiness.? Segment A: Elevate advisory offerings (e.g., AI readiness, OKR alignment, BI dashboards). Enable roadmap co-planning and co-ownership models.This tiered approach allows for strategic clarity and CS Health alignment without overengineering.Example Table:Service CategoryServiceClient Business Goal LevelSegmentCloud & Data-Centre ServicesPublic / Hybrid Cloud Management1.3–1.5B–ACloud & Data-Centre ServicesCloud Security Posture Management1.3–1.5B–ACloud & Data-Centre ServicesWorkload Migration & Testing1.3–1.5B–AThis segmentation ensures that Public/Hybrid Cloud Management and its associated service items are primarily presented to mid-to-high maturity clients (Segments B and A), aligning with their appetite for modernization and transformation.Step 4: Integrate the Catalog with Playbooks and GovernanceEach CS playbook (1.3) should reference specific catalog items as expected deliverables. This ensures every meeting, roadmap, or assessment is linked to a scoped offering.Then, use governance reviews (5.5) to:? Audit catalog adoption by segment and CS role? Identify gaps between offered services and delivered services? Flag cross-sell and upsell opportunities based on Health signals (e.g., low Adoption or Alignment)This links the Service Catalog strategy to real-world delivery and CS Health outcomes.Example:For the financial services client described in Step 2, once the "Cloud Readiness Assessment and Pilot Migration" initiative is approved, a playbook is activated to guide the Customer Success team through execution:? Trigger: Approval of Cloud Readiness Assessment initiative.? Preparation: Assign a technical lead, prepare a migration plan, and gather compliance checklists.? Execution: Conduct assessment, pilot migration, and report findings.? Follow-up: Schedule a roadmap meeting to discuss results, next steps, and any necessary budget adjustments.This playbook ensures consistent delivery, clear ownership, and repeatable quality, reinforcing client confidence and supporting measurable progress in CS Health metrics like Adoption and Alignment.Final Output: A Dynamic, Role-Integrated, Client-Facing CatalogBy executing this process, you create a catalog that:? Helps clients see what’s possible and what’s next? Helps CS teams anchor proposals, budgets, and initiatives in consistent offerings? Helps the MSP scale service definition and delivery with role clarity and operational efficiencyA living service catalog becomes more than a reference—it becomes the bridge between strategy and execution, supporting trust, transparency, and transformation across the client lifecycle.

?? 1.5 Alignment
1.5 AlignmentOverviewWhat is the objective?Why is it important?As an MSP, why do you need to do this?What is the Customer impact?Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: Alignment = Portfolio-Wide Stack + Vendor MappingConcept #2: The Standard Stack Structures the Entire CS SystemConcept #3: Technology Integration and Compatibility at ScaleConcept #4: Vendor Mapping—Comprehensive, Not Ad-HocConcept #5: Stack-Based Advisory, Enablement, and CS HealthImplementation ProcessStep 1: Comprehensive Service/Service Item Inventory and Vendor MappingStep 2: Standard Stack Assessment and MappingStep 3: Versioning and Portfolio-wide ReviewStep 4: Advisory, Enablement, and CS Support Built on the Standard StackAppendixHow does it connect to the Client Business Goal levels?How does it connect to other blueprints?
OverviewWhat is the objective?The objective of standardization is for MSPs to introduce unified, standardized technologies across all clients and every major service area (e.g., endpoint protection, backup, email, collaboration). For each service, MSPs designate a single, proven, tested, and supported technology—and, where appropriate, a specific vendor—that will be adopted across the entire client base (unless justified exceptions exist for client size or vertical). This ensures that the MSP’s entire team (including CS, technical, operations, and support staff) is working with the same stack at every client. As a result, Customer Success gains a clear, consistent foundation for health measurement, assessment, reporting, and planning—while enabling faster, less error-prone support, easier training, and fewer exceptions.Why is it important?If every client—or even every service line item—reliies on a different technology, errors multiply, operations become more expensive, and support slows down. Exception management drains resources across CS, technical, and project teams, creating confusion for both clients and the MSP. By contrast, when a single vendor’s technology stack is adopted MSP-wide to cover most (or all) service items within a service or service category, efficiency rises, mistakes fall, and onboarding, support, reporting, and training become far more scalable. This cross-client alignment is the operational backbone of Customer Success, making segmentation, discovery, health scoring, and initiative planning reliable and actionable. Standardized vendor-to-service item mapping also makes the MSP’s portfolio transparent, easier to manage, and future-proof for both the CS organization and the client experience.As an MSP, why do you need to do this?Standardization is essential for scaling, efficiency, and clarity—not just for a single client, but across your entire managed client base. When all services and their underlying technologies are unified MSP-wide, you avoid the pitfalls of ad-hoc exceptions and reduce the chaos of managing multiple disparate solutions. This approach:? Empowers the CS team to evaluate every client environment against the same standards during Discovery and Assessment, making health signals and risk factors transparent and comparable.? Enables the creation of a single, unified service catalog that supports proposal generation, roadmap design, and budgeting at the portfolio level.? Allows for the assignment of recommended vendors to each service line item, establishing clear guidelines for quality, support, and future planning.? Facilitates scalable onboarding, training, and reporting—no matter which team member or client is involved.? Reduces operational and technical risk by eliminating unnecessary variability, accelerating support, and simplifying escalation and troubleshooting.What is the Customer impact?For customers, MSP-wide alignment means transparency, reliability, and better outcomes:? Clients always know which technology is being used and why, with the assurance that their environment aligns with proven, supported, and regularly reviewed standards.? Decision-making is easier when recommendations are built on a clearly defined, portfolio-wide stack, supported by deep MSP expertise.? Support, project delivery, and upgrades become more predictable and faster, since all teams work from the same technology playbook.? Initiatives for improvement or change (from Business Discovery through to Assessment, Meeting, Initiatives, and Roadmap) are grounded in consistent logic, allowing value and progress to be visible to both the client and the MSP.
Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: Alignment = Portfolio-Wide Stack + Vendor MappingAlignment is not a custom-fit project for individual clients; it’s the deliberate selection and enforcement of a unified stack and vendor set across the MSP’s entire client portfolio. For every major service area—endpoint security, backup, collaboration, identity, cloud, and more—the MSP identifies a single (or, at most, a shortlist of proven) technologies and vendors to be deployed everywhere possible.? The objective is not to “force” every client onto the stack, but to guide, propose, and recommend adoption, so the maximum possible proportion of the client base benefits from the same platform.? This is not just about tool rationalization; it’s about making CS, onboarding, project delivery, training, documentation, and reporting easier, cheaper, and more reliable for all clients.? A portfolio-level vendor mapping is the critical backbone for scale: it clarifies who supports what, ensures fast upskilling, and makes health scoring, budgeting, and strategic reporting consistent across every engagement.Explanation:Standardization means defining a unified technology stack and preferred vendors across your entire client portfolio for key service areas (e.g., Device & Endpoint Management, Backup-as-a-Service (BaaS), Productivity & Collaboration Suite Management). This consistency allows your MSP to streamline onboarding, training, support, and reporting.Practical Example:Your MSP standardizes on Microsoft Defender for Endpoint for endpoint security across 90% of clients, rather than supporting multiple antivirus solutions. This enables you to:? Train your support staff once on the Defender platform.? Develop a single assessment template that evaluates Defender configurations to ensure consistency and accuracy.? Use a shared vendor management process with Microsoft for licensing and updates.? Develop a standardized Defender-focused assessment that evaluates endpoint security posture uniformly across all clients.? Develop a standardized playbook to guide CSMs through quarterly security review meetings, focusing on Defender configuration and threat monitoring.? Create a unified roadmap template linking Defender upgrade initiatives to client risk reduction goals and scheduled quarterly milestones.? Utilize a pre-built proposal template that outlines Defender deployment phases, costs, and expected security outcomes for expedited client approvals.? Prepare standardized budgets that forecast Defender licensing, deployment services, and ongoing support costs, aligned with client size and segment.Concept #2: The Standard Stack Structures the Entire CS SystemA standard stack is much more than a technical foundation. It serves as the organizing principle for every CS discipline—from segmentation, engagement strategy, and playbooks to service catalogues, budgeting, assessments, and beyond.? When the majority of clients use the same stack, the MSP can build assessment templates, roadmap models, and reporting workflows that are reusable, consistent, and benchmarked across the whole book of business.? This means health, alignment, and adoption scores are measured with the same criteria everywhere, enabling trend analysis and benchmarking that are truly meaningful.? This also unlocks the ability to automate playbook triggers, build CS Health alerts based on deviations from the standard, and run health and risk reviews across the entire client base, not just piecemeal.Example: The service catalog is mapped to the standard stack, and any deviation (e.g., a client using Dropbox instead of M365 for file sharing) triggers CS Health issues and a documented opportunity in the roadmap.Explanation:The chosen standard stack isn’t just a technical choice—it underpins all Customer Success activities from segmentation and playbooks to assessments and roadmaps. Using the same stack across clients allows for reusable templates and benchmarking.Practical Example:When all clients use the same backup platform (e.g., Veeam), your assessment reports can automatically flag deviations (e.g., missing backups) with uniform severity ratings. Your roadmap templates then consistently recommend the same upgrade path or best practices, accelerating planning and reducing client confusion.Concept #3: Technology Integration and Compatibility at ScaleSelecting the standard stack is not only about picking the “best” tool for each service; it’s about designing a portfolio-level architecture where all parts fit together, and where integration, support, and upgrades can happen smoothly, at scale.? This requires a systematic review of how well each vendor’s solution supports all service items within a service or service category, and how each integrates with the rest of the standard stack.? Portfolio-wide integration is always the priority. If exceptions are necessary (due to industry requirements or legacy constraints), these should be documented, tracked, and scheduled for phased migration wherever possible.? Regular (e.g., annual) reviews of the standard stack, with collaboration between CS and technical teams, ensure the stack stays current, and any planned transitions are aligned with the MSP’s Customer Success rhythms, not just ad hoc tech pushes.Explanation:Standardization involves selecting tools that integrate seamlessly within the portfolio’s overall architecture, thereby minimizing friction and operational overhead. This ensures scalable deployments and fewer client-specific exceptions.Practical Example:MSP selects a collaboration platform (e.g., Microsoft Teams) that integrates with your ticketing, monitoring, and identity management systems as well as client tools. This means:? Automated user provisioning tied to identity tools.? Seamless alerting for collaboration outages within your PSA.? Unified reporting across all clients on collaboration health.Clients experience faster issue resolution and better cross-team collaboration, while MSP teams benefit from streamlined workflows and reduced manual coordination.Concept #4: Vendor Mapping—Comprehensive, Not Ad-HocVendor mapping must be done systematically and for the entire portfolio, not just one-off for special clients or projects:? Every service line item, under every service and service category, is mapped to the preferred vendor(s) that can best deliver the requirements. The goal is to have as few exceptions as possible, to maximize repeatability.? Where a single vendor can cover 80–90 %+ of items in a service category, this is almost always the preferred approach.? Where integration between vendors is required, technical teams and customer service (CS) must document and communicate the data flows, handoffs, and potential failure points.? Vendor mapping must be visible and updated across the entire portfolio. If new vendors are added or stack changes made, updates are rolled out as a planned transition (never in isolation), and always with clear communication to all CS and technical staff.Explanation:Vendor mapping must cover every service line item portfolio-wide, with minimal exceptions, to avoid operational complexity. This creates clarity about who supports what and where risks or overlaps exist.Practical Example:For your managed email service, your MSP designates Google Workspace as the preferred vendor for 85% of clients, with detailed documentation on integration points and escalation paths. Exceptions for special clients (e.g., in regulated industries) are documented and scheduled for eventual migration. This avoids support confusion and enables faster training and troubleshooting.Concept #5: Stack-Based Advisory, Enablement, and CS HealthA standardized stack across most of the portfolio turns Customer Success into a proactive, advisory, and metrics-driven function:? Discovery & Assessment: In every business discovery ? assessment ? meeting ? initiative, ? roadmap cycle, CS teams use the standard stack as the baseline for gap analysis. For example, if a client is using non-standard backup or lacks multi-factor authentication (MFA), these are flagged as risk and maturity issues.? Health Scoring: The technology adoption metric becomes highly objective: if a client’s usage of standard technologies is incomplete, their adoption score is lowered (and, for example, their Service Level Alignment or Engagement scores can also be flagged).? Technology Adoption = (Number of Service Items on Standard Stack) / (Total Relevant Service Items)? This percentage can be trended quarter-over-quarter, portfolio-wide, for real CS impact analysis.? Enablement: Training materials, onboarding templates, and QBR agendas are all rooted in the standard stack, making onboarding, upskilling, and documentation faster and more reliable.? Client Value: Clients experience quicker improvement, more actionable recommendations, and more consistent long-term support—because the advice, reporting, and training they receive is rooted in a real, proven foundation, not in ad-hoc guesswork.Explanation:A standard technology stack becomes the foundation for advisory services, training materials, enablement workflows, and CS Health scoring. Deviations from the standard stack highlight risks and opportunities.Practical Example:During Discovery or Assessment, your team identifies a client using a non-standard backup solution. This triggers a CS Health alert, lowering their Technology Adoption score. The MSP’s roadmap includes a “Backup Standardization Initiative” from the catalog, with training sessions planned for the client’s IT team. This proactive advisory and enablement help raise the client’s maturity level and adoption score over time.
Implementation Process Step 1: Comprehensive Service/Service Item Inventory and Vendor Mapping? Inventory all services across every service category in the MSP’s portfolio—both recurring (managed) and project-based.? Decompose each service into granular service items (e.g., “Endpoint Security” splits into EDR, patch management, device encryption, etc.).? Map one or more preferred vendor technologies to every service item:? For each service, identify the technology or vendor that can reliably cover the broadest range of service items.? Prioritize solutions that enable portfolio-wide scale, easy deployment, and proven support.? Document the degree of integration between technologies across all service categories:? Prefer vendors and products that support robust integrations, minimize friction, and complement the rest of the stack.? Identify potential overlaps, gaps, or integration challenges as early as possible.? Align vendor mapping decisions with business criteria:? Consider supportability, training requirements, product roadmap, and vendor stability.? Factor in client vertical or regional requirements only where necessary; default to unified solutions wherever possible.? Practical Tip: Maintain this inventory as a living document, accessible to CS, technical, and project teams, and use it as the foundation for every proposal, assessment, and client onboarding.Step 2: Standard Stack Assessment and Mapping? Classify service items and technologies by their impact on client maturity, appetite, and operational priorities:? Flag service items as “core,” “advanced,” or “optional” for each Client Business Goal level (1–5).? Note which technologies are mandatory for baseline compliance, security, or insurability.? Identify which technologies support business enablement (e.g., collaboration, automation, analytics).? Use the stack as a benchmark during every Discovery, Assessment, or periodic review:? Identify and record all non-standard technologies or exceptions at each client.? Map client gaps or outlier solutions to the corresponding standardized alternatives, ready for future CS-driven initiatives.? Integrate stack mapping into CS Health scoring:? Define how deviations from the standard stack negatively impact health and alignment metrics.? Use “stack conformance” as a visible, trackable metric across the entire portfolio.?
