Practical Tip: Make these benchmarks visible in internal dashboards and client-facing health reports, so gaps become clear drivers for roadmap, initiative, and budget discussions.Step 3: Versioning and Portfolio-wide Review? Schedule regular (e.g., annual or semi-annual) portfolio-wide reviews of the standard stack:? Include input from CS, project, security, and technical leads, ensuring both business and technical voices are heard.? Review industry trends, vendor roadmaps, integration feedback, and client needs.? Evaluate stack performance across all clients:? Analyze support metrics, incident reports, and enablement feedback for each technology to inform decision-making.? Identify which stack elements are delivering the most value, and where pain points or new needs are emerging.? Plan stack changes and upgrades portfolio-wide:? Coordinate transitions: Develop rollout and enablement plans to ensure all teams (CS, tech, training, and project) and all clients are prepared for the shift.? Avoid fragmented or one-off migrations—ensure stack evolution is a planned, strategic process that minimizes disruption.? Communicate the change rationale to both internal teams and clients:? Share why new technologies are selected, how transitions will happen, and what benefits are expected.? Prepare updated onboarding, enablement, and client training materials before changes go live.? Practical Tip: Use the version history to inform future audits, compliance reporting, and M&A due diligence.Step 4: Advisory, Enablement, and CS Support Built on the Standard Stack? Anchor all CS processes to the standard stack—no exceptions:? Every Discovery, Assessment, Meeting, Initiative, and Roadmap is structured around the current, portfolio-wide standard stack.? Enable CS and technical teams with ready-to-use templates, training, and conversation guides:? Develop standardized “Why We Use This Stack” narratives for every major service area.? Prepare risk/benefit guides and business impact explanations for client conversations.? Integrate standard stack conformance into every CS Health workflow:? Health scoring, initiative prioritization, and segment assignment should all reflect the degree of stack adoption at each client.? Automated triggers in the CS platform can flag non-standard elements for future action.? Leverage the standard stack to drive measurable improvements:? Utilize stack conformance to expedite onboarding, minimize support escalations, and optimize roadmap execution.? Track the impact of initiatives and service adoption across the portfolio for continuous improvement.? Practical Tip: Standard stack adoption should become a key performance indicator for both CS and technical teams, recognizing and rewarding teams for driving portfolio-wide alignment.
AppendixHow does it connect to the Client Business Goal levels?LevelRole of Alignment1.1 Technology SupportInitial introduction of foundational standard stack elements (e.g., monitoring, patching, backup, AV) MSP-wide.1.2 Technology EnablementPortfolio-wide stack alignment; enablement services standardized, BCDR and onboarding protocols unified.1.3 Technology ModernizationStandard cloud, SaaS, and lifecycle management solutions rolled out across the client base, enabling roadmap-driven modernization.1.4 Business TransformationCross-functional frameworks and advanced technology stacks are deployed across departments for all relevant clients.1.5 Business InnovationOKR-driven advisory, BI, data governance, and AI-ready stacks maintained and optimized for every client operating at this levelHow does it connect to other blueprints?? Service Catalog (1.4): Alignment defines the underlying technologies for every catalog entry, ensuring that all CS planning and recommendations utilize the same references.? Technology Budget (3.3): Technology budgeting and forecasting leverage the standard stack for all clients.? Assessment (4.3): All assessments benchmark clients against the standard stack, providing precise gap analyses and upgrade paths.? Discovery (4.2): Discovery is structured around the standard stack, allowing non-standard elements and risks to be visible early.? Roadmap (3.5): Roadmap planning and initiative tracking follow the standard stack, supporting the realization of scalable and consistent business value.
?? 2. CS Health
2. CS HealthMeasuring What Matters in Customer SuccessCS Health includes five key blueprints:2.1. Client Experience2.2. Technology Adoption2.3. Engagement2.4. Service Quality2.5. Service Level AlignmentIn SummaryMeasuring What Matters in Customer SuccessOnce the client's business goal is defined, the next step is understanding how well the client is progressing toward that goal and how effectively the MSP enables that progress. CS Health provides the metrics and signals that surface early risks, guide prioritization, and validate impact. Each health category connects to a different client experience and maturity facet, helping MSPs build context-aware Customer Success at scale.Without clear health signals, CS becomes reactive. CS becomes predictive and adaptive with theme, allowing MSPs to evolve client engagement based on real-world signals, not assumptions.“You can’t manage what you don’t measure. CS Health tells you which clients are thriving, which are stagnating, and what needs to change.”CS Health includes five key blueprints:2.1. Client ExperienceWhat it measures: How clients perceive their overall relationship with the MSP, including communication, reliability, professionalism, and trust.Why it matters: A positive experience builds trust, renewals, and strategic access. Poor experience erodes all other delivery value, even when execution is strong.How to track it:? CSAT and post-meeting surveys? Manual sentiment input? NPS and complaint tracking? Decision-maker relationship strengthBusiness Goal connection: CX becomes more strategic as clients mature. In Segment D, satisfaction with service is reflected. Segment reflects trust in roadmap co-ownership and advisory leadership.High CX reinforces Client Engagement—a core axis in the segmentation quadrant—and reveals whether appetite is increasing.2.2. Technology AdoptionWhat it measures: How effectively clients adopt and use the technologies recommended or managed by the MSP.Why it matters: Unadopted tools create no business value. Adoption is a key predictor of transformation readiness, initiative success, and ROI realization.How to track it:? LMx Digital Maturity Index (DMI)? Feature/stack utilization? Onboarding and change management completion? Asset lifecycle and compliance alignmentBusiness Goal connection: Adoption drives movement from Enablement (Level 1.2) to Modernization and beyond. DMI acts as a maturity proxy, informing segmentation, planning, and roadmap scoping.Adoption scores inform the Client Maturity axis in segmentation, helping predict readiness for more strategic services.2.3. EngagementWhat it measures: The rhythm, depth, and quality of client interactions, especially those tied to CS strategy, planning, and execution.Why it matters: Engagement enables influence. Low engagement weakens advisory value and signals risk; high engagement fuels momentum and initiative follow-through.How to track it:? Meeting frequency and stakeholder participation? Follow-up adherence and action item tracking? Touchpoint variety (strategic vs. operational)? Communication responsivenessBusiness Goal connection: As clients mature, engagement evolves—from reactive tickets to proactive collaboration. Engagement is the other half of the Client Segmentation quadrant, paired with Impact. Low engagement in high-impact clients signals a gap in trust or strategy that CS must address.2.4. Service QualityWhat it measures: How consistently services are delivered relative to client expectations and internal standards.Why it matters: Quality is the foundation of trust. Strategic initiatives fail when basic service fails. Reliable execution underpins roadmap credibility.How to track it:? SLA adherence (response + resolution)? Incident metrics (volume, root cause)? QA or audit logs? Client feedback on delivery consistencyBusiness Goal connection:Quality issues often drag down Client Impact, even when maturity and appetite grow, especially in Segment B and C clients. Quality issues often drag down Client Impact, even when maturity and appetite grow, especially in Segment B and C clients.2.5. Service Level AlignmentWhat it measures:How well the services being delivered match the client’s maturity, appetite, segment, and strategic goals.Why it matters: Misalignment creates friction, either by over-servicing passive clients or under-serving strategic ones. Alignment enables scale without compromising relevance.How to track it:? CS effort vs. Engagement Strategy by segment? Over/underservicing flags? Playbook adherence and cadence tracking? Roadmap coverage vs. initiative targetsBusiness Goal connection:Alignment reflects the transition from standard delivery to co-planned outcomes. The more mature and engaged the client, the more tailored the services must be.This is the integrator across all quadrants. Misalignment reveals mismatches between health score data and delivery model, often signalling readiness for segmentation review.
Definitions: CS Health1. Client Experience (CX) How your customers feel about their interactions with your MSP. It measures things like trust, satisfaction, and overall impression of your service quality, usually through surveys or direct feedback.2. Technology Adoption How effectively and consistently your customers are using the technology solutions you’ve provided or recommended. If technology is deployed but not properly used, it doesn't add value.3. Engagement How actively and regularly your customers participate in meetings, discussions, and strategic planning with your team. Good engagement means customers are responsive, attend meetings, and show interest in working together.4. Service Quality The consistency and reliability of your MSP's service delivery. It means your team resolves issues quickly, communicates clearly, and meets service expectations without surprises or errors.5. Service Level Alignment How closely the services you provide match the customer's actual needs, maturity, and strategic goals. Good alignment means customers get exactly what they need—not too much, not too little.6. Digital Maturity Index (DMI) A simple scoring system that measures how effectively your customers are adopting and using recommended technologies. It helps you easily see if customers are improving or falling behind.7. Net Promoter Score (NPS) A popular, easy-to-understand survey question asking customers how likely they are to recommend your service to others. It shows how satisfied and loyal your customers are.8. Health Score A combined score made up of Client Experience, Technology Adoption, Engagement, Service Quality, and Service Level Alignment. It gives you a quick, overall view of your customer's relationship health and predicts risk or growth.9. Health Indicator Specific signals or metrics that help you quickly see if a customer is thriving, stable, or at risk. Examples include missed meetings, reduced usage, unresolved issues, or complaints.10. Churn Risk The likelihood that a customer might leave or reduce their business with you. It's influenced by factors like low engagement, poor service quality, or misalignment between services provided and actual needs.In SummaryCS Health enables proactive, personalized Customer Success by showing where clients are today—and what’s likely to happen next. It connects directly to appetite, maturity, engagement, and impact—the four strategic indicators used to segment and prioritize.When tracked holistically, CS Health fuels better segmentation, sharper role targeting, more relevant playbooks, and a rhythm of delivery that aligns with client growth.When done right, CS Health becomes the real-time customer success dashboard, turning goals into measurable milestones and delivering impact at scale.
?? 2.1 Client Experience
2.1 Client Experience (CX) OverviewWhat is the objective?Why is it important?As an MSP, why do I need to do this?What is the Customer impact?Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: CX = 2-question pulse + sponsor heartbeat + complaint log (G/Y/R)Concept #2: CX Is the Visible Output of CS Execution QualityConcept #3: CX Drives Retention When Built on Strategic RelevanceConcept #4: CX Is the First Health Score—and the Easiest to OverlookConcept #5: CX Feedback Loops Strengthen Every CS DisciplineImplementation ProcessOperationalizing CX as the Frontline Health IndicatorStep 1 — Define the 3 CX inputs and G/Y/R thresholds (segment-aware)Step 2 — Wire collection points & automationsStep 3 — Review rhythm & watchlist (manage by exception)Step 4 — Use CX to tune alignment, cadence, and asksStep 5 — Close the loop (client-visible) & improve the systemFinal Output: A Real-Time, Client-Centric CX Operating ModelAppendixHow does it connect to the Client Business Goal levels?How does it connect to the other parts?Product Links / Tooling Support
OverviewWhat is the objective?To measure how clients perceive their experience with your MSP across touchpoints like communication, responsiveness, meetings, and professionalism. It reflects trust, not just technical success. It is operationalized with a simple 3-question pulse after strategic sessions (QBR/Strategy/Service Review), a monthly Green/Yellow/Red colour, and clear ownership (RACI: CSM Accountable, TAM provides adoption/lifecycle inputs, vCIO consulted for A/B).Why is it important?? Client Experience is a leading indicator of relationship health and loyalty.? Even with solid delivery, a poor experience erodes trust.? Strong CX builds advocacy, increases renewals, and deepens engagement.? It creates an early-warning system: CX colour changes automatically trigger small, named playbooks (Health ? CTAs) instead of debates.? It ties directly to outcomes you care about (GRR/NRR) and is evidenced in QBR/JSP-Lite notes (decisions, owners, dates).As an MSP, why do I need to do this?? Identify relational risk early and route it to the right owner within 72 hours (time-to-first-action SLA).? Adjust delivery, cadence, or stakeholder mix based on what clients feel.? Run CX with lightweight guardrails: one-screen pulse, monthly colour rules, and response-rate targets (A/B ≥50%, C/D ≥30%).? Keep data where it belongs: pulse results in the CS/Health workspace, decisions in PSA, stakeholders in CRM—so your dashboards match reality.What is the Customer impact?? Clients feel heard and respected, not just “worked on.”? Every recap includes a 2-line “we heard / we changed,” plus a maximum of two decisions with owner/date and the next checkpoint.? Faster approvals and clearer priorities because sessions stay relevant to business goals.? A consistent, predictable rhythm (prep ? Health ? Roadmap ? decisions) that builds trust and renewal readiness.? Supports transparency and builds trust in both people and process.
Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: CX = 2-question pulse + sponsor heartbeat + complaint log (G/Y/R)Typical MSP cases solved? NPS/CSAT “looks fine,” yet renewals feel shaky, and execs are absent.? Teams chase smiley scores instead of fixing cadence, relevance, or follow-through.? Positive ticket feedback masks weak roadmap/value conversations.How to apply? Track 3 inputs monthly: (1) post-meeting pulse (2 questions), (2) exec relationship signal (sponsor seen ≤120 days), (3) complaint/missed-expectation log with root-cause tag.? Roll into G/Y/R per account (e.g., Green if pulse ≥4.5/5 and sponsor seen and zero open complaints).? Set a guardrail: 2 consecutive CX Reds ? expansion credit gate (until Yellow/Green returns).Practical examples? Pulse questions: “Was this meeting valuable?” / “What was missing?” (1–5)? Exec signal: “Has an exec sponsor attended in the last 120 days? (Y/N)”? Root-cause tags: Cadence | Relevance | Follow-through | Quality.Common pitfalls? Long surveys no one answers.? Treating CX as an AM “soft skill” vs. system signal.? Collecting data without a first-action SLA.Concept #2: CX Is the Visible Output of CS Execution QualityTypical MSP cases solved? Technically correct delivery, but clients feel “lost” (no recap, unclear next steps).? Handoffs between CSM ? TAM, ? vCIO are inconsistent; meetings become repetitive.? QBRs record activity, not decisions.How to apply? Add a 5-point Meeting Quality Checklist to every strategic touchpoint: clear purpose, max two decisions (or limit to two asks), owner/date, recap ≤48h, link to roadmap.? Track two simple KPIs: % meetings with recap ≤48h (target ≥95%) and % meetings with at least one logged decision (target ≥70%).? Reference the QBR credit gate (owner + date + budget) before counting expansion.? Also set First-Action SLA ≤72h on any new complaint entry (owner + due date).Practical examples? Recap template: “What we decided / Why now / Owner & date / Risks / Next cadence.”? Dashboard widget: “Recap ≤48h” by account (Red if <90% last 30 days).Common pitfalls? Slide parades with no decisions.? Treating the recap as optional.? Counting “verbal approvals” without artifacts.Concept #3: CX Drives Retention When Built on Strategic RelevanceTypical MSP cases solved? Fast responses, happy ticket CSAT—yet renewals stall; proposals feel off-target.? Meetings are “busy” but not tied to outcomes execs care about.How to apply? Start every QBR with a 1-screen “Business Outcomes Snapshot” (OKRs/risks, last quarter decisions, two proposed approvals).? Tie each recommendation to “Why this / Why now / Expected impact” and **limit to max two decisions (two asks).? Calibrate by segment: A = OKR link + exec sponsor; B = roadmap + budget cadence; C = lifecycle hygiene + quick wins; D = reliability + clarity.Practical examples? Segment C: TAM runs Lifecycle Review, closes 1–2 quick wins before any new project ask.? Segment A: vCIO anchors two initiatives to exec OKRs; AM confirms budget frame.Common pitfalls? Selling features vs. outcomes.? Too many asks; no prioritization.? Tech-first language that loses non-technical stakeholders.Concept #4: CX Is the First Health Score—and the Easiest to OverlookTypical MSP cases solved? Quarterly NPS gathered, then ignored; early churn signals missed.? Complaints logged in tickets but never rolled up to Health.How to apply? Any Red CX event ? auto-create CTA with owner and due-by (First-Action SLA ≤72h).? Tag each issue with a root cause and review monthly in CS Ops; adjust cadence or playbooks accordingly.? Escalation by segment: A/B = vCIO review ≤7 days; C/D = CSM/TAM fix ≤7 days and confirm.Practical examples? Monthly “CX Watchlist”: accounts with **2+ CX Reds or ≥120 days since exec sponsor seen..? Portfolio widget: Time-to-first-action on CX Reds (target ≤72h).Common pitfalls? Over-surveying without action.? Hiding negatives to “protect” scores.? Treating CX in isolation from Engagement/Quality signals.Concept #5: CX Feedback Loops Strengthen Every CS DisciplineTypical MSP cases solved? Recurring comments (“meetings repetitive,” “unclear next steps”) never change the process.? The same enablement gaps reappear; there are no template or playbook updates.How to apply? Route CX themes into quarterly governance: update agendas, playbooks, and templates; add or remove steps in the campaign runbook.? Feed CX patterns into segmentation and proposal pacing (e.g., weak CX + low engagement ? resequence roadmap before new asks).? Close the loop with clients: “We heard X; we’re changing Y; you’ll see Z next cadence.”Practical examples? If “repetitive meetings” appear≥3 times in a quarter ? switch to JSP-Lite + two-decision format for that segment.? Add a “CX Themes” box to QBR prep: top 2 positive, top 2 to improve, planned change.Common pitfalls? One-off apologies instead of systemic fixes.? Changing too much at once (lose repeatability).? No named owner for CX theme actions.
Implementation ProcessOperationalizing CX as the Frontline Health IndicatorThe Client Experience (CX) Implementation Process enables MSPs to proactively track, interpret, and act on client perception across all segments. CX uses three simple inputs (2-question pulse, exec-sponsor heartbeat, complaint log) with G/Y/R thresholds, is reviewed on a light weekly/monthly cadence, and auto-creates CTAs on Reds (First-Action SLA ≤72h). QBRs remain the evidence anchor (recap ≤48h, max two decisions, owner/date, budget for credit).Step 1 — Define the 3 CX inputs and G/Y/R thresholds (segment-aware)Goal: Standardize what “good CX” means and how it’s scored.Owner: CS Lead (+ CS Ops/AM).Do this:? Lock the three inputs per account:? Post-meeting 2-question pulse (“Was this valuable?” / “What was missing?” 1–5).? Exec-sponsor heartbeat (seen ≤120 days).? Complaint / missed-expectation log (with root-cause tag: Cadence | Relevance | Follow-through | Quality).? Set G/Y/R thresholds (start point; tune by segment):? Pulse: Green ≥4.5, Yellow 4.0–4.49, Red <4.0.? Sponsor: Green if seen ≤120d, Red if >120d.? Complaints this month: Green = 0, Yellow = 1, Red ≥2.? Roll-up rule: Green if pulse Green and sponsor seen and complaints=0; Yellow if any Yellow and none Red; Red if any Red.Definition of done: One-pager with thresholds + field names published; team can score any account in <2 minutes.Step 2 — Wire collection points & automationsGoal: Capture signals without admin drag; turn Reds into actions.Owner: CS Ops/Admin.Do this:? Add a default 2-question pulse to every strategic meeting template (QBR, budget, roadmap).? Track exec-sponsor heartbeat in CRM (auto-remind at 90/120 days).? Log complaints with root cause in PSA/CS tool (single list, not scattered tickets).? For any CX Red ? auto-create CTA (named owner, checklist, First-Action SLA ≤72h).? Enforce Meeting Quality Checklist on strategic touches: clear purpose, max two decisions, owner/date, recap ≤48h, link to roadmap. Definition of done: Forms/snippets live; automations tested; CTAs appear in red with due-by dates.Step 3 — Review rhythm & watchlist (manage by exception)Goal: Keep attention on risk and momentum, not reports.Owner: CS Lead.Do this:? Weekly CS Ops (30 min): review CX watchlist = accounts with 2+ CX Reds or ≥120 days since exec sponsor seen; confirm CTAs in flight.? Monthly Portfolio (60 min): CX G/Y/R by segment; time-to-first-action trend; root-cause distribution; escalate by segment (A/B ? vCIO review, C/D ? CSM/TAM).? Guardrail: 2 consecutive CX Reds ? expansion credit gated until Yellow/Green returns (QBR notes must show owner/date/budget). Definition of done: Dashboards show time-to-first-action ≤72h median; watchlist cleared or escalated each month.Step 4 — Use CX to tune alignment, cadence, and asksGoal: Make meetings relevant and decisions faster.Owner: vCIO (A/B), CSM/AM (B/C/D), TAM (lifecycle items).Do this:? Start QBRs with a 1-screen Business Outcomes Snapshot (OKRs/risks, last decisions, max two proposed approvals).? If CX flags Relevance ? reframe to “Why this / Why now / Expected impact”; if Follow-through ? tighten recap ≤48h and ownership; if Cadence ? adjust rhythm.? Segment rules of thumb: A = OKR link + exec present; B = roadmap + budget cadence; C = lifecycle + quick wins; D = reliability + clarity. Definition of done: Next-cadence agenda updated; two decisions or clear “no-go with reason” captured in notes.Step 5 — Close the loop (client-visible) & improve the systemGoal: Show you listened; keep templates current.Owner: AM/CSM (client comms), CS Lead (template updates).Do this:? Send a “We heard X / We’ll change Y / You’ll see Z by <date>” note after negative CX.? Update JSP-Lite and playbooks when a theme repeats ≥3 times/quarter (e.g., switch format, resequence asks).? Re-score CX on the next cadence; remove the expansion gate when going back to Yellow/Green. Definition of done: Client acknowledgment logged; template/playbook diff published; CX colour rebounded or escalated.Final Output: A Real-Time, Client-Centric CX Operating ModelYou now have:? Three CX inputs with G/Y/R thresholds and a one-page rulebook.? Automations: CX Red ? CTA with First-Action SLA ≤72h; meeting recap ≤48h; exec sponsor ≤120d heartbeat.? Review rhythm: weekly watchlist + monthly portfolio; 2 consecutive CX Reds ? expansion gate.? Client-visible loop and template updates tied to recurring themes.This keeps CX simple, measurable, and actionable for a 10–150 person MSP—fully aligned with Governance, Enablement, and Compensation.
AppendixHow does it connect to the Client Business Goal levels?LevelRole of CX Measurement1.1 Technology SupportMay not be measured consistently; feedback is often informal or issue-based (e.g., complaints).1.2 Technology EnablementCX feedback begins to surface via post-meeting CSAT or onboarding reviews.1.3 Technology ModernizationCX metrics gain structure; trends are tied to assessments, usage, and initiative progress.1.4 Business TransformationCX becomes critical, measured across both business and technical interactions.1.5 Business InnovationCX is embedded in OKR reviews and strategic planning; sentiment and stakeholder trust are tracked across departments.How does it connect to the other parts?? 1. Client Business Goal - Customer Experience (CX) becomes increasingly important as the client matures. At lower levels, it reflects the quality of issue resolution; at higher levels, it shapes trust, collaboration, and the innovation potential.? 3. Customer Success Delivery - CX trends inform how reports, proposals, or meetings are received and whether outcomes meet expectations. Poor customer experience (CX) may indicate delivery gaps despite completion.? 4. Customer Success Process - Feedback loops are triggered through post-meeting surveys, Quarterly Business Reviews (QBRs), or sentiment check-ins. CX signals can drive service adjustments or engagement escalations.? 6. Customer Success People - Helps evaluate how CSMs, TAMs, vCIOs, and PMs interact with clients. Can support coaching, enablement, or escalation models across roles.? 7. Customer Success Strategy - CX informs segmentation review, SOP adjustments, and roadmap prioritization, ensuring the delivery model remains experience-aligned.Product Links / Tooling SupportThe LMx Client Health score incorporates key CX indicators, including CSAT, NPS, post-meeting feedback, customer sentiment (manually input), relationship with decision-makers, and custom flags (e.g., missed expectations, complaints). These inputs help surface relational risks early and strengthen renewal and upsell potential.
?? 2.2 Technology Adoption
2.2 Technology Adoption OverviewWhat is the objective?Why is it important?As an MSP, why do I need to do this?What is the Customer impact?Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: Adoption = business enablement, not deploymentConcept #2: Keep scoring dead simple (DMI = weighted % coverage) and segment-awareConcept #3: Adoption is the execution feedback loop (Assessment ? Proposal ? DMI move)Concept #4: Clear role ownership and a light cadence (TAM gathers, CSM validates, vCIO frames)Concept #5: Adoption Scores Are a Core Input for CS Health and Strategic ForecastingConcept #6: Use DMI to drive sequencing, forecasting, and pricing hygieneImplementation ProcessStep 1 — Stand up the DMI sheet (one afternoon)Step 2 — Baseline every client (timebox, don’t boil the ocean)Step 3 — Wire cadence & triggers (turn drops into tasks)Step 4 — Make DMI the QBR evidence (two slides, two asks)Step 5 — Use DMI in planning, segmentation, and forecastingStep 6 — Keep the framework light and accurateStarter kit (ship these with the plan)AppendixHow does it connect to the Client Business Goal levels?How does it connect to the other parts?Product Links / Tooling Support
OverviewWhat is the objective?Track whether clients are using what you’ve deployed—so you can prove value, spot gaps, and sequence the next steps. Use a simple, segment-aware Digital Maturity Index (DMI) so every client gets one clear adoption score by category and overall, updated on a fixed cadence (A/B quarterly; C/D semi-annual), and visible in QBRs.Why is it important?? Unused tools create zero business value—even if projects are “completed.”? Adoption is a leading indicator for modernization readiness and retention.? A standard DMI (Green ≥ 80%, Yellow 50–79%, Red <50%) keeps conversations objective across accounts.? Adoption data reduces rework/escalations and builds credibility for roadmap asks.As an MSP, why do I need to do this?? See where value is missing after delivery (e.g., MFA deployed but not enrolled).? Prioritize enablement and quick-win remediation before proposing new work.? Gate proposals when foundations aren’t adopted (e.g., MFA <60% = fix first).? Feed DMI into QBR evidence, segmentation reviews, Health triggers, and TAM/CSM scorecards (Compensation).? Keep it compute-light: one DMI sheet, same thresholds, same refresh rhythm.What is the Customer impact?? Clear, shared view of progress and risk; fewer surprises.? Faster ROI: adoption gaps become small, funded initiatives with owners/dates.? Better decisions: budgets and roadmaps tie to measured usage, not opinions.? Trust increases as hygiene improves—opening the door to higher-value projects.
Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: Adoption = business enablement, not deploymentTypical MSP cases solved? Tools are “installed,” but users don’t change behaviour (no MFA, Teams usage, and backups untested).? Projects marked “complete,” yet QBRs show no measurable outcome.? Tickets are down, but execs don’t feel progress.How to apply? Define adoption as “% of users/assets consistently using the capability as intended,” not “installed = yes.”? Track 5–8 “vital” insights that drive outcomes (e.g., MFA, endpoint compliance, backup success, identity hygiene, collaboration use).? Score each insight by % coverage ? weight; show a single Adoption/DMI percentage per account.Practical examples? MFA: users enrolled / total users; Backups: last-30-day success rate; Patch: % endpoints within 14 days; Collaboration: WAU/MAU ratio.? Weights: Security items heavier (e.g., MFA x2).Common pitfalls? Dozens of signals no one maintains.? Treating a one-time rollout as “adopted.”? Counting lab/test users in the denominator.Concept #2: Keep scoring dead simple (DMI = weighted % coverage) and segment-awareTypical MSP cases solved? Binary “yes/no” adoption hides partial rollouts.? Same thresholds for all clients create noise and arguments.How to apply? Use a lightweight DMI: each insight has a weight (1–5). Score = ?(%coverage ? weight) / ?(weight).? Colour rules by segment (example starting point):? Segment C: Green ≥70%, Yellow 55–69%, Red <55%? Segment B: Green ≥80%, Yellow 65–79%, Red <65%? Segment A: Green ≥90%, Yellow 80–89%, Red <80%? Track monthly in one sheet; review quarterly in QBR.Practical examples? Insights (weights): MFA(5), Endpoint compliance(4), Backup success(4), Conditional Access(3), Email security(3), Collaboration usage(2), Device encryption(2).? A C-segment client with 72% DMI = Green; next quarter target = +8 pts.Common pitfalls? Fancy formulas no one can audit.? Constantly changing thresholds mid-year.? “Everything critical” (no weighting).Concept #3: Adoption is the execution feedback loop (Assessment ? Proposal ? DMI move)Typical MSP cases solved? Assessments create long roadmaps, but DMI doesn’t budge.? Expansion credited before adoption proves value.How to apply? For every approved initiative, define the adoption move you expect (e.g., MFA +30 pts, Endpoint +20 pts).? Use the QBR credit gate: expansion/roadmap credit counts only when QBR notes show decision + owner + date + budget, and the related adoption insight improves by the following review.? If adoption stalls, trigger a remediation play before proposing new projects.Practical examples? “MFA rollout” target: enroll 90% users in 60 days; DMI security block moves from 52% ? 82%.? QBR slide: “What we changed / DMI before-after / next adoption move.”Common pitfalls? Crediting “intent” without measured change.? Proposing tier-2 tools while tier-1 adoption is still Red.? No owner for post-project adoption follow-through.Concept #4: Clear role ownership and a light cadence (TAM gathers, CSM validates, vCIO frames)Typical MSP cases solved? TAMs collect data ad hoc; CSMs don’t know what “good” looks like; vCIOs present without context.? Adoption scoring drifts because no one owns updates.How to apply? TAM: owns data capture and updates insights monthly from PSA/RMM/M365/backup.? CSM/AM: confirms initiative status matches the DMI move; logs blockers; preps QBR talking points.? vCIO: connects adoption to business outcomes and budget; sequences next moves.? Cadence: A/B quarterly updates, C/D semi-annual (monthly for high-risk Reds).Practical examples? Source-of-truth map: RMM for patch %, M365 portal for MFA/CA, backup console for success rate.? 20-minute monthly “Adoption huddle”: top 5 deltas, owners, due-by dates.Common pitfalls? “Everyone” owns it (so no one does).? Hunting across tools with no field naming standard.? Quarterly surprises because monthly checks didn’t happen.Concept #5: Adoption Scores Are a Core Input for CS Health and Strategic ForecastingTypical MSP cases solved? Dashboards turn Red and nothing happens.? Teams debate numbers instead of acting.How to apply? Stand up four core automation-first triggers (plus two optional):1. MFA below target ? Owner: TAM · Due: 5 days · Play: enroll laggards + exec note2. Endpoint compliance < target ? TAM · 5 days · Play: patch policy fix + recheck3. Backup success <95% (rolling 30) ? TAM · 3 days · Play: root cause + test restore4. Adoption flat 2 cycles ? CSM · 7 days · Play: value reset + quick win Optional: A new system was delivered, but the DMI was unchanged. ? CSM; Stakeholder change ? CSM intro.? Add a “First Action SLA ≤72h” widget.Practical examples? Email snippet library: exec-friendly notes for MFA/backup gaps.? QBR metric: “Time-to-first-action on adoption Reds” (target ≤72h).Common pitfalls? Assigning to a team instead of a named owner.? No due-by window or checklist.? Too many triggers ? alert fatigue.Concept #6: Use DMI to drive sequencing, forecasting, and pricing hygieneTypical MSP cases solved? Roadmaps jump to advanced items while basics lag.? Renewals surprise you because adoption never stuck.? Over-servicing low-adoption clients kills margin.How to apply? Sequencing gate: don’t push tier-2 initiatives until tier-1 adoption is Green.? Forecasting: combine Adoption (DMI trend) + Engagement + CX to grade renewal confidence.? Pricing: if DMI remains low after agreed plays, right-size service level or price to fit reality.? Compensation fit: The TAM variable includes the adoption/DMI delta; the AM/CSM expansion credit is gated by adoption readiness (see Compensation blueprint).Practical examples? Portfolio board: “Adoption vs. Proposal Success Rate” by segment.? Segment move: C?B when DMI ≥75% and engagement is Strong for 2 quarters.Common pitfalls? Selling the roadmap you wish they’d adopt vs. the one they’re ready for.? Ignoring margin leakage on chronic low-adoption accounts.? Treating DMI as a vanity metric (no actions tied).
Implementation ProcessStep 1 — Stand up the DMI sheet (one afternoon)Owner: CS Ops (or TAM if Ops-lite)Goal: One place to score adoption the same way for every client.Do this? Create a single spreadsheet with tabs:? Threshold Library: Green ≥ 80%, Yellow 50–79%, Red <50%; segment targets (A/B quarterly refresh; C/D semi-annual).? Categories: Security, Productivity/Collab, Backup/DR, Identity/Access, Endpoint/Lifecycle (adjust to your stack).? Insights: 2–5 per category (e.g., MFA enrollment %, EDR coverage %, patch compliance %, backup test ≤90 days, Teams MAU %).? Formula: Insight score = weight ? compliance % ? DMI = (? earned / ? weights) ? 100.? Account Summary: one row per client: Current DMI, ? vs last, Top-3 gaps, following actions.? Preload gates you’ll reuse everywhere: MFA <60% or Endpoint protection <80% ? remediation before any new initiative.Definition of done? The sheet calculates DMI per account using colours.? Every insight has a plain-English definition and data source.Step 2 — Baseline every client (timebox, don’t boil the ocean)Owner: TAM (data) + CSM (initiative linkage) + vCIO (business impact notes)Goal: A first pass that’s “accurate enough” to act.Do this? Pull quick exports (PSA/EDR/AV/Backup/M365) and enter coverage % per insight.? For each account, list the top-3 gaps and write one sentence on business risk.? Add one quick win per gap (owner/date). Keep it small and fundable.Definition of done? 100% accounts have a DMI baseline and Top-3 gaps.? Each account has at least one quick win with the owner/date.Step 3 — Wire cadence & triggers (turn drops into tasks)Owner: CS Ops (rules) + role owners (execution)Goal: Health-style automation so adoption gaps create work, not debates.Do this? Refresh rhythm: A/B quarterly, C/D semi-annual (put dates in the sheet).? Auto-CTAs (First-Action SLA ≤ 72h):? MFA <60% ? Owner: TAM · Due: 14 days · Play: 3-step remediation + 15-min ops sync.? Endpoint/EDR <80% ? Owner: TAM · Due: 14 days · Play: coverage push + exceptions log.? DMI drop ≥10 pts or flat two cycles ? Owner: vCIO/CSM · Due: 7 days · Play: resequence roadmap; add quick wins.? Add a small dashboard widget: “DMI CTAs open / Time-to-first-action.”Definition of done? Triggers create CTAs with named owners and due dates automatically.? Average time-to-first-action on adoption CTAs ≤ 72h.Step 4 — Make DMI the QBR evidence (two slides, two asks)Owner: CSM (pack), TAM (numbers), vCIO (story)Goal: Use DMI to justify pace and budget—without a slide parade.Do this? Put two slides in every QBR:1. DMI Trend (last ? now) with Top-3 gaps2. Proposed approvals (max 2) ? “Why this / Why now / Expected impact”? Apply your credit gate: an approval only counts when the owner + date + budget are in the QBR notes.? Gate proposals if foundations aren’t adopted (e.g., MFA <60% / Endpoint <80% ? fix first).Definition of done? QBRs show DMI trend + two asks; decisions are logged with owner/date/budget (counts for Comp & Governance).Step 5 — Use DMI in planning, segmentation, and forecastingOwner: CS Lead + Finance (quarterly)Goal: Let adoption shape where time and money go.Do this? Forecasting: Low DMI + low Engagement = high risk; flag in renewal board.? Segmentation: Move C ? B when DMI sustains ≥70% and cadence holds; move B ? C if DMI regresses and CTAs age out.? Capacity: Prioritize TAM time on Red/Yellow insights that unblock the roadmap.? Comp tie-in: TAM variable uses Adoption/DMI delta; AM/CSM use health guardrails (expansion gated until Yellow/Green).Definition of done? A quarterly note records any segment changes and the DMI evidence.? Renewal forecast includes an “Adoption risk” column.Step 6 — Keep the framework light and accurateOwner: CS Ops (quarterly), CS Lead (approve)Goal: Improve quality without adding complexity.Do this? Review weights and retire/add insights (max 20 total across categories).? Spot-check 5 accounts: does evidence match the score?? Update playbooks where the same gap keeps reappearing.Definition of done? Sheet refresh takes <30 minutes/account.? No more than two insight changes per quarter (stability over churn).Starter kit (ship these with the plan)? DMI Spreadsheet v1 (tabs: Thresholds, Categories, Insights, Accounts).? The trigger list (+ owners & due-by) is ready to paste into the PSA/CS tool.? QBR mini-pack (2 slides + decision log block).? One-page “Fix-first” gates (MFA <60%, Endpoint <80%).? How-to: where each number comes from (data links/fields).
AppendixHow does it connect to the Client Business Goal levels?LevelRole of Technology Adoption1.1 Technology SupportDMI is typically low; tools may be deployed but not used consistently.1.2 Technology EnablementDMI rises as core systems gain usage; adoption gaps are surfaced.1.3 Technology ModernizationDMI becomes a core input for the roadmap and stack standardization.1.4 Business TransformationDMI drives improvement planning and prioritizes transformation efforts.1.5 Business InnovationDMI supports cross-departmental tech optimization and innovation readiness, including AI, automation, and business intelligence (BI).How does it connect to the other parts?? 1. Client Business Goal - Technology Adoption, via DMI, becomes the clearest signal of readiness to move up the CS maturity curve. It converts asset and stack insights into business-aligned decision support.? 3. Customer Success Delivery - DMI results feed into assessment reports, platform utilization metrics, and roadmap proposals. High or low scores inform CS focus areas.? 4. Customer Success Process - The DMI informs intake processes and roadmap planning. Sudden dips or improvement plateaus can trigger initiatives, playbooks, or training workflows.? 6. Customer Success People - TAMs, CSMs, and vCIOs use DMI to drive engagement agendas, segment reviews, and stakeholder coaching. It supports quarterly or annual planning sessions with structured input and feedback.? 7. Customer Success Strategy - Adoption and DMI trends guide segmentation, capacity planning, and service mix development. They ensure that the CS strategy is tied to measurable client outcomes, rather than anecdotal perceptions.Product Links / Tooling SupportThe LMx Digital Maturity Index (DMI) is the key metric that quantifies technology adoption and maturity. It aggregates compliance across insights (e.g., patching, EOL coverage, identity protection), weighted by severity and adoption gaps. DMI supports both negative scoring and weighted average strategies, allowing it to reflect progress at the organizational, client, or global level.Inputs may include M365 usage, backup status, stack alignment ratios, endpoint compliance, and other relevant metrics. A rising DMI score indicates growing maturity; a stagnant or declining score highlights the adoption risk.
?? 2.3 Engagement
2.3 EngagementOverviewWhat is the objective?Why is it important?As an MSP, why do I need to do this?What is the Customer impact?Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: Engagement = observable behaviour, not “interest”Concept #2: Keep scoring dead simple (4 signals ? one colour)Concept #3: Segment-aware expectations (D?A)Concept #4: Triggers create tasks (Health ? Playbooks), not meetingsConcept #5: Engagement Scoring Strengthens Forecasting, Planning, and PrioritizationConcept #6: Use Engagement to prioritize time, forecast renewals, and set rhythmConcept #7: Roles & hygiene make or break engagement qualityImplementation ProcessStep 1 — Set segment expectations & ownersStep 2 — Instrument the four signalsStep 3 — Score monthly (G/Y/R) & auto-trigger playsStep 4 — Run the lightweight review rhythmStep 5 — Gate proposals & align with CompensationStep 6 — Coach the basics, fix the templatesStep 7 — Publish the Starter KitCopy/Paste thresholds (keep consistent across blueprints)Minimal data map (one source per signal)30-60-90 quick rolloutAppendixHow does it connect to the Client Business Goal levels?How does it connect to the other parts?Product Links / Tooling Support
OverviewWhat is the objective?To measure and manage how clients show up in the CS rhythm—not by gut feel, but through a few observable signals:? Cadence adherence: planned meetings happen on time.? Stakeholder mix: the right people attend (incl. an exec sponsor seen ≤120 days).? Decision velocity: proposals/initiatives move (max two decisions per QBR, logged with owner/date/budget).? Follow-through: recap ≤48h and actions closed on time. Roll these into a monthly Green/Yellow/Red per account and use them to trigger the right playbooks.Why is it important?? Engagement enables influence. Low engagement = slow/no approvals, stalled Adoption/DMI, weak outcomes.? Early risk signal. Drops in engagement typically precede CX dips and renewal surprises.? Fewer wasted cycles. Keeps meetings relevant, short, and decision-oriented (no slide parades).? Clean handoffs. AM/CSM ? TAM ? vCIO stay in sync because the rhythm is visible and scored.As an MSP, why do I need to do this?? Prioritize time: Focus AM/CSM and vCIO on accounts where engagement + impact justify it.? Gate proposals wisely: If engagement = Red for 2 months, gate expansion credit until Yellow/Green returns (ties to Compensation).? Trigger actions, not debates: Any engagement drop auto-creates a CTA (first-action SLA ≤72h) with the matching play.? Forecast better: Engagement + Adoption + CX = a simple, accurate renewal confidence view.? Align segments: Expectations differ by segment (A/B strategic cadence, C lifecycle hygiene, D reliability); the score reflects that.What is the Customer impact?? Faster, clearer decisions: Two well-framed asks per QBR; next steps are owned and dated.? Less meeting fatigue: Right people, right cadence, short agenda, recap ≤48h.? Visible progress: Clients see momentum in roadmaps and quick wins, not just activity.? More trust: A predictable rhythm that respects time and ties every touchpoint to outcomes.
Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: Engagement = observable behaviour, not “interest”Typical MSP cases solved? “They like us,” but skip QBRs and don’t approve initiatives.? Long email threads, zero decisions.? In opt-only meetings, the decision-maker is never in the room.How to apply? Measure behaviour you can see: Cadence Adherence, Stakeholder Mix, Decision Velocity, Follow-up Closure.? Score Engagement monthly; pay attention to trends, not one-off spikes.? Treat engagement as a gate for expansion and roadmap pacing.Practical examples? Cadence Adherence = completed/planned meetings.? Stakeholder Mix = % sessions with a decision-maker present.? Decision Velocity = median days from proposal to yes/no.? Follow-up Closure = % meeting recaps sent ≤48h and action items accepted.Common pitfalls? Confusing “responsiveness” with engagement.? Counting any meeting as equal (ops-only ≠ strategic).? No decision timestamps ? can’t measure velocity.Concept #2: Keep scoring dead simple (4 signals ? one colour)Typical MSP cases solved? Gut-feel debates: “I think they’re engaged.”? Complex rubrics no one updates.How to apply? Engagement Score (0–100) = 30% Cadence Adherence · 30% Stakeholder Mix · 25% Decision Velocity · 15% Follow-up Closure.? Convert to G/Y/R by segment (starting points):? C: Green ≥70, Yellow 55–69, Red <55? B: Green ≥75, Yellow 60–74, Red <60? A: Green ≥80, Yellow 70–79, Red <70? Track monthly; review in QBR prep.Practical examples? If a B account hits: Cadence 90, Mix 70, Velocity 65, Closure 80 ? Score = 0.3·90 + 0.3·70 + 0.25·65 + 0.15·80 = 77.25 ? Green.Common pitfalls? Changing weights mid-year.? Using 10+ inputs (noise).? Ignoring segment context.Concept #3: Segment-aware expectations (D?A)Typical MSP cases solved? Expecting A-level executive engagement from D/C clients.? Over-servicing low-maturity accounts with heavy workshops.How to apply? D: short ops check-ins; prove reliability.? C: quarterly lifecycle/QBR; get sign-offs on quick wins.? B: roadmap reviews, multi-stakeholder planning; push approvals.? A: exec-level sessions tied to OKRs; co-owned roadmap & budget.? Use the same four signals, but raise the thresholds as you move up segments.Practical examples? C segment: target Stakeholder Mix ≥50% with a budget owner present at least every other QBR.? A segment: Decision Velocity target ≤30 days on approved items.Common pitfalls? One flat standard for all clients.? Mistaking friendly ops chats for strategic engagement.Concept #4: Triggers create tasks (Health ? Playbooks), not meetingsTypical MSP cases solved? “We’ll discuss it next week,” while momentum dies.? It is a red engagement but has no owner and no due date.How to apply? Stand up four automation-first triggers (plus two optional). Each opens a CTA with owner + due-by + checklist:1. Missed cadence twice ? Owner: CSM · Due: 72h · Play: 2-line value recap ? propose 30-min reset ? add exec.2. No decision ≥30 days on proposal ? Owner: AM/CSM · Due: 72h · Play: decision brief + options (approve/adjust/park).3. Decision-maker absent two sessions ? Owner: CSM · Due: 5d · Play: sponsor re-intro + “why now” note.4. Follow-ups not closed in 48h twice ? Owner: CSM · Due: 72h · Play: fast recap + confirm next steps. Optional: stakeholder change (new exec), repeated agenda “no value” feedback.Practical examples? Dashboard widget: “Time-to-first-action on Engagement Reds” (target ≤72h).? Snippet library for exec outreach.Common pitfalls? Assigning to a team instead of a named person.? No due-by windows; CTAs age out.? Trigger overload (keep it to 4–6).Concept #5: Engagement Scoring Strengthens Forecasting, Planning, and PrioritizationTypical MSP cases solved? Deals pushed into disengaged accounts ? slow/no adoption, future churn.? Internal fights over what “counts.”How to apply? If Engagement = Red for 2+ months, expansion from that account does not count toward NRR that quarter (credit returns when Engagement ≥ Yellow and a QBR resets next steps).? Use the “credit gate” in Compensation for AM/CSM; keep vCIO advisory neutral.Practical examples? QBR slide: “Engagement status ? credit status” per account.? The AM plan shows gated vs. eligible expansion.Common pitfalls? Overriding the gate with exceptions.? Paying for proposals sent, not decisions made.Concept #6: Use Engagement to prioritize time, forecast renewals, and set rhythmTypical MSP cases solved? Team spends hours on low-engagement, low-value accounts.? Renewal surprises because engagement decayed months earlier.How to apply? Prioritization: Focus vCIO/AM time on High Adoption + High Engagement first; deploy re-engagement plays on Low Engagement before pitching.? Forecasting: Renewal confidence = blend of Engagement colour + DMI trend + CX.? Rhythm: If Engagement Red, shorten meeting scope and increase frequency briefly; once Yellow/Green, widen scope again.Practical examples? The segment board combines engagement colour with DMI and CX to rank the QBR prep order.? Playbook: “Disengaged B account” = reduce agenda to one decision + one quick win.Common pitfalls? Proposing complex initiatives for Red engagement.? Treating Engagement as “nice to have” vs. the execution gate.Concept #7: Roles & hygiene make or break engagement qualityTypical MSP cases solved? Meetings drift tactical; execs stop showing up.? Next steps unclear; nothing moves.How to apply? CSM/AM: owns cadence, recap ≤48h, decision tracking.? vCIO (A/B): anchors strategic narrative, ties to OKRs/budget, keeps max two decisions per session.? TAM: brings adoption/quality facts and quick wins.? Use a one-page meeting checklist: agenda, who the decision-maker is, desired decisions, recap deadline, and owner/date.Practical examples? JSP-Lite format: Health snapshot ? Roadmap progress ? 1–2 approvals with owner/date/budget.? A monthly 20-minute “Engagement huddle” will be held to review deltas and stuck items.Common pitfalls? Slide parades without decisions.? Recaps that restate minutes but lack owners/dates.
Implementation ProcessStep 1 — Set segment expectations & ownersGoal: Make “good engagement” explicit by segment.Owner: CS Lead (input from AM/CSM, TAM, vCIO).Do this:? Publish a 1-pager with segment baselines:? A: exec sponsor present ≤120 days; quarterly strategy; 1–2 decisions per QBR.? B: roadmap cadence; approvers present; 1–2 decisions per QBR.? C: lifecycle reviews; initiative sign-offs; keep cadence.? D: operational check-ins; reliability updates.? Map who owns what: AM/CSM = cadence & decisions, TAM = lifecycle inputs, vCIO = exec relevance.Definition of done: The 1-pager is posted; each item has an A (Accountable) role that also appears on that role’s scorecard (Compensation link).Step 2 — Instrument the four signalsGoal: Capture observable engagement data every time, no opinions.Owner: CS Ops (or CS Lead if Ops-lite).Do this (copy/paste):? Cadence adherence: % planned meetings held on time from the calendar/CS tool/PSA.? Stakeholder mix: flag exec sponsor seen ≤120 days (Y/N) in CRM.? Decision velocity: per QBR, max two decisions, each logged with owner/date/budget.? Follow-through: recap ≤48h with actions recorded.? Add a 5-point Meeting Quality Checklist to every strategic touchpoint (purpose, ≤2 decisions, owner/date, recap ≤48h, roadmap link).Definition of done: A simple data map shows where each signal lives (Calendar/CS tool/PSA/CRM/Docs) and who updates it.Step 3 — Score monthly (G/Y/R) & auto-trigger playsGoal: One colour per account; rules everyone understands.Owner: CS Ops sets rules; AM/CSM execute.Do this:? Green if: cadence ≥90% and exec seen ≤120d and recap ≤48h ≥95% and ≥70% QBRs have ≥1 decision.? Yellow if: any one metric slips (cadence 80–89%, recap 80–94%, no exec ≤120d, or decisions <70%).? Red if: cadence <80% or no exec >120d or recap <80% or zero decisions in last 2 QBRs or a complaint tagged “Relevance/Follow-through”.? Automation: Any Red ? create CTA with first-action SLA ≤72h and prefilled play:? “Re-engage Stakeholders” (CSM, 72h)? “Reset Cadence & Scope” (CSM, 72h)? “Exec Intro + Value Recap” (AM/CSM, 10 days)? “Unblock/Resequence Roadmap” (vCIO, 7 days) Definition of done: Portfolio dashboard shows colour per account + time-to-first-action for Reds.Step 4 — Run the lightweight review rhythmGoal: Keep momentum without meeting bloat.Owner: CS Lead runs; team participates.? Weekly AM/CSM (30 min): next 14 days of QBRs; confirm two asks, assets, owners; check open CTAs from engagement Reds.? Weekly CS Ops (20 min): data freshness, trigger audits, field corrections.? Monthly Segment Review (60 min): heatmap (Engagement G/Y/R, Adoption/DMI, CX); reassign owners; launch/close micro-campaigns.Definition of done: Meetings on calendar, action log shows owners/dates; aging CTAs decrease month over month.Step 5 — Gate proposals & align with CompensationGoal: Stop pushing projects into low-engagement accounts.Owner: AM/CSM (with vCIO for A/B).Do this:? Expansion gate: 2 consecutive Engagement Reds ? expansion credit is paused until Yellow/Green returns (ties to Compensation guardrail).? Allow urgent risk-reduction items (e.g., MFA) but log them as stability work, not portfolio growth.Definition of done: Calculator/plan notes the gate; disputed credits reference the QBR decision log.Step 6 — Coach the basics, fix the templatesGoal: Improve the system where it actually broke.Owner: CS Lead + Enablement.Do this:? If recap ≤48h <95% ? train on the recap template; add checklist to the meeting note.? If exec seen >120d ? run the Exec Intro play (AM/CSM), involve vCIO in A/B.? If “repetitive meetings” appear≥3? in a quarter ? switch to JSP-Lite + two-decision format for that segment.Definition of done: Next month’s KPI improves (recap rate, exec heartbeat, decision %).Step 7 — Publish the Starter KitGoal: Make it self-serve for a 1–5 person CS team.Owner: CS Lead.Pack contents:? Segment expectations one-pager (A/B/C/D).? Meeting Quality Checklist + recap ≤48h template.? Engagement scoring rules (G/Y/R) + automation triggers (≤72h first action).? Three re-engagement plays (checklists + email snippets).? Dashboard how-to (which fields, where).Definition of done: New hires can run the system in one sitting.Copy/Paste thresholds (keep consistent across blueprints)? Recap ≤48h, first-action ≤72h, exec sponsor seen ≤120 days, max two decisions per QBR.? Green: cadence ≥90%, recap ≥95%, exec seen ≤120d, decisions ≥70%.? Yellow: anyone slips.? Red: cadence <80% or recap <80% or no exec >120d or zero decisions in last 2 QBRs or complaint tag (Relevance/Follow-through/Quality).? Guardrail: 2 consecutive Reds ? expansion credit gate until Yellow/Green returns.Minimal data map (one source per signal)? Cadence adherence: Calendar/CS tool/PSA meeting records.? Stakeholder mix/exec heartbeat: CRM contact roles + last-seen date.? Decision velocity: QBR Decision Log (owner/date/budget).? Follow-through: Docs/CS tool/PSA note with timestamp; dashboard widget: “Recap ≤48h”.30-60-90 quick rollout? Days 1–30: Publish segment 1-pager + checklist; turn on recap ≤48h tracking; colour 10–20 accounts.? Days 31–60: Automate Red?CTA with ≤72h SLA; start weekly AM/CSM + CS Ops.? Days 61–90: Enforce expansion gate; add dashboard widgets; run enablement where a KPI is below target.This keeps Engagement simple, visible, and actionable—and fully aligned with CX, Governance, and Compensation.
AppendixHow does it connect to the Client Business Goal levels?LevelRole of Engagement1.1 Technology SupportSporadic or issue-based contact; meetings are rare or reactive.1.2 Technology EnablementEngagement becomes more regular, with reviews conducted monthly or quarterly.1.3 Technology ModernizationA meeting cadence is established, including a roadmap and initiative tracking.1.4 Business TransformationEngagement expands to include more departments and outcome reviews.1.5 Business InnovationStrategic engagement is continuous and multilevel, aligned with OKRs and innovation cycles.How does it connect to the other parts?1. Client Business Goal - The level and type of engagement reflect client maturity. As goals shift from support to innovation, engagement evolves from reactive troubleshooting to proactive co-planning and alignment.3. Customer Success Delivery - Engagement is the gateway to delivering reports, roadmaps, and strategies. Missed meetings or a lack of stakeholder participation reduce delivery effectiveness and perceived value.4. Customer Success Process - Engagement is tied to scheduling, meeting execution, and intake processes. It also informs initiative tracking and follow-up task management.6. Customer Success People - Tied closely to Account Managers, vCIOs, CSMs, and other client-facing roles. Low engagement can indicate role misalignment or missed handoffs. High engagement supports coaching and prioritization.7. Customer Success Strategy - Engagement metrics inform segmentation, cadence planning, and SOP performance. Strategy also adapts when engagement quality impacts delivery consistency or roadmap velocity.Product Links / Tooling SupportThe LMx Client Health score may reflect engagement indicators, including the number of meetings held, meeting frequency compared to the target cadence, stakeholder attendance, action item completion, and executive relationship tracking. These inputs help assess whether the relationship is growing, stagnating, or declining.
?? 2.4 Service Quality
2.4 Service QualityOverviewWhat is the objective?Why is it important?As an MSP, why do I need to do this?What is the Customer impact?Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: Quality = reliability the client can feel (not just speed)Concept #2: Keep scoring dead simple (4 signals ? one colour)Concept #3: Segment-aware standards (D?A)Concept #4: Triggers create tasks (Health ? Playbooks), not meetingsConcept #5:  Quality is a dependency for strategy (gate big approvals)Concept #6: Tie ownership to roles you already haveConcept #7: Make RCA a habit (small, fast, useful)Implementation ProcessStep 1 — Pick your four core signals and set segment thresholdsStep 2 — Wire data to a single monthly score (one source of truth)Step 3 — Automate 4 quality triggers ? playbooks (alerts create tasks)Step 4 — Run the rhythm (weekly huddle, monthly roll-up, quarterly review)Step 5 — Close the loop: mini-RCA + client-visible fixStep 6 — Evidence quality in QBRs (and gate big asks)Step 7 — Calibrate and coach (lightweight, predictable)Final Output: Service Quality Starter KitAppendixHow does it connect to the Client Business Goal levels?How does it connect to the other parts?Product Links / Tooling Support
OverviewWhat is the objective?To measure and improve the reliability of day-to-day delivery across tickets, projects, and initiatives using a short, repeatable set of signals:? SLA adherence (response + resolution)? Milestone delivery (projects/initiatives on time)? Recurrence & root cause (repeat incidents closed with RCA)? Client-facing follow-through (recap ≤48h after strategic meetings)? First action on quality CTAs (≤72h) when thresholds are missed Score accounts monthly (G/Y/R) and trigger simple playbooks when quality slips.Why is it important?? Trust foundation: strategy stalls if basics wobble; quality keeps QBRs credible.? Early risk signal: missed SLAs or late milestones flag churn/renewal risk sooner than sentiment.? Margin protection: fewer escalations/rework; clearer ownership and handoffs.? Portfolio velocity: consistent quality makes approvals and adoption move faster.As an MSP, why do I need to do this?? One truth, low effort: pull SLA/milestones from PSA; recap timestamps from docs/PSA; roll up in a single Health widget.? Auto-action, not debate: any Red opens a CTA with first-action ≤72h (e.g., TAM “Root Cause + Client Comms” due in 5 days).? Segment-aware:? D: response/resolution consistency? C: lifecycle visibility + error remediation? B: initiative execution + cadence alignment? A: project performance + outcome transparency? Aligned with Compensation: TAM/CSM quality trends feed scorecards (no activity pay, outcome proof via QBR).? Fits small teams: a handful of metrics, one monthly colour, one quarterly review.What is the Customer impact?? Fewer surprises, faster recovery: clear updates and predictable timelines.? Higher confidence to approve work: reliable execution ? easier decisions in QBRs.? Better outcomes: less firefighting, more time for adoption and modernization.? Stronger trust: professional follow-through (recap ≤48h) and visible root-cause fixes.
Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: Quality = reliability the client can feel (not just speed)Typical MSP cases solved? “We hit response SLAs, but they still complain.”? Tickets close fast, then re-open; projects slip quietly.? Status updates are late or opaque, so trust erodes.How to apply? Define quality as: SLA reliability + low recurrence + on-time initiatives + professional follow-through.? Make this the first slide in QBRs before roadmap approvals.Practical examples? Include “no surprises” checks: ETA given, progress updates during incidents, recap with owners/dates.? Track re-opened tickets within 30 days as a quality proxy.Common pitfalls? Treating CSAT alone as “quality”.? Optimizing first response while ignoring resolution, recurrence, or communication.Concept #2: Keep scoring dead simple (4 signals ? one colour)Typical MSP cases solved? Endless debates about “Is quality good?”? Complex QA rubrics no one updates.How to apply Use four signals ? 0–100 score ? G/Y/R by segment:? SLA Compliance Trend (30%) – response + resolution vs target (last 30/90 days).? On-Time Delivery (25%) – % milestones met for projects/initiatives.? Recurrence/Reopen (25%) – % tickets re-opened or repeated issue within 30 days (lower is better).? Follow-Through (20%) – % client-facing meetings with recap ≤48h and action acceptance. G/Y/R thresholds (starting points): D ≥70/55–69/<55 · C ≥75/60–74/<60 · B ≥80/70–79/<70 · A ≥85/75–84/<75.Practical examples? B account: SLA 88, On-Time 72, Recurrence 80, Follow-Through 90 ? 0.3·88 + 0.25·72 + 0.25·80 + 0.2·90 = 82.1 (Green).Common pitfalls? Changing weights mid-year.? Adding >6 inputs (noise).? No agreed source of truth (PSA/initiative tracker).Concept #3: Segment-aware standards (D?A)Typical MSP cases solved? Holding D/C accounts to A-level project rigour.? Over-engineering reports for small clients.How to apply? D: Prioritize stable response/resolution and clear comms.? C: add lifecycle hygiene and visible remediation of recurrent issues.? B: emphasize on-time initiative delivery; publish milestone plans.? A: executive-ready change control, risk logs, and RCA discipline.Practical examples? C: monthly “Top 5 recurring issues” with fixes and owners.? A: “Change window + rollback plan” required for high-impact work.Common pitfalls? One flat bar for all segments.? Fancy dashboards without basic reliability.Concept #4: Triggers create tasks (Health ? Playbooks), not meetingsTypical MSP cases solved? Quality turns Red, and nothing happens except a longer agenda.? Escalations repeat because no one owns the root cause.How to apply Stand up four automation-first triggers (plus two optional). Each opens a CTA with owner + due-by + checklist:1. SLA trend Red 2 weeks ? Owner: TAM · Due: 5 days ? Play: root-cause + client comms + prevention plan.2. Milestone slip >14 days ? Owner: vCIO/Lead · Due: 72h ? Play: resequence + new ETA + risk note to client.3. Reopen rate >8% (30d) ? Owner: TAM · Due: 10 days ? Play: eliminate top 2 repeaters; verify in QBR notes.4. Follow-through <80% (last 60d) ? Owner: CSM · Due: 72h ? Play: recap discipline reset + template coaching. Optional: High-priority incident (P1) ? exec update template; Change fail ? post-mortem within five biz days.Practical examples? Dashboard widget: “Time-to-first-action on Quality Reds” (target ≤72h).? Snippet library for P1 comms (initial/update/close).Common pitfalls? Assigning to a team, not a person.? No due-by window; CTAs age out.? Trigger bloat (>6 rules).Concept #5:  Quality is a dependency for strategy (gate big approvals)Typical MSP cases solved? Pushing modernization while tickets burn.? Selling new work that later stalls due to shaky delivery.How to apply? If Service Quality = Red for 2+ months, pause new initiatives >$X unless a risk plan is agreed in QBR (owner/date/budget).? Start every QBR with the Quality snapshot; approve the roadmap only after risks have owners.Practical examples? QBR section: “Quality gates ? Approved/Deferred” with rationale.? Small “quick wins” were allowed during Red to rebuild trust.Common pitfalls? Waiving the gate with one-off exceptions.? Hiding slips until quarter-end.Concept #6: Tie ownership to roles you already haveTypical MSP cases solved? Quality “belongs to support,” CS just reports it.? vCIO gets dragged into ticket triage.How to apply? TAM: SLA trend, recurrence removal, lifecycle hygiene.? CSM/AM: follow-through discipline, client comms, expectation setting.? vCIO (A/B): milestone risk management, change control, escalation path.? Keep a one-page Quality RACI by segment inside playbooks and review quarterly.Practical examples? TAM monthly: “Top 5 fixes delivered” slide.? vCIO: “Next 30-day risk & mitigation” panel in A/B QBRs.Common pitfalls? Blurry ownership (“everyone helps”).? Pushing all updates via email, no CS tool/PSA/record.Concept #7: Make RCA a habit (small, fast, useful)Typical MSP cases solved? The same outages happen again.? Post-mortems are too heavy for a small team, so none happen.How to apply? 5-Why mini-RCA template, ≤15 minutes, within five biz days; log fix + prevention in CS tool/PSA and summarize in QBR notes.? Track “RCA on time %” as a Quality sub-metric.Practical examples? Two-column note: “What happened / What we changed.”? Share the top 3 RCAs across clients if applicable.Common pitfalls? Novel-length RCAs no one reads.? Fix shipped, but no validation (issue returns).
Implementation ProcessStep 1 — Pick your four core signals and set segment thresholdsGoal: Define “quality” in plain terms that you can score monthly.Owner: CS Lead with Service Manager (or TAM Lead).Do this? Choose four core signals (keep it tight):? SLA adherence (response + resolution)? Milestone on-time % (projects/initiatives)? Repeat-ticket rate (same category within 30 days)? Meeting recap ≤48h rate (strategic meetings/QBRs) Optional #5: First action on quality CTAs ≤72h (execution discipline)? Set G/Y/R by segment (start points you can tune):? D: SLA ≥90% (G) · Milestones n/a or ≥75% · Repeat ≤15% · Recap ≥90%? C: SLA ≥92% · Milestones ≥80% · Repeat ≤10% · Recap ≥92%? B: SLA ≥95% · Milestones ≥85% · Repeat ≤8% · Recap ≥95%? A: SLA ≥97% · Milestones ≥90% · Repeat ≤5% · Recap ≥95%Definition of done: One page with signals, segment thresholds, and colour rules.Step 2 — Wire data to a single monthly score (one source of truth)Goal: Make scoring a 30-minute job, not archaeology.Owner: CS Ops (or CS Lead + Finance if Ops is light).Do this? Map sources: PSA (SLA, milestones, repeats), Docs/PSA (recap timestamps), CS tool (CTAs).? Pick a snapshot day (e.g., last business day). Export ? paste into a Quality Sheet:? Account tab: raw metrics + auto G/Y/R per signal? Summary tab: %Green/Yellow/Red by segment + trendsDefinition of done: Anyone can produce the monthly colour in <30 minutes.Step 3 — Automate 4 quality triggers ? playbooks (alerts create tasks)Goal: Turn dips into action, not debate.Owner: CS Ops (rules) + Role owners (execution).Do this? Stand up these automation-first triggers (each creates a CTA with owner + due date):1. SLA Red (this month) ? TAM “Root Cause + Client Comms” · Due: 5 days2. Milestone late >14 days ? PM/TAM “Resequence + Risk Note” · Due: 3 days3. Repeat-ticket spike (>threshold) ? TAM “Problem Mgmt mini-RCA” · Due: 7 days4. Recap ≤48h violation (<target) ? CSM “Recap Discipline Reset” · Due: 72h? Add a guardrail: 2 consecutive Quality Reds on an account ? vCIO reviews roadmap; limit new asks until back to Yellow.Definition of done: New CTAs appear automatically; first-action SLA ≤72h is visible on the dashboard.Step 4 — Run the rhythm (weekly huddle, monthly roll-up, quarterly review)Goal: Keep momentum without meeting bloat.Owner: CS Lead.Do this? Weekly Quality Huddle (20 min): top deltas, CTAs aging, unblock owners.? Monthly Portfolio (60 min): score G/Y/R per account, aim for ≥80% Green; note systemic themes.? Quarterly: fold Quality trends into QBR prep and Compensation calibration (TAM/CSM quality components).Definition of done: Meetings on calendar; aging CTAs decrease month over month.Step 5 — Close the loop: mini-RCA + client-visible fixGoal: Convert fixes into trust.Owner: CTA owner (TAM/PM/CSM) + vCIO for A/B accounts.Do this? Use a 1-page mini-RCA: What happened / Why / Fix / Prevent / Owner & date.? Send a client note (plain English) and log it to QBR notes.? Verify on next cadence; mark “Verified” when the metric rebounds.Definition of done: RCA is attached to CTA; verified within one cadence cycle.Step 6 — Evidence quality in QBRs (and gate big asks)Goal: Keep QBRs credible and outcome-led.Owner: CSM (prep) + vCIO (A/B).Do this? Add a 1-screen Quality Snapshot to every QBR: last 90 days SLA, milestones, repeats, recap rate, and CTAs closed.? Tie 1–2 roadmap asks “Why now” and the quality trajectory.? If Quality = Red this quarter, lead with the fix plan; keep max two decisions.Definition of done: Expansion/roadmap credit only when decisions have owner + date + budget (credit gate) and quality risk is addressed.Step 7 — Calibrate and coach (lightweight, predictable)Goal: Improve the system without adding bureaucracy.Owner: CS Lead + Service Manager.Do this? Monthly: coach from themes (e.g., recap discipline, handoff gaps).? Quarterly: adjust thresholds once if needed; update playbooks; share 10-minute Loom on what changed.? Feed systemic issues to Process/Governance (SOP tweaks) and align weights with Compensation.Definition of done: Updated thresholds/playbooks published; next quarter calendar set.Final Output: Service Quality Starter Kit? Signals & Thresholds one-pager (by segment)? Quality Sheet (Account + Summary tabs) with auto G/Y/R? 4 Triggered Playbooks (owners, due-bys, checklists)? Mini-RCA template + client note snippet? Meeting rhythm (agenda for Weekly/Monthly/Quarterly) This keeps quality measurement small, visible, and actionable—so strategy rides on a stable base and clients feel the improvement quickly.
AppendixHow does it connect to the Client Business Goal levels?LevelRole of Service Quality1.1 Technology SupportThe primary success metric is proof that “things are working” and SLAs are met.1.2 Technology EnablementStill heavily operational, but quality signals readiness for deeper projects.1.3 Technology ModernizationQuality ensures the stable execution of modernization initiatives.1.4 Business TransformationEnables trust in productivity and transformation outcomes.1.5 Business InnovationQuality is assumed; any disruption undermines the credibility of strategic partnerships.How does it connect to the other parts?? 1. Client Business Goal - Quality delivery underpins every goal level. At lower levels, it enables stability; at higher levels, it becomes invisible but critical infrastructure for strategic progress.? 3. Customer Success Delivery - Delivery consistency is tied directly to ticket metrics, SLA dashboards, incident logs, and QBR outputs. Quality influences whether the MSP is perceived as reliable.? 4. Customer Success Process - Closely linked to SOPs, execution frameworks, and verification procedures. Triggers escalation or feedback loops when KPIs or SLAs are not met.? 6. Customer Success People - Relies on the performance of helpdesk, field techs, TAMs, and service managers. Quality gaps can reflect issues in enablement, process adoption, or bandwidth.? 7. Customer Success Strategy - Segmented service models depend on quality consistency to scale. Strategy also evaluates whether quality variation correlates with segment, industry, or CS model.Product Links / Tooling SupportThe LMx Client Health score can incorporate quality signals, such as SLA response and resolution compliance, incident closure times, service-level audit results, and deliverable consistency. These data points reflect the MSP’s ability to execute repeatably and reliably.
?? 2.5 Service Level Alignment
2.5 Service Level AlignmentOverviewWhat is the objective?Why is it important?As an MSP, why do I need to do this?What is the Customer impact?Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: Alignment = “Are we delivering the right things for this client right now?”Concept #2: Decide Alignment in conversations, not in PSA reportsConcept #3: Keep Alignment scoring to a 3?3 rubric (fast ? one color)Concept #4: Segment-aware expectations (D?A) prevent over/under-servicingConcept #5: Alignment drives proposal rhythm and cadence (gate approvals)Concept #6: Triggers create tasks (Alignment ? Playbooks), not more meetingsConcept #7: Clear ownership + RACI tie-in (and comp)Implementation ProcessOperationalizing Alignment as a Strategic Fit IndicatorStep 1: Define Segment-Based Service ExpectationsStep 2: Validate Alignment Through Structured ConversationsStep 3: Score Alignment Using a Repeatable FrameworkStep 4: Use Alignment Scores to Trigger CS ActionsStep 5: Monitor and Adjust Through Governance ReviewsFinal Output: A Targeted, Scalable Engagement ModelAppendixHow does it connect to the Client Business Goal levels?How does it connect to the other parts?Product Links / Tooling Support
OverviewWhat is the objective?To ensure each client gets the right type and intensity of service for their maturity and appetite—right now. Alignment measures the fit between what’s expected (by segment and goal level) and what’s delivered (cadence, deliverables, roles). Keep it simple: 3–4 checks per account each month ? G/Y/R, and use QBRs to confirm and adjust.Why is it important?? Protects margin & focus: Stops over-servicing D/C accounts and under-servicing A/B accounts.? Prevents churn & stalls: Misalignment is a top cause of silent disengagement and slow approvals.? Enables scale: Clear, segment-based expectations allow a small CS team to work consistently.? Improves forecasting: GRR/NRR and initiative timing get more predictable when the service level fits the appetite.? Ties to quality & adoption: The right level unlocks smoother execution and higher DMI movement.As an MSP, why do I need to do this?? Run a segment menu, not one-offs: Publish what A/B/C/D get (QBR/JSP-Lite, roadmap, lifecycle, budget, vCIO time).? Measure fit with four checks (monthly):1. Cadence delivered vs plan,2. Core deliverables present (evidence + recap ≤48h),3. Exec sponsor seen ≤120 days (A/B),4. Effort mix roughly matches segment (ops vs advisory). Roll to G/Y/R and fix Reds with a first-action SLA ≤72h.? Gate big asks: Use the QBR credit gate (owner + date + budget) and pause expansion if alignment = Red.? Plan capacity clearly: Know when to add vCIO, keep TAM-led lifecycle, and reduce cadence..What is the Customer impact?? Less friction, more relevance: Meetings feel right-sized; proposals match goals and timing.? Faster decisions: Clear scope and cadence = fewer surprises and quicker approvals (max two decisions per QBR).? Trust in the rhythm: Clients see consistent follow-through and understand what’s included vs optional.? Visible progress: Alignment keeps adoption, service quality, and engagement moving together—so outcomes stick.
Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: Alignment = “Are we delivering the right things for this client right now?”Typical MSP cases solved? Providing premium advisory to a D/C client that only wants stability.? Running ticket-only for a B/A client expecting roadmap, budgets, and exec touch.How to apply? Define Alignment as fit between service mix + cadence and the client’s segment (D?A) and goals.? Maintain a one-page Service Map per client: what we deliver, how often, who owns it, and which business goal it supports.Practical examples? C client: quarterly lifecycle review + 1–2 small initiatives; no executive QBR.? A client: quarterly executive QBR with roadmap, budget track, and OKR check.Common pitfalls? Equating “more service” with “better.”? Letting the legacy scope linger after the client’s needs changed.Concept #2: Decide Alignment in conversations, not in PSA reportsTypical MSP cases solved? Assuming alignment based on ticket volume or CSAT.? Missing silent misalignment (e.g., “roadmap feels generic”).How to apply? Use structured checkpoints: Discovery refresh, QBR, Lifecycle Review. Ask three quick questions:1. Relevance: “Does this still help hit your near-term goals?”2. Cadence fit: “Is the rhythm right (too much/too little)?”3. Coverage: “Are we missing anything material?”? Capture answers in JSP-Lite + Decision Log and adjust the Service Map.Practical examples? Add a 2-minute “Alignment check” at the end of every strategic meeting.? Tag feedback as Alignment notes in the QBR recap (visible next time).Common pitfalls? Fishing for NPS instead of relevance.? Skipping exec input on A/B accounts.Concept #3: Keep Alignment scoring to a 3?3 rubric (fast ? one color)Typical MSP cases solved?
