Complex scoring, no one updates.? Debates about “how misaligned is misaligned?”How to apply Score Presence / Perception / Performance (0–100 each), then average ? G/Y/R by segment:? Presence (40%) – expected services for the segment exist (e.g., roadmap for B/A, lifecycle for C).? Perception (30%) – client says services are relevant/valuable (captured in notes/pulse).? Performance (30%) – services delivered on time and at the correct depth. Threshold starters: D ≥70/55–69/<55 · C ≥75/60–74/<60 · B ≥80/70–79/<70 · A ≥85/75–84/<75.Practical examples? B account: Presence 90, Perception 70, Performance 80 ? 0.4·90 + 0.3·70 + 0.3·80 = 80 (Green).Common pitfalls? Changing weights mid-year.? Measuring activity instead of fit (too many meetings are still misaligned).Concept #4: Segment-aware expectations (D?A) prevent over/under-servicingTypical MSP cases solved? D/C drowning in strategy meetings they didn’t ask for.? A/B stalling because they don’t get exec-level outputs.How to apply? D: Support/stability; clear comms; minimal strategy.? C: Lifecycle hygiene + small, well-scoped improvements.? B: Modernization roadmap + budget rhythm; projectized delivery.? A: Executive QBRs, OKR link, portfolio view and risks.Practical examples? C: swap monthly “reports” for quarterly lifecycle + adoption minis.? A: Include “Decision ? Owner ? Date ? Budget” block in every QBR.Common pitfalls? One flat engagement model.? Publishing the same deck to every segment.Concept #5: Alignment drives proposal rhythm and cadence (gate approvals)Typical MSP cases solved? Proposals are pushed while the service model feels off to the client.? “Why no approvals?” ? misalignment, not price.How to apply? Gate: If Alignment = Red for 2+ months, pause new initiatives >$X until a Roadmap Reset is recorded in the QBR notes.? Pace proposals to the segment: more, smaller approvals in C; fewer, larger exec decisions in A.Practical examples? QBR first slide: Alignment snapshot ? either “Go / Fix first.”? Allow “quick wins” during Red (low-risk fixes that rebuild trust).Common pitfalls? Waiving the gate “just this time.”? Treating misalignment as a discount issue.Concept #6: Triggers create tasks (Alignment ? Playbooks), not more meetingsTypical MSP cases solved? Noticing misalignment, but nothing changes.? Long internal threads without an owner or due date.How to apply Stand up four automation-first triggers (plus two optional). Each opens a CTA with owner + due-by + checklist:1. Perception = Red ? Owner: CSM · 5 biz days ? Play: client value check + reset summary.2. Presence gap (missing required deliverable for segment) ? Owner: TAM/CSM · 10 days ? Play: add/replace service; update Service Map.3. Performance slip (late roadmap/lifecycle twice) ? Owner: vCIO/Lead · 72h ? Play: resequence + risk note; confirm next checkpoint.4. Segment drift signal (engagement/adoption up or down) ? Owner: CSM · 7 days ? Play: propose segment review. Optional: stakeholder change ? exec intro play; repeated “generic roadmap” feedback ? enablement coaching for owner.Practical examples? Dashboard widget: “Alignment CTAs open / time-to-first-action (≤72h target).”? Snippet pack: “We heard X, we’ll adjust Y by Z date.”Common pitfalls? Assigning “to the team.”? No due dates or defined outputs.Concept #7: Clear ownership + RACI tie-in (and comp)Typical MSP cases solved? Everyone “kind of” owns alignment.? vCIO pulled into ticket triage; TAM chasing execs.How to apply? D/C: CSM/TAM Accountable for Alignment (cadence + lifecycle fit).? B/A: vCIO Accountable (roadmap/budget relevance, exec alignment).? Mirror this in the RACI-by-Segment and link to Compensation (Alignment trend/guardrails as a small Health component).Practical examples? Scorecard line: “Alignment colour this month” with owner initials.? Quarterly Governance: “Who owns fixes for misaligned accounts?”Common pitfalls? Splitting accountability across roles.? There is no owner visibility on the one-pager.
Implementation ProcessStep 1 — Publish the Segment Service Menu (what each tier gets)Goal: Make “what’s included” and who owns it crystal-clear for A/B/C/D.Owner: CS Lead (with vCIO, CSM/AM, TAM)Timebox: 60–90 min workshopDo this? One page/table with deliverables & cadence by segment (e.g., A: Exec QBR, Roadmap, Budget; B: QBR, Roadmap; C: Lifecycle Review; D: Ops Check-in).? Add role A/R/C/I per deliverable (ties to Roles/Responsibilities).? Mark the evidence anchor for each (QBR note with owner + date + budget; meeting recap ≤48h). Definition of done? A/B/C/D menu is posted; the team can answer “What does B get?” in one sentence.Step 2 — Build the Alignment Scorecard + G/Y/R rules (4 checks)Goal: Score fit monthly with lightweight, repeatable rules.Owner: CS Lead + CS Ops-lite/FinanceTimebox: 60 min to templateDo this? Use four checks (each 25 pts). Calibrate by segment:1. Cadence delivered vs plan (held on time, attendees present).2. Core deliverables present with recap ≤48h and links.3. Exec sponsor seen ≤120 days (A/B only; C/D = N/A or substitute “service owner confirmed”).4. Effort mix fits segment (A/B = advisory-heavier; C/D = ops-heavier).? Scoring: Green ≥85, Yellow 65–84, Red <65. (If you want simpler: Green = 3–4 checks true; Yellow = 2; Red = 0–1.)Definition of done? One-pager scorecard exists; anyone can score an account in <5 minutes.Step 3 — Map evidence & wire simple flags (one source of truth)Goal: Ensure every check has a place to live and can be audited.Owner: CS Ops-lite (or CS Lead)Timebox: 60 min mappingDo this? “What lives where” map: PSA (initiatives/tasks/SLA), CRM (contacts/exec sponsor), CS/Health tool (scores/CTAs/playbooks), Files (QBR/JSP-Lite).? Add two tiny hygiene items to templates: “2 decisions max” per QBR; credit gate = owner + date + budget.? Create auto-flags (reports or views):? “Exec sponsor last seen” (days)? “Recap ≤48 h% (last 30 days)”? “Cadence on-time %”Definition of done? Each check has a field/report link; a sample account shows all four.Step 4 — Run the Monthly Alignment Check + trigger playbooks.Goal: Turn Red/Yellow into action within ≤72h.Owner: CSM/AM (run), vCIO/TAM (fix)Timebox: 15–30 min/monthDo this? Review Alignment heatmap (G/Y/R by account).? For any Red: auto-create CTA with owner + due-by (first-action SLA ≤72h).? Cadence Red ? “Reset Rhythm” play (simplify agenda, re-confirm stakeholders).? Deliverables Red ? “Backfill Evidence” play (recap, link artifacts, set next step).? Exec Red ? “Sponsor Re-engage” play (intro + value recap).? Effort mix Red ? “Right-size Coverage” play (shift vCIO/TAM hours; adjust meeting type).Definition of done? New CTAs created; following portfolio review shows time-to-first-action ≤72h.Step 5 — Use Alignment to pace proposals & cadences (gate expansion)Goal: Don’t sell into misalignment; fix fit ? then ask.Owner: vCIO (A/B), CSM/AM (C/D)Timebox: In normal QBR prepDo this? Start QBR with a 1-slide Alignment snapshot (G/Y/R, what changed, next fix).? Keep a maximum of two decisions per QBR; only count expansion with the credit gate artifact.? Guardrail: If the alignment is red for two consecutive months, pause the expansion credit and resequence to alignment fixes; resume when yellow/green is used.Definition of done? QBR decks show the Alignment slide; proposal rhythm reflects alignment status.Step 6 — Quarterly tune & capacity planning (governance)Goal: Keep the model tight as segments and workload shift.Owner: CS Lead + LeadershipTimebox: 45–60 min/quarterDo this? Recheck segment placement (A?B?C?D) based on CX/DMI/Engagement.? Adjust effort mix targets (advisory vs ops) and meeting cadence where needed.? Review disputes/exceptions; update thresholds or plays once/quarter (not mid-quarter).? Ensure Accountable owners in RACI match Compensation levers. Definition of done? Updated menu/thresholds published; following quarter capacity forecasted.Minimal artifacts to publish (fits on one page each)? Segment Service Menu (A/B/C/D deliverables & cadence, owner A/R/C/I).? Alignment Scorecard (4 checks, G/Y/R rules).? What Lives Where map + QBR credit-gate checklist.? Playbook cards for the 4 Red types (owner, steps, snippets).That’s it—four checks, one score, clear plays. It stays calculable in a spreadsheet, auditable in your PSA/CRM/CS tool, and perfectly in sync with Roles, Responsibilities, Enablement, and Governance.
AppendixHow does it connect to the Client Business Goal levels?LevelRole of Service Level Alignment1.1 Technology SupportService is highly standardized, with a focus on execution rather than customization.1.2 Technology EnablementService begins aligning with maturity, e.g., onboarding and platform rollout.1.3 Technology ModernizationAlignment ensures that delivery aligns with strategic tech roadmaps and cadence.1.4 Business TransformationServices expand to reflect business-specific goals and cross-departmental needs.1.5 Business InnovationServices are tailored to meet OKRs, departmental objectives, and innovation initiatives.How does it connect to the other parts?? 1. Client Business Goal - Service level alignment is determined by the client’s maturity and appetite, which define their current business goals. This ensures services match both their operational capacity and strategic intent.? 3. Customer Success Delivery - The type, frequency, and depth of CS deliverables are shaped by service level alignment. As client needs evolve, delivery adapts to ensure value is created proportionately to its potential impact.? 4. Customer Success Process - The expected service level influences planning, cadence, and engagement workflows. Over-delivery creates unnecessary load; under-delivery risks missed goals or client frustration.? 6. Customer Success People - Clear service levels help teams know how deeply to engage with each client. This improves role clarity, prioritization, and team performance while minimizing misallocation of time and effort.? 7. Customer Success Strategy - Strategic plans, segmentation, and playbook design rely on accurate service level alignment. Without it, CS becomes either too reactive or inefficient to scale.Product Links / Tooling SupportThe LMx Client Health score can reflect service level alignment by analyzing: CS activity tracking vs. segment expectations, missed or over-delivered engagements, cadence adherence, and service vs. roadmap coverage. This ensures service delivery remains scalable and maturity-aligned.
?? 3. CS Delivery
3. CS DeliverablesTurning Strategy into Tangible ValueCS Deliverables include five key blueprints:3.1. Reports3.2. Proposals3.3. Budgets3.4. Client Strategy3.5. RoadmapIn Summary
Turning Strategy into Tangible ValueCustomer Success isn’t just about meetings and conversations—it’s about delivering tangible outputs that drive momentum, validate alignment, and connect IT strategy to business priorities.CS Deliverables are where strategy becomes visible. They turn insights into structured assets that clients can review, approve, act on, and share with stakeholders. These outputs help MSPs show—not just say—where value is being created.“Deliverables are where intentions become outcomes—and where clients start to feel the value of your work.”As clients move up the maturity and appetite curve, deliverables evolve—from tactical snapshots to integrated business assets. The format may stay consistent (e.g., report, roadmap, budget), but the depth, framing, and strategic language shift to match each client’s segmentation tier and business goal level.CS Deliverables include five key blueprints:3.1. ReportsWhat it is: Structured assets—automated or manually curated—that present key information on the client’s environment, risks, priorities, and progress.How it evolves: From operational snapshots (e.g., hardware lifecycle, ticket metrics) to executive-ready summaries that link MSP activities to business objectives, trends, and initiative outcomes.Why it matters:? Creates transparency and shared understanding? Anchors strategic meetings with facts, not assumptions? Enables async alignment across roles and departments? Increases trust through repeatable structureBusiness Goal connection:At early stages, reports prove delivery. They become part of business storytelling at higher levels, helping clients evaluate ROI, timing, and alignment. Reports evolve into a platform for decision-making, not just documentation.3.2. ProposalsWhat it is:Scoped recommendations and financial estimates for client initiatives—formatted for approval, follow-up, and internal coordination.How it evolves:From simple itemized quotes to strategic proposals grounded in Discovery, Assessment, and Roadmap context. Includes business rationale and projected impact.Why it matters:? Ties the initiative scope to strategic appetite and maturity? Builds trust through clarity and pre-qualification? Speeds up approvals and avoids scope misalignmentBusiness Goal connection:As clients move toward Transformation and Innovation, proposals must evolve into value stories, not just cost outlines. Strategic proposals are a bridge between opportunity and execution.3.3. BudgetsWhat it is: Forecasts of expected IT investment across OpEx, CapEx, and projects—aligned with roadmap milestones and initiative planning.How it evolves: From ad hoc renewal tracking to annual budget plans that reflect segment-based pacing, initiative tiers, and future-state goals.Why it matters:? Empowers clients to plan ahead? Reinforces initiative, timing, and prioritization? Positions the MSP as a financial planning partnerBusiness Goal connection: At higher maturity levels, budgets are tied to roadmap progress, initiative grouping, and business planning cycles. They shift from reporting costs to funding strategy, which is especially important in Segments A and B.3.4. Client StrategyWhat it is: A client-facing strategic narrative that integrates goals, risks, roadmaps, and budget into one cohesive decision-making framework.How it evolves: From informal themes to structured strategy plans tied to industry context, segment posture, and leadership direction.Why it matters:? Provides context for initiative prioritization? Reinforces the MSP’s role as a strategic advisor? Aligns decisions across leadership and technical teamsBusiness Goal connection: Clients in Transformation and Innovation (1.4–1.5) require integrated strategic framing. Strategy deliverables connect CS execution to departmental OKRs and C-level priorities.3.5. RoadmapWhat it is: A visual, time-based layout of planned initiatives—sequenced by priority, readiness, and impact.How it evolves: From quarter-based task lists to multi-layered transformation maps categorized by business domain, timeline, or strategic theme.Why it matters:? Ensures continuity and visibility across planning cycles? Tracks initiative dependencies and business alignment? Clarifies decision timelines and stakeholder accountabilityBusiness Goal connection: A roadmap is the strategic spine of the engagement. For Segment A/B clients, it reflects initiative layering, timing, and budget readiness. For C/D clients, it simplifies scope and cadence.Definitions: CS Deliverables1. Roadmap A simple, visual timeline that shows clients exactly what technology improvements or projects are planned, including when each step will happen. It helps clients see clearly how you'll move from today’s reality to future goals.2. Initiative (Projects) Clearly defined actions or projects, each designed to solve a specific problem or seize an opportunity uncovered during assessments or client conversations. Initiatives turn strategy into practical, achievable tasks.3. Proposal A clearly outlined recommendation you give the client, detailing exactly what will be done, how much it will cost, and what benefits they'll see. Proposals help clients quickly understand, evaluate, and approve your recommendations.4. Budget A clear, forward-looking financial plan that shows what the client is expected to invest in technology over the coming months or years. Budgets help clients plan their finances confidently, knowing exactly what to expect and when.5. Client Strategy A concise, client-facing summary that clearly explains the long-term plan for technology alignment and improvement. It helps the client understand the purpose behind each initiative, how it supports their business, and what success looks like.6. Executive Report A high-level, easy-to-understand report prepared for business leaders that summarizes technology performance, risks, progress, and opportunities. It helps executives quickly grasp how IT aligns with their broader business objectives.7. Assessment Report A structured report showing exactly where the client stands in key technology areas, highlighting risks, issues, or improvement opportunities. It makes technical issues clear and understandable, allowing informed decisions.8. Discovery Summary A clear and concise overview of key insights and priorities gathered during initial client conversations. It ensures both parties understand the business goals, concerns, and opportunities from the start.9. Cadence Planner An internal schedule that clearly defines when and how often client meetings, reviews, and planning sessions happen, based on the client's segment and goals. It ensures consistency and helps you plan effectively.10. Statement of Work (SOW) A formal document outlining exactly what tasks or deliverables you will provide, when they'll be delivered, and what outcomes the client can expect. It removes ambiguity, helping both parties stay aligned and accountable.In SummaryCS Deliverables are the execution engine of Customer Success. When tailored to client maturity and appetite, they:? Communicate value in a way clients can understand? Align internal and external stakeholders at every level? Accelerate initiative acceptance and business planning? Anchor all CS processes—Discovery, Assessment, Meetings—in visible progressEach deliverable plays a role in the broader CS ecosystem. Together, they transform Discovery insights into outcomes and ensure Customer Success is not just a conversation, but a measurable business result.
?? 3.1 Reports
3.1 ReportsOverviewWhat is the objective?Why is it important?As an MSP, why do I need to do this?What is the Customer impact?Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: Present, don’t just send — you are the reportConcept #2: Segment-Driven Report StrategyConcept #3: Decision-first reporting = Executive Snapshot + two asksConcept #4: Three report types, one story spineConcept #5: Reports are CS Health checkpoints (with follow-through SLAs)Concept #6: Why clients ignore reports (and how to fix it)Implementation ProcessStep 1: Determine Reporting Format and Frequency by Segment and Goal LevelStep 2: Structure the report to reflect strategic intentStep 3: Link each report to CS Process & CS Health (with follow-through SLAs)Step 4: Assign Reporting Ownership by RoleStep 5: Operationalize with Templates and GovernanceOutcome: Reports That Drive Action and Prove ValueAppendixHow does it connect to the Client Business Goal levels?How does it connect to the other parts?Product Links / Tooling SupportHow we recommend doing it (product-based)
OverviewWhat is the objective?To create and deliver clear, structured, and visually engaging reports that reflect the client's current IT state, business alignment, risk exposure, service delivery, and roadmap progress, supporting informed decisions and reinforcing MSP credibility.Why is it important?Reports are not just documentation—they are activation tools in the Customer Success delivery chain. They provide a shared language between technical teams and business stakeholders, translating service activity and CS Process insights (from Discovery and Assessment) into clear business value.Done right, reports serve as the connective tissue between the CS Process and CS Delivery—bridging insights and context with decision-ready outputs, such as Initiatives, Budgets, and Roadmaps. They create continuity between meetings, reinforce trust, and enable executive-level planning with consistent, data-rich summaries. Without reports, strategic alignment breaks down and initiative momentum stalls. A decision-first report (two asks max) accelerates approvals, and standard guardrails—recap ≤ 48h and first-action SLA ≤ 72h—ensure follow-through instead of “report parking.”As an MSP, why do I need to do this?Because without transparent, segment-aligned reporting, your clients won’t connect your efforts to their outcomes. Reports transform invisible effort into visible progress. They give structure to your CS cadence and help move the conversation from service delivery to strategic value.With a solid reporting rhythm, even junior team members can confidently frame initiatives, budgets, and roadmaps. Reports support proposal approvals, showcase risk mitigation, and highlight technology improvements—all through a repeatable format that aligns with your engagement strategy.Done right, reports are not just summaries—they are decision enablers that link CS Process (Discovery, Assessment) to CS Delivery (Initiatives, Budgets, Roadmaps). They turn your insights into action.Define “delivered” by segment (live presentation for A/B; async + short video for C/D) and track simple KPIs: Snapshot present ≥ 95%, live-delivery rate (A/B) ≥ 80%, ≥1 logged decision in ≥ 70% of strategic reports.What is the Customer impact?? Clients understand how IT investments support their business goals.? Builds trust through transparency, insight, and strategic context.? Promotes co-ownership of priorities through clear documentation.? Enhances the MSP's perceived value in planning, budgeting, and risk management.? Decisions move faster thanks to the Executive Snapshot and two clear asks, while visible follow-through (recap ≤ 48h, first-action ≤ 72h) increases confidence. High-touch clients get an engaging live walkthrough; lower-touch clients still receive a concise summary video to make the report actionable.
Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: Present, don’t just send — you are the reportReports are not just deliverables—they are strategic conversations. Just like a proposal should be presented, not emailed, a report should be delivered, not just sent.When you present the report, you become the storyteller. You guide the client through the data, explain the significance, and tie it directly to their business outcomes. Whether it’s operational metrics in a service report, strategic KPIs in an executive report, or recommendations in a consulting report, you are the interpreter, the context, and the voice of value.Presenting live, either in person or virtually, builds clarity, trust, and engagement. It allows you to answer questions, frame decisions, and reinforce your MSP’s role as a strategic advisor, not just a service provider.It also ensures that CS Health signals—especially Engagement and Alignment—are captured and reviewed during the conversation, rather than being lost in asynchronous delivery.Why it matters: Live delivery builds clarity, captures questions, and reinforces your advisory role.How to apply (plain rules):? A/B segments: deliver live; target live-delivery ≥ 80%.? C/D segments: deliver async + 2–3 min summary video.? Always open with the Executive Snapshot (Business Outcomes, mini Health, Risks/Trends, max two decisions).? Assign a presenter by role: vCIO (A/B), CSM/TAM (B/C), AM supports budgets/renewals.Practical example: Quarterly Executive Report for a Segment B client: vCIO presents live for 20 minutes; two decisions pre-framed; CSM records decisions and owners.Common pitfalls: Emailing PDFs with no session; reading slides word-for-word; no decision ask.Concept #2: Segment-Driven Report StrategyReporting must be built for and aligned to the client’s Segment—not just the cadence or delivery model. Each report—its depth, content, and presentation style—should reflect the client’s strategic relevance, maturity, and appetite as defined by the segmentation model (Segment A–D / Business Goal Levels 1.1–1.5).Segment A (Level 4–5 – Business Transformation and Innovation) receive comprehensive, strategy-heavy reports:? Roadmap, Budget, Goals, and CS Health metrics, all structured to support OKR alignment and executive planning.? Delivery is live, interactive, and conducted via Presentation Mode with a monthly or every other month rhythm.? Reports are directly tied to initiative status, adoption trends, and cross-departmental alignment, supporting real co-planning.Segment B (Level 3 – Technology Modernization) receive structured, quarterly reports that balance strategic and tactical content:? Core elements include Roadmap Milestones, Risk Trends, and Technology Alignment Summaries.? Reports are either delivered live or as hybrid (shared with a summary walkthrough).? Engagement, Adoption, and Service Quality Health scores should be included to flag readiness or bottlenecks.Segment C (Level 2 – Technology Enablement) receive simplified, tactical reports:? Focused on project execution, adoption progress, and service quality outcomes.? Delivered quarterly or semi-annually, typically in async formats (e.g., PDF + summary email).? Health insights are included in basic form—particularly Engagement and Service Level Alignment.Segment D (Level 1 – Technology Support) receive lightweight, auto-generated reporting:? Content covers ticket trends, asset risk, compliance snapshots, or SLA metrics.? Delivered via email or client portal, these are built for operational stability, not strategy.? Reports act as trust signals and provide transparency, not decision-making tools.Key principle: Standardize report design by segment—don’t build custom reports from scratch for each client.Segment-based templates (e.g., “Segment A Strategic QBR,” “Segment C Tactical Summary”) allow CS teams to:? Focus on what matters most to each segment? Scale report production without sacrificing relevance? Connect reporting cadence directly to the Engagement Strategy and resource allocation planStructured CS Health data ensures that each report serves its strategic purpose: A ? alignment & innovation readiness • B ? modernization momentum • C ? enablement progress • D ? operational reliability.This segment-driven model makes reporting a lever for strategic growth, not just a documentation exercise. It supports clarity, consistency, and co-planning—while reducing effort duplication and enabling role-specific ownership across the CS team. Concept #3: Decision-first reporting = Executive Snapshot + two asksWhy it matters: Clients act when the next two moves are obvious, justified, and time-bound.How to apply:? Start every strategic report with an Executive Snapshot:1. Business Outcomes & risks,2. Mini Health (CX/Engagement/Adoption/Quality/Alignment),3. Key trendlines,4. Two decisions only — each with Why this / Why now / Expected impact / Owner & target date.? Gate “expansion credit” on owner + date + budget being confirmed.? Track report hygiene KPIs: Snapshot present ≥ 95%; ≥1 logged decision in ≥ 70% of strategic reports.Practical example: “Approve MFA rollout Phase 2 (Why now: insurance requirement; Impact: risk ?; Owner: CFO; Date: Jun 15).”Common pitfalls: Ten recommendations with no priorities; burying the ask; no “Why now.”Concept #4: Three report types, one story spineReports are not one-size-fits-all—they serve different purposes depending on the audience and objective. The three core types:? Service Reports – Regular, detail-oriented for IT managers and technical staff (tickets, backup, patching, SLA). Focus: operational transparency and accountability.? Executive Reports – High-level, strategic summaries for business leaders (outcomes, risk trends, ROI, initiative progress, roadmap). Format: visual, concise, outcome-oriented.? Consultant Reports – One-off deep dives or project scoping (maturity assessment, opportunity analysis, strategic recommendations, phased plan).Label reports clearly and align the content to the client’s role and business goals at the appropriate level. This ensures every stakeholder receives the insights they need, in the format they expect. All report types should contribute to—or be informed by—CS Health scoring (Service ? Quality, Executive ? Engagement/Alignment, Consultant ? Adoption/strategy).Why it matters: Different audiences, same narrative: Context ? Highlights ? Action Drivers ? What’s Next.How to apply:? Service: SLA/tickets/backup/patching; audience = IT lead; cadence = monthly/quarterly.? Executive: outcomes/risks/roadmap/budget; audience = execs; cadence = quarterly; present live for A/B.? Consultant: deep-dive/scoping; include phased plan + health impacts.? Reuse the same spine to reduce prep and increase comprehension.Practical example: Assessment (Consultant) ? Executive Report distills two decisions ? Service Report tracks follow-through.Common pitfalls: Data dumps without a spine; executive decks full of minutiae; inconsistent section order. Concept #5: Reports are CS Health checkpoints (with follow-through SLAs)Every report is a moment to measure and move Health.Why it matters: Health signals guide pace and sequencing—ignore them and momentum dies.How to apply:? Always show the mini Health dashboard and note change vs. last meeting.? Send recap ≤ 48h using a standard template (decisions, owners, dates, risks).? Open CTAs with first-action SLA ≤ 72h (owner assigned, next step logged).? Portfolio KPIs: Recap ≤ 48h ≥ 95%, First-action ≤ 72h ≥ 95%.Practical example: Executive Report shows Engagement dip ? schedule Re-engage session; CTA opened same day; owner = CSM.Common pitfalls: Reporting Health but not acting; week-late recaps; CTAs without owners.Concept #6: Why clients ignore reports (and how to fix it)Why they ignore:? No context. If the report doesn’t tie to the last conversation—or the next decision—it feels irrelevant.? Too much detail, too little meaning. Technical charts without strategic framing exhaust attention.? Wrong audience. Not tailored to role, priorities, or language ? “just another PDF.”? No follow-through. If it doesn’t lead to a discussion, decision, or plan, clients tune out.? No narrative. Without a beginning (what changed), middle (what matters), end (what’s next), it’s noise.Fixes (practical):? Start with the Executive Snapshot; stick to two decisions.? Use role-based views (executive vs. operational).? Keep slides to signal, not to impress; push depth to appendix/report locker.? Enforce recap ≤ 48h and first-action ≤ 72h; review in the next meeting.Practical example: Replace a 30-slide dump with a 1-page snapshot + 6 supporting slides; appendix holds the technical evidence.Common pitfalls: Over-surveying for input, then changing nothing; sending decks without a meeting; “FYI only” reports.
Implementation ProcessTurning insights into segment-calibrated reports that drive decisionsThe Reports Implementation Process helps MSPs turn Customer Success insights into decision-ready, segment-aligned reports that clients will actually use. It embeds live vs. async delivery rules, an Executive Snapshot with two asks, and follow-through SLAs (≤48h / ≤72h) so reports move CS Health and roadmap momentum—not just document activity.Step 1: Determine Reporting Format and Frequency by Segment and Goal LevelUse Segmentation and Engagement Strategy to define how often you report and how you deliver it. Pair cadence with delivery mode and presenter so every report lands with context.Goal LevelReport CadenceDelivery ModePrimary FocusTypical Owner / PresenterSegment D_  Goal 1 – Technology SupportAd hoc or auto-generatedEmail / Client Portal (auto reports)Tickets, SLA, asset/lifecycle risk snapshotsCSM/TAM = async owner; AM back-up for renewalsSegment C_ Goal 2 – Technology EnablementQuarterly or semi-annualAsync PDF + 2–3-minute summary videoProject execution, adoption progress, service quality outcomesCSM/TAM = presenter/owner; AM supports budgetsSegment B_ Goal 3 – Technology ModernizationQuarterlyLive or hybrid (shared deck + walkthrough)Roadmap milestones, risk trends, alignment summary, Health highlightsvCIO = presenter; CSM/TAM = recorder; AM = budget/renewal supportSegment A: Goals 4–5 – Business Transformation & InnovationMonthly or bi-monthlyLive delivery (target ≥ 80%) via Presentation ModeOutcomes/OKRs, risks, roadmap, budget, CS HealthvCIO = presenter; AM = budget framing; CSM/TAM = recorderDefinition of Done / KPI: Each active account has a set cadence and a named presenter; Segments A (Goals 4–5) and B (Goal 3) live-delivery rate ≥ 80%.This segmentation-driven cadence ensures reports are not just sent, but experienced as part of a structured Customer Success journey—aligned to both strategic relevance and economic scale. High-value segments receive live, consultative reporting experiences; lower-touch clients receive automated, scalable updates, still mapped to CS Health and roadmap checkpoints.Step 2: Structure the report to reflect strategic intentOpen every report with a decision-first Executive Snapshot, then follow the same story spine.Executive Snapshot (page 1, always):? Business Outcomes & risks (what changed since last touchpoint)? Mini Health (CX, Engagement, Adoption, Service Quality, Alignment) with ? vs. last meeting? Key trendlines (tops & tails only)? Two decisions max, each with: Why this / Why now / Expected impact / Owner & target dateStory spine: Context ? Highlights ? Action Drivers ? What’s Next (push technical depth to appendix/locker). Expansion credit gate: Count expansion only when the owner + date + budget are confirmed. KPI: Snapshot present ≥ 95% across strategic reports.Step 3: Link each report to CS Process & CS Health (with follow-through SLAs)Reports are CS Health checkpoints and Process connectors.Tie-ins:? Process inputs: Discovery & Assessment power the narrative; Initiatives/Budgets/Roadmap supply the actions and timing.? Health hooks: If Engagement dips or Adoption is below the threshold, auto-schedule a Re-engage/Remediation session and surface it in the next Meeting agenda.Follow-through SLAs:? Recap ≤ 48h (decisions, owners, dates, risks)? CTA first-action ≤ 72h per decision (owner assigned, next step logged)Portfolio KPIs: Recap ≤ 48h ≥ 95% • First-action ≤ 72h ≥ 95% • ≥1 logged decision in ≥ 70% of strategic reportsStep 4: Assign Reporting Ownership by RoleMap roles to your segment labels so delivery is consistent and scalable.Role map (presenter/recorder/back-up):? Segments A (Goals 4–5) / B (Goal 3): vCIO = Presenter; AM = Budget support; CSM/TAM = Recorder? Segments B (Goal 3) / C (Goal 2): CSM or TAM = Presenter; AM = Budget support as needed; Recorder = CSM/TAM? Segment D (Goal 1): CSM/TAM = Async owner (auto report + optional 2–3 min video); AM back-up for renewalsDefinition of Done: Every account shows a named presenter, recorder, and back-up aligned to the segment.Step 5: Operationalize with Templates and GovernanceStandardize once, then scale.Templates:? Use segment-based templates (e.g., “Segment A – Strategic QBR,” “Segment C – Tactical Summary”)? Lock the Executive Snapshot as mandatory? Pre-wire Mini Health and Two decisions blocks? Add appendix modules (Assessments, Initiative detail, Lifecycle, SLA, etc.)Governance & hygiene:? Monthly review of report KPIs: Snapshot ≥ 95%, Recap ≤ 48h ≥ 95%, First-action ≤ 72h ≥ 95%, ≥1 logged decision ≥ 70%? Corrective Play (2 consecutive misses): Template refresh + coach presenter; gate expansion credit until back to Green.Tooling tips: Use presentation mode for A/B; store evidence in a report locker; auto-pull service metrics for C/D; link to detailed views instead of bloating the deck.Outcome: Reports That Drive Action and Prove ValueYour reporting rhythm now:? Connects CS Process insights to CS Delivery outcomes? Moves CS Health with time-boxed follow-through? Clarifies ownership by segment label and role? Matches economics (live where it matters, async where it scales)Success signal: Decisions made and kept; strong Snapshot hygiene; on-time recaps; ≤72h first actions; steady approval velocity tied to the roadmap across Segments D/C/B/A as defined above.
AppendixHow does it connect to the Client Business Goal levels?Reports evolve as the client's maturity and appetite increase. At lower levels, they focus on operational transparency; at higher levels, they drive business strategy and innovation. The scope and content of the report are shaped by the client's goals, investment readiness, and need for structured accountability.LevelRole of Reports1.1 Technology SupportReports focus on infrastructure visibility and tactical operations, including backups, ticket volumes, and asset health, targeting a low-impact, low-engagement audience.1.2 Technology EnablementBegin showing tool adoption, project impact, and alignment gaps. High-impact topics but low engagement—clients need guidance.1.3 Technology ModernizationShowcase stack trends, risks, and roadmap relevance. Higher-impact, strategic audience—ready to act but needs reinforcement.1.4 Business TransformationCapture ROI, cross-functional metrics, and initiative status. Reports support strategic prioritization and momentum.1.5 Business InnovationReports reflect long-term OKRs, innovation themes, and AI readiness. High maturity and high engagement—executive-level strategy.How does it connect to the other parts?? 1. Client Business Goal – Reports reflect client maturity, appetite, and strategic direction, making progress visible.? 2. Customer Success Health – Reports surface Health metrics through visual summaries of:? CX sentiment (e.g., CSAT, NPS)? Technology Adoption Trends? Engagement (meeting cadence, follow-ups)? Service Quality (SLA, tickets)? Service Level Alignment (goal and playbook alignment)? 3. Customer Success Delivery – Reports bring together Assessments, Budgets, Roadmaps, and Initiatives—showing the outcome of all CS activities.? 4. Customer Success Process – Delivered on cadence, driven by Discovery, and supporting Initiative alignment.? 6. Customer Success People – Empowers vCIOs, CSMs, and AMs to lead strategic conversations with confidence and data-driven insights.? 7. Customer Success Strategy – Report content, depth, and frequency vary by client tier and segment. Standardized templates make it scalable.Product Links / Tooling SupportThe LMx Executive Report Builder enables MSPs to:? Select from pre-built templates or create custom ones? ?? 3.2 Proposal
3.2 Proposal (Ongoing / Project) OverviewWhat is the objective?Why is it important?As an MSP, why do I need to do this?What is the Customer impact?Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: A Proposal Is a Gated Process—Not the First StepConcept #2: Match Proposal Complexity to Segment and Spend TypeConcept #3: Tie Proposals to Budget, Roadmap, and Business GoalsConcept #4: Define Scope, Assumptions, and Client Responsibilities ClearlyConcept #5: Proposal hygiene = Executive Decision Sheet + Owner/Date/Budget gateConcept #6: Proposal velocity & declines are Health signalsImplementation Process1. Trigger from strategic insight2. Align proposal depth to the client’s segment and goal level3. Embed in the Delivery and Budget cycles4. Present in contextAppendixHow does it connect to the Client Business Goal levels?How does it connect to the other parts?Product Links / Tooling Support
OverviewWhat is the objective?To activate the CS strategy by translating Discovery and Assessment insights into clearly scoped, segment-aligned proposals—bridging CS Process with CS Delivery. Proposals define mutual expectations (scope, impact, timeline, budget) and serve as the formal transition from plan to action in the Customer Success lifecycle.Why is it important?Because without well-timed, well-framed proposals, CS insights stall and initiatives remain ideas. Proposals:? Connect CS Process (Discovery, Assessment, Roadmap) to CS Delivery (Initiatives, Budgets, Execution)? Clarify what needs to happen, when, and why, based on strategic insight? Build confidence and trust by showing clients that recommendations are prioritized, structured, and financially sound? Provide a single source of truth for service teams, finance, and clients.As an MSP, why do I need to do this?Strategic alignment without execution is merely theory. A clear, segment-matched proposal:? Aligns CS workstreams to business context, client appetite, and timing? Secures buy-in through early financial signalling and phased rollout options? Prevents ghosted ideas by turning roadmap items into scoped, fundable actions? Feeds the pipeline for services, staffing, and resource planning—improving predictability? Connects back to discovery: This is where you prove you're listening and turning insight into progressWhat is the Customer impact?Clients:? Gain clarity on investment, scope, and timing? Feel included in decision-making, not just reactive approval? Align internal stakeholders around strategic technology priorities? Receive fewer surprises and more transparency? View the MSP as a structured partner, not an ad-hoc vendor
Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: A Proposal Is a Gated Process—Not the First StepNever build a proposal before validating interest. It’s a common pitfall: MSPs jump into detailed scoping and packaging because it feels productive—while skipping the hard but essential question: is the client ready?Instead of diving into the “how,” start with the “would you?” This is called price testing—a lightweight validation method to test both interest and feasibility, using real-world comparisons.Say:“Similar clients have solved this in the $10K–$15K range—does that sound viable for your team this quarter?”This approach respects the client’s investment expectations and gives you an early appetite signal without overcommitting internal time. It also lets you gracefully pause when the client isn’t ready—without burning hours on deliverables that go nowhere.Price testing is part of the Closed Loop Theory: each Discovery or Assessment insight must pass a readiness checkpoint before proposal development begins.Expanded with a Practical Example: A vCIO hears about a legacy firewall that’s due for replacement. Instead of scoping the whole upgrade, they say: “We’ve helped other clients transition to zero-trust firewalls for around $9K. Should we look into it further?” The client says, “Yes, if it’s under $10K and can be done before our audit.” Only then does the team build the proposal.Impact:? Reduces time lost on proposals that aren’t actionable? Increases trust by aligning early on budget range and intent? Helps CS teams prioritize where to focus planning energyConcept #2: Match Proposal Complexity to Segment and Spend TypeProposal depth should reflect both the client segment and spending behaviour.? Lower-maturity, lower-appetite clients (Segment D or 1.1–1.2 Goal Levels) tend to prefer operational expenditure (OpEx)- focused proposals, such as licenses, recurring services, or tactical upgrades. These clients benefit from straightforward scopes, clear timelines, and streamlined approvals.? Higher-maturity, high-appetite clients (Segment A or 1.4–1.5) are ready for CapEx-aligned proposals, such as strategic platforms, innovation pilots, or multi-phase projects. These need layered proposals with clear ROI language, long-term outcomes, and formal approval processes.Your proposal process should scale with the segment:? Boutique (9% MRR CS investment): polished presentations, linked to OKRs? Cost Driver (1%): one-click summaries embedded in meeting notesProposal complexity should also correlate with CS Health indicators. High Engagement and Adoption enable richer, more strategic proposals. Low Service Alignment or Execution consistency suggests a need to simplify or delay.Concept #3: Tie Proposals to Budget, Roadmap, and Business GoalsEvery proposal must serve as a bridge—not just between CS Process and CS Delivery, but also between the client’s stated business goals, your roadmap plan, and the budget forecast.To do that, proposals should:? Reference prior Discovery or Assessment inputs – These reveal the “why” behind the initiative, not just the technical symptoms.? Link to Budget forecasts – Define when the client will likely fund the work, and how it fits into OpEx or CapEx expectations.? Embed into the Roadmap – Align timing and priority so the proposal is seen in context, not isolation.? Connect to Goals – Especially for low-maturity clients, use assessment-driven goals (e.g., “Improve Cyber Posture” or “Modernize Core Stack”) to translate technical recommendations into business-aligned outcomes.This is especially important for Segment D (Sustain) clients, where strategic goals are less explicit. In these cases:? Let Assessments define the Goal narrative (e.g., “You’re at a CSAT of 6.2 and your backup score is red—your goal is to reach stability”).? Use CS Health visuals (yellow/red scoring) to make risks and outcomes tangible.? Keep proposals framed in client value (“You’re currently at risk, and this will help you move into the green.”)Expanded with a Practical Example: A Segment D client has no defined roadmap, but an Assessment shows red scores in backup and patching. Instead of proposing upgrades directly, the MSP sets a goal: “Achieve foundational cyber hygiene.” The proposal says: “To reach a green status in Security Health, we recommend this $3.2K initiative. It moves you from 48% to 85% compliance.” The roadmap simply records the initiative under Q3, and the budget reserves the funding.Impact:? Lower-maturity clients engage with clearer outcomes, not technical specs? Risk-based proposals gain traction by connecting to visible pain? The roadmap and budget remain the client’s compass—not just a list of transactionsThis integrated approach reduces friction, improves proposal acceptance, and reinforces your CS narrative: from insight ? to goal ? to initiative ? to execution.Concept #4: Define Scope, Assumptions, and Client Responsibilities ClearlyA common challenge in MSP project proposals is the lack of clarity regarding what is included, what is assumed, and what the client is responsible for. This ambiguity can lead to misunderstandings, scope creep, and strained client relationships.To mitigate these risks, it's essential to explicitly define:? Scope of Work: Detail the specific services and deliverables the MSP will provide.? Assumptions: List any conditions assumed to be true for the project (e.g., "Client will provide access to necessary systems").? Client Responsibilities: Outline tasks or resources the client is expected to provide (e.g., "Client will supply hardware components").By clearly articulating these elements, MSPs can set proper expectations, reduce the likelihood of disputes, and ensure smoother project execution.Concept #5: Proposal hygiene = Executive Decision Sheet + Owner/Date/Budget gateWhy it mattersApprovals slip when proposals are long, unclear, or lack a crisp decision moment. A consistent “hygiene” standard makes approvals faster and auditable across roles.How to apply (plain rules)? Lead every proposal with a 1-page Executive Decision Sheet (front-matter before any appendix): Problem/Why now • Options (max 2) with cost band • Expected impact • Risks/assumptions • Owner & target date.? Approval hygiene gate: count “expansion credit” only when Owner + Date + Budget are confirmed in writing (same gate as QBR).? Follow-through SLAs: send a recap ≤ 48h (decisions, owners, dates, risks); open a CTA with first action ≤ 72h.? Segment fit:? A/B ? full deck + Decision Sheet, presented live.? C/D ? slim summary embedded in meeting notes/roadmap + Decision Sheet.Practical example “Approve MFA Phase 2 (Why now: insurance mandate; Impact: risk ?; Owner: CFO; Target: Jun 15; Budget: $12–15k).”Common pitfallsBurying the ask in slide 27 • More than 2 options • No written Owner/Date/Budget • Recap sent a week later.Concept #6: Proposal velocity & declines are Health signalsWhy it mattersProposal movement reflects Engagement, Alignment, and timing. Stalls and silent declines are early churn indicators unless you capture and act on them.How to apply (plain rules)? Track Time-to-first-action (CTA opened/owner set) ? target ≤ 72h.? Track Time-to-decision and aging buckets: 0–14d, 15–30d, >30d.? Stale > 30d ? trigger Re-engage play (cadence reset, reframe options).? > 60d with no movement ? auto-close or re-sequence on the roadmap; capture decline reason.? Portfolio KPIs to review monthly:? Win rate by segment? Median days-to-approval? % proposals with decline reason captured (≥ 90%)? % proposals linked to a roadmap slot/initiative ID (100%)Practical exampleSegment B proposal hits 32 days with no decision ? schedule a 20-min live reset, offer 2 options (now vs. next quarter), log reason if deferred, update roadmap & budget.Common pitfallsOrphan proposals with no roadmap link • No reason codes on declines • Chasing aged proposals without adjusting segment/cadence • Counting “verbal yes” without artifacts.
Implementation ProcessTurn insight into approval. The proposal is the formal handshake between CS planning and delivery execution.1. Trigger from strategic insight? Discovery reveals the opportunity? Assessment validates risk, readiness, or urgency? The proposal scopes the solution and timing2. Align proposal depth to the client’s segment and goal level? Segment A–B / Levels 4–5: deck-style proposals with OKRs, KPIs, timelines? Segment C–D / Levels 1–3: streamlined summaries embedded in the roadmap or meeting3. Embed in the Delivery and Budget cycles? Include budget reference, cost structure, and approval path? Tag proposal items as initiatives and track follow-through? Link to roadmap progress and CS Health indicators4. Present in context? Proposals are delivered live, not just sent? They frame decisions, not just documentationWhen done well, proposals are not standalone sales documents—they are activation tools in the CS operating system.
AppendixHow does it connect to the Client Business Goal levels?Proposals reflect the client’s position on the maturity and appetite curve. Their depth, frequency, and language shift with the Client Business Goal level:LevelProposal Role1.1 Technology SupportShort-form scopes for break/fix, patching, and basic backup—limited appetite.1.2 Technology EnablementService proposals tied to enablement projects (AV, SaaS standardization, firewall replacement). Still mostly OpEx.1.3 Technology ModernizationStack change proposals, lifecycle upgrades, endpoint refreshes. Multi-step projects with measurable outcomes.1.4 Business TransformationProposals formalize strategic initiatives, including workflow redesign, automation, and analytics. Often linked to department priorities.1.5 Business InnovationMulti-stakeholder initiatives with OKR alignment, new platforms, and co-funded pilots. The proposal serves as both an investment and a change document.How does it connect to the other parts?? 1. Client Business Goal - Proposals translate the client’s current goal level into defined CS workstreams, bridging business needs with technical execution in a scalable and understandable format.? 2. Customer Success Health - Proposal cadence and follow-through influence adoption, engagement, and service quality scores. Delayed or misaligned proposals signal breakdowns in planning or a lack of trust.? 3. Customer Success Delivery - Proposals form the entry point to delivery. They act as the contract for future deliverables, budgets, and meeting agendas.? 4. Customer Success Process - Discoveries or assessments often trigger the development of proposals. It defines the next steps in service intake and initiative launch.? 6. Customer Success People - TAMs, vCIOs, and CSMs rely on proposals to formalize their recommendations. Proposals also provide context for hand-offs to project managers or delivery teams.? 7. Customer Success Strategy - Proposal design and complexity are adapted based on segmentation, playbook maturity, and available CS capacity. This keeps engagement scalable and repeatable across clients.Product Links / Tooling SupportThe LMx Quoter Proposal feature enables MSPs to generate polished, professional proposals in seconds using reusable templates and standardized pricing.Key capabilities include:? Prebuilt, branded sales proposal templates for clean, client-ready formattingAbility to include a cover page, introductory message, marketing content, terms, and order instructions? Support for attaching supplementary content like contracts, brochures, and documents? E-signature-ready delivery via secure links—enabling easy client review and acceptance on any device? Significant time savings by minimizing manual entry and formatting, while improving accuracy and professionalismThis tool supports both ongoing service recommendations and project-based proposals, ensuring consistent presentation across all segments and business goal levels.
?? 3.3 Budget
3.3 BudgetOverviewWhat is the objective?Why is it important?As an MSP, why do I need to do this?What is the Customer impact?Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: Budgets Reflect the CommitmentsConcept #2: Budgeting Is a Strategic Advisory Process, Not Just a SpreadsheetConcept #3: Price TestingConcept #4: Pre-ApprovalConcept #5: Do’s and Don’tsConcept #6: Segment-Driven Budget Formats (keep it simple, by tier)Concept #7: Budget Hygiene & Follow-Through SLAsConcept #8: Budget Signals = Health SignalsImplementation Process1. Collect the right inputs:2. Structure the budget for client readiness:3. Embed into the CS lifecycle:4. Use budgets to move from intention to action:AppendixHow does it connect to the Client Business Goal levels?How does it connect to the other parts?Product Links / Tooling SupportHow we recommend doing it (product-based)
OverviewWhat is the objective?To deliver a clear, forward-looking financial plan that translates strategic initiatives into actionable investment timing. Budgets connect CS Process insights (Discovery, Assessment, Roadmap) to CS Delivery execution (Proposals, Projects, Renewals), enabling clients to prioritize confidently and MSPs to plan sustainably.Why is it important?Because budgets are not just about costs—they’re how CS strategy becomes reality. Without a budget, even the best roadmap lacks traction. A well-delivered budget:? Shows the client you’ve thought ahead—strategically and financially? Frame proposals in context, making approvals easier? Enables prioritization and phasing of initiatives? Reduces last-minute objections and increases decision speed? Helps the MSP stabilize delivery, hiring, and capacity by forecasting demandBudgets are where trust is earned, alignment is confirmed, and execution begins.As an MSP, why do I need to do this?Because if you’re not helping clients plan financially, you’re not acting as a strategic partner. A budget:? Connects CS workstreams across Discovery, Assessment, Roadmap, and Initiative planning? Secures buy-in with early price signals and realistic scheduling? Prevents stalled proposals and ghosted initiatives by clarifying timing and cost? Gives internal delivery teams a clearer view of what’s coming and when? Turns your strategic plan into a resource-backed execution pathBudgets are your way of saying: “We’re not just recommending this—we’ve thought through how and when you can afford to act.”What is the Customer impact?Budgets give clients clarity on what they’re spending, what’s changing, and what’s coming next. Done well:? They reduce last-minute objections or sticker shock? Clients can plan initiatives alongside broader business priorities? They improve confidence in the MSP’s advice and planning? Clients who don’t receive the proper budget format for their segment may disengage, especially if meeting time is wasted or initiative plans feel vague.
Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: Budgets Reflect the CommitmentsBudgets are not just downstream outputs of Discovery, Assessment, and Reporting—they are the financial codification of mutual commitments. A well-structured budget signals that both parties agree on what needs to be done, why it matters, and when it’s realistic to execute.The budget answers the question: “When and how do we pay for what we have agreed needs to be done?”To build that answer, the MSP must consider the client's Client Business Goal, which is shaped by their maturity and strategic appetite. A high-maturity, high-appetite client may be ready for aggressive innovation cycles. A low-maturity, low-appetite client may only commit to tactical improvements.Your budget scope and delivery style should reflect where the client is today—and where they’re ready to go.Budgeting also plays a direct role in Customer Success Health, particularly in the Alignment, Adoption, and Engagement dimensions. A well-structured budget confirms strategic alignment, validates readiness for initiative delivery, and strengthens the engagement rhythm.Concept #2: Budgeting Is a Strategic Advisory Process, Not Just a SpreadsheetMany MSPS view budgeting as a static deliverable—“What does the client spend with us?” But the real value lies in the process of advising around financial planning, risk mitigation, and investment alignment. Budgeting enables the MSP to become a financially credible partner in the client's strategic planning, rather than just a vendor with a price list.This means:? Helping prioritize initiatives across OpEx, CapEx, and project spend? Providing input on timing and trade-offs based on business cycles or ROI potential? Bringing financial literacy into strategic planning conversations? Leading multi-stakeholder discussions about impact, resourcing, and sequencingAs maturity increases, the MSP shifts from submitting budget lines to guiding the budget conversation. Budgeting becomes the place where strategic alignment occurs, not just where numbers reside.It also becomes a crucial touchpoint in the CS Health feedback loop, where Engagement, Alignment, and Execution capabilities converge. Budgets reflect not only what the client wants to do, but also whether your MSP can reliably guide and deliver it.This concept echoes the “shared ownership” described in Level 5 Budget Maturity in the workshop doc: budgeting is not something you do for the client—it’s something you do with them. Strategic MSPs embed themselves in this process early and often.Concept #3: Price TestingClients don’t need a final quote to make early decisions—they need a financial signal to test interest. Instead of diving straight into detailed project scoping, MSPs should present initiative estimates early in the conversation. This acts as a “reality check” and helps clients self-qualify their interest and readiness. For example:“For similar clients, this type of initiative typically runs around $8K–$12K. Is that within a range that makes sense to solve this?”While LMx Budgets don’t support cost ranges natively, MSPs can use early estimates to test appetite. This keeps decision-making informal and faster, saving hours of planning on initiatives the client may not be ready to fund or prioritize. It also builds trust by respecting the client’s time and investment expectations.These early signals should be tracked and surfaced in CS Health scoring, particularly within Engagement and Appetite tracking, to inform whether formal budgeting is likely to succeed.How to applyLog every price test as a Budget Note with owner + quarter + range; if interest = no/“later,” tag and re-sequence on the roadmap.Concept #4: Pre-ApprovalPre-approval is the client’s informal commitment to proceed, often before the scope is finalized. It could be: “Let’s plan to do this in Q3 if the scope matches.” Or even: “If it’s under $12,000, we’re good.” This lightweight approval builds momentum and improves proposal hit rates, especially when roadmaps and budgets are presented in the same meeting.Pre-approvals are also valuable indicators of engagement within the CS Health system. When appropriately captured, they reflect momentum and can positively influence Engagement and Alignment scores.How to apply“Count pre-approval only when Owner + Target quarter + Budget band are recorded; send recap ≤48h and open a CTA ≤72h to prepare the proposal.”Concept #5: Do’s and Don’tsDo:? Match the depth of the forecast to the client’s engagement level? Keep initiative descriptions client-facing? Tie each item to a Discovery, Assessment, or Roadmap insight? Present multi-year plans in chunks—by quarter or half-year? Use budgeting milestones to validate CS Health indicators such as cadence participation, appetite alignment, and initiative readinessDon’t:? Overwhelm clients with overly detailed cost data? Assume budgets = approval. Always validate interest first? Skip the strategic connection—always link back to Discovery findings, Assessment validation, or Roadmap context? Ignore budget-stalling patterns—they are often signals of declining CS Health that require Governance follow-upConcept #6: Segment-Driven Budget Formats (keep it simple, by tier)Why it mattersBudgets land when the format matches attention span and decision depth. Over-formatting for D/C, or under-formatting for A/B, kills momentum.How to apply (plain rules)? Segment D (Goal 1 – Technology Support): 1-page list of renewals, licenses, overdue hardware; quarterly view; simple totals.? Segment C (Goal 2 – Technology Enablement): semi-annual view; add 2–4 near-term initiatives with rough ranges; short notes (“Why now / Impact”).? Segment B (Goal 3 – Technology Modernization): rolling 4-quarter view; split OpEx vs. CapEx; link each line to Roadmap/Initiative ID.? Segment A (Goals 4–5 – Transformation & Innovation): rolling 4-quarter + 1–2 year outlook; OpEx/CapEx split; decision flags; pre-approval field per line.Practical exampleSegment B budget: Q2–Q1 rolling table, OpEx/CapEx columns, each line shows Initiative ID, cost band, quarter, owner.Common pitfallsOne “master spreadsheet” for all segments • No OpEx/CapEx split for A/B • No initiative IDs (orphan lines).Concept #7: Budget Hygiene & Follow-Through SLAsWhy it mattersBudgets only drive approvals when the “decision moment” is explicit and the follow-through is fast.How to apply (plain rules)? Lead with a 1-page Budget Snapshot: totals by quarter, OpEx/CapEx split, top 3 risks, max two decisions.? Hygiene gate (same as QBR/proposals): count “expansion credit” only when Owner + Target date + Budget band are captured.? Recap ≤ 48h after the budget session; open CTAs with first action ≤ 72h.? Each budget line must link to a Roadmap/Initiative ID (no orphans).? Versioning: v1, v2… and a one-line change note (“Moved MFA to Q3 per audit window”).Practical example Approve Endpoint Refresh Phase 1 — Owner: Ops Dir; Target: Sep; Budget: $28–32k.Common pitfallsSnapshot missing • More than two asks • Recap next week • Lines not tied to roadmap.Concept #8: Budget Signals = Health SignalsWhy it mattersBudget movement reflects Engagement, Alignment, Adoption. Stalls are early churn indicators.How to apply (portfolio KPIs)? Time-to-first-action (CTA opened/owner set): target ≤ 72h.? Budget realization rate: % of budgeted initiatives that convert to approved proposals in-quarter.? Forecast vs. actual variance by quarter (±10–20% green / >20% investigate).? Pre-approval aging: >30 days stale ? re-engage/reset; >60 days ? re-sequence.? Decline reasons captured ≥ 90% (price, timing, relevance, dependency).Practical exampleSegment C: realization rate 40% for two quarters ? simplify scope, move one item to OpEx, re-frame “Why now”.Common pitfallsChasing stale pre-approvals • No decline reasons • Celebrating “verbal yes” without artifacts.
Implementation ProcessDevelop a structured, forward-looking budget that aligns with the client's maturity and appetite, enabling both parties to plan, prioritize, and commit with confidence.1. Collect the right inputs:? Use Discovery and Assessment findings to define initiatives? Include upcoming contract renewals, hardware replacements, and platform changes? Tag by category: CapEx, OpEx, lifecycle, compliance, etc.2. Structure the budget for client readiness:? Segment A/B or Level 4–5: multi-year plans with phase timing, pre-approval fields, and initiative notes? Segment C/D or Level 1–3: quarterly or semi-annual budgets with clear summaries and estimated ranges3. Embed into the CS lifecycle:? Link each item to the Roadmap and Proposal pipeline? Validate interest through informal price testing? Present during strategic meetings—not as a spreadsheet, but as a planning tool4. Use budgets to move from intention to action:? Confirm priorities and remove ambiguity? Enable faster proposal approvals? Track budget evolution over time as maturity growsDone right, a budget is not just a list of costs—it’s a strategic decision tool that connects investment insight and transforms planning into progress.
AppendixHow does it connect to the Client Business Goal levels?Budgets evolve in depth and strategic value alongside the client’s Business Goal level, driven by their maturity (standardization, visibility, and financial discipline) and appetite (willingness to invest in forward-looking change). Each level reflects a different budget role: from basic visibility to long-term co-planning.But budgets aren’t just about what the client spends—they clarify how strategic the relationship is, and what pace of investment is realistic. MSPs must align budget timelines and format to the client’s readiness. A low-appetite client needs simplicity and flexibility; a high-appetite client needs phased, roadmap-linked planning.At higher levels of maturity, clients also expect a clear separation between capital expenditures (CapEx, such as hardware or projects) and Operational Expenditures (OpEx, including licenses, services, and subscriptions). Reflecting both types in budget presentations signals financial professionalism and supports executive planning.This progression mirrors the broader CS process:? Discovery Intake identifies potential areas of change.? Assessment Intake validates readiness.? Reports clarify risks and the initiative's value.? Budgeting defines the timing, scope, and financial alignment of what happens next.LevelBudgeting Role and Scope1.1 Technology SupportBasic spend visibility. Covers recurring services, contracts, licenses, and overdue hardware. Used to avoid surprises and reinforce trust. Often manual or email-based.1.2 Technology EnablementAdds forecasting for short-term replacements and operational improvements. Helps shift budgeting from a reactive to a planned approach. Clients may begin recognizing patterns.1.3 Technology ModernizationIntroduces multi-period forecasts and “price testing” for projects—Aligns initiatives to lifecycle and platform changes. MSP uses the budget to validate interest before investing in deep planning.1.4 Business TransformationBudgets support roadmap execution. They include departmental initiatives, phased sequencing, and stakeholder approvals. Presentation format matters—it must guide decisions. Capital expenditures (CapEx) and operating expenditures (OpEx) are tracked and presented separately to support business justification and decision-making.1.5 Business InnovationBudgeting becomes a shared strategic process. The scope encompasses long-term investment themes, including AI, analytics, cloud architecture, and OKR-aligned initiatives. Includes pre-approvals and forward commitments. Budgets integrate CapEx and OpEx categories across multi-year views, supporting CFO-level alignment.Budgets are how MSPs translate ideas into investment timing. The further the client climbs the Business Goal pyramid, the more essential budgeting becomes to drive buy-in, pacing, and prioritization. It's not just a tool—it's a strategic discipline.How does it connect to the other parts?? 1. Client Business Goal – The budget scope adapts to the client's maturity and appetite. It gives a financial lens to goal progression.? 2. Customer Success Health – Transparent spend forecasting enhances customer experience and trust. Missed expectations or surprises erode sentiment.? 3. Customer Success Delivery – Budget data defines what gets proposed, when it’s affordable, and how execution is phased.? 4. Customer Success Process – Budgets are downstream of Initiative planning and upstream of proposal. They anchor meeting discussions.? 6. Customer Success People – TAMs, vCIOs, and CSMs utilize budgets to facilitate financial planning conversations with both technical and non-technical stakeholders.? 7. Customer Success Strategy – Budgets reflect the depth of engagement. Lower-touch = automated summaries. Higher-touch = consultative, phased forecasts.Product Links / Tooling SupportThe LMx Budget Forecast tool allows MSPs to:? Automatically generate client-specific forecasts based on:? Recommended Initiatives (from Discovery, Assessments, or existing asset/contract data)? Vendor contracts and subscriptions? Hardware lifecycle timelines (based on maximum replacement age and estimated replacement cost)? View in spreadsheet or board-style layout? Include or exclude categories like overdue assets, unscheduled recommendations, and warranty renewals? Filter by period (monthly, quarterly, yearly), category, and tagsExport to Word, PDF, or CSV formats and store in the Report Locker? Share budget reports directly with clients or use them in meeting follow-upsLMx Initiatives in the budget include:? Timeline: When is the initiative expected or recommended to be executed (e.g., Q2 2025)?? Action items: Tasks or follow-ups associated with each initiative.? Description / Summary: Clear, client-facing explanation of the initiative’s purpose and value.? Cost: A budget estimate is tied to each initiative for forecasting purposes.This tool enables the delivery of impressive, data-driven, and forward-looking financial plans that effectively reinforce the MSP's strategic value.How we recommend doing it (product-based)1. Open LMx > Budget Forecast tab for the selected client.2. Review the automatically generated forecast, which includes:?
