Configure the budget view:? Choose periods (e.g. quarterly), filters (e.g. tags, categories), and whether to include overdue or unscheduled items.? Toggle visuals on and off for different presentation needs.4. Use board or spreadsheet views to show spend by time and category.5. Drill into each budget item:? View the initiative description, timeline, and cost? Explore linked contracts or devices? Edit or tag for tracking6. Export and share the budget in Word, PDF, or CSV format. Optionally save to the Locker.7. Link the budget to upcoming meetings using LMx Meeting integration for full context.8. Repeat quarterly or annually, and adjust as needed based on progress in Discovery, Roadmap, or other initiatives.Knowledge Base resource 1Help article resource 2New to LCI - week 2 - The Budget
?? 3.4 Strategy
3.4 Strategy OverviewWhat is the objective?Why is it important?As an MSP, why do I need to do this?What is the Customer impact?Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: Strategy Must Evolve by Segment, Maturity, and AppetiteConcept #2: Strategy Is Synthesized—and Best Delivered LiveConcept #3: Strategy Aligns the Entire CS LifecycleConcept #4: A Good Strategy Makes Budget Conversations EasierConcept #5: Strategic Planning Is a Team SportConcept #6: Strategy = 1-page Snapshot + two decisions (delivered live)Concept #7: Strategy Hygiene & Freshness (keep it current, tie to roadmap)Implementation ProcessTurning Strategy into a Repeatable Customer Success MotionStep 1: Structure Strategy by Segment and Goal LevelStep 2: Connect Strategy to the CS Process LifecycleStep 3: Assign Ownership and Standardize FormatStep 4: Embed Strategy in CS Health, Governance, and Role ExecutionStep 5: Link to Proposal and Budget ExecutionFinal Output: A Segmented, Live Strategy SystemAppendixHow does it connect to the Client Business Goal levels?How does it connect to the other parts?Product Links / Tooling Support
OverviewWhat is the objective?To define and communicate a coherent technology strategy for the client, based on their business objectives, digital maturity, and growth appetite. The strategy serves as the long-term compass, ensuring that tactical wins ultimately lead to strategic outcomes.Why is it important?Strategy bridges the gap between technical actions and business value. A well-articulated strategy:? Connects Discovery and Assessment findings to long-term vision? Aligns stakeholders across IT and business functions? Enables prioritization of initiatives based on impact and feasibility.? Creates buy-in for multi-phase improvements, especially in higher maturity segments.? Builds trust and clarity for sustained investmentAs an MSP, why do I need to do this?Executing projects without a shared strategy leads to fragmented value. A strong client strategy:? Positions your MSP as a strategic business partner? Creates continuity between the roadmap, proposal, and budget planning? Reduces churn and pricing pressure by demonstrating forward vision? Guides future planning—ensuring you know what to recommend, and when? Anchors technology workstreams to the client’s maturity and appetiteWhat is the Customer impact?Clients:? Gain a clear vision for how IT supports their business goals? Engage more confidently in budget and roadmap decisions? Feel guided, not just supported—especially at higher goal levels? Can align internal departments and timelines around a shared digital strategy
Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: Strategy Must Evolve by Segment, Maturity, and AppetiteA client’s technology strategy should never be one-size-fits-all. Strategic planning must reflect two key aspects: the client's current maturity level and their readiness to change (appetite). These two factors define the Client Business Goal level, which in turn informs:? Format – Clients in Segments A and B may expect a,complete co-branded strategic plan; clients in Segments C and D may benefit more from summary slides or roadmap commentary.? Depth – High-maturity and appetite clients (e.g., Goals 4–5) require a multi-year vision and initiative sequencing; lower levels (Goals 1–2) need just enough direction to avoid reactive cycles.? Cadence – Strategic conversations may occur quarterly, annually, or at key roadmap inflection points, depending on the segment and engagement rhythm. In short, strategy delivery must evolve in tandem with the client. The more mature and committed they become, the more valuable— and expected —your strategic guidance will be.Use a segment map to set format depth: D = embedded notes, C = project plan + milestones, B = initiative map + roadmap summary, A = co-branded multi-year plan.Concept #2: Strategy Is Synthesized—and Best Delivered LiveEffective strategies are not invented in isolation. They are crafted from what Discovery and Assessment reveal, what the Budget can support, and what the Roadmap needs to communicate. Strategy connects the dots:? Discovery = Why the client wants to change? Assessment = Where they are exposed or behind? Roadmap = How improvements can be sequenced? Budget = What’s feasible and justifiableBut the power of strategy lies in the delivery, not just the document. A strategy must be reviewed and discussed live with the client. That’s how objections surface, timelines align, and buy-in is secured. Never treat strategy as an output—treat it as a conversation.These live conversations also offer the best opportunity to validate CS Health signals. When the strategy is reviewed, Engagement patterns, Alignment gaps, or Appetite shifts can be observed and logged to refine scoring and follow-up actions.For Segments A/B, target live delivery ≥80%; for C/D, allow async delivery with a short video recap, then schedule a brief decision check-in.Concept #3: Strategy Aligns the Entire CS LifecycleStrategy gives meaning and continuity to every CS deliverable. It is:? The bridge between Discovery and the Roadmap? The business case that backs your Proposal? The narrative lens for your Executive Report? The context that gives your Budget credibility If CS is a chain, strategy is the thread that connects each link. It ensures the client doesn’t see disjointed projects or reports, but rather a coordinated plan with a clear direction.This coherence is critical for CS Health scoring, especially Alignment. A clearly communicated strategy ensures each tactical move is part of a broader, visible plan. Misalignment in Health scoring often reflects a breakdown in strategy delivery or visibility.Concept #4: A Good Strategy Makes Budget Conversations EasierMost clients hesitate to invest without a reason. Strategy gives them that reason. When done well, your strategic plan:? Shows how initiatives ladder up to business goals? Breaks large programs into digestible phases? Justifies timing, investment, and outcomes with clear logicThis is especially important in the Proposal ? Budget ? Approval cycle. A strategy-backed roadmap gives sales and vCIOs the talking points they need to secure commitment. And it reduces pushback, because the story has already been co-written.Budget, Health and Initiative follow-through become stronger when strategy is used as the financial justification engine. Strategic framing supports CS Health by tying each investment to business impact, which reinforces Adoption, Alignment, and Engagement metrics.Include early price testing for each near-term theme (cost band) and capture pre-approval (Owner + Quarter + Budget band) to speed Proposal creation.Concept #5: Strategic Planning Is a Team SportStrategy shouldn’t live in a silo. It must be shared across the CS team:? vCIOs guide the vision and manage executive alignment? CSMs reinforce it during day-to-day engagement.? TAMs and Engineers execute initiatives with the strategy in mindWhen everyone knows the direction, tactical work becomes part of a bigger story. That improves morale, sharpens communication, and ensures that each team member understands how their role contributes to the client’s long-term success.It also ensures that CS Health scores—especially Service Quality and Execution—are supported by a shared internal framework. Standardized strategy sharing reduces role drift, protects against misalignment, and enhances the quality of governance reviews.Keep a mini-RACI: vCIO owns the narrative (A/B), CSM co-drives (B/C), AM handles renewals/budget signals, TAM provides readiness inputs.Concept #6: Strategy = 1-page Snapshot + two decisions (delivered live)Why it mattersStrategy lands when decisions are made. A long strategy deck only works if it’s led by a 1-page, decision-first summary.How to apply (plain rules)? Start every strategy session with a 1-page Strategy Snapshot: Business goals/OKRs; mini Health (CX/Engagement/Adoption/Quality/Alignment); top 3 themes/risks; max two decisions (Why this / Why now / Expected impact / Owner & target date).? Deliver live for Segments A/B (target ≥80%). C/D: async deck + 2–3 min summary video, then a short Q&A follow-up.? Count “expansion credit” only when Owner + Target date + Budget band are captured.? Recap ≤48h (standard template). Open decision CTAs with first action ≤72h.Practical example “Approve Data Retention Policy rollout — Why now: audit; Impact: risk?; Owner: CFO; Target: Q3; Budget: $5–7K.”Common pitfallsMissing snapshot • 5+ asks in one session • Recap sent a week later • No CTA/owner.Concept #7: Strategy Hygiene & Freshness (keep it current, tie to roadmap)Why it mattersStrategy must be a living document—when it goes stale, Alignment and Engagement suffer.How to apply (portfolio guardrails)? Freshness: Strategy reviewed ≤120 days for A/B; ≤180 days for C; D = annual/trigger-based.? Traceability: Every strategy theme must map to a Roadmap/Initiative ID (no orphans).? Versioning: v1, v2… + 1-line change note (“Moved MFA to Q3 due to audit window”).? Health hooks: In each review, note Health deltas and open CTAs for any red/yellow theme.? KPIs: Strategy presented live (A/B) ≥80%; Recap ≤48h ≥95%; First-action ≤72h ≥95%; % themes with roadmap link = 100%.Common pitfalls “Once-a-year deck” • Themes not linked to the roadmap • No change log.
Implementation ProcessTurning Strategy into a Repeatable Customer Success MotionThe Strategy Implementation Process enables MSPs to translate Discovery and Assessment findings into a clear, business-aligned technology strategy—tailored by client segment, maturity, and appetite. This process ensures that strategy is not treated as a static document, but as an active planning and communication tool embedded in the cadence of Customer Success.The objective is to make strategic planning:? Scalable across segments? Integrated across CS Process and CS Delivery? Deliverable by any enabled CS role? Visible through CS Health metricsStep 1: Structure Strategy by Segment and Goal LevelUse segmentation (1.1) and the client's Business Goal level to define the format, depth, and cadence of strategic planning:SegmentGoal LevelStrategy FormatCadenceA4–5Co-branded multi-year strategic planQuarterly review, annual refreshB3–4Initiative map + roadmap summaryQuarterlyC2–3Project planning + milestone notesSemi-annualD1–2Optional; embedded in roadmapAnnual (if any)Strategy at Segment A becomes a living document; at Segment D it may simply be a roadmap comment.Step 2: Connect Strategy to the CS Process LifecycleUse outputs from each CS Process blueprint to inform and justify strategic framing:? Discovery (4.2): Identify business context, priorities, and constraints? Assessment (4.3): Define gaps, exposures, and readiness? Initiatives (4.5): Package improvements into scoped outcomes? Budget (3.3): Ensure strategy matches financial feasibility? Roadmap (3.5): Align strategic objectives to milestone trackingThen deliver strategy via a live Quarterly Meeting (4.4) where the client can confirm direction, adjust timing, and validate prioritization.Step 3: Assign Ownership and Standardize FormatEach strategy document or slide should be owned and delivered by the appropriate role based on segment:? vCIO / Strategic Advisor: Owns strategic content and presentation (Segment A/B)? CSM / AM: Supports narrative and initiative alignment (Segment B/C)? TAM / SDM: May reference strategic themes but do not lead strategy delivery (Segment C/D)Use playbooks (1.3) and standard templates by segment to ensure consistency in:? Structure (e.g., Executive Summary ? Current State ? Initiatives ? Timeline ? Goals)? Language (business-aligned, free from technical jargon)? Visuals (OKRs, budget ties, Health metrics)Step 4: Embed Strategy in CS Health, Governance, and Role Execution? Tie CS Health Alignment scores to strategic clarity and follow-through? Validate Engagement through strategy session attendance and contribution? Score Adoption through initiative uptake and alignment to strategic roadmapGovernance (5.5) should review:? Is the strategy up to date?? Was it presented in the last QBR?? Are initiatives and budget aligned to the plan?? Is the client moving toward their stated business goals?This turns strategy into a measurable, reviewable CS discipline—not just a deck.Step 5: Link to Proposal and Budget ExecutionA good strategy makes downstream execution easier. Ensure:? Proposals (3.2) directly reference strategic themes and expected outcomes? Budgets (3.3) reflect strategy pacing and investment alignment? Roadmaps (3.5) evolve as strategy matures or priorities shiftBy embedding strategy into planning tools, MSPs increase initiative conversion, client trust, and forecast reliability.Final Output: A Segmented, Live Strategy SystemAt the end of this process, every client should have:? A strategic framing aligned to their maturity, appetite, and segment? A defined update and review rhythm? A shared understanding of how tactical initiatives support long-term outcomesThis is how strategy becomes more than a deliverable. It becomes the narrative backbone of Customer Success—one that links insight, investment, and impact.
AppendixHow does it connect to the Client Business Goal levels?LevelRole of Strategy1.1 Technology SupportStrategy is minimal; focus is on operational uptime and service clarity.1.2 Technology EnablementStrategy begins to form around platform alignment and project planning.1.3 Technology ModernizationA formal strategy articulates modernization objectives and sequencing.1.4 Business TransformationStrategy aligns IT with process improvement, productivity, and business metrics.1.5 Business InnovationStrategy becomes cross-functional, tied to OKRs, customer success, and innovation cycles.How does it connect to the other parts?1. Client Business Goal - Client strategy defines how the MSP supports the client's evolving goals. As the client progresses in maturity and appetite, the strategy provides a framework for coordinated action.2. Customer Success Health - Strategic alignment enhances CSAT and engagement by instilling confidence in clients' direction. A well-communicated strategy helps manage expectations and assess long-term service quality.3. Customer Success Delivery - The strategy serves as a foundation for reports, proposals, budgeting, and roadmaps, ensuring that all deliverables align with the same guiding vision.4. Customer Success Process - Strategic planning defines cadence and depth for planning cycles. It supports initiative intake prioritization and defines which stakeholders must be engaged.6. Customer Success People - vCIOs, strategic advisors, and CSMs use the strategy as a guide for quarterly meetings, initiative sequencing, and client coaching. It drives long-term account planning across roles.7. Customer Success Strategy - Segment-specific strategy formats, templates, and delivery rhythms are defined within the overall CS Strategy discipline, ensuring consistent strategic delivery across the portfolio.Product Links / Tooling SupportThere is currently no direct product feature supporting Client Strategy development. However, strategies are often built using inputs from:? LMx Executive Reports? Discovery assessments? Budget forecasts? Client Goals documentationThese components form the basis for custom strategy documents that can be delivered as part of high-touch engagements or quarterly business reviews.
?? 3.5 Roadmap
3.5 Roadmap OverviewWhat is the objective?Why is it important?As an MSP, why do I need to do this?What is the Customer impact?Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: A Roadmap Is a Story Told Over TimeConcept #2: Roadmaps Must Flex with Segment, Maturity, and AppetiteConcept #3: Roadmaps Align All CS DeliverablesConcept #4: Roadmaps Improve Buy-In by Reducing SurpriseConcept #5: Roadmaps Should Be Interactive, Not StaticConcept #6: Roadmaps Should Surface Gaps as Well as PlansImplementation ProcessMaking the Roadmap the Centerpiece of Strategic CS DeliveryStep 1: Align Roadmap Format with Segment and Client Goal LevelStep 2: Source Roadmap Content from Core CS Process InputsStep 3: Build the Roadmap Using Role-Based OwnershipStep 4: Use the Roadmap as a Strategic Planning and Review ArtifactStep 5: Enable Roadmap Execution via Health and Governance SystemsFinal Output: A Segment-Calibrated, Cadence-Driven Roadmap SystemAppendixHow does it connect to the Client Business Goal levels?How does it connect to the other parts?Product Links / Tooling Support
OverviewWhat is the objective?To visualize and communicate the timing, priority, and cost of current and future technology initiatives in alignment with the client’s business strategy. Roadmaps help clients understand not just what needs to happen, but when and why.Why is it important?? Clarifies which projects and improvements are planned for the future.? Helps clients prepare for workload, cost, and organizational impact.? Prevents initiative overload or poor sequencing.? Strengthens CS credibility by showing a proactive, long-term vision.? Connects recommendations to real business value and operational timing.As an MSP, why do I need to do this?? Provides a tangible way to organize, prioritize, and communicate initiatives.? Helps ensure that proposed projects are scheduled in a manageable and fundable sequence.? Reinforces CS value by tying initiatives to the client’s maturity and appetite, reflecting their Client Business Goal progression over time.? Enables better internal coordination across CS, Projects, Sales, and Procurement teams.What is the Customer impact?? Clients gain confidence from a clear, forward-looking plan for improvements.? Enables resource planning, change management, and financial forecasting.? Reduces friction and last-minute decision-making for strategic projects.? Provides visibility for stakeholders across departments to align on priorities.
Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: A Roadmap Is a Story Told Over TimeA roadmap isn’t just a list—it’s the visual narrative of how strategic change unfolds. It answers not only what should happen, but when and why. Effective roadmaps organize multiple initiatives into time-based themes that reflect business relevance, risk urgency, and resource capacity.They help clients and internal teams move from isolated projects to coordinated progress, showing how Discovery, Assessment, and Strategy translate into sequenced action.A strong roadmap:? Clarifies initiative timing across quarters or years? Prevents overload by spreading work and investment? Communicates priority at a glance? Sets expectations for future planning and budgetingDone well, it becomes the centrepiece of the CS engagement cycle, returning in every proposal, meeting, and QBR.It also becomes a core CS Health artifact—validating Alignment, Adoption planning, and Execution capacity. A roadmap without movement over time signals stagnation and should trigger a review of underlying Health metrics.Use three lanes to keep the story readable: Stability (risk/lifecycle), Efficiency (enablement/automation), Growth (innovation/OKR-linked).Concept #2: Roadmaps Must Flex with Segment, Maturity, and AppetiteThe roadmap format, complexity, and planning cadence should align with the client’s maturity (how well they operate) and appetite (how willing they are to improve). This reflects their Client Business Goal level, which determines:? Segment A–B (Goal 4–5) ? Multi-year vision tied to OKRs and department initiatives? Segment C–D (Goal 1–3) ? Short-term prioritization, lifecycle upgrades, or reactive supportIn other words, don’t overwhelm a Segment D client with a 2-year innovation plan—or deliver a one-liner to a CFO-backed innovation team. Roadmaps must earn trust by aligning with business ambitions. This ensures the roadmap is seen as relevant, not theoretical.It also ensures CS Health signals are interpreted correctly. A minimal roadmap may be appropriate for a low-maturity client, but a similar roadmap in Segment A would likely indicate misalignment or low Engagement.Set depth by segment: D = lifecycle board only, C = 1–2 quarter view, B = 12-month view, A = multi-year, department-tagged.Concept #3: Roadmaps Align All CS DeliverablesThink of the roadmap as a canvas that organizes everything else:? Reports explain progress along the roadmap? Proposals justify spending based on roadmap priorities? Budgets reflect roadmap timing and financial weight? Meetings check alignment against the roadmapThis coordination builds credibility, avoids overlap, and ensures each CS touchpoint adds value.It also supports CS Health review—offering a single frame where Engagement rhythm, Adoption status, and Service Quality outcomes are visibly linked to a structured plan.When clients see every recommendation fitting into a larger plan, their confidence in execution grows.Gate proposal ‘credit’ on roadmap placement + quarter; every Proposal/Budget line must reference a Roadmap ID.Concept #4: Roadmaps Improve Buy-In by Reducing SurpriseOne of the biggest reasons clients delay approvals is a lack of context. The roadmap solves this by making plans visible and predictable. When initiatives are mapped ahead:? Clients can prepare resources and a budget? Department heads are looped in earlier? Sales, tech, and CS can collaborate on timingEven if priorities shift, the roadmap provides a shared reference point.That shared reference point is also essential for sustaining CS Health during change. If Engagement or Alignment scores drop, the roadmap helps clarify where expectations or planning may have broken down.It provides clients with a mental model to say yes, and CS teams with a structure for managing timing, dependencies, and workload.Show early price bands on near-term items and capture pre-approval (Owner + Quarter + Budget band) during roadmap reviews.Concept #5: Roadmaps Should Be Interactive, Not StaticA great roadmap isn’t a PDF—it’s a working tool that can:? Drag and drop initiatives across quarters? Update status as progress occurs? Export timeline-specific reports for meetings or budgetsWhen roadmaps are easy to update and share, they become an integral part of everyday planning, not just a one-time presentation. This interactivity is key to operationalizing CS Health. When roadmap status aligns with initiative execution and cadence reviews, Health scores stay current, explainable, and governance-ready.That’s how CS teams scale strategic conversations across roles and clients.Require drag-and-drop re-sequencing live in the meeting; export the snapshot for the recap, not a static PDF deck.Concept #6: Roadmaps Should Surface Gaps as Well as PlansRoadmaps aren’t just about what’s happening—they’re also about what’s missing. If a roadmap lacks security initiatives or modernization steps, that becomes a topic for discussion. If too many high-cost items cluster in one quarter, you can re-sequence them. By surfacing these gaps:? CS teams anticipate pushback before it happens? Clients appreciate the transparency? Planning becomes proactive, not reactiveThis makes roadmap review not just a project tracker, but a strategic touchpoint as well.It also supports CS Health scoring by identifying where missing or stalled roadmap items suggest underlying issues in Adoption, Execution, or Engagement, allowing for early intervention.Run a gap scan each review: no orphan quarters, no missing security items, and ≤2 big rocks/quarter.Concept #7: Decision-first Roadmap = 1-page Snapshot + two decisionsWhy it mattersRoadmaps drive momentum when they surface decisions, not just timelines. A long board or deck lands best when it’s led by a 1-page, decision-first snapshot.How to apply (plain rules)? Start every review with a 1-page Roadmap Snapshot: Business outcomes; mini Health (CX/Engagement/Adoption/Quality/Alignment); next 2 quarters at a glance; max two decisions (Why this / Why now / Expected impact / Owner & target date).? Segments A/B: present live (target ≥80%). C/D: async board + 2–3 min summary video, then short Q&A.? Count expansion credit only when Owner + Target date + Budget band are captured.? Recap ≤48h (standard template). Open decision CTAs with first action ≤72h.Practical example “Approve Endpoint Refresh Q3 — Why now: warranty risk; Impact: downtime?; Owner: COO; Target: 09/30; Budget: $18–22K.”Common pitfallsEndless backlogs • No explicit “asks” • Recap a week later • CTAs without owners.Concept #8: Roadmap Hygiene & Freshness (keep it live, tie to initiatives)Why it mattersA stale roadmap erodes Alignment and Engagement. Hygiene rules keep it trusted and actionable.How to apply (portfolio guardrails)? Freshness: Reviewed ≤120 days for A/B; ≤180 days for C; D annual/trigger-based.? Traceability: Every roadmap item maps to an Initiative/Proposal ID (no orphans).? Versioning: v1, v2… + 1-line change note (“Moved MFA to Q3 due to audit window”).? Capacity guardrail: Max 2 “big rocks”/quarter; push the rest to next periods.? Health hooks: Note Health deltas each review; open CTAs for any red/yellow theme.? KPIs: Snapshot present ≥95%; Recap ≤48h ≥95%; First-action ≤72h ≥95%; % items linked to Initiative/Proposal = 100%.Common pitfalls “Once-a-year roadmap” • Items not linked to initiatives • Overloaded quarters • No change log.
Implementation ProcessMaking the Roadmap the Centerpiece of Strategic CS DeliveryThe Roadmap Implementation Process enables MSPs to transform disconnected initiatives into a coordinated, time-based strategic plan. It provides the client with visibility into what’s coming, why it matters, and when it will happen—while giving the MSP a practical way to manage pacing, dependencies, and stakeholder alignment.This process ensures that roadmaps are:? Tailored to client segment and Business Goal level? Embedded into CS Process, Delivery, and Health workflows? Owned and updated collaboratively across roles? Presented not as static documents, but as live planning toolsStep 1: Align Roadmap Format with Segment and Client Goal LevelUse segmentation and maturity scoring to select the right level of complexity and frequency for roadmap creation and review:SegmentGoal LevelRoadmap DepthUpdate RhythmA4–5Multi-year, cross-departmental viewQuarterlyB3–412-month view with quarterly pacingQuarterlyC2–3Short-term (1–2 quarter) outlookQuarterly or Semi-AnnualD1–2Minimal (lifecycle updates only)AnnualRoadmaps must feel ambitious to Segment A and achievable to Segment D—never generic.Step 2: Source Roadmap Content from Core CS Process InputsBuild the roadmap using structured inputs from CS Process deliverables:? Discovery (4.2): Capture business priorities and change signals? Assessment (4.3): Identify risks, gaps, and readiness? Initiatives (4.5): Translate insights into phased actions? Proposals (3.2): Insert scoped, budget-ready projects? Budget (3.3): Confirm initiative pacing and investment feasibility? Strategy (3.4): Use roadmap as a visual summary of the strategic planThis creates a closed-loop roadmap system that reflects both technical needs and business ambition.Step 3: Build the Roadmap Using Role-Based OwnershipEach roadmap must have a clear internal owner and contributor model:? vCIO / Strategic Advisor: Owns roadmap narrative and executive delivery? CSM / AM: Manages updates, initiative tracking, and follow-up? TAM / SDM: Supports input for technical tasks, project milestones, and resource sequencingUse standardized templates for each segment to define:? Time horizon (e.g., 1-year, 2-year)? Initiative format (title, scope, owner, cost, status)? Strategic tags (e.g., AI, Security, Productivity, Lifecycle)Embed roadmap ownership into role charters to ensure accountability for movement.Step 4: Use the Roadmap as a Strategic Planning and Review ArtifactThe roadmap must be part of the client cadence—not a one-off deliverable. Integrate it into:? Quarterly Business Reviews (4.4): Use as the centerpiece for strategic alignment? Proposal Conversations: Ensure each new initiative fits into an existing or evolving roadmap? Budget Forecasting: Align roadmap phases with known budget constraints or approval cyclesIf a roadmap is missing or unchanged for more than two quarters, treat it as a CS Health warning—indicating potential Engagement, Alignment, or Adoption risk.Step 5: Enable Roadmap Execution via Health and Governance SystemsRoadmaps are tracked not just for delivery—but for signal strength:? CS Health Alignment: Confirm that roadmap milestones match stated business goals? CS Health Adoption: Review initiative status and velocity over time? Governance (5.5): Conduct quarterly roadmap audits to assess delivery quality and client alignment? Reporting (3.1): Reference roadmap progress in Executive ReportsThis turns the roadmap into a living strategic system, with direct implications for client retention and strategic trust.Final Output: A Segment-Calibrated, Cadence-Driven Roadmap SystemWhen this process is complete, each client should have:? A roadmap appropriate to their segment and business goals? A defined rhythm for review and adjustment? A clear link between roadmap items and proposals, budgets, and CS Health signalsThis is how MSPs ensure the roadmap is not just a plan—but a strategic platform that powers momentum, reinforces value, and scales with client maturity.
AppendixHow does it connect to the Client Business Goal levels?LevelRole of Roadmap1.1 Technology SupportMinimal use; roadmaps may include basic lifecycle or compliance actions.1.2 Technology EnablementThe roadmap highlights key alignment tasks and foundational projects that are essential for success.1.3 Technology ModernizationInitiatives are phased to modernize the stack and support business operations.1.4 Business TransformationRoadmaps include productivity, automation, and collaboration strategies.1.5 Business InnovationRoadmaps span multiple departments and support OKRs, innovation, and AI initiatives.How does it connect to the other parts?1. Client Business Goal - The roadmap outlines how the MSP will assist the client in evolving, based on their maturity and strategic appetite. It connects high-level goals with actionable plans.2. Customer Success Health - Roadmap adherence influences adoption, engagement, and service alignment scores. Unrealistic or unmaintained roadmaps signal a breakdown in CS.3. Customer Success Delivery - All other deliverables, including reports, proposals, and budgets, align with the roadmap timeline. It sets the rhythm for execution and review.4. Customer Success Process - Roadmaps drive initiative scheduling, stakeholder engagement, and cadence planning. They guide what happens when and why.6. Customer Success People - Used by TAMs, vCIOs, and CSMs to lead planning conversations, manage expectations, and guide stakeholder alignment. Encourages collaborative engagement.7. Customer Success Strategy - Roadmap design and granularity reflect client segmentation. High-touch clients receive strategic, multi-year views, while lower-touch segments receive simplified rollout guidance.Product Links / Tooling SupportThe LMx Recommendation Roadmap enables MSPs to:? Create and save recommendation templates with cost, priority, and timeline metadata? Drag and drop initiatives across quarters or years in a visual board view? Export roadmap reports grouped by period, company, or cost type? Link recommendations to assessments, assets, or manually created initiatives? Support clients in long-term planning and gain approval with budget-aligned recommendationsThese tools provide both a strategic framework and an execution calendar, helping MSPs drive engagement and accountability across time.
?? 4. CS Process
4. CS Process[5][6]4. CS ProcessExecuting Customer Success with Structure and ConsistencyCS Process includes five key blueprints:4.1 Scheduling / Trigger4.2 Discovery Intake4.3 Assessment Intake4.4 Meeting4.5 Initiative (Projects)In SummaryExecuting Customer Success with Structure and ConsistencyThe CS Process discipline defines how Customer Success is executed—when engagements occur, what they include, and how they evolve across maturity levels. It connects strategic intent (Client Goals, CS Health, and Deliverables) with repeatable execution patterns.Process ensures that no client falls through the cracks and that every action, from Discovery to Roadmap delivery, is anchored in the client’s actual business posture, not just a calendar. It enables MSPs to scale engagement, reduce variability, and drive meaningful outcomes, regardless of client segment or CSM capacity.“Process is what ensures nothing slips through the cracks. It turns good intentions into repeatable results.”As clients move up the maturity and appetite quadrant, the CS Process must evolve. Reactive support transforms into insight-driven rhythms. Tactical meetings give way to co-planned initiatives. The CS Process discipline is what keeps the entire CS ecosystem moving in sync—from Discovery to Proposal to Budget—anchored in business relevance.CS Process includes five key blueprints:4.1 Scheduling / TriggerWhat it is: The framework for determining when CS engagements occur and what triggers them is based on cadence, CS Health signals, or business events.How it evolves: From manual check-ins ? to fixed cadences ? to triggered engagements aligned with roadmap reviews, health score changes, or initiative milestones.Why it matters:? Prevents inconsistent engagement and late interventions? Enables just-in-time meetings that reflect business reality? Aligns CS team effort to actual client needs and behaviourHow it connects to the Client Business Goal levels: Segment D clients may need biannual cadences; Segment A clients require monthly reviews tied to roadmaps and KPIs. Scheduling aligns engagement rhythm with quadrant-based priorities and appetite for planning.4.2 Discovery IntakeWhat it is: A structured method for uncovering business context, department needs, and strategic changes—before initiating reports, assessments, or proposals.How it evolves: From ad hoc conversations ? to standardized Discovery templates ? to segmented Discovery workflows based on maturity, appetite, and industry.Why it matters:? Surfaces client-side changes that affect the IT direction? Helps the MSP align technology with business priorities? Enables strategic relevance without requiring constant reinventionHow it connects to the Client Business Goal levels: Discovery uncovers readiness. It ensures MSPs understand where the client wants to go before recommending action. It’s especially critical as clients move from Enablement to Modernization and beyond.4.3 Assessment IntakeWhat it is: The structured scoring and intake of risk, readiness, or maturity across categories are tied directly to initiative design and prioritization.How it evolves: From asset inventories ? to category-based risk reviews ? to milestone-based assessments tied to transformation goals.Why it matters:? Creates objectivity and consistency in recommendations? Justifies project timing and initiative scope? Bridges technical insight with business planningHow it connects to the Client Business Goal levels: Assessment converts Discovery insights into structure. It’s how MSPs move from “what changed” to “what to do about it.” In high-maturity clients, assessments validate timing and investment. In lower segments, they clarify immediate risk.4.4 MeetingThe execution of strategic engagements typically covers Discovery insights, assessment findings, reports, roadmap alignment, and action planning.How it evolves: From issue-focused check-ins ? to QBR-style reviews ? to executive sessions focused on roadmap progress and initiative velocity.Why it matters:? Aligns stakeholders across business and IT? Reinforces trust through structured communication? Moves strategy forward by clarifying what’s nextHow it connects to the Client Business Goal levels: Meetings reflect segmentation. A Segment C meeting may focus on lifecycle risk and budgeting. A Segment A meeting is about OKR alignment and innovation planning. The format adapts, but the structure ensures consistency and progression.4.5 Initiative (Projects)What it is: The packaging of Discovery and Assessment outputs into scoped, named, and budgeted actions, ready for execution and tracking.How it evolves: From loosely defined follow-ups ? to ticketed actions ? to fully scoped initiatives with timelines, ROI framing, and approval triggers.Why it matters:? Turns insight into momentum? Makes value tangible and measurable? Enables roadmap-based delivery planningHow it connects to the Client Business Goal levels: Initiatives are the client’s transformation engine. For lower-maturity clients, initiatives represent targeted fixes. For higher-maturity clients, they become business-aligned programs, defined by department, goal, and projected value.
Definitions: CS Process1. Scheduling/Trigger A clear plan and timeline defining exactly when meetings, reviews, or check-ins with clients should happen. Triggers are specific events or time-based rules that automatically prompt these activities, ensuring consistent and timely engagements.2. Discovery Intake A structured conversation with your client designed to uncover business goals, challenges, and changes. Discovery helps you truly understand what’s important to your client before recommending any actions or projects.3. Assessment Intake A methodical, detailed evaluation of a client's IT environment, focusing on key areas like security, technology adoption, and risk. It validates issues found in discovery, providing clear scores and findings for decision-making.4. Meeting Structured and scheduled sessions with your clients to discuss progress, address issues, and plan next steps. Meetings connect everything—from reports and assessments to proposals and budgets—turning insights into decisions and actions.5. Initiative (Projects) Clearly defined and scoped actions that come from assessments and discovery, designed to address specific problems or opportunities. Initiatives translate strategy into tasks that can be executed and tracked.6. Lifecycle Review A regular check to confirm the client's technology is up-to-date, secure, and aligned with industry standards and best practices. It ensures equipment, software, and services are refreshed at the right times, avoiding unnecessary risks or downtime.7. Quarterly Business Review (QBR) A regularly scheduled strategic meeting (usually quarterly) with the client to review progress, update roadmaps, and align on key business and technology priorities. QBRs help maintain momentum and strategic alignment.8. Health Review Session Meetings specifically focused on discussing customer health metrics (such as engagement, adoption, satisfaction) to identify any risks or opportunities. It ensures client relationships remain strong, healthy, and proactive.9. ClientIQ A structured approach to using data and client-specific insights (industry, business priorities, past engagements) to personalize your conversations, recommendations, and assessments, making them highly relevant and impactful.10. CS Rhythm The consistent, predictable schedule of customer success activities (meetings, reviews, initiatives) tailored to each client segment and maturity. It ensures every client gets the right level of attention and engagement at the right times.In SummaryCS Process is the operational core of the Customer Success system. It transforms goals and insights into scheduled, structured, and actionable workflows that scale. It adapts by segment, client behaviour, and engagement model—ensuring the right actions happen at the right time, in the right way.When fully implemented, the CS Process ensures:? Engagements happen predictably, but flexibly? Discovery and assessments are not skipped or rushed? Meetings drive alignment, not just activity? Initiatives move forward with clarity, confidence, and valueUltimately, CS Process is what makes Customer Success scalable, repeatable, and quadrant-aware—keeping every engagement in rhythm with client readiness, appetite, and business trajectory.
?? 4.1 Scheduling/Trigger
4.1 Scheduling/Trigger OverviewWhat is the objective?Why is it important?As an MSP, why do I need to do this?What is the Customer impact?Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: Cadence matrix by segment = your metronome (one-pager)Concept #2: The 6 triggers that actually scale cadence (date / event / health)Concept #3: Owner-by-role mini-RACI for scheduling (who schedules, who prepares, who backs up)Concept #4: Quality guardrails: prep pack + 2 decisions + recap ≤48hConcept #5: Capacity-aware scheduling for small teamsConcept #6 — Missed-cadence recovery play (1 miss = reschedule; 2 miss = re-engage)Concept #7 — Portfolio radar: 20-minute weekly CS Ops (Past Due / Next 30 Days)Implementation ProcessOperationalizing Strategic Cadence with TriggersStep 1: Publish the Cadence Matrix + mini-RACI (one-time)Step 2: Define Cadence by Segment and Client Business Goal LevelStep 3: Configure and Monitor Triggers to Automate SchedulingStep 4: Align Scheduling with Deliverables and Strategic MilestonesStep 5: Track Cadence Execution and Adjust Based on PerformanceFinal Output: A Structured, Scalable Engagement Rhythm30–60–90 Day Rollout (small CS team)AppendixHow does it connect to the Client Business Goal levels?How does it connect to the other parts?Product Links / Tooling Support
OverviewWhat is the objective?To ensure that client-facing activities—especially strategic meetings—are consistently scheduled based on client segmentation, service tier, and business objectives. Triggers help standardize CS cadence, reduce manual effort, and surface missed opportunities.Why is it important?? Aligns meeting frequency and type with client maturity and appetite? Prevents missed engagements that lead to churn or stalled initiatives? Creates structure and accountability across Customer Success teams? Enables scalable CS delivery without losing personalizationAs an MSP, why do I need to do this?? Increases visibility into client meeting schedules across the team.? Ensures strategic meetings occur at the right frequency per segment (e.g. annual, quarterly).? Reinforces CS value by aligning touchpoints with the client’s maturity and appetite, and therefore their Client Business Goal.? Reduces time spent manually coordinating meetings or recovering from missed ones.What is the Customer impact?? Clients receive the right level of engagement based on their needs, not just reactively.? Builds trust and predictability through consistent communication.? Makes strategic planning more effective when meetings are timely and context-aware.? Reduces confusion and friction when meetings are well-prepared and follow a known rhythm.? Fewer “why are we meeting?” moments: every session arrives with a clear purpose, the last recap, two proposed decisions, and next steps—so approvals happen faster and meetings feel valuable.
Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: Cadence matrix by segment = your metronome (one-pager)Context: Rhythm matters. Timing isn’t admin work; it’s a strategic lever. A clear, segment-based rhythm prevents “too late” or “too often” and keeps planning proactive, not reactive.Typical MSP cases solved? Meetings drift or bunch up at quarter-end; critical reviews happen “when we have time.”? New CSMs/AMs “inherit” chaos; no one knows what good cadence looks like.How to apply1. Publish a one-page cadence matrix in your playbook:? Segment A: Monthly strategy + Quarterly roadmap? Segment B: Quarterly strategy + Semi-annual budget? Segment C: Quarterly review or Semi-annual check-in? Segment D: Semi-annual or Annual operational sync2. Add guardrails to the invite template: agenda, 2 proposed decisions max, prior recap, Health snapshot.3. Track “Coverage Next 30 Days” per segment (target ≥90%).Practical examples? Segment B portfolio view shows QBRs evenly spread across the quarter; no month has >40% of B-segment meetings.Common pitfalls? “One-size-fits-all” cadence; too many exceptions; no scorecard KPI for coverageConcept #2: The 6 triggers that actually scale cadence (date / event / health)Context: Triggers automate cadence. Define conditions (time, lifecycle, change) that automatically create the meeting/task.Typical MSP cases solved? CS spends hours chasing calendars; key sessions happen late or not at all.How to apply? Set six automation rules in PSA/CRM/CS tool. Each rule must create: owner, due-by, invite + prep pack, and a checklist.? Date-based1. Renewal window: planning call 90 days before renewal.2. Fiscal year: budget session 30 days before client year-end.? Event-based1. Assessment completed ? roadmap meeting +10 days.2. Initiative stage change (e.g., from Proposed?Approved) ? delivery kick-off.? Health-based1. Engagement drop (missed 2 touchpoints / no decision in 30 days) ? 30-min reset ≤7 days.2. Adoption below threshold (e.g., MFA<60% / endpoint<80%) ? TAM remediation sync ≤5 days. (Optional: Stakeholder change; Missed-SLA threshold.)Practical examples? After a Cyber assessment, CS tool creates a “Roadmap Validate” meeting for Day+10 with agenda + last recap attached.Common pitfalls? 10+ triggers (noise), triggers without due-by, or “team” as owner (no one acts).Concept #3: Owner-by-role mini-RACI for scheduling (who schedules, who prepares, who backs up)Context: Scheduling creates visibility and accountability across the team.Typical MSP cases solved? “Who owns this client’s cadence?” “Who sends the invite?” Silence.How to apply? Add Cadence Owner on each account (AM/CSM).? Consulted: vCIO (A/B strategy), TAM (C/D lifecycle).? Back-up: named per account; automatic reassignment during absence.? Scorecards: % on-time scheduling, exec sponsor seen ≤120 days coverage.Practical examples? If Cadence Owner is out, back-up receives auto task to send invites within 24h.Common pitfalls? “The team” listed as owner; no back-up; no scorecard linkage.Concept #4: Quality guardrails: prep pack + 2 decisions + recap ≤48hContext: Meetings are where deliverables converge; decisions move roadmaps; governance checks they happened.Typical MSP cases solved? Technically fine delivery but clients feel lost; QBRs log activity, not decisions.How to apply? Prep pack auto-attached to every strategic invite: 1-screen Business Outcomes Snapshot, last recap, Health snapshot, max two proposed decisions.? Track two KPIs: % meetings with recap ≤48h (≥95%); % meetings with ≥1 logged decision (≥70%).? Apply QBR credit gate: count expansion only if owner + date + budget are captured.Practical examples? Recap template: “What we decided / Why now / Owner & date / Risks / Next cadence.”Common pitfalls? Slide parades; “verbal approvals” with no artefact; skipping the recap.Concept #5: Capacity-aware scheduling for small teamsContext — kept from the current text: Cadence follows segmentation and signals investment; to scale, match rhythm to capacity (original “Cadence Follows Segmentation—and Signals Investment”). Typical MSP cases solved? vCIO calendar overloaded in Week 12; nothing earlier moved.How to apply? Set weekly slot limits: e.g., vCIO ≤8 strategic meetings/week; CSM batch days (Tue/Thu).? Enforce 80% rule to leave room for follow-ups and prep.? No double-booking; avoid all-hands Fridays.Practical examples? Portfolio view warns if a role is >90% booked next week; auto-rebalances B/C meetings.Common pitfalls? Hero mode scheduling; every day open for everything; ignoring prep time.Concept #6 — Missed-cadence recovery play (1 miss = reschedule; 2 miss = re-engage)Context — kept from the current text: Without Health tracking, cadence falls apart; use signals to protect the rhythm (original “Without Health Tracking, Cadence Falls Apart”).Typical MSP cases solved? Repeatedly skipped QBRs; engagement quietly decays.How to apply? 1 missed session ? auto-reschedule within 7 days.? 2 consecutive misses ? create CTA: Re-engage Stakeholders (First-Action SLA ≤72h).? 3 misses ? segmentation & cadence review; consider cadence downgrade or executive reset.Practical examples? Watchlist widget: “Past-due strategic sessions” with owner and next date.Common pitfalls? Treating misses as harmless; no escalation path; waiting for renewal to fix it.Concept #7 — Portfolio radar: 20-minute weekly CS Ops (Past Due / Next 30 Days)Context: Health and cadence must be monitored as a system; leadership needs a line of sight.Typical MSP cases solved? Leaders find out about slipped cadences only when CX drops or renewal nears.How to apply? Run a 20-minute weekly CS Ops huddle:? Top 10 past-due strategic meetings; assign owners and dates.? Next 30 days load by role; rebalance if >90%.? Review trigger efficacy; retire noisy rules; tune thresholds.? Track time-to-first-action on cadence misses (≤72h target).Practical examples? Heatmap by segment (A/B/C/D) shows cadence coverage, recap ≤48h, exec sponsor seen ≤120 days.Common pitfalls? Only looking backwards; no CTA closure; never pruning bad triggers.
Implementation ProcessOperationalizing Strategic Cadence with TriggersThe Scheduling/Trigger Implementation Process ensures that all Customer Success (CS) engagements—especially strategic meetings—occur at the right time, with the right depth, for the right client. This cadence-based model replaces ad hoc coordination with a structured rhythm aligned to segmentation, business goals, and health metrics. It enables the CS system to scale while preserving personalization and strategic value.Step 1: Publish the Cadence Matrix + mini-RACI (one-time)What this adds: Before you start, publish a one-page matrix that lists the meeting rhythm per segment (A/B/C/D) and a mini-RACI for scheduling (Cadence Owner / Consulted / Back-up).Definition of Done: Matrix shared in your playbook; every account has a named Cadence Owner and Back-up.Default role map: A/B ? vCIO = Accountable; AM = Consulted; CSM/TAM = Consulted; Back-up = AM. C/D ? CSM = Accountable; TAM = Responsible; AM = Consulted; Back-up = TAM.Step 2: Define Cadence by Segment and Client Business Goal LevelBegin by assigning meeting frequency based on client maturity and appetite. Use segmentation and Business Goal levels to determine the rhythm:SegmentGoal LevelRecommended CadenceA5Monthly strategy + quarterly roadmapB3–4Quarterly strategy + semi-annual budgetC2–3Quarterly review or semi-annual check-inD1–2Semi-annual or ad hoc operational syncMatch cadence to:? Engagement strategy and initiative planning cycles? Reporting and budgeting rhythms? Stakeholder roles (e.g., vCIO vs. AM vs. CSM involvement)Strategic cadence is a resource signal. Over-servicing low-engagement clients wastes capacity; under-engaging high-value clients increases churn risk.Do this (practical):? Record the next strategic meeting date for every account according to the matrix.? Make cadence visible on a shared calendar/board.Definition of Done / KPI:? Portfolio “Next 30 days coverage” ≥ 90% (each account has a booked strategic session in the next 30 days).Step 3: Configure and Monitor Triggers to Automate SchedulingUse repeatable trigger conditions to schedule meetings and CS touchpoints:? Date-based triggers: Schedule based on calendar milestones like renewal dates, fiscal year-end, or roadmap checkpoints.1. Renewal ?90 days ? Schedule Renewal/Strategy review (+ auto-CTA).2. Fiscal year-end ?30 days ? Budget planning session (+ auto-CTA).? Event-based triggers: Initiate meetings after a completed Assessment, major incident, or key Discovery insight.3. Assessment completed +10 days ? Roadmap review (+ auto-CTA).5. Initiative Approved ? Delivery kick-off / handoff (+ auto-CTA).? Health-based triggers: Re-engage clients after Engagement or Adoption scores drop.5. Engagement drop (missed 2 touchpoints or no decision in 30 days) ? Re-engage session (+ auto-CTA).6. Adoption under threshold (e.g., MFA <60% or endpoint <80%) ? Remediation planning (+ auto-CTA).For each client, define:? Meeting types (Strategic Review, Roadmap Sync, Budget Planning)? Roles required (TAM, AM, vCIO)? Prep requirements (Reports, Assessments, Proposals)These triggers reduce friction, reinforce strategic structure, and help managers oversee cadence consistency.Practical rule: ? Every trigger auto-creates (a) the meeting invite and (b) a CTA with owner + due date (first-action SLA ≤ 72h).? Manual fallback: If automation isn’t available, every trigger lands in a Trigger Queue table; it’s processed in Weekly CS Ops – Cadence Radar; first-action SLA ≤ 72h still applies.Definition of Done / KPIs: ? Trigger coverage = 100% (each active client has the six triggers configured or appears in the manual queue); Trigger first-action ≤ 72h ≥ 95%.? Monthly trigger smoke-test completed (all six fires at least once in the sandbox or on a pilot account).Step 4: Align Scheduling with Deliverables and Strategic MilestonesCadence is only effective when timed with meaningful client-facing content. Ensure each scheduled meeting is:? Anchored to content: Initiatives, Reports, Budgets, Assessments? Role-aware: Tailored to executive, operational, or tactical audiences? Health-informed: Adjusted based on CS Health trends, appetite shifts, or maturity changesScheduling is not a calendar exercise—it is a trigger for momentum. This alignment turns every scheduled meeting into a launchpad for execution.Meeting Quality Guardrails (keep it simple):? Prep pack attached to the invite: 1-screen Business Outcomes Snapshot + Health snapshot.? Bring max 2 decisions (two asks) to each strategic meeting.? Send recap ≤ 48h using your standard template.? Apply the QBR credit gate before counting expansion (owner + date + budget).Definition of Done / KPIs:? Recap ≤ 48h ≥ 95%; ≥1 logged decision ≥ 70% of strategic meetings.? % meetings with prep pack attached ≥ 95%.Step 5: Track Cadence Execution and Adjust Based on PerformanceUse cadence logs, segment filters, and meeting history to flag overdue clients, identify risk, and adjust frequency based on maturity or initiative velocity.Implement governance checkpoints:? Are strategic meetings occurring on time by segment?? Are preparation materials delivered consistently?? Are Engagement and Alignment scores reflecting meeting quality?Add three lightweight routines:1. Weekly CS Ops “Cadence Radar” (20 min)? Review Past due, Next 30 days, and noisy triggers; rebalance load by role.? Output: updated invites, cleared blockers, clean trigger queue.2. Missed-Cadence Recovery Play? 1 miss ? auto-rebook ≤ 7 days.? 2 in a row ? Re-engage CTA (first-action ≤ 72h).? 3 in a row ? segmentation/cadence review at the next governance check.3. Capacity Guardrails for small teams? Weekly slot limits per role (e.g., vCIO ≤ 8 strategic sessions/week).? Use “batch days” for strategic meetings; keep average role load <85%.Definition of Done / Portfolio KPIs:? Past-due trend ?; Exec sponsor seen coverage (≤120 days): A/B ≥ 90%, C/D ≥ 75%. ?; role load <85%.Final Output: A Structured, Scalable Engagement RhythmAt the end of this process, every client should have a segment-appropriate cadence with visible meeting triggers; engagements are timely, role-specific, and tied to outcomes; CS Health improves as rhythm stabilizes.Shared KPI set (track monthly):? Coverage (Next 30 days) ≥ 90%? Recap ≤ 48h ≥ 95%? Time-to-First-Action on trigger CTAs ≤ 72h? Exec sponsor “seen” coverage (≤120 days)? ≥1 logged decision ≥ 70% of strategic meetings? Count of past-due strategic meetings (downward trend)30–60–90 Day Rollout (small CS team)? Days 1–30: Step 0–2 live (matrix, mini-RACI, 6 triggers); Coverage ≥ 80%.? Days 31–60: Step 3 + 4a live (guardrails + weekly radar); Recap ≤48h ≥ 90%.? Days 61–90: Step 4b–4c live (recovery + capacity); KPIs stable; fine-tune thresholds.
AppendixHow does it connect to the Client Business Goal levels?LevelRole of Scheduling/Trigger1.1 Technology SupportBasic, ad-hoc, or operational check-ins are often conducted monthly or in response to incidents.1.2 Technology EnablementIntroduces regular quarterly or annual review cadences.1.3 Technology ModernizationQuarterly strategic meetings become standard.1.4 Business TransformationSegmented meetings by role (e.g. vCIO annual, CSM quarterly) to execute cross-departmental initiatives.1.5 Business InnovationStrategic planning syncs with OKRs, department-level planning, and innovation reviews.How does it connect to the other parts?? 1. Client Business Goal - Scheduling is derived from the client’s goal level. Higher-maturity clients require more structured and multi-layered engagement cadences, while lower-maturity clients benefit from simple operational check-ins.? 2. Customer Success Health - Engagement frequency and missed meetings are key indicators in the Health Score. Scheduling discipline supports stronger engagement and reduces blind spots.? 3. Customer Success Delivery - Scheduling triggers ensure reports, proposals, strategies, and roadmaps are prepared and presented promptly, aligning deliverables with business timelines.? 4. Customer Success Process - Scheduling is the foundation of the CS process, triggering discovery, intake, meetings, and initiatives in the proper sequence, at the right time.? 6. Customer Success People - Supports oversight for AMs, CSMs, and vCIOs by making meeting accountability visible. Helps managers assess customer service (CS) load, consistency, and follow-through.? 7. Customer Success Strategy - Tied to segmentation and standard operating procedures (SOPs). Meeting cadence, frequency, and type are determined based on segment tier and CS maturity model.Product Links / Tooling SupportLMx Meeting Scheduler and Meeting Management features support:? Preparing the agenda, materials, and tracking follow-ups within the meeting recordThese tools enable proactive, scalable scheduling while ensuring each client receives the appropriate rhythm of engagement based on their segment and business profile.
?? 4.2 Discovery Intake
4.2 Business Discovery IntakeOverviewWhat is the objective?Why is it important?As an MSP, why do I need to do this?What is the Customer impact?Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: Discovery Is a Segment-Aware PlaybookConcept #2: Sync Discovery to Engagement CadenceConcept #3: Ask Across Three Dimensions—Don’t Just Talk TechConcept #4: Discovery Builds Trust—If You Show Up to Learn, Not SellConcept #5: Discovery Prepares the Ground for Everything ElseConcept #6: Do’s and Don’ts of Discovery ConversationsImplementation ProcessMaking Discovery Intake Strategic and RepeatableStep 1: Prepare Strategically by Segment and Goal LevelStep 2: Guide the Discovery Conversation Across 3 DimensionsStep 3: Translate Discovery into Action and IntegrationFinal Output: A Segment-Aware Discovery Process That Powers the CS LifecycleProduct ConceptSimplify by Client ArchetypesHow we recommend doing it (product adoption)LMx Business Discovery Tool Adoption ProcessHow we recommend implementing it (methodology implementation)CS Adoption ProcessAppendixHow does it connect to the other parts?Product Links / Tooling Support
OverviewWhat is the objective?To uncover recent or upcoming changes in the client’s business environment by asking structured, high-value questions across Business, Enablement, and Technology dimensions. Discovery Intake is the first and most segment-aware strategic intake—it sets the direction for all future customer service (CS) actions.Why is it important?Discovery is the starting point of every strategic customer service (CS) engagement. It helps MSPs move beyond tickets and reports by exploring what the client values. Its structure, depth, and format must align with the client's segment, Business Goal level, and engagement cadence. The goal isn’t to track change for its own sake, but to deeply understand: ? What outcomes matter to the client ? What’s holding them back ? How to bridge technology and business objectives. This opens the door to relevance and positions the MSP as a business advisor. When ambiguity or misalignment is uncovered, the next step is to narrow the scope with a structured Assessment. This is the Inverted Bow Tie model: Discovery opens the scope, Assessment closes it. As an MSP, why do I need to do this?Because strategic partnerships aren’t built on assumptions. Discovery Intake provides the critical visibility and strategic context that informs CS Health scoring, Client Business Goal segmentation, and playbook activation. It also helps overcome the discomfort MSPs often feel when shifting from technical comfort zones to business dialogue. Done correctly: ? Discovery becomes a segment-aware playbook, not just a loose conversation ? Timing and depth sync with Engagement Strategy and scheduling triggers ? Initiatives, Reports, Proposals, and Budgets all start from here What is the Customer impact?Clients feel truly understood, not just supported. When Discovery is done right:? Conversations shift from systems to strategy? Priorities become clearer, faster? Planning becomes collaborative, not prescriptive. Clients in high-maturity or strategic segments expect structured, proactive discovery sessions. Clients in lower-touch tiers may benefit from shorter, more focused formats.
Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: Discovery Is a Segment-Aware PlaybookDiscovery isn’t one-size-fits-all—it’s how you show clients you understand their time, context, and growth potential. Segment A clients might expect multi-stakeholder strategy sessions. Segment C or D might just need a brief conversation or an async form. The proper format depends on the client’s maturity (how standardized and scalable their tech is) and appetite (how willing they are to engage and improve). These two factors define their Client Business Goal level, which shapes the tone, depth, and structure of your Discovery. Done right, Discovery earns trust by respecting the client's stage and making your questions feel relevant, not random.It also provides essential inputs into CS Health scoring, surfacing early indicators of Engagement strength, Alignment potential, and even shifts in client appetite. These signals should be captured and fed into the CS Health system for trend analysis and prioritization.Concept #2: Sync Discovery to Engagement CadenceDiscovery works best when it’s built into your rhythm, not bolted on as an extra. Whether it’s part of a quarterly roadmap review or tied to an annual renewal, use your Engagement Strategy to determine how often Discovery should happen—and your Scheduling/Trigger tools to make it automatic. Done right, Discovery becomes a habit that keeps CS aligned and insightful.More importantly, regular Discovery becomes a structural CS Health safeguard, ensuring that Alignment and Engagement trends don’t drift over time. It helps MSPs proactively surface change signals before they become risk events.Concept #3: Ask Across Three Dimensions—Don’t Just Talk TechDiscovery isn’t about diving straight into patch schedules or backups. To add value, you need a 360° view of the business. That means exploring three core dimensions:? Business Topics – What are the client’s goals, growth plans, or upcoming challenges?? Enablement Topics – Where Are Processes Stuck? What’s slowing down teams or departments?? Technology Topics – What infrastructure risks or opportunities are emerging?A well-rounded Discovery balances all three. If you skip the business or process side, you’ll miss the context behind tech needs. And if you only discuss technology, your conversations remain stuck in the past, rather than planning for the future.These three areas feed directly into CS Health metrics: Business and Enablement topics often reveal Alignment opportunities, while Technology topics may point to Adoption gaps or Service Quality risks. Discovery makes these dimensions visible and trackable.Concept #4: Discovery Builds Trust—If You Show Up to Learn, Not SellDiscovery only works when it feels safe and valuable for the client. That means showing up with curiosity, not a hidden agenda. Start every session by making your intent clear: “We’re here to learn, not to pitch. The better we understand what’s changing, the better we can support you.”This slight shift breaks down defences and opens the door to honest answers. Clients become collaborators, not targets.Skip the sales pitch. Lead with questions. Then listen. That’s how Discovery becomes the start of something strategic, not just another meeting.These early-stage signals of openness and responsiveness are meaningful contributors to Engagement Health. Governance and Enablement should both ensure that CS teams are trained and measured on Discovery quality, not just completion.Concept #5: Discovery Prepares the Ground for Everything ElseDiscovery is the one part of the CS process where you don’t need to fix anything—you just need to listen. It’s not about providing answers; it’s about surfacing the right questions. When you slow down, let the client speak, and ask open-ended, layered questions, you uncover the deeper “why” behind their needs—the part they may not even know how to articulate.That “why” becomes the foundation for everything else: better assessments, clearer proposals, smoother approvals. Discovery isn’t the project—it’s the prep work that makes every future step easier.Think of it like gardening: you don’t plant strategy into hard soil. You still get it first. Discovery is how you earn trust, reduce surprises, and prepare clients to say yes when it matters most.It's also where CS Health measurement starts. If Discovery is skipped or shallow, every downstream metric—Engagement, Alignment, and Adoption—becomes distorted.Concept #6: Do’s and Don’ts of Discovery ConversationsDiscovery isn’t a script—it’s a mindset. Clients don’t want a checklist; they want to feel understood. That’s why the best Discovery conversations feel natural, not clinical. You’re not cross-examining them—you’re uncovering what matters, together.Do:? Ask open-ended questions across Business, Enablement, and Technology topics.? Tailor language to the client’s role, industry, and comfort level.? Listen for signs of change, such as new hires, shifting goals, or emerging roadblocks.? Summarize what you hear and show how you’ll use that insight.? Tag Discovery insights as inputs into CS Health, especially where appetite, risk, or value alignment are discussed.Don’t:? Jump into initiatives or solutions too early.? Stick rigidly to a template without adapting to the client’s mood or responses.? Ask only about services you already deliver—it limits the conversation to the past.? Skip the notes. If you don’t document it, it didn’t happen.? Ignore weak or absent Discovery signals—they can forecast future CS Health degradation, and should trigger Governance follow-up.A great Discovery feels like a thoughtful conversation, not a disguised sales pitch. It builds relevance, reveals opportunity, and sets the tone for a collaborative future.And when captured consistently, it feeds the CS Health system with the most reliable data on client change, intent, and alignment.
Implementation ProcessMaking Discovery Intake Strategic and RepeatableThe Discovery Implementation Process transforms casual client check-ins into structured, segment-aware conversations that reveal business priorities, uncover hidden risks, and guide downstream Customer Success actions. This process ensures Discovery is not ad hoc—it becomes the insight engine for CS Health, segmentation, initiative planning, and strategic alignment.This process enables:? Structured Discovery conversations across all segments? Role-based ownership and preparation? A scalable method to surface change and unlock relevance across the portfolioThis turns Discovery into the most repeatable and robust signal in Customer Success—feeding segmentation, alignment, and initiative planning with clarity and confidence.
Product ConceptSimplify by Client ArchetypesDiscovery Intake is how MSPs learn a client's current level of operation—by asking the right questions, not guessing. It helps define their maturity (readiness to change) and appetite (willingness to act), which together determine the Client Business Goal.The questions you ask—and the language you use—should shift based on this level. Think of it as progressive depth:C - EducateStrategic and structured questions across departments and workflows. Discovery supports deeper strategic planning.A - TransformHigh-impact, high-engagement questions about innovation, OKRs, market positioning, and emerging technologies.D - SustainLow-impact, operational questions. Focus on short-term issues and tactical support.B - ModernizeHigh-impact, strategic questions. The client shows an appetite but may lack full maturity. Discovery helps build a shared language.Discovery doesn’t just gather information—it aligns tone, focus, and expectation to the client’s current state.
How we recommend doing it (product adoption) Create structured conversations that reveal the client’s current goals, pain points, and opportunities, mapped to their Business Goal level. The process consists of four key milestones—each designed to ensure discovery is relevant, actionable, and consistently drives strategic follow-up.Milestone 1: Schedule a Discovery Meeting[7]The first milestone is about laying a strong foundation: you begin by enriching your understanding of the client and their industry. Before any meeting, it’s essential to go beyond basic facts—leverage automated enrichment to gather industry trends, company background, decision-maker profiles, and current initiatives. With this context, you then determine the most relevant CS Strategy quadrant for the client (maturity–appetite), which will shape the style and focus of your discovery. Only then do you finalize the core client information—validating details such as business size, leadership, locations, and technology stack. This preparation ensures that when you schedule the meeting, you can position it as a strategic business conversation, not just a routine check-in.Milestone 2: Prepare & Conduct the Discovery MeetingWith context in hand, the second milestone is all about the quality of the conversation. The tool provides you with a tailored set of high-impact discovery questions, customized to the client’s industry, business profile, and strategic context. During the meeting, your job is to use these questions to guide the discussion across three core dimensions: business goals, enablement/process, and technology posture. The objective is not just to collect surface-level answers, but to go deeper—probing for underlying drivers, change signals, and pain points. It is highly recommended that all insights be captured in a structured, standardized note format. This ensures that no information is lost and all insights can contribute to future planning.Milestone 3: Capture Business GoalsThis milestone is where insight becomes structure. After the conversation, you review the discovery canvas—a visual summary that integrates all client, industry, and meeting data—and use it to extract the main business goals, thematic topics, and initiative opportunities that have emerged. Rather than just saving raw notes, you explicitly categorize each point: what does the client ultimately want to achieve, what business areas or challenges are involved, and what concrete initiatives or follow-ups can move things forward? This transforms unstructured dialogue into actionable CS intelligence that powers roadmap planning, playbook selection, and client segmentation.Milestone 4: Write the Follow-Up and Close the LoopThe final milestone ensures discovery doesn’t end as an isolated event. Here, you organize your notes, validate your takeaways with the client, and send a clear, client-friendly summary of business goals, topics, and next steps. This summary might include a proposed roadmap, initiative recommendations, or the need for a targeted assessment. Crucially, you always schedule the next engagement—whether a project review, roadmap planning, or assessment session—ensuring that every insight leads to concrete action. By following up, you close the loop, demonstrating to the client that discovery leads directly to strategic progress and accountability.LMx Business Discovery Tool Adoption ProcessSmart Goal:"Run your first Business Discovery Meeting, Capture Business Goals, and send a Follow-up to a client."This process is designed to help MSPs confidently adopt the LMx Business Discovery Tool by guiding them through a structured, repeatable engagement.
