2. Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: Value-First Expansion, Not Product PushEvery upsell must solve a named business problem (risk, compliance, productivity, growth). Tie to Discovery insight or Assessment finding; speak in outcomes, not line items.Concept #2: Signal-Driven PipelineCreate expansion from signals: Health dips (risk), adoption gaps, lifecycle/EOL, compliance/insurance asks, exec priorities, usage anomalies, roadmap dependencies. Log each signal with source + date.Concept #3: Two-Lane Upsell (OpEx vs. CapEx) Matched to Segment? OpEx lane (licenses, services): lighter scoping; great for D/C.? CapEx/Project lane (platforms, refresh, migrations): phased proposals; fit B/A. Depth and storytelling scale with segment + spend type.Concept #4: Decision Hygiene = Price-Test ? Pre-Approval ? Proposal? Price-test: “Peers solved this for $8–12k—viable this quarter?”? Pre-approval (log Owner + Quarter + Budget band).? Build the proposal only after the gate is met; front it with an Executive Decision Sheet (Problem/Why now, 1–2 options, Impact, Risks/Assumptions, Owner & target date).Concept #5: Roadmap + Budget Are the SpineNo orphans: every upsell item must sit on the Roadmap and in the Budget. Version both as decisions evolve (v1?v2 notes).Concept #6: Proposal Velocity = Health SignalTrack time-to-first-action ≤ 72h, aging buckets (0–14d/15–30d/>30d), win rate by segment, median days-to-approval, decline reason capture ≥ 90%. Stalls trigger Re-engage or At Risk play.Concept #7: Two Decisions MaxIn any strategic session, surface two upsell decisions only. More ? backlog & roadmap.
3. Implementation ProcessStep 1: Capture & Qualify Signals (Continuous)? Sources: Reports, Assessments, Health trends, Lifecycle, Security/Insurance, Exec asks.? CSM/TAM logs the signal with client language; tag lane (OpEx/CapEx), urgency, dependency.Step 2: Price-Test & Appetite Check (T+0–3 days from signal)? Float range (or unit economics for OpEx).? If “yes, if under X and in QY,” record pre-approval (Owner + Quarter + Budget band).? If “not now,” re-sequence on roadmap and note reason.Step 3: Place on Roadmap & Budget (Same day)? Create/adjust Roadmap card (quarter, lane, impact tag).? Add to Budget Forecast with band and decision flag; version note (“added per audit”).Step 4: Build the Proposal (Segment-calibrated)? A/B: deck-style proposal with outcomes/ROI, phased plan, risks/assumptions, OKR tie.? C/D: slim summary embedded in meeting notes + e-sign ready.? Lead with Executive Decision Sheet (max 2 options).Step 5: Present in Context (Next strategic/tactical touchpoint)? Open with Executive Snapshot (Outcomes, mini-Health ?, two asks).? Confirm Owner + target date + budget in writing before “expansion credit.”Step 6: Recap & First Actions (Post ≤ 48h / ≤ 72h)? Recap email ≤ 48h (decisions, owners, dates, risks, versions).? Open CTA ≤ 72h (proposal acceptance, PO, kickoff prep).? Link Proposal ? Initiative ID ? Project in PSA/PM.Step 7: Portfolio Governance (Monthly)? Review KPIs: win rate, median days-to-approval, % proposals with decline reason ≥ 90%, % proposals linked to Roadmap ID = 100%, time-to-first-action ≤ 72h, aging distribution.? Plays: >30d stale ? reset session (offer 2 options: now vs next quarter); >60d ? auto-close or re-sequence with logged reason.Common Pitfalls & Fixes? Scoping before appetite. ? Always price-test first.? Ten options. ? Two options max.? No written owner/date/budget. ? Don’t count credit; hold until artifacts exist.? Orphan proposals. ? Roadmap/Budget link is mandatory.
4. AppendixHow does it connect to the Client Business Goal levels?? 1.1 Technology Support (D): Small OpEx upsells (backup coverage, AV, patching); async summary; minimal proposal.? 1.2 Technology Enablement (C): Hygiene projects (MFA, onboarding fixes, BCDR validation); slim proposal + budget band.? 1.3 Technology Modernization (B): Lifecycle refresh, stack consolidation, cloud moves; phased proposals; OpEx/CapEx budget split.? 1.4 Business Transformation (A): Department outcomes (collab redesign, automation, data governance); ROI framing; multi-phase.? 1.5 Business Innovation (A): OKR-linked initiatives (AI/BI pilots, CX/EX programs); co-planning; portfolio cadence.How does it connect to the other parts?? CS Deliverables? Reports (3.1): Surface signals and track decision outcomes.? Proposals (3.2): The Upsell artifact; Executive Decision Sheet first.? Budgets (3.3): Holds bands, quarters, and decision flags; versioned.? Client Strategy (3.4): Frames why this initiative matters now.? Roadmap (3.5): Mandatory anchor; shows sequencing and dependencies.? CS Health? Proposal velocity, decline reasons, pre-approval aging feed Engagement/Alignment/Adoption scoring and At Risk triggers.? CS People? A/B: vCIO presents; AM frames budget; CSM/TAM records.? C/D: CSM/TAM presents; AM supports renewals/licensing; PM readies delivery.? CS Process? Upstream: Engagement provides the stage and decisions.? Downstream: At Risk uses stalls/declines to trigger re-engage plays; Delivery executes won initiatives.Product Links / Tooling Support? LMx Quoter Proposal: Templates, executive front-sheet, e-signature.? LMx Budget Forecast: Quarter bands, OpEx/CapEx split, decision flags, version notes.? LMx Recommendation Roadmap: Drag/drop to quarters; export snapshot for recaps.? LMx Executive Report Builder: Pull signals; show Snapshot + two asks.? LMx Client Health: Track proposal velocity, pre-approval aging, decline reasons; trigger plays.? Report Locker: Archive proposals, recaps, and versions for auditability.
?? 4.5. At Risk
4.5. At Risk1. OverviewWhat is the objective?Why is it important?As an MSP, why do I need to do this?What is the Customer impact?2. Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: Risk Is a Signal, Not a SurpriseConcept #2: Classify Before You Fix (4 Risk Buckets)Concept #3: Two-Horizon Save Plan (Containment ? Correction)Concept #4: Decision-First EscalationConcept #5: Segment-Calibrated ResponseConcept #7: Close the Loop in Health & Governance3. Implementation ProcessStep 1: Detect & Log the Risk (Day 0)Step 2: Stabilize (Days 0–3)Step 3: Executive Re-Engage & Two Decisions (Days 2–5)Step 4: Publish the Save Plan (≤ 48h after meeting)Step 5: Execute & Communicate (Weeks 1–8)Step 6: Governance & Escalation PathsStep 7: Exit to Green + Lessons LearnedCommon Pitfalls & Fixes4. AppendixHow does it connect to the Client Business Goal levels?How does it connect to the other parts?Product Links / Tooling Support
1. OverviewWhat is the objective?Detect, classify, and resolve risk conditions early—stabilizing delivery, restoring trust, and returning the account to a healthy cadence with a clear, measurable Save Plan.Why is it important?Without a disciplined At Risk motion, small issues compound into churn: aging proposals, missed meetings, scope drift, or sentiment dips. A signal-driven, decision-first play prevents surprises and preserves lifetime value.As an MSP, why do I need to do this?? Predictable retention: Convert leading indicators into fast mitigation.? Portfolio control: Standard scoring and SLAs let leaders prioritize where to intervene.? Learning loop: Root causes feed Process, People, Strategy improvements.? Commercial clarity: When remediation requires spend, it flows through Roadmap, Budget, Proposal—no hidden work.What is the Customer impact?? Faster acknowledgments, clear owners, and visible progress.? A concise Save Plan that distinguishes immediate containment from structural fixes.? Fewer escalations; restored confidence in cadence, quality, and outcomes.
2. Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: Risk Is a Signal, Not a SurpriseDefine objective triggers. Examples (any one can flag At Risk):? Engagement: Missed two consecutive strategic meetings; no roadmap movement ≥ 120 days (A/B) or ≥ 180 days (C); champion left.? CX: CSAT < 4.0 for month or 2+ detractor tickets in 30 days; NPS detractor.? Quality: SLA breach trend 2 cycles; backlog aging > 30 days; repeat incidents.? Alignment: Proposal > 30 days stale with no decision; decline reason “relevance/timing” recurring; budget variance > 20%.? Compliance/Security: Insurance/compliance ask unmet; unresolved P1/P2 post-mortem actions. Log trigger + date in Client Health and open the play.Concept #2: Classify Before You Fix (4 Risk Buckets)? Service Risk (tickets/SLA).? Delivery Risk (projects/hand-offs).? Strategic Risk (cadence/roadmap/budget misalignment).? Financial Risk (AR dispute, scope mismatch). Severity = Impact ? Likelihood ? pick containment window and comms level.Concept #3: Two-Horizon Save Plan (Containment ? Correction)? H1 (0–14 days): Stop the bleeding (stabilize service, assign owners, pause scope creep).? H2 (15–60 days): Structural fixes (process, roles, roadmap/budget resets). Each action must show Owner + Date + Budget (or Action).Concept #4: Decision-First EscalationOpen the conversation with an Executive Snapshot: What changed (facts), mini-Health ?, top risks, two decisions max (e.g., “Approve capacity buffer for 60 days” and “Move Endpoint Refresh to Q3”).Concept #5: Segment-Calibrated Response? A/B: Live executive session within 5 business days; monthly progress until green.? C: Hybrid (live + short summary video); simplify asks to 1–2 corrective actions.? D: Async acknowledgment + clear service fixes; avoid heavy strategy until stable.Concept #6: Evidence Over NarrativeTie every claim to Deliverables: ticket analytics, assessment excerpts, roadmap status, budget variance, proposal aging. Store artifacts in Report Locker.Concept #7: Close the Loop in Health & GovernanceRisk open/close affects Engagement, Alignment, Quality, Adoption, CX scores. Quarterly governance reviews trend risks, root causes, and time-to-green.
3. Implementation ProcessStep 1: Detect & Log the Risk (Day 0)? Auto/Manual triggers from Client Health, Reports, PM, AR.? Classify bucket(s) + severity; assign CSM/TAM (owner) and Exec Sponsor.? SLA: Acknowledge to client within 4 business hours (High) / 1 business day (Medium/Low).Step 2: Stabilize (Days 0–3)? Stand up a War Room (internal): Support Lead, PM, CSM/TAM, AM, vCIO/CS Manager.? Containment checklist (selective):? Freeze scope on affected project(s).? Add temporary capacity (after Owner + Date + Budget agreement).? Priority queue for P1/P2; daily brief until stable.? Draft Executive Snapshot (facts only; no blame).? First-action ≤ 72h: open CTAs in PSA (who/what/when).Step 3: Executive Re-Engage & Two Decisions (Days 2–5)? 30–45 min session (A/B live; C live/hybrid; D async + brief call).? Present Executive Snapshot:? What changed vs last meeting; mini-Health with ?.? Root-cause hypothesis (people/process/tech/expectation).? Two decisions (e.g., “Approve 20-hour remediation SOW” and “Reset QBR cadence to monthly for 90 days”).? Gate expansion/credit on written Owner + Date + Budget (or Action).Step 4: Publish the Save Plan (≤ 48h after meeting)? One-pager sections:1. H1 Containment (0–14d).2. H2 Correction (15–60d).3. Risks/Assumptions/Dependencies.4. Version note (v1, v2…).? Distribute recap ≤ 48h; link Roadmap/Budget/Proposals; update Health.Step 5: Execute & Communicate (Weeks 1–8)? Cadence: Weekly progress email; bi-weekly client touch (C/D may be weekly email only).? Keep board current: tickets, milestones, owner status.? If remediation needs spend: raise Proposal (Executive Decision Sheet first) and place it on Roadmap and Budget (no orphans).Step 6: Governance & Escalation Paths? KPIs to track (portfolio & account):? Time-to-acknowledge (target ≤ 4h High).? Time-to-plan (Save Plan published ≤ 5 business days).? Time-to-first-action (≤ 72h).? % actions on time (≥ 90%).? Risk resolution ≤ 30 days (or re-classify with rationale).? Repeat-risk rate within 120 days (aim < 10%).? If no movement 14 days, schedule reset with two new options (now vs next quarter).? If > 60 days open, escalate to leadership; consider contract review.Step 7: Exit to Green + Lessons Learned? Close criteria (pick all that apply):? Health back to baseline or improved for 30 days.? SLA trend normalized 2 cycles.? Approved roadmap/budget reset is in place.? CSAT detractors addressed with follow-up.? Run brief After-Action: root cause taxonomy (People / Process / Tech / Expectation).? Feed improvements to Playbooks, Templates, Role Enablement.Common Pitfalls & Fixes? Hand-wavy updates. ? Publish Save Plan; track CTAs.? Too many “asks.” ? Two decisions max.? Silent proposals. ? Age buckets; >30d triggers reset; log decline reason.? Orphan fixes. ? Everything links to Roadmap/Budget/Proposal/Health.
4. AppendixHow does it connect to the Client Business Goal levels?? 1.1 Technology Support (D): Focus on SLA/ticket stabilization; async summary; no heavy strategy until noise drops.? 1.2 Technology Enablement (C): Fix hygiene gaps (MFA, BCDR validation, onboarding flow); one-page plan; minimal options.? 1.3 Technology Modernization (B): Re-sequence lifecycle/stack initiatives; phased proposals; monthly executive check-ins until green.? 1.4 Business Transformation (A): Cross-department impacts; add KPI/OKR references; monthly strategy reviews during remediation.? 1.5 Business Innovation (A): Protect innovation cadence; portfolio-level Save Plan; steering committee visibility.How does it connect to the other parts?? CS Health (2.x): Triggers, deltas, and closure update Engagement, Alignment, Quality, Adoption, CX; “At Risk” tag appears on account + initiatives.? CS Deliverables (3.x):? Reports: Show trendlines and Save Plan status.? Proposals: Only when remediation needs spend; front with Executive Decision Sheet.? Budgets: Add remediation bands and timing; version notes.? Client Strategy: If strategic risk, publish a snapshot refresh.? Roadmap: Re-sequence items; no orphans.? CS Process: Inputs from Engagement and Upsell aging; outputs feed back to those motions once stabilized.? CS People (5.x):? Owner: CSM/TAM. Presenter: vCIO (A/B) or CSM/TAM (C/D).? Support Lead/PM: containment & delivery. AM: commercial/budget alignment. CS Manager/Exec Sponsor: escalation.Product Links / Tooling Support? LMx Client Health: Risk triggers, watchlist, score deltas, time-to-green.? LMx Executive Report Builder: Executive Snapshot + two decisions; trend visuals.? LMx Recommendation Roadmap: Drag/drop re-sequencing; export snapshot for recaps.? LMx Budget Forecast: Add remediation bands, decision flags, version notes.? LMx Quoter Proposal: Remediation SOWs with executive front sheet; e-signature.? Report Locker: Store Save Plan versions, recaps, post-mortems.
?? 5. CS People
5. CS PeopleOrganizing the Human Side of Customer SuccessCS People includes five key blueprints:5.1. Roles5.2. Responsibilities5.3. Enablement5.4. Compensation5.5. GovernanceIn Summary
Organizing the Human Side of Customer SuccessThe CS People discipline defines how Customer Success is staffed, enabled, and managed. It determines which roles are involved in delivery, how their responsibilities align with client outcomes, how they’re trained and measured, and how the system stays accountable.Great strategy fails without great execution. And execution only scales when the right people are doing the right things, with clarity, consistency, and support. “Behind every initiative, roadmap, or Health Score is a person. CS People is how we make success human, repeatable, and scalable.”As clients move across the quadrant (from low to high Maturity and Appetite), the roles, responsibilities, and oversight mechanisms must adapt. Tactical support teams evolve into strategic engagement teams. Ownership becomes distributed—but must remain coordinated. CS People ensures this evolution happens by design, not by accident.
CS People includes five key blueprints:5.1. RolesWhat it is: The definition and assignment of Customer Success roles are mapped to client segment, business goal level, and CS Deliverables. Typical roles include TAM, CSM, vCIO, Strategic Advisor, and vCXO.How it evolves: From generalist support roles (e.g. owner/operator) ? to specialized functional roles by client tier ? to multi-role orchestration in high-maturity strategic accounts.Why it matters:? Aligns the right person to the right conversation? Prevents role confusion and fragmented client experience? Supports scalable segmentation-based deliveryHow it connects to the Client Business Goal levels:? Level 1–2: TAMs and service staff focus on stability and lifecycle execution? Level 3: AMs and vCIOs deliver standardization, modernization, and roadmaps? Level 4–5: Strategic Advisors and vCXOs drive transformation and innovation, supporting OKRs, department-level initiatives, and annual planning5.2. ResponsibilitiesWhat it is: The outcomes, metrics, and CS Health are areas for which each role is accountable. Responsibilities are mapped to CS Deliverables (3.x), Process steps (4.x), and strategic goals (1.x).How it evolves: From implicit task lists ? to clearly defined KPIs and deliverable ownership ? to full lifecycle accountability across the CS system.Why it matters:? Links individual actions to client progress? Clarifies ownership in collaborative accounts? Makes Health Score data actionable at the role levelHow it connects to the Client Business Goal levels:? Low levels: Focused on SLA performance, CX, DMI, and reactive cadence? Mid-levels: Initiative pacing, reporting, and roadmap coordination? High levels: OKR alignment, cross-departmental planning, and transformation tracking5.3. EnablementWhat it is: The training, tools, and workflows that prepare each CS role to succeed in their context, including methodology, product fluency, and strategic dialogue.How it evolves: From onboarding checklists ? to role-specific templates and playbooks ? to real-time enablement tied to segment cadence and initiative type.Why it matters:? Prevents underdelivery by inexperienced team members? Drives consistency in how CS is executed across accounts? Ensures roles can act confidently at any Business Goal levelHow it connects to the Client Business Goal levels:? Level 1–2: Enablement focuses on lifecycle talk tracks and service alignment? Level 3: Adds roadmap, budget, and proposal delivery support? Level 4–5: Expands to business conversations, strategic facilitation, and department-specific framing5.4. CompensationWhat it is: The incentive models that reward CS roles for driving the right outcomes—blending retention, engagement, initiative execution, and health performance.How it evolves: From fixed salary ? to retention-linked bonuses ? to multi-factor models aligned with Health metrics and Business Goal progress.Why it matters:? Aligns incentives with strategic CS outcomes? Prevents internal misalignment between delivery and revenue? Rewards deep engagement, not just activity volumeHow it connects to the Client Business Goal levels:? Low levels: Compensation tied to service quality, retention, and ticket velocity? Mid-levels: Bonuses tied to roadmap adoption and engagement improvements? High levels: Recognition for strategic co-planning, OKR execution, and cross-functional initiative success? 
Definitions: CS PeopleCS Roles (Role Type)Definition: A general category or type of role that includes all client-facing positions focused on Customer Success—such as TAM, AM, vCIO, vCTO, or vCISO. Role Focus: All CS roles share a common goal: to ensure clients realize business value from their technology investments.1. Technical Account Manager (TAM)Definition: A tactical, technology-focused role responsible for maintaining the client's IT environment and ensuring technical operations are aligned with agreed standards. Role Focus:? Tactical: Addresses day-to-day technology alignment, technical stability, lifecycle management, and compliance.? Technology Focused: Primarily deals with hardware, software, and service delivery, ensuring that the technology works correctly and meets operational standards.2. Account Manager (AM)Definition: A tactical, business-focused role that serves as the main point of contact for clients, managing the ongoing relationship, renewal processes, and client communications. Role Focus:? Tactical: Manages day-to-day relationship interactions, client communications, and service-related issues.? Business Focused: Ensures clients understand the value they’re getting, maintains satisfaction, and coordinates proposals, budgets, and client health reporting.3. Virtual Chief Information Officer (vCIO)Definition: A strategic, business-focused advisory role that helps clients align technology initiatives with their broader business goals and long-term strategy. Role Focus:? Strategic: Focuses on roadmap development, budgeting, and aligning IT with business outcomes, often engaging with executive-level client stakeholders.? Business Focused: Helps clients plan strategically, ensuring technology drives measurable business success and supports long-term transformation.4. Virtual Chief Technology Officer (vCTO)Definition: A strategic, technology-focused advisory role responsible for guiding technology strategy, architecture, and innovation planning for clients. Role Focus:? Strategic: Provides expert guidance on emerging technologies, infrastructure decisions, technology architecture, and long-term innovation planning.? Technology Focused: Focuses on the technical vision, emerging technology, infrastructure evolution, and proactive technology investments that align with business goals.5. Virtual Chief Information Security Officer (vCISO) (Emerging Role)Definition: A strategic and specialized advisory role focused on ensuring that the client's cybersecurity posture meets business, regulatory, and compliance requirements. Role Focus:? Strategic: Guides security strategy, risk management, regulatory compliance, cybersecurity frameworks, and business continuity planning.? Business & Technology Focused: Bridges the gap between technical cybersecurity practices and strategic business risk management, often engaging executive-level stakeholders.GovernanceDefinition: The practice of clearly defining, managing, and overseeing the Customer Success methodology through guiding documents, regular meetings, and performance reporting to ensure consistent delivery and improvement. Key Elements Include:? Guiding Documents: Policies, playbooks, SOPs, and standards that ensure consistency and clarity across the team.? Meeting Cadence: Regularly scheduled check-ins, team reviews, client reviews, and strategic planning sessions.? Reporting & Performance Measurement: Tracking key performance indicators (KPIs), Health Scores, adoption metrics, and CS execution quality to ensure continuous improvement and accountability.Summary of CS Role Types for Easy Reference:RoleTactical/StrategicBusiness/Technology FocusTAMTacticalTechnologyAMTacticalBusinessvCIOStrategicBusinessvCTOStrategicTechnologyvCISOStrategicBusiness & TechnologyNote: In our methodology, "CS" is not a specific individual role—it’s an overarching category (a "Role Type") that includes any client-facing roles designed to drive customer success.
In SummaryCS People defines the talent, structure, and support system behind every MSP's Customer Success execution. It ensures that roles are clear, responsibilities are tied to value, enablement supports performance, compensation aligns effort, and governance keeps the system accountable.When designed and managed effectively:? Engagement becomes segment-aware and outcome-driven? Strategic clients receive strategic coverage—by design, not luck? Health Scores reflect real-world execution, not role confusion? Growth becomes scalable, repeatable, and human-centredIn a quadrant-aware CS model, CS People is the backbone. It translates strategic intent into human action, anchored in the client's maturity, appetite, and evolving business goals.
?? 5.1 Roles & Responsibilities
5.1 Roles & ResponsibilitiesOverviewWhat is the objective?Why is it important?As an MSP, why do I need to do this?What is the Customer impact?Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: Overview of CS RolesConcept #2: Segment-Aware “Responsibility Packs” per Role (A–D)Concept #3: One Owner End-to-End (RACI Accountable) + Named BackupConcept #4: Map Responsibilities to the Right Client StakeholdersConcept #5: Responsibility = Process Ownership (Trigger ? Prep ? Lead ? Follow-Up)Concept #6: Use Health to Tune Responsibilities (Measure ? Signal ? Adjust)Concept #7: Same Logic as You Grow (Small ? Mid ? Large MSP)Implementation ProcessStep 1: Design Roles Based on Client Segments and Business GoalsStep 2: Build the one-page Responsibility Matrix (by segment A–D)Step 3: Assign Role Ownership for Key CS DeliverablesStep 4: Stamp RACI into every meeting and deliverable templateStep 5: Operationalize Roles Through Playbooks and Process AlignmentStep 6: Tie responsibilities to the right stakeholders and cadenceStep 7: Use CS Health as a Feedback Loop to Optimize Role CoverageStep 8: Review Roles Quarterly and Scale with Client & Team MaturityFinal Output: A Role-Aligned Customer Success SystemAppendixHow does it connect to the Client Business Goal levels?Goal Level / Segment Matrix (Owners, Emphasis, Health, Cadence)How does it connect to the other parts?Product Links / Tooling Support
OverviewWhat is the objective?To clearly define who does what in Customer Success—making sure every client segment (A–D) gets the right role coverage, at the right depth, without overlap or confusion. Roles set the “who,” responsibilities set the “what,” and together they create the foundation for a scalable, repeatable Customer Success system.We manage CS to NDR/NRR as the north star, using a Growth Loop of Discover ? Align ? Deliver ? Measure.Why is it important?In most MSPs, people wear multiple hats. Owners, TAMs, AMs, or vCIOs often juggle both tactical and strategic work. Without role clarity, this quickly leads to dropped handoffs, stalled initiatives, or wasted senior time on basic tasks. Defining roles and stamping clear responsibilities ensures:? The right person talks to the right client stakeholder (CEO with vCIO, IT lead with TAM).? Every deliverable (Report, Roadmap, Budget, QBR) has one named Accountable owner and a named Backup.? Engagement scales cleanly from reactive Segment D clients up to strategic Segment A partners.? NRR/NDR links CS execution to revenue outcomes (expansion, contraction, churn) independent of new-logo sales.As an MSP, why do I need to do this?? It prevents firefighting by making ownership visible in day-to-day delivery.? It avoids “random acts of CS,” where nobody knows who owns the next step.? It enables hiring, onboarding, and promotion to follow a clear path (TAM ? CSM/AM ? Advisor ? vCIO).? It allows a small MSP to act like a bigger one—because even if one person holds multiple titles, the RACI logic stays consistent.What is the Customer impact?Clients experience clarity, not confusion. They know exactly who to go to for technical fixes, service reviews, roadmap discussions, or budget approvals. Trust builds faster because meetings run smoother, decisions stick, and follow-through happens reliably. Multi-threaded relationships also reduce risk: if one MSP contact leaves, another already understands the client and can step in.
Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: Overview of CS RolesEffective Customer Success (CS) is pivotal for Managed Service Providers (MSPs) aiming to align technology investments with client business outcomes. 1. Technical Account Manager (TAM)? Type: Tactical | Technology-focused? Core Responsibilities:? Ensuring operational stability, lifecycle management, and technology standards.? Proactive management of client technical infrastructure.? Required Skills? Technical proficiency in IT infrastructure and service delivery.? Strong organization and detail-oriented problem-solving skills.? Familiarity with industry-standard frameworks (e.g., ITIL, lifecycle management).? Job-To-Be-Done? Internal: Ensures operational consistency and technology quality, reducing client incidents.? Client: Provides reliability and proactive technical management, maintaining client confidence.? What makes them successful? Follows technical standards and MSP best practices? Proactively identifies risks and improvement areas? Communicates clearly with both technical and non-technical people? Keeps client systems aligned with lifecycle and compliance goals? What makes them less effective? Reacts to tickets instead of planning proactively? Over-complicates technical recommendations? Avoids client conversations or hides behind tools? Misses structured reviews or cadence
2. Account Manager (AM)? Type: Tactical | Business-focused? Core Responsibilities:? Managing client relationships, renewals, and communication.? Coordinating proposals, budgets, and client satisfaction.? Required Skills? Experience in account management, sales coordination, or customer relationship roles.? Exceptional communication, negotiation, and client relationship management skills.? Comfortable translating technical outcomes into business language.? Job-To-Be-Done? Internal: Ensures account stability, renewals, and effective internal coordination.? Client: Provides clear communication, trusted partnership, and strong relationship management.? What makes them successful? Maintains consistent, high-touch client communication? Understands the business value of renewals and upsells? Coordinates internal delivery teams and sets client expectations? Tracks health, satisfaction, and contract timelines? What makes them less effective? Focuses only on the relationship without strategic impact? Misses renewal dates or fails to grow accounts? Avoids tough conversations about scope or pricing? Lacks awareness of technical delivery status
3. Customer Success Manager (CSM)? Type: Tactical ? Strategic | Business-focused? Core Responsibilities:? Own Customer Health (CX, Engagement, Adoption, Alignment) and keep the cadence (QBR in B/C) on track.? Orchestrate initiatives: capture decisions, create/drive follow-ups, update roadmap/success plan.? Prepare and de-risk Strategy/Executive QBRs for A: pre-work, storyline, outcomes, next steps.? Signal risk early (low engagement/adoption), trigger playbooks, and coordinate internal roles (TAM, vCIO, PM).? Maintain clean records (LMx/CRM): meeting notes, approvals, health changes, stakeholder map.? Required Skills? Facilitation & stakeholder management; business storytelling; light financial literacy (budgets/ROI).? Data literacy on Health/Adoption; strong follow-through and task coordination.? Job-To-Be-Done? Internal: Keep the rhythm and translate Health signals into actions that move the roadmap.? Client: Make meetings valuable, keep promises visible, and turn discussions into approved outcomes.? What makes them successful? Runs a predictable cadence; sends clear summaries and closes actions.? Aligns proposals and initiatives to stated goals; multi-threads relationships.? Keeps LMx/CRM tidy; escalates early when engagement or adoption drops.? What makes them less effective? Over-indexes on slides vs. decisions; misses follow-ups.? Avoids healthy pushback or hard prioritization.? Poor data hygiene; health signals aren’t captured or acted on.? Segment calibration? D/C: Focus on Service Review inputs, basic QBR (C), initiative intake, adoption nudges.? B: Own QBRs, pace initiatives, prep Strategy Planning.? A: Co-pilot Executive QBRs with vCIO; drive exec-level follow-through and cross-dept coordination.
4. Virtual Chief Information Officer (vCIO)? Type: Strategic | Business-focused? Core Responsibilities:? Aligning technology strategy with client business objectives.? Strategic planning, budgeting, and executive engagement.? Required Skills? Proven experience in strategic technology leadership and business alignment.? Deep understanding of business operations and financial planning.? Strong analytical, strategic thinking, and executive presentation abilities.? Job-To-Be-Done? Internal: Drives strategic client growth, translating technical service delivery into business outcomes.? Client: Aligns technology strategy with business objectives, ensuring ROI on technology investments.? What makes them successful? Builds trust with client decision-makers? Creates clear, strategic roadmaps tied to business goals? Plans long-term initiatives and technology budgets? Connects IT strategy to tangible business outcomes? What makes them less effective? Stays too tactical or overlaps with TAM work? Uses too much tech jargon with business leaders? Doesn’t tie roadmap to tangible business benefits? Doesn’t involve clients in roadmap decisions
5. Virtual Chief Technology Officer (vCTO)? Type: Strategic | Technology-focused? Core Responsibilities:? Guiding technology architecture, emerging tech, and infrastructure strategies.? Ensuring proactive technology innovation and long-term infrastructure planning.? Required Skills? Extensive experience with advanced IT architecture, technology evaluation, and innovation planning.? Expertise in emerging technologies, cloud solutions, and infrastructure planning.? Capability to advise and translate complex technology scenarios into clear strategies.? Job-To-Be-Done? Internal: Maintains cutting-edge technology strategies, positioning the MSP as a technology leader.? Client: Provides future-proofed technology guidance, reducing risk and enhancing innovation capabilities.? What makes them successful? Drives innovation and technical strategy? Aligns technology decisions with future business needs? Works closely with vCIO and TAM to balance vision and execution? Leads conversations on AI, integrations, and modernization? What makes them less effective? Gets lost in deep tech or abstract ideas? Avoids client-facing communication? Ignores the practical maturity level of the client? Doesn't align with service and support delivery
+1 Emerging Role: Virtual Chief Information Security Officer (vCISO)? Type: Strategic | Business & Technology-focused? Core Responsibilities:? Leading cybersecurity strategy, risk management, and compliance.? Bridging technical security practices with strategic business outcomes.? Required Skills? Comprehensive background in cybersecurity management, compliance, and risk assessment.? Certification (e.g., CISSP, CISM) and understanding of compliance frameworks (GDPR, HIPAA, ISO 27001, etc.).? Proven capability in strategic security advisory roles.? Job-To-Be-Done? Internal: Strengthens security posture and compliance, and reduces client exposure to cybersecurity threats.? Client: Delivers peace of mind, strategic compliance, and actionable cybersecurity strategies aligned with business risk management.? What makes them successful? Understands industry-specific risks and compliance needs? Builds confidence with clear, calm security advice? Helps clients prioritize and invest wisely in security? Aligns security with business risk and continuity? What makes them less effective? Leads with fear or overly technical language? Focuses only on tools, not business impact? Doesn’t give clear steps or priorities? Works in isolation from the rest of the CS teamConcept #2: Segment-Aware “Responsibility Packs” per Role (A–D)One-size-fits-all role definitions create ambiguity, missed handoffs, and wasted senior time on tactical work. Pack responsibilities by role and segment (4–6 outcome responsibilities per role per segment) so ownership matches client readiness.Segment D (Goal 1 – Technology Support):? TAM/Owner ? SLA rhythm, lifecycle hygiene.? Meeting focus: Service Reviews + Annual IT Strategy Meeting (D).Segment C (Goal 2 – Technology Enablement):? TAM + AM/CSM split: service alignment vs cadence/reporting & initiative intake.? The meeting focus: Service reviews, QBR (C), and annual strategy planning (C).Segment B (Goal 3 – Technology Modernization):? vCIO + CSM ? roadmap, budget framing, initiative pacing.? Meeting focus: QBR (B) and Annual Strategy Planning (B).Segment A (Goals 4–5 – Business Transformation & Innovation):? vCxO/Advisor anchors OKR-linked strategy; CSM runs executive cadence.? Meeting focus: Executive QBR (A) (up to 3/yr if the budget allows it) + Annual Strategy Planning (A).Health focus by segment: D ? Service Quality + baseline Engagement; C ? Adoption + Engagement; B ? Service Level Alignment + Engagement + sustained Adoption; A ? exec-level CX + Alignment + transformation-grade Service Quality.Practical examples? C: TAM owns lifecycle assessment inputs + service alignment; CSM owns QBR (C) delivery and initiative intake.? B: vCIO owns roadmap + budget; CSM runs cadence and progress reporting..Concept #3: One Owner End-to-End (RACI Accountable) + Named BackupWhen “the team” supposedly owns a deliverable, handoffs get fuzzy, follow-ups slip, and meetings drift without decisions. Make ownership explicit by assigning one RACI Accountable per deliverable/process and one named Backup per account. The same person can wear multiple hats in a small MSP, but RACI must remain separate: AM = commercial Accountable, CSM = health/cadence Accountable.How to set it up? One Accountable, consistently: Exactly one named owner per deliverable or meeting type, per account.? Named Backup: Visible on agendas and in your CS tool//PSA/CRM so continuity is automatic (OOO, turnover, load).? RACI stamp on every agenda/template: Accountable | Responsible (prep/follow-up) | Consulted | Informed | Backup.? Follow-up SLAs: Summary within 48h, tasks in system within 72h, approvals chased within 7–10 days.? Cadence & format flex by budget: Keep the Accountable even if you switch from a full QBR to a shorter session or a “deck + 3-minute screen-recorded video + 30-min call.” If budget requires a lighter format (e.g., concise deck + 3-minute screen-recorded video + 30-minute call), Accountable/Backup roles remain unchanged. If budget requires a lighter format (e.g., concise deck + 3-minute screen-recorded video + 30-minute call), Accountable/Backup roles remain unchanged.Meeting ownership (names and cadence aligned to Roles)Annual Strategy Planning (A/B/C)? Accountable: vCIO / Strategic Advisor? Responsible (prep & follow-up): CSM? Consulted: AM (commercial), TAM (technical risks)? Informed: SMEs as needed? Backup: CSM? Output: updated roadmap, OKR links, top 2–3 initiatives with dates/owners.Executive QBR (A) — up to 3/year if budget permits? Accountable: vCIO / vCxO? Responsible: CSM? Consulted: AM, SMEs (security/architecture/etc.)? Informed: TAM? Backup: CSMQBR (B/C) — 1–3/year based on budget? Accountable: CSM;? Consulted: AM;? Informed: vCIO (B), TAM (C);? Backup: vCIO (B) / AM (C).Service Review (C/D) — monthly/quarterly or trigger-based? Accountable: TAM? Consulted: AM/CSM (only if scope/cadence changes)? Informed: vCIO (C)? Backup: AM/CSMCommercial vs. health/cadence (RACI line you’ll keep everywhere)? Renewal & Pricing: Accountable AM, Consulted CSM, Informed vCIO.? Customer Health & Alerts (CX, Engagement, Adoption, Alignment): Accountable CSM, Responsible for inputs TAM, Informed AM, vCIO.Documentation you use? One-page RACI by segment (A–D) per account: list each deliverable with A/R/C/I + Backup.? The RACI field is in every agenda (top-right corner).? The decision log is linked to the roadmap/success plan (who decided, what, when, and next date).Practical examples (ready to copy)? Segment B QBR? RACI: Accountable CSM, Consulted vCIO & AM, Informed TAM, Backup vCIO.? Prep: CSM pulls Health & initiative status; vCIO adds roadmap context; AM tags renewal horizon.? Follow-up: CSM summary in 48h, 2 CTAs in LMx within 72h, next date booked.? Segment A Executive QBR? RACI: Accountable vCIO, Responsible CSM, Consulted AM + SMEs, Informed TAM, Backup CSM.? Output: two exec-level outcomes (e.g., OKR tie-in, cross-dept initiative), next decision date.? Segment C Service Review? RACI: Accountable TAM, Consulted CSM (if cadence/scope change), Informed AM, Backup CSM.? Output: lifecycle gaps + one small approval; CSM nudges adoption owners.Concept #4: Map Responsibilities to the Right Client StakeholdersApprovals stall when you talk to the wrong audience. Keep every conversation relevant—and faster—by pairing MSP roles to the matching client stakeholders and embedding that map into your responsibilities and meeting plans.The simple mapping (use this on your one-pager)? TAM ? IT Lead / Operations — service quality, SLA/lifecycle, adoption nudges.? CSM ? Ops / Admin / Team Leads — cadence, decisions, initiative follow-through, Health.? AM ? Budget Holder / Procurement / Owner-Manager — renewals, pricing, terms, upsell timing.? vCIO / vCxO ? CEO / MD / CFO — strategy, roadmap, OKRs, prioritization, value narrative.? vCISO ? Compliance / Risk / Exec Sponsor — risk posture, controls, audits.? vCTO ? Tech-savvy Exec / Architect — architecture, modernization, innovation.How to operationalize it? Stakeholder map in LMx/CRM (one page): names, roles, influence (D/M/I), preferred channel, cadence, backups.? Invite list by meeting archetype (baked into templates):? Annual Strategy Planning (A/B/C): CEO/CFO + vCIO (A), Ops + CSM included for follow-through.? Executive QBR (A): vCIO + CEO/CFO + CSM; AM only for commercial context.? QBR (B/C): CSM + Ops/Admin; add vCIO (B) for roadmap blocks; TAM (C) for lifecycle items.? Service Review (C/D): TAM + IT/Ops; CSM attends only if cadence/scope changes.? Pre-flight check (48–72h prior): confirm the decision-maker is present; otherwise rescope (shorter session + book a decision call with the right exec).? Aftercare: Decisions are logged to the success plan/roadmap, tasks are assigned to the people who are in the room, and renewal timing is noted for AM.Segment-aware meeting aim (who must be in the room)? A (4–5): Executive relevance is non-negotiable ? CEO/CFO + vCIO/vCxO in Executive QBRs; CSM ensures outcomes and next steps are locked.? B (3): Move decisions faster ? Ops + CSM for QBR; vCIO joins roadmap segments; invite budget holder when approvals are expected.? C (2): Keep it operational ? IT/Ops + TAM for Service Reviews; CSM handles cadence and captures initiative intake.? D (1): Keep it simple ? Owner/Manager + TAM annually; otherwise Service Reviews with IT/Ops.Templates that make this stick? Agenda header: “Stakeholders for this session (Name, Role, Why here, Decision right)”.? Slide 1: “What we need from you today” (approve X, choose Y, confirm date Z).? Email pre-read: 3 bullets (last outcomes, today’s decisions, what happens next).Practical examples (ready to copy)? B-segment Roadmap + Budget Checkpoint? Attendees: vCIO + CSM + Ops Lead + Budget Holder (Owner/CFO).? Flow: CSM (cadence & status) ? vCIO (sequence & value) ? Budget holder (approve 1–2 items).? Output: approvals captured; next decision date; renewal note to AM.? C-segment Quarterly Review (QBR)? Attendees: CSM + Ops/Admin, TAM for lifecycle portion.? Flow: CSM (Engagement & initiative status) ? TAM (adoption/lifecycle gaps) ? CSM (one small approval).? Output: one approved initiative; tasks in LMx; 90-day date booked.? A-segment Executive QBR? Attendees: vCIO / vCxO + CEO/CFO + CSM; AM consulted if commercial topics arise.? Flow: vCIO (value recap vs. OKRs) ? decisions (2 max) ? CSM (next steps, owners, dates).? Output: exec-level outcomes; risks noted for vCISO/vCTO if relevant; follow-through meetings set.? D-segment Annual IT Strategy? Attendees: Owner/Manager + TAM.? Flow: TAM (SLA/asset hygiene, 12-month priorities) ? pick one improvement ? agree on a simple date/budget.? Output: A single upgrade is scheduled; Service Reviews will handle the rest.Concept #5: Responsibility = Process Ownership (Trigger ? Prep ? Lead ? Follow-Up)Fragmented task lists create invisible gaps. Make ownership visible and end-to-end for every CS motion using a simple arc: Trigger ? Prep ? Lead ? Follow-Up, with a single RACI Accountable and a named Backup per account. Stamp this at the top of every agenda/template so no one has to guess.Apply by meeting type (aligned to Roles & cadence):Annual Strategy Planning (A/B/C)? Accountable: vCIO / Strategic Advisor? Responsible (prep & follow-up): CSM? Consulted: AM (commercial context), TAM (technical risks)? Backup: CSM? Outputs: Updated roadmap, OKRs link, and next 2–3 initiatives with dates.Executive QBR (A) — up to 3/year if budget permits? Accountable: vCIO / vCxO? Responsible (prep & follow-up): CSM? Consulted: AM, SMEs (as needed)? Backup: CSM? Outputs: exec-level progress, decisions, approvals, and a refreshed success plan.QBR (B/C) — 1–3/year based on budget? Accountable: CSM? Consulted: AM, vCIO (B), TAM? Informed: SMEs as needed.Service Review (C/D) — monthly/quarterly or trigger-based? Accountable: TAM? Consulted: AM/CSM (only if scope/cadence changes)? Backup: AM/CSM? Outputs: SLA & lifecycle hygiene, risks, ticket trends, adoption nudges.Make it operational with lightweight guardrails:? Agenda header “RACI stamp” (Accountable | Backup | Consulted | Informed).? Follow-up SLA: summary in 48h, tasks in CS tool//PSA in 72h, approvals chased within 7–10 days.? Templates: every deck/report starts with “Owner (A), Backup, Next review date”.? Handoff notes: a one-page “decision log” linked to the roadmap/success plan.Practical examples (ready to copy):? Segment B QBR (CSM Accountable)? Trigger: QBR due in 30 days (auto-notice).? Prep: CSM pulls Health & initiative status; vCIO adds roadmap notes.? Lead: CSM runs the meeting; vCIO handles roadmap questions.? Follow-Up: CSM sends 48h summary, creates 2 CTAs, books next date.? Segment C Service Review (TAM Accountable)? Trigger: monthly SLA review.? Prep: TAM updates lifecycle gaps; CSM adds any engagement risks.? Lead: TAM walks tickets/SLA/adoption; asks for one small approval.? Follow-Up: TAM logs decisions; CSM nudges adoption task owners.Concept #6: Use Health to Tune Responsibilities (Measure ? Signal ? Adjust)When Health dips, don’t swap tools—retune RACI ownership. Treat CX, Engagement, Adoption, and Service Level Alignment as routing signals that decide who leads what for the next cycle.Portfolio Health is summarized on CX, Engagement, Adoption, and Alignment. Service Quality is a TAM-owned input that feeds Adoption/Alignment and is reviewed in Service Reviews.Simple playbook:? Measure weekly (portfolio board) and before each meeting.? Signal thresholds (example):? Engagement < target for two cycles ? CSM escalates cadence reset.? Adoption ? 10–20% in C ? TAM deep-dives assessments; CSM owns follow-up.? CX risk in A ? vCIO/vCxO must own the next Executive QBR agenda.? Adjust ownership for one quarter, then revert or lock in.By segment—typical retunes:? A (4–5): Low CX or unclear exec value ? vCxO/vCIO leads next Executive QBR; CSM tightens pre-work & decision capture; AM consulted on commercial impacts only.? B (3): Slipping decision velocity ? CSM remains Accountable for cadence, vCIO co-leads roadmap block until two approvals land.? C (2): Adoption stalls ? CSM becomes Accountable for initiative follow-through for 60 days; TAM focuses on lifecycle inputs and risk notes.? D (1): SLA noise ? TAM is kept accountable; CSM joins only if scope/cadence needs to change.Lightweight governance:? Health + Role board (columns: Segment, Health signal, Who is Accountable now, When we revert).? Green target: 80% of accounts “on target” mid-year; review exceptions monthly.Practical examples (ready to copy):? A account, CX amber ? Next Executive QBR: Accountable vCIO, Responsible CSM; add “Value recap” slide, confirm two executive-level outcomes; CSM books a 30-min follow-through within 7 days.? C account, Adoption down 15% ? CSM Accountable for two initiatives; TAM updates DMI and provides config notes; weekly 15-min sync until back to baseline.? Any segment missed approvals twice ? CSM is accountable for resetting cadence (shorter QBR, clear CTAs); AM is consulted if renewal timing collides.? NRR/NDR ownership (KPI): AM = Accountable; CSM = Consulted (engagement/health signals); TAM = Responsible (inputs); vCIO = Consulted (A/B roadmap decisions).Concept #7: Same Logic as You Grow (Small ? Mid ? Large MSP)Growth and budget shifts shouldn’t force a redesign. Keep the same responsibility logic and split it cleanly as your portfolio and CS budget evolve—precisely as defined in 5.1 Roles.Calibration rules (match Roles 1:1):? AM vs CSM stays separated in RACI even if one person covers both day-to-day.? Commercial (renewals, pricing, proposals) = AM Accountable? Health & Cadence (CX, Engagement, Adoption, Alignment) = CSM AccountableMeeting mix by segment & budget? A: 1? Annual Strategy Planning + up to 3 Executive QBRs (budget-dependent).? B/C: 1? Annual Strategy Planning + 1–3 QBRs (budget-dependent).? D: 1? Annual IT Strategy Meeting + Service Reviews.? Specialists (vCISO, vCTO) join Segment A when justified by risk/innovation—not by habit.? If budget tightens: keep Accountables, downgrade format (e.g., QBR ? concise deck + 3-min screen-recorded video + 30-min call), but do not drop the owner.Quarterly RACI refresh (fast checklist):? Per segment, verify each deliverable’s Accountable + Backup.? Remove senior roles from C/D unless needed; add vCIO/vCxO to A if CX/Alignment lags.? Confirm AM=commercial and CSM=health/cadence in all agendas and templates.? Tie any changes to Enablement updates (talk tracks, checklists) and Compensation levers.Practical examples (ready to copy):? Budget cut in a B account ? Keep CSM Accountable for QBR; switch to shorter QBR cadence with one approval per cycle; vCIO consulted only for roadmap decisions.? C account grows into B ? Add Annual Strategy Planning (Accountable vCIO), keep CSM Accountable for QBRs; introduce one roadmap initiative per quarter.? A account adds security scope ? Invite vCISO as consulted to Executive QBR; vCIO remains Accountable; CSM owns follow-up and risk register updates.
Implementation ProcessDefining Roles for Scalable, Segment-Aware Engagement The Roles Implementation Process ensures that MSPs define, assign, and operationalize Customer Success roles based on client maturity, appetite, and Business Goal level. This process creates the foundation for delivering consistent value, enabling strategic alignment, and tracking impact through role clarity and accountability.Operationalizing Responsibilities for Scalable, Segment-Aligned CS Execution Goal: turn role definitions into clear, segment-aware ownership with smooth handoffs, the right people in the room, and Health-driven adjustments.Step 1: Design Roles Based on Client Segments and Business GoalsStart by mapping roles to each client segment, using segmentation and Client Business Goal levels to calibrate role depth and complexity:SegmentGoal LevelPrimary Roles InvolvedPurposeA4–5vCxO, Strategic Advisor, SMEs (e.g., vCISO for risk/compliance; vCTO for architecture/innovation)Drive innovation, OKRs, and cross-departmental planningB3vCIO, CSMEnable business alignment and initiative executionC2TAM, AM/CSMEnsure operational quality, stack alignment, and roadmap deliveryD1TAM, Owner/FounderMaintain service visibility, reinforce stabilityRole depth should scale by both strategic ambition and delivery needs—not simply by contract size. Smaller MSPs may assign multiple roles to a single person, but role functions must remain distinct and visible.Step 2: Build the one-page Responsibility Matrix (by segment A–D)Create a single page per segment that lists every recurring CS deliverable and its RACI per account, plus a named Backup.Deliverables to include? Annual Strategy Planning (A/B/C)? Executive QBR (A)? QBR (B/C)? Service Review (C/D)? Assessments / DMI inputs? Reports (creation & delivery)? Initiatives & Budget drafting? Health Dashboard & Alerts? Renewal & PricingRACI quick rules? Exactly one Accountable per item.? Always list a Backup (person, not “the team”).? Keep AM vs. CSM split even if one person holds both titles:? Commercial = AM (Accountable)? Health/Cadence = CSM (Accountable)Starter example (copy into your template)? Annual Strategy Planning (A/B/C) ? A: vCIO | R: CSM | C: AM | I: TAM | Backup: CSM? Executive QBR (A) ? A: vCIO | R: CSM | C: AM, SMEs | I: TAM | Backup: CSM? QBR (B/C) ? A: CSM | C: AM; vCIO (B), TAM (C) | I: SMEs | Backup: vCIO (B) / AM (C)? Service Review (C/D) ? A: TAM | C: AM/CSM (if scope/cadence changes) | I: vCIO (C) | Backup: CSM? Renewal & Pricing ? A: AM | C: CSM | I: vCIO | Backup: AM delegate? Health Dashboard & Alerts ? A: CSM | R (inputs): TAM | I: AM, vCIO | Backup: AMStep 3: Assign Role Ownership for Key CS DeliverablesAlways name an Accountable role and a Backup for every deliverable. Clarify which roles are RACI owners (Accountable = single named owner) for each deliverable, and add a named Backup per account for continuity.? TAM/SDM ? Service Reviews (Lead), Health inputs, basic assessments (A/R).? AM/CSM ? QBR (Lead in B/C), Engagement tracking, initiative intake (A).? vCIO/Strategic Advisor ? Executive QBRs (Lead in A) and annual Strategy Planning (Lead A/B/C), budget framing (A).? Specialists/SMEs (vCISO, vCTO) ? consulted primarily in A (and sometimes B) accounts when risk/innovation justifies.Map each RACI owner to the matching client stakeholder (e.g., vCIO ? CEO/CFO; AM/CSM ? Ops/Admin; TAM ? IT lead). Create a role-to-segment engagement matrix. This becomes the foundation for planning team coverage, onboarding paths, and accountability during cadence-based execution. The deliverable owner should also be the relationship owner for the corresponding client stakeholder.For every deliverable and meeting, assign a RACI owner (Accountable) and a named Backup per account to guarantee continuity (no ‘the team’ owners).? Annual Strategy Planning (A/B/C) — Accountable: vCIO; Responsible: CSM (prep & follow-up); Consulted: AM; Informed: TAM.? Executive QBR (A) — Accountable: vCIO; Responsible: CSM; Consulted: AM; Informed: TAM/SMEs.? QBR (B/C) — Accountable: CSM; Consulted: AM; Informed: vCIO (B), TAM (C).? Service Review (C/D) — Accountable: TAM; Consulted: AM/CSM (if scope/cadence changes); Informed: vCIO (C).? Renewal & Pricing — Accountable: AM; Consulted: CSM; Informed: vCIO.? Health Dashboard & Alerts (CX/Engagement/Adoption/Alignment) — Accountable: CSM; Responsible (inputs): TAM; Informed: AM, vCIO.The deliverable owner is also the relationship owner for the matching client stakeholder.Step 4: Stamp RACI into every meeting and deliverable templateAdd a tiny RACI block to the top-right of agendas, notes, and report covers so ownership is visible in every interaction.Agenda header (paste this)? Accountable | Responsible | Consulted | Informed | Backup? Decisions needed today (max 2): …? Who decides: Name/Role? Follow-up SLA: Summary in 48h; CTAs in system in 72h; approvals chased within 7–10 daysDocumentation habit? Log decisions to the Success Plan/Roadmap (not just email).? Assign named owners + dates for each CTA in your CS tool//PSA/CRM.? Book the next date before the call ends.? If budget requires a lighter format (e.g., concise deck + 3-minute screen-recorded video + 30-minute call), Accountable/Backup roles remain unchanged.Step 5: Operationalize Roles Through Playbooks and Process AlignmentFor every meeting type, set Trigger ? Prep ? Lead ? Follow-up with a RACI owner and Backup:? Strategy Planning (annual, A/B/C): Lead = vCIO/Strategic Advisor; Backup = CSM.? Executive QBR (A): Lead = vCIO/Strategic Advisor; Backup = CSM. Target 3/yr if budget permits.? QBR (B/C): Lead/Accountable = CSM; Consulted = AM; Informed = vCIO (B), TAM (C); Backup = vCIO (B) / AM (C). 1–3/yr depending on budget.? Service Review (C/D): Lead = TAM; Backup = AM/CSM. Monthly/quarterly or trigger-based.Ensure each role is embedded in process flows.? Assign meeting ownership by segment and type (e.g., vCIO ? Strategy Meeting; TAM ? Service Review)? Define initiative lead role per segment (e.g., CSM for C-level clients; TAM for D-level)? Link roles to reporting: who presents which reports, and to whom?? Align intake responsibilities: Discovery and Assessment prep should have named role owners.This alignment reduces confusion, increases consistency, and ensures roles are actioned—not just labelled.Bake responsibilities into simple, repeatable playbooks Turn each deliverable into a 4-step mini-playbook with explicit ownership.Trigger ? Prep ? Lead ? Follow-up (examples)? QBR (B/C)? Trigger: CSM (Health window/cadence)? Prep: CSM (status & slides), vCIO (B roadmap), TAM (C lifecycle)? Lead: CSM (Accountable)? Follow-up: CSM (summary/CTAs), AM (commercial notes)? Executive QBR (A)? Trigger: CSM (exec cadence)? Prep: CSM (storyline & outcomes), vCIO (value/OKR link), AM (commercial horizon)? Lead: vCIO (Accountable)? Follow-up: CSM (actions/dates), AM (renewal timing), vCIO (risks to next Strategy checkpoint)? Service Review (C/D)? Trigger: TAM (SLA/lifecycle)? Prep: TAM (tickets, adoption, asset gaps)? Lead: TAM (Accountable)? Follow-up: TAM (technical CTAs), CSM (if cadence/scope changes)? Renewal & Pricing? Lead/Accountable: AM; Consulted: CSM; Informed: vCIOPut these 4-step strips on the agenda footer so no one wonders who does what next.Step 6: Tie responsibilities to the right stakeholders and cadenceUse the role-to-stakeholder map and the segment cadence rules from Roles.Who talks to whom? TAM ? IT/Ops (service, lifecycle, adoption nudges)? CSM ? Ops/Admin/Team Leads (cadence, decisions, follow-through, Health)? AM ? Owner/Procurement/Budget holder (renewal, pricing, terms)? vCIO/vCxO ? CEO/CFO (strategy, OKRs, prioritization)? vCISO ? Compliance/Risk | vCTO ? Tech-savvy exec/architectCadence by segment (name meetings correctly)? A (4–5): Annual Strategy Planning + Executive QBR (up to 3/year if budget permits)? B/C (3 / 2): Annual Strategy Planning + QBR (1–3/year based on budget)? D (1): Annual IT Strategy only; use Service Reviews for operational rhythmPre-flight check (48–72h before)? Confirm decision-maker attendance; if missing, switch to a shorter update and book a decision call with the right exec.? Keep the invite list lean and role-matched.Step 7: Use CS Health as a Feedback Loop to Optimize Role CoverageTrack Engagement, CX, and Alignment scores to detect whether roles are misaligned with client expectations. Examples:? Low CX in Segment A ? Possibly lacking strategic facilitation (assign or improve vCxO coverage)? Low Adoption in Segment C ? Potential misfit between TAM and roadmap follow-through? Missed Initiatives or Roadmaps ? Likely absence of CSM ownership or cadence planningCreate internal Health + Role dashboards to monitor which roles produce results and where refinement or support is needed.Treat Health as routing signals for responsibility fixes, not just reports.Fast adjustments? Low Engagement (any segment): CSM runs re-engagement play (short update + decision call) and keeps Accountable until green.? Low Adoption (C): Keep TAM responsible for assessment inputs, and make CSM accountable for follow-through (weekly nudges for 60 days).? Low CX (A): Add/strengthen vCIO/vCxO presence in the next Executive QBR; CSM keeps actions tight.? Missed initiatives (any): Reset cadence; CSM Accountable for follow-up SLA; escalate to vCIO if decisions slip >30 days.Simple dashboard? One sheet per segment: Owner | Backup | Last meeting | Next date | Health (CX/Eng/Adopt/Align) | Risks | Next action.? Review weekly inside the CS team; escalate exceptions in your internal governance huddle.Step 8: Review Roles Quarterly and Scale with Client & Team MaturityAs clients mature, their role expectations shift. Conduct quarterly role reviews across the CS portfolio:? Promote TAM ? AM/CSM ? Strategic Advisor as engagement complexity rises? Reassign clients based on role bandwidth, Health data, or Business Goal level changes? Use playbook coverage and deliverable execution to identify team gaps? Tie role progression to enablement and compensation plans (see 5.3 and 5.4)? Establish recurring CS leadership checkpoints to review each role category's segment-role alignment, escalation patterns, and staffing capacity.Every quarter, run a short Responsibilities Review to keep the system sharp:Checklist? Is Accountable still the proper role by segment? (Avoid senior over-servicing C/D)? Are Backups named and present in key calls?? Are AM (commercial) and CSM (health/cadence) still clearly split in RACI?? Are Strategy/QBR/Service Review counts aligned to budget and segment rules?? Do we need to introduce vCISO/vCTO in A accounts?? Any role progression we can unlock (TAM ? CSM ? Advisor)?Update the one-page matrices, agendas, and playbooks and keep going.Final Output: A Role-Aligned Customer Success SystemWhen implemented correctly, the MSP will have:? Clear role definitions calibrated to client segments and goal levels? Assigned ownership of all strategic and operational CS deliverables? Embedded roles across the CS lifecycle (Discovery, Roadmap, Meeting, Budget)? Measurable accountability tied to Customer Success Health? A scalable role system that evolves with both the team and the client base“Done” looks like this? Every deliverable has one Accountable, a named Backup, and a visible RACI on the agenda.? Meeting names and cadences match the segment rules (Strategy Planning / Executive QBR / QBR / Service Review).? Stakeholder mapping ensures the right people are in the room, every time.? Follow-ups hit the 48h/72h/7–10d rhythm and live in the Success Plan/Roadmap.? Health triggers change responsibilities or add coverage—you can see that on a single sheet.
Appendix How does it connect to the Client Business Goal levels?1A) Role Composition ? MSP ArchetypeLevelRole CompositionMSP Archetype0.0 DIY ITNo formal roles; clients self-manage, call for reactive support onlyDIY IT1.1 Technology SupportThe Owner/Founder fills all roles. Reactive support from Helpdesk or Techs.Break-Fix MSP1.2 Technology EnablementTAMs or Service Delivery Managers are introduced for structured delivery.Proactive MSP1.3 Technology ModernizationDedicated AMs and vCIOs take ownership of client outcomes.Full-Service MSP1.4 Business TransformationStrategic Business Advisors, CS Managers, and possibly vCISO roles introduced.Strategic Partner MSP1.5 Business InnovationAdvanced vCxO roles and SME contributors (e.g., BI, AI, ERP, ISO) support transformation and innovation.Transformation / Innovation MSP1B) Key Responsibilities by Role (per Level)? 1.1 Technology Support The owner/technician handles all reactive support, ticket escalations, and basic client communication.? 1.2 Technology Enablement TAMs handle delivery coordination, basic onboarding, and hardware/software rollouts. SDM may oversee client SLAs.? 1.3 Technology Modernization vCIOs lead strategic planning, AMs manage cadence and reporting, TAMs support initiative execution.? 1.4 Business Transformation Strategic Advisors lead planning, CS Managers coordinate initiatives, and vCISOs assess risk and compliance.? 1.5 Business Innovation vCxOs oversee innovation portfolios, SME partners deliver advanced insights, and cross-functional coordination is formalized.Goal Level / Segment Matrix (Owners, Emphasis, Health, Cadence)Goal Level / SegmentPrimary role ownersOwnership emphasisHealth emphasisTypical cadence (aligned to Roles)D (Goal 1 - Technology Support)TAM / OwnerSLA stability, lifecycle hygiene, and incident follow-throughService Quality, baseline EngagementAnnual IT Strategy; Service Reviews monthly/quarterly or trigger-basedC (Goal 2 - Technology Enablement)TAM + AM/CSMAssessments input, service alignment, reports, and initiative intakeTechnology Adoption, EngagementAnnual Strategy Planning + QBR (1–3/yr based on budget); Service Reviews as neededB (Goal 3 - Technology Modernization)vCIO + CSMRoadmap, budget framing, initiative pacing, decision velocityService Level Alignment, Engagement, and Sustained AdoptionAnnual Strategy Planning + QBR (1–3/yr based on budget)A (Goals 4 - Business Transformation and 5 Business Innovation)vCxO/Strategic Advisor + CSMOKR linkage, executive cadence, cross-dept programsExec-level CX, Alignment, transformation-grade Service QualityAnnual Strategy Planning + Executive QBR (up to 3/yr if budget permits)How does it connect to the other parts?Roles View1. Client Business Goal – Role specialization evolves with client maturity and appetite. Higher levels require strategic, consultative roles, while foundational levels may only require reactive technical support.2. Customer Success Health – CX, Engagement, and Service Level metrics inform whether current roles are sufficient or need adjustment. Role depth influences perception, participation, and satisfaction.3. Customer Success Delivery – Certain deliverables (e.g., Strategy, Roadmap) require specific roles, such as vCIO or Strategic Advisor, to be effective. Role ownership helps ensure deliverables are understood and actionable.4. Customer Success Process – Roles must be aligned with intake, meeting, and initiative workflows. Poor alignment can lead to dropped handoffs or unclear ownership of customer service activities.5. Customer Success Strategy – Segmentation and SOPs dictate role engagement by client tier. Strategy must account for role bandwidth, specialization, and scalability across segments.6. North-star KPI – We track NRR/NDR for existing clients; AM Accountable, CSM Consulted (health), TAM Responsible (inputs), vCIO Consulted (A/B roadmap).Responsibilities View1. Client Business Goal – Responsibilities evolve as the client moves up in maturity and appetite. Tactical roles dominate early stages, while strategic, planning, and innovation responsibilities emerge at higher levels.2. Customer Success Health – Role responsibilities directly impact CS Health metrics: Account Managers (AMs) and Customer Success Managers (CSMs) influence Engagement and Customer Experience (CX); vCIOs drive Technology Adoption and Service Level Alignment; Technical Account Managers (TAMs) and Technical Specialists (Techs) affect Service Quality.3. Customer Success Delivery – Each deliverable (e.g., Budgets, Roadmaps, Proposals) requires clear ownership to ensure they are appropriately produced, presented, and followed up on.4. Customer Success Process – Responsibilities dictate who triggers, prepares, leads, and follows up in each SOP/playbook and ensure cadence adherence (Strategy Planning, Executive QBR/QBR, Service Review).5. Customer Success People – Responsibilities reflect the finalized Roles model and RACI usage. Keep AM and CSM distinct in RACI even if one person holds both titles (commercial = AM Accountable; health/cadence = CSM Accountable).6. Customer Success Strategy – Segmentation, SOPs, and capacity models require role-specific responsibilities to be well-defined. This allows the CS strategy to scale across segments without confusion or duplication.7. Metrics Link – NRR (a.k.a. NDR) is the primary outcome KPI; GRR, Expansion %, and Churn % are supporting metrics.Product Links / Tooling SupportNot currently tied to a specific LMx product feature. Role modelling is part of MSP organizational design and delivery planning. Future tooling may support role-to-client alignment, role competency mapping, and visibility at the engagement level.

?? 5.2 Enablement
5.2 EnablementOverviewWhat is the objective?Why is it important?As an MSP, why do I need to do this?What is the Customer impact?Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: Segment-Calibrated Role-Deliverable EnablementConcept #2: Live-of-Work Tooling Packs (by role)Concept #3: QBR Kit + Lightweight Joint Success Plan (JSP-Lite)Concept #4: Health-Triggered CTAs & Playbooks (Automation-First)Concept #5: Two-Track Learning: “In the Flow” + Role CertificationsConcept #6 — Digital CS for Segment C/D (Tech-Touch That Still Feels Human)Concept #7 — CS Ops-Lite (0.2–0.5 FTE Function or Rotating Duty)Concept #8 — Journey-Stage Playbooks (Onboarding ? Adoption ? Value ? Renewal)Implementation ProcessStep 1 — Build the Role?Segment?Deliverable Matrix (1 page)Step 2 — Publish Live-of-Work Packs (by role & segment)Step 3 — Standardize the QBR Kit + JSP-LiteStep 4 — Wire Health-Triggered CTAs & Playbooks (automation-first)Step 5 — Bake Stakeholder Mapping & Invite Logic into TemplatesStep 6 — Launch Two-Track Learning & Role CertificationsStep 7 — Switch On Digital CS for C/D (pilot, then scale)Step 8 — Stand Up CS Ops-Lite + Measure/Report/IterateAppendixHow does it connect to the Client Business Goal levels?How does it connect to the other parts?Product Links / Tooling Support
OverviewWhat is the objective?Equip each CS role (TAM, AM, CSM, vCIO, and—when justified—vCTO/vCISO) with simple, “in-the-flow” tools and micro-skills to deliver their segment-calibrated responsibilities (A=4–5, B=3, C=2, D=1). Enablement activates Roles & Responsibilities with lightweight playbooks, talk tracks, templates, checklists, and live reports/alerts, all tied to clear RACI ownership (one Accountable + a named Backup) and the standard meeting types and cadence:? Annual Strategy Planning (A/B/C)? Executive QBR (A, up to 3/year if budget permits)? QBR (B/C, 1–3/year based on budget)? Service Review (C/D)Enablement ladders explicitly to the NRR/NDR north star and follows the Growth Loop of Discover ? Align ? Deliver ? Measure.Why is it important?? Turns role definitions into execution: people know what to run, with which asset, for which segment, and who is Accountable.? Reduces Health drift: health signals (CX, Engagement, Adoption/DMI, Service Quality, Alignment) trigger concise plays with owners and due dates.? Fits MSP reality: keeps QBR/Service Review central, avoids enterprise process bloat, and protects senior capacity for A/B.? Strengthens multi-threading: each deliverable has one Accountable, a Backup, and the right client counterpart.? Speeds ramp: short, role-based guides and check-rides standardize outcomes without heavy training programs.? Creates a straight line of sight from enablement usage to revenue outcomes (NRR/NDR).As an MSP, why do I need to do this?? Stamp RACI (Accountable/Responsible/Consulted/Informed + Backup) on every agenda, template, and report—no “the team” owners.? Ship role?segment packs that mirror Responsibilities:? A: vCIO strategy/OKR facilitation; CSM follow-through? B: vCIO roadmap/budget; CSM cadence & approvals? C: CSM QBR & initiative intake; TAM lifecycle inputs? D: TAM Service Reviews; AM renewal hygiene? Keep AM vs CSM distinct in RACI even if one person wears both hats: Commercial = AM (Accountable); Health/Cadence = CSM (Accountable).? Automate four core health-triggered plays with owners and due dates.? Make outcomes measurable: recap ≤48h, tasks in system ≤72h, approvals chased within 7–10 days, Joint Success Plan (JSP) - Lite updated.? Treat Service Quality as a TAM-owned Health input that feeds Adoption and Alignment (reviewed in Service Reviews)—do not create a separate sixth Health dimension.? Engage vCTO/vCISO primarily in A (and selectively B) segments when risk/innovation justifies—format/budget may flex, RACI owners do not.What is the Customer impact?? Proper conversation with the right person (Executive QBR with vCIO; Service Review with TAM; QBRs in B/C run by CSM).? Faster decisions: pre-reads and JSP-Lite focus meetings on 1–2 approvals and visible next steps.? Trust through rhythm: predictable cadence and clean follow-through raise Engagement and CX; tighter initiative execution lifts Adoption and Alignment.? Scales without complexity across segments and budgets.Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: Segment-Calibrated Role-Deliverable EnablementEnablement mirrors who owns which deliverable in which segment. Give each role only what they need to deliver their outputs for that segment.How to implement (simple):1. Build a one-page matrix: rows = deliverables (Assessment, Report, QBR, Roadmap, Budget, Proposal, Meeting Notes); columns = segments (D/C/B/A).2. Assign RACI Accountable + Backup per cell using TAM, AM/CSM, vCIO (specialists optional in A).3. Attach exactly one talk track, template, checklist, and required data input per cell.4. Define “Done” in one sentence (e.g., “Roadmap B: 1–2 initiatives approved, budget range noted, next checkpoint booked.”).Ownership by segment (examples):? D: TAM Accountable — Service Review report + risks; AM/CSM Backup for renewal dates & CX pulse.? C: CSM Accountable — QBR pack + initiative intake; TAM Backup for DMI/adoption inputs.? B: vCIO Accountable — Roadmap + Budget; CSM Backup for cadence & approvals.? A: vCIO Accountable — Strategy/Executive QBR with OKRs; CSM Backup — governance follow-through.Success metrics: approval landed? Owner/date assigned? Recap ≤48h sent? Health stabilized? Definition of Done by segment (use on the matrix): D = 1 quick win approved + recap ≤48h + next date set; C = 1 approval + DMI/adoption inputs captured + recap ≤48h; B = 1–2 approvals + budget frame noted (this Q + next 2Q) + recap ≤48h; A = ≤2 executive decisions + OKR link visible + recap ≤48h.Concept #2: Live-of-Work Tooling Packs (by role)Each role works from a compact pack used during prep and delivery. Packs cut prep time and reduce variance so a lean CS team can deliver consistently.Pack anatomy (6–8 items):? Playbook (Trigger ? Prep ? Lead ? Follow-up; RACI stamp with Accountable + Backup)? Talk tracks (2–3 prompts)? Templates (3–5 slides or 1–2 pages)? Checklist (prep + recap ≤48h + who/when)? Reports/Alerts/Insights (health, adoption/DMI, SLA)? Service-catalog tiles (pre-scoped initiatives)Put packs where work happens (PSA/CRM/CS tool).Examples:Segment B (Technology Modernization)? vCIO Pack (Accountable: Roadmap & Budget Review) Agenda: re-confirm business goals ? sequence roadmap ? frame budget this Q + next 2 Q ? decision log. Talk tracks: “Two approvals today. Keep the pace we agreed on.” Checklist & assets: roadmap slides, 1-page budget, decision log, DMI snapshot.? CSM Pack (Accountable: QBR cadence & approvals) Agenda: status ? blockers ? approvals. Checklist: Ensure the decision-maker attends; draft the approval email; trigger the play if it is stalled.? TAM Support Pack (Consulted): risk review for upcoming steps.Segment D (Technology Support)? TAM Pack (Accountable: Service Review) Agenda: SLA/incidents ? recurring patterns ? lifecycle snapshot ? 1–2 mini-initiatives. Assets: SLA report, EOL list, quick-wins catalog.? AM/CSM Support: renewal hygiene + close loose ends.Concept #3: QBR Kit + Lightweight Joint Success Plan (JSP-Lite)Make every Strategy/QBR/Service Review outcome-led and fast to run. The kit standardizes what’s shown, what’s decided, and how follow-ups land—so each role can perform confidently by segment and budget.What’s in the kit? Three-slide deck you can reuse:1. Health snapshot (CX, Engagement, Adoption/DMI, Service Quality, Alignment)2. Roadmap/initiatives (progress, blockers, new proposals)3. Decisions & next steps (2 max, owners/dates)? Joint Success Plan (JSP) - Lite (one page) with: business goal ? metric/target ? 2–4 initiatives ? owner ? date ? risks ? next meeting date? Pre-read email template (subject, three bullets, attachments/links)? Recap template (≤48h; summary, decisions, tasks, dates)? RACI stamp on slide 1 (Accountable + Backup + Consulted + Informed)Cadence and Accountable by segment? A (4–5): Annual Strategy Planning + Executive QBR (up to 3/year if budget permits). Accountable: vCIO. Backup: CSM.? B/C (3/2): Annual Strategy Planning + QBR (1–3/year depending on budget). Accountable: CSM. Backup: vCIO (B) / AM (C).? D (1): Annual IT Strategy meeting + Service Reviews. Accountable: TAM. Backup: CSM/AM.How to implement (step by step)1. Save the deck and Joint Success Plan (JSP) - Lite as account templates in your PSA/CRM/CS workspace.2. Add a tiny RACI block to the top right of every agenda and slide 1.3. Timebox prep: ≤60 minutes for any QBR/Strategy/Review.4. Lock the outcomes: aim for 1–2 approvals per session and book the next date before you hang up.5. Recap rhythm: summary ≤48h, tasks in the system ≤72h, approvals chased within 7–10 days.Practical example (Segment B, vCIO + CSM)? Pre-read (sent 72–48h prior): last decisions, today’s two proposed approvals, roadmap excerpt.? Meeting flow: CSM (status/health) ? vCIO (sequence and business value) ? decision 1–2.? Recap: decisions, owners, budget notes, risks flagged to vCISO/vCTO if relevant.What to measure - Approvals per QBR, recap timeliness, “time-to-decision” trend, Health movement next cycle.Common pitfalls - Too many slides, no decision asked, wrong attendees, no RACI on the deck, and recap delays. Concept #4: Health-Triggered CTAs & Playbooks (Automation-First)Turn Health signals into the right owner doing the right small set of actions fast—without re-inventing the wheel every time.Core rules to start (keep it to four):1. Engagement down (missed two touchpoints / no decision in 30 days)? Owner: CSM · Due: 72h? Tasks: 2-line recap ? propose 30-minute reset ? If the executive is missing, cc the vCIO and add the stakeholder.? Output: reset booked, Joint Success Plan (JSP) - Lite updated, next approval attempt scheduled.2. CX down (negative survey or complaint)? Owner: CSM · Due: 48h? Tasks: “we own the miss” call ? 3-point fix plan ? 14-day check-in.? Output: Log the plan, customer acknowledgment, and follow-up on the calendar.3. Adoption/DMI below threshold (e.g., MFA <60% or endpoint compliance <80%)? Owner: TAM · Due: 5 days? Tasks: 3-step remediation ? 15-minute ops sync ? pre-approve quick win before next QBR.? Output: mini-initiative opened, owner/date set, risk reduced.4. Alignment low (“roadmap not relevant”)? Owner: vCIO · Due: 7 days? Tasks: 20-min alignment check ? re-map to business goals ? resequence/cut items.? Output: refreshed roadmap, next decision checkpoint booked.Segment nuance? D/C: quick wins first (catalog items), low lift.? B: Include a budget frame per ask.? A: Ensure exec sponsor attends; keep decisions to two or fewer.How to implement? Create four automation rules in your PSA/CRM/CS tool with owner + due date + tasks.? Prewrite email/snippet text so it’s plug-and-play.?
