Add a “First Action SLA <72h” widget to your CS dashboard.What to measure - Time-to-first-action, resolution within one cadence cycle, score rebound at the following review.Common pitfalls - Assigning tasks to “the team,” ambiguous due dates, too many rules, and no outcome defined.Concept #5: Two-Track Learning: “In the Flow” + Role CertificationsShorten ramp and stabilize delivery quality with lightweight learning that matches real work, not a heavy academy.Track 1 — In-the-flow learning (always available)? One-page primers per deliverable (what “good” looks like by segment).? 3–5 minute Looms showing a live run-through of prep and recap.? Pre-meeting prompts: “Which decision do we need today?” “Is the decision-maker invited?”? QA rubrics (5 criteria, 1–5 scale): prep completeness, story clarity, decision capture, recap timing, health linkage.Track 2 — Role certification (30/60/90 check-rides)? CSM: observe C QBR ? co-deliver ? lead C QBR (score ≥18/25 on rubric).? TAM: run D Service Review ? log two mini-initiatives ? deliver C lifecycle input block in QBR.? vCIO (new): shadow B ? co-lead B QBR ? lead B roadmap/budget checkpoint.? AM: renewal hygiene walkthrough ? price/terms talk track ? co-present commercial slide in B/C QBR.How to implement? Publish each role’s 90-day plan and book the first check-ride date on day 1.? Store primers, Looms, and rubrics inside the same workspace as the packs.? Tie certification to progression (e.g., CSM certified on C ? eligible to run B under supervision).What to measure - Ramp time to “first solo,” rubric averages, % sessions to standard, rework rate.Common pitfalls - Training not accessible in the flow, no scheduled check-rides, rubrics ignored, promotions without certification.Concept #6 — Digital CS for Segment C/D (Tech-Touch That Still Feels Human)Preserve margins on smaller accounts while keeping cadence, clarity, and perceived value high.Tactics you can run with? Quarterly email + 3-minute screen-recorded video: state of service, top 2 insights, 1–2 recommended quick wins, book-a-slot link.? Auto-reports (SLA, DMI/adoption) with two lines of commentary from the Accountable.? Micro-survey (2 questions) feeding CX Health.? Resource hub: 3–5 curated items (e.g., how to check backups, MFA tips, short policy explainer).? Digital format does not change RACI: Accountable and Backup remain as defined in 5.1 regardless of whether the touch is live or digital.RACI & cadence? D: TAM is accountable for service reviews and quarterly digital touch; CSM Backup is responsible for cadence resets; AM is consulted for renewal timing.? C: CSM is accountable for QBRs and digital touch; TAM provides adoption/DMI inputs; vCIO is optional for escalation.How to implement (pilot 10–15 accounts)? Build a simple list view that shows: last touch date, health, one next ask, and book-a-slot link.? Record a 3-minute recap once per cohort; personalize with the account name, last completed action, and the next ask.? Pre-schedule the quarterly sends; auto-insert the right report snapshots.What to measure - Open/click/book rates, quick-win approval rate, CX pulse trend.Common pitfalls - Generic videos, no next ask, no booking link, trying to replace all meetings instead of mixing formats.Concept #7 — CS Ops-Lite (0.2–0.5 FTE Function or Rotating Duty)Keep templates, packs, playbooks, and health rules tidy and aligned to segments/roles—without creating a big function.Scope & rhythm? Monthly (2–4 hours):? Audit 10 QBR/Review decks: Do they show health, decisions, and recap proof?? Refresh 1–2 templates; verify health rules still fire correctly.? Post a “what changed” note with links.? Quarterly (? day):? Sample 5 accounts/segment for data quality & enablement coverage.? Refresh one playbook; propose two improvements (backlog).Who does it? The CS Lead or senior CSM takes a rotating “Ops-Lite” hat, and the TAM/vCIO lends inputs.Targets - ≥80% sessions to standard; ≥90% recap ≤48h; at least one enablement improvement shipped per quarter.What to measure - Template adoption, play close-rate, first-action SLA hit-rate, data quality spot-checks.Common pitfalls -  No owner, no calendar holds, improvement backlog never shipped, over-engineering dashboards.Concept #8 — Journey-Stage Playbooks (Onboarding ? Adoption ? Value ? Renewal)Make every interaction move the client to the next outcome with 2–3 required artifacts per stage—tuned by segment.Stages, owners, artifacts, exits? Onboarding (D/C) — Accountable: TAM; Backup: CSM? Artifacts: “First 45 days” checklist, asset/lifecycle baseline, stakeholder map.? Exit: Baseline DMI was captured, the first QBR was booked, and the service review rhythm was set.? Adoption (C/B) — Accountable: CSM; Backup: TAM? Artifacts: DMI mini-review, 1–2 quick-win initiatives approved, owner/date in system.? Exit: KPI improved (e.g., MFA to 90%) or initiative started.? Value / QBR (B/A) — Accountable: CSM; Consulted: vCIO (B) / Co-lead: vCIO (A)? Artifacts: QBR kit + Joint Success Plan (JSP) - Lite; decision log.? Exit: 1–2 approvals; budget checkpoint noted; next decision date set.? Renewal — Accountable: AM; Consulted: CSM; Informed: vCIO? Artifacts: realized-value summary, next-year plan (2–4 initiatives).? Exit: renewal confirmed or executive escalation booked.How to implement? Add stage gates to your account view (stage, owner, exit criteria, date).? The artifacts are required to close the stage (links live in the account record).? Tie stage changes to Health nudges (e.g., Adoption ? Value only when a KPI moved).What to measure - Stage conversion %, time-in-stage, initiative throughput, renewal forecast confidence.Common pitfalls - Too many artifacts, unclear stage exits, owners not visible, stage changes not tied to Health.
Implementation ProcessStep 1 — Build the Role?Segment?Deliverable Matrix (1 page)Owner: CS Lead (with one TAM, one CSM, one vCIO)Inputs: 5.1 Roles and Responsibilities (RACI rules), segment cadence (A/B/C/D), Client Segmentation Worksheet – Appetite ? MaturityAction:? Create a 1-page grid: rows = deliverables (Assessments, Reports, Strategy Planning, Executive QBR/QBR, Service Review, Roadmap, Budget, Renewal, Health Dashboard); columns = segments (D, C, B, A).? Assign exactly one Accountable and a named Backup in every cell (RACI). Keep AM = commercial Accountable, CSM = health/cadence Accountable, even if one person wears both hats.? Link each cell to 1 talk track + 1 template + 1 checklist + data inputs.? Add a one-sentence Definition of done per cell (e.g., “B-Roadmap: 1–2 initiatives approved, budget range noted, next checkpoint booked”).? Add a KPI/threshold per cell (e.g., A-Executive QBR: exec attendance ≥95%, decision latency ≤14 days; C-QBR: ≥1 approval; D-Review: ≥1 quick win).Acceptance: Fits on one page; no empty cells; each cell shows Accountable + Backup + asset links; accessible in PSA/CRM/CS workspace (≤2 clicks).Output: “Role?Segment?Deliverable Matrix v1.0” (PDF/Doc with links).Why this matters: implements the segment-calibrated enablement idea (Concept #1).Step 2 — Publish Live-of-Work Packs (by role & segment)Owner: CS Lead; Contributors: one TAM, one CSM, one vCIOInputs: Matrix (Step 1)Action:? Ship two high-impact packs first:? Segment C: CSM QBR Pack (Accountable CSM) + TAM Lifecycle Pack (Backup inputs).? Segment A: vCIO Strategy/Executive QBR Pack (Accountable vCIO) + CSM Portfolio-Follow-Through Pack (Backup CSM).? Each pack includes: Playbook (Trigger?Prep?Lead?Follow-up), RACI stamp, 3–5 slide/template, checklist, reports/alerts/insights, service-catalog tiles, talk tracks.? Pin packs inside the account workspace (shortcuts in PSA/CRM/CS tool).Acceptance: Pack can run a session end-to-end; prep ≤60 minutes; RACI visible on page 1.Output: A- and C-segment packs live; matrix cells link to them.Why this matters: equips roles with the “live-of-work” kit (Concept #2).Step 3 — Standardize the QBR Kit + JSP-LiteTemplate steward (keeps templates current): A/B = vCIO · C = CSM · D = TAM.Meeting delivery Accountable (per Roles/Responsibilities): Executive QBR (A) = vCIO · QBR (B/C) = CSM · Service Review (D/C) = TAM · Annual Strategy Planning (A/B/C) = vCIO.Inputs: Packs (Step 2), cadence rules from Roles/Responsibilities.Action:? Publish 3-slide decks for Strategy/Executive QBR/QBR/Service Review:1.  Health (CX, Engagement, Adoption/DMI, Service Quality, Alignment)2. Roadmap/initiatives (progress, blockers, new asks)3. Decisions & next steps (max 2, owners/dates)? Add Joint Success Plan (JSP) – Lite (1 page): business goal ? metric/target ? 2–4 initiatives ? owner/date ? risks ? next meeting date.? Stamp RACI + named Backup on slide 1 / agenda header. Use these quick stamps:? Executive QBR (A): A = vCIO · R = CSM · C = AM/SMEs · I = TAM · Backup = CSM? QBR (B): A = CSM · C = vCIO, AM · I = TAM/SMEs · Backup = vCIO? QBR (C): A = CSM · C = AM, TAM · I = SMEs · Backup = AM? Service Review (C/D): A = TAM · C = CSM/AM (only if scope/cadence changes) · I = vCIO (C) · Backup = CSM? Lock cadence by segment:? A: Annual Strategy Planning + Executive QBR (up to 3/yr if budget permits)? B/C: Annual Strategy Planning + QBR (1–3/yr by budget)? D: Annual IT Strategy + Service ReviewsAcceptance: Every session saves a JSP-Lite + recap ≤ 48h; ≥ 1 approval per QBR (A/B target = 2). Prep time ≤ 60 minutes using the kit.Output: Deck templates + JSP-Lite stored and linked in the Role?Segment?Deliverable matrix.Why this matters: It makes strategy/QBR/service reviews outcome-led and approvals-oriented, with clear ownership and fast follow-through.Step 4 — Wire Health-Triggered CTAs & Playbooks (automation-first)Owner: CS Lead (with Ops-Lite support)Inputs: Health model (CX, Engagement, Adoption/DMI, Service Quality, Alignment)Action: Create four rules with prebuilt tasks, owners, and due dates:1. Engagement down ? CSM re-engage play (recap ? 30-min reset ? add exec if missing) — due 72h2. CX down ? CSM “we own the miss” plan + 14-day check-in — due 48h3. Adoption/DMI below threshold ? TAM 3-step remediation + 15-min ops sync — due 5 days4. Alignment low ? vCIO 20-min goal check ? resequence/cut — due 7 days Segment nuance: D/C = quick wins first; B = add budget frame; A = exec sponsor present.Acceptance: Task lists auto-create with owner/due; time-to-first-action <72h.Output: 4 active rules; playbooks linked in packs.Why this matters: converts Health signals into concrete actions (Concept #4).Step 5 — Bake Stakeholder Mapping & Invite Logic into TemplatesOwner: CSM (keeps the map current)Inputs: Role?Stakeholder mapping from ResponsibilitiesAction:? Add a Stakeholder block to agendas: Name · Role · Why here · Decision right.? Pre-fill invite lists by meeting type:? Strategy Planning (A/B/C): CEO/CFO + vCIO + CSM; AM consulted; TAM informed.? Executive QBR (A): vCIO + CEO/CFO + CSM; AM consulted; TAM informed.? QBR (B/C): CSM Accountable; B: vCIO consulted; C: TAM consulted; AM consulted for commercial.? Service Review (C/D): TAM Accountable; CSM/AM consulted only if scope/cadence changes.? Add a pre-flight check (48–72h): if the decision-maker will be absent, rescope to a short update and book a decision call.Acceptance: Correct decision-maker in the room ≥90%; rescope path used when needed.Output: Updated agenda templates; stakeholder maps per account.Why this matters: keeps “right people, right topics” and speeds approvals (Concept #3).Step 6 — Launch Two-Track Learning & Role CertificationsOwner: CS LeadInputs: Packs, QBR kit, rubricsAction:? In-flow learning: one-pagers, 3–5 min Looms, pre-meeting prompts, QA rubric (5 criteria: prep completeness, story clarity, decision capture, recap timing, health linkage).? 30/60/90 check-rides:? CSM: observe C QBR ? co-deliver ? lead C QBR (rubric ≥18/25).? TAM: run D Service Review ? log two mini-initiatives ? deliver C lifecycle input.? vCIO: shadow B ? co-lead B ? lead B roadmap/budget.? AM: renewal hygiene ? price/terms talk track ? co-present commercial slide in QBR.? Tie certification to progression (C ? B ? A readiness).Acceptance: Each role has a 90-day plan; the first check-ride is scheduled, and the rubric is used in the first real session.Output: Role ramp guides + rubrics published with the packs.Why this matters: shortens ramp and standardizes outcomes (Concept #5).Step 7 — Switch On Digital CS for C/D (pilot, then scale)Owner: CSM (content) · TAM (data) · CS Lead (approval)Inputs: Health data, SLA/DMI reports, resource hubAction:? Quarterly email + 3-minute screen-recorded video: state of service, top 2 insights, 1–2 quick wins, book-a-slot link.? Attach auto-reports with two-line commentary; include a 2-question micro-survey.? Personalize with account name, last action, and next ask.Acceptance: ≥60% open, ≥10% book rate, ≥1 quick-win approved in pilot.Output: Digital CS flow live for C/D; playbooks documented.Why this matters: preserves margins while keeping cadence and perceived value high (Concept #6).Step 8 — Stand Up CS Ops-Lite + Measure/Report/IterateOwner: Rotating “Ops-Lite” hat (CS Lead or senior CSM)Inputs: Packs, templates, health rules, dashboardAction (Ops-Lite):? Monthly (2–4h): audit 10 sessions (health shown? decisions? recap proof?), refresh 1–2 templates, verify health rules, post “what changed.”? Quarterly (? day): sample 5 accounts/segment for data quality & enablement coverage; refresh one playbook; propose two fixes. Action (Measure/Report):? Enablement adoption: pack usage, prep ≤60 min, % sessions with Joint Success Plan (JSP) - Lite.? Execution quality: recap ≤48h, decisions/QBR, time-to-first-action after health trigger.? Health outcomes: Engagement on cadence, DMI trend, Service Quality signals, and Alignment green rate.? Business outcomes: retention, renewal predictability, initiative-led expansion, NRR (a.k.a. NDR) and GRR tracked; ownership for NRR: AM = Accountable, CSM = Consulted (health), TAM = Responsible (inputs), vCIO = Consulted (A/B roadmap).? Hook into Compensation/Governance: QBR-to-standard, recap timeliness, health-play SLA hit-rate (alongside retention/expansion).Acceptance: ≥80% sessions to standard; ≥90% recap ≤48h; approvals/QBR trending up within a quarter.Output: Monthly enablement snapshot + quarterly improvement log; refreshed packs/templates.Why this matters: keeps enablement current and measurable without “enterprise” overhead (Concepts #7 & #8).
AppendixHow does it connect to the Client Business Goal levels?LevelEnablement Focus1.1 Technology SupportService Review kit for TAM (SLA/incident trends, lifecycle snapshot), mini-initiatives checklist, recap ≤48h.1.2 Technology EnablementQBR (C) kit for CSM + Digital CS elements (quarterly email + 3-min screen-recorded recap), adoption/DMI inputs from TAM, stakeholder map starter.1.3 Technology ModernizationQBR (B) kit (CSM Accountable; vCIO consulted) with roadmap pacing & simple Budget framing; objection-handling talk tracks; decision log template.1.4 Business TransformationAnnual Strategy Planning (vCIO Accountable, CSM Responsible) + outcome-led Executive QBR framing; OKR linkage; portfolio view; risk/controls hooks (vCISO consulted when relevant).1.5 Business InnovationAdvanced advisory enablement (vCxO/vCTO/vCISO playbooks), innovation portfolio canvas, value narrative patterns; exec-level recap & governance checklist.Cadence rule of thumb (mirrors Roles/Responsibilities):? A: Annual Strategy Planning + Executive QBR (up to 3/yr if budget permits)? B/C: Annual Strategy Planning + QBR (1–3/yr based on budget)? D: Annual IT Strategy + Service Reviews (monthly/quarterly or trigger-based)How does it connect to the other parts?? Client Business Goal — Enablement content and stage gates reflect the segment goal levels (D=1, C=2, B=3, A=4–5) and the meeting mix above.? Customer Success Health — Health snapshots and automation-first CTAs are built into the packs; they drive time-to-first-action <72h and recovery within the next cadence.? Customer Success Delivery — Every deliverable (Report, Assessment, Strategy Planning, Executive QBR/QBR, Service Review, Roadmap, Budget) has a template + checklist + talk track linked from the Role?Segment?Deliverable matrix.? Customer Success Process — Playbooks follow Trigger ? Prep ? Lead ? Follow-up and include a visible RACI stamp (Accountable | Responsible | Consulted | Informed | Backup) on every agenda.? Customer Success People — Enablement operationalizes 5.1 Roles and 5.2 Responsibilities: keep AM = commercial (Accountable) and CSM = health/cadence (Accountable) separate in RACI even when one person wears both hats.? Customer Success Strategy — Packs, SOPs, and vertical guides are segment-aware; senior capacity is focused on A/B while Digital CS and light kits keep C/D efficient.Product Links / Tooling SupportNot yet available in LMx. This blueprint lays the foundation for a future enablement module, such as role-based learning paths, in-app checklists, or competency matrices mapped to Customer Success functions.
?? 5.3 Compensation
5.3 CompensationOverviewWhat is the objective?Why is it important?As an MSP, why do I need to do this?What is the Customer impact?Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: Pay for outcomes, not output (anchor on GDR/GRR and NDR/NRR)Concept #2: Role-clear levers — AM/CSM are commercial; vCIO stays advisory; TAM anchors quality & adoptionConcept #3: Segment-aware compensation (D?A)Concept #4: Include a small, shared Health component (simple · predictive · actionable)Concept #5: Simple measurement: monthly Green/Yellow/Red, one quarterly payout, target 80% GreenConcept #6: QBR remains the evidence anchor in MSPsConcept #7: Mixed roles get blended weights (e.g., 30% AM / 70% vCIO)Concept #8: Ground base salary in MSP benchmarks; let this blueprint govern the variableImplementation ProcessStep 1 — Define the 3–4 outcomes each role is paid on (one-pager scorecards)Step 2 — Tie scorecards to your segments (A/B/C/D) and set payout cadencesStep 3 — Build a single calculator and the Green/Yellow/Red thresholdsStep 4 — Map metrics to data sources and the QBR evidence anchorStep 5 — Set governance rhythm (lightweight, predictable)Step 6 — Pilot ? Parallel Run ? Go-Live (minimal change management)Step 7 — Publish the starter kit so everyone can self-serveAppendixHow does it connect to the Client Business Goal levels?How does it connect to the other parts?Product Links / Tooling Support
OverviewWhat is the objective?Design a simple, segment-aware compensation model for CS roles (TAM, AM/CSM, vCIO, and—where justified—vCTO/vCISO) that pays for customer outcomes: retention (GRR), healthy growth (NRR), and visible Health improvements. Keep it calculable monthly and payable quarterly for a 10–150 person MSP, while preserving the advisory neutrality of strategic roles.Note: NRR (a.k.a. NDR) and GRR (a.k.a. GDR) aliases are treated equivalently for targets and payout math.Why is it important?? Compensation drives behaviour: the plan aligns day-to-day actions to renewals, right-sized expansion, and Health.? Prevents misalignment: no pay for raw activity (tickets/meetings) without outcomes that customers feel in QBRs.? Protects strategy: vCIO stays an unbiased advisor (no deal commissions).? Fair across segments: ops-heavy D/C aren’t over-bonused; A/B strategic work is recognized.? Easy to run: 3–4 metrics/role, Green/Yellow/Red thresholds, one quarterly payout.? Direct line-of-sight to the CS north star: variable components ladder to portfolio NRR/GRR with Health as a guardrail.As an MSP, why do I need to do this?? Make renewals predictable (AM/CSM variable on GRR/NRR with a light Health guardrail).? Lift adoption and quality (TAM variable tied to SLA trend, Adoption/DMI movement, lifecycle hygiene).? Keep strategy strategic (vCIO variable on portfolio outcomes: NRR, OKR/roadmap progress, Alignment).? Track simply and pay reliably (one spreadsheet calculator; monthly snapshots from CS tool/PSA/CRM/Billing).? Handle mixed hats cleanly (blended weights—for example, 30% AM / 70% vCIO—on one payslip).? Honor RACI ownership from 5.1/5.2 in crediting: NRR ? AM Accountable; CSM Consulted (Health), TAM Responsible (inputs), vCIO Consulted (A/B roadmap).What is the Customer impact?? Advisory over pressure: strategic reviews stay outcome-led, not sales-led.? Better QBRs: decisions and progress get rewarded, not slide count.? Higher reliability: incentives reinforce lifecycle hygiene, SLA consistency, and adoption follow-through.? Stronger trust and growth: pay aligns with the value customers experience, improving renewals and right-sized expansion.
Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: Pay for outcomes, not output (anchor on GDR/GRR and NDR/NRR)Typical MSP cases solved? Teams rack up meetings or tickets, but renewals don’t improve.? Expansion is pushed before the customer sees value or adopts the basics.How to apply? Make revenue-retention your primary levers: GRR/GDR = revenue kept (excluding expansion); NRR/NDR = revenue kept plus expansion/downgrades.? Track monthly in a simple sheet; pay quarterly. Limit each role to 3–4 metrics.? Credit expansion occurs only when a decision is captured in the QBR/JSP-Lite with the owner, date, and budget.? Use “decision latency” (days from proposal to approved decision) as a quality modifier for CSM/AM; A-segment Green ≤14 days (see KPI workbook).Practical examples? AM/CSM variable (quarterly): 60% GRR/GDR vs target, 40% NRR/NDR vs target.? Green/Yellow/Red example thresholds: GRR ≥95% = Green, 92–94.9% = Yellow, <92% = Red. NRR ≥102% = Green, 100–101.9% = Yellow, <100% = Red.? A-segment stretch box (portfolio): NRR ≥120% = Green; exec attendance ≥95% (credit gate); adoption depth ≥85%.What to measure? Monthly GRR/NRR snapshot by account and portfolio; QBR decisions logged; expansion dollars tied to approved initiatives.Common pitfalls? Paying for activity volume (meetings/tickets) with no link to retention.? Crediting expansion without QBR evidence or when engagement is weak.Concept #2: Role-clear levers — AM/CSM are commercial; vCIO stays advisory; TAM anchors quality & adoptionTypical MSP cases solved? vCIOs chase commissions and lose strategic trust.? TAMs don’t get credit for adoption and lifecycle hygiene, which makes renewals possible.How to apply? AM/CSM: variable tied to GRR/NRR, plus a light Health guardrail.? vCIO: no deal-by-deal commission; variable tied to portfolio outcomes across A/B (NRR, roadmap/OKR progress, Alignment).? TAM: variable tied to Service Quality trend, Adoption/DMI movement, and lifecycle completeness.? Digital touches (video/email) count the same as live sessions if the QBR/JSP-Lite “credit gate” is met.Practical examples? AM/CSM (quarterly): 60% GRR/GDR, 25% NRR/NDR, 15% Health guardrail (Engagement/CX not Red).? vCIO (annual, tracked quarterly): 50% portfolio NRR/NDR, 30% roadmap/OKR milestones accepted in QBRs, 20% Service Level Alignment trend.? TAM (quarterly): 40% SLA/resolution trend, 40% Adoption/DMI delta, 20% lifecycle completeness.What to measure? SLA/resolution trends, DMI/adoption %, Alignment colour, portfolio NRR/GRR by segment.Common pitfalls? Mixing sales commissions into vCIO pay.? Giving TAMs generic CSAT only, ignoring adoption/lifecycle outcomes.Concept #3: Segment-aware compensation (D?A)Typical MSP cases solved? Overpaying for reactive work in low-margin D/C accounts.? Under-rewarding high-effort strategic work in B/A accounts.How to apply? Keep metric types consistent across segments, change weights and thresholds with maturity.? Salary/variable mix gets more strategic as you move up the segments.? Mirror 5.2 “Definition of Done” by segment when setting Green thresholds (e.g., D = ≥1 quick win approved + recap ≤48h; C = ≥1 approval + recap ≤48h; B = 1–2 approvals + budget frame noted; A = ≤2 executive decisions + OKR link).Practical examples? Segment D (Goal 1—Support): 80% salary / 20% variable on SLA trend + CX; small retention guardrail.? Segment C (Goal 2—Enablement): 80/20; variable on Adoption/DMI trend + initiative approvals.? Segment B (Goal 3—Modernization): 75/25; variable on roadmap adoption, proposal velocity, and budget cadence.? Segment A (Goals 4–5—Transformation/Innovation): 85/15; variable on portfolio NRR, OKR progress, Alignment staying Green.What to measure? Thresholds by segment (e.g., Adoption Green in C = DMI +10 points quarter-over-quarter).Common pitfalls? One flat plan for all clients, regardless of maturity or margin.? Rewarding the same behaviours in D as in A.Concept #4: Include a small, shared Health component (simple · predictive · actionable)Typical MSP cases solved? “Revenue at any cost” behaviour hurts experience and long-term retention.? Leaders can’t spot early risk when cadence/adoption slips.How to apply? Dedicate 10–20% of the variables to health signals the team can influence weekly: Engagement (on-course with the right people), adoption/DMI trend, service quality trend, and alignment.? Use a colour model with clear, segment-specific thresholds.? A-segment guardrail: if Executive QBR attendance (CEO/CFO) <95% in a quarter, expansion credit from A accounts is deferred until a decision meeting occurs.Practical examples? Engagement Green = last QBR held on schedule with decision-maker present and recap ≤48h; Yellow = late or no decision-maker once; Red = late twice or no decision-maker twice.? Guardrail: if Engagement is Red for 2+ months, expansion $ from that account doesn’t count toward NRR that quarter; credit returns when Engagement is back to Yellow/Green, and a QBR resets next steps.What to measure? Monthly Health colours, time-to-first-action after a Health trigger, rebound by next cadence.Common pitfalls? There are too many health inputs and thresholds that no one understands.? Treating Health as a report, not a trigger for CTAs/Playbooks.Concept #5: Simple measurement: monthly Green/Yellow/Red, one quarterly payout, target 80% GreenTypical MSP cases solved? Scorecards no one can compute; endless disputes about “what counts.”How to apply? Set G/Y/R thresholds per metric; update one page per person monthly; aim for ~80% Green mid-quarter.? Pay once per quarter with a transparent formula.? Apply the same formula to blended roles by weighting the underlying role plans (see Concept #7).Practical examples? Payout math: Paid Variable = Target Bonus ? (0.5 ? %Green + 0.25 ? %Yellow).? Reds trigger coaching/enablement actions, not ad-hoc exceptions.What to measure? %Green/%Yellow/%Red per role, per person; correlation to GRR/NRR.Common pitfalls? Paying monthly (too noisy for SMB MSPs).? Over-weighting Yellow so mediocre months pay like great ones. Concept #6: QBR remains the evidence anchor in MSPsTypical MSP cases solved? Slide-heavy reviews with no decisions; disputes about whether value was delivered.? Expansion is credited before outcomes are accepted.How to apply? Use QBR/JSP-Lite artifacts to confirm decisions and progress.? Make “credit gates” explicit: decision captured with owner, date, and budget in QBR notes, or it doesn’t count.? Digital QBRs/email+video recaps qualify if the credit gate fields are present and the recap is sent ≤48h.Practical examples? Count expansion only when the initiative is approved in QBR and scheduled (owner/date in system).? Evidence first slide: Health snapshot ? Roadmap progress ? Decisions (max 2) with owners/dates.What to measure? Approvals per QBR, time-to-decision, % sessions with saved JSP-Lite + recap ≤48h.Common pitfalls? Crediting “verbal approvals.”? No owner/date/budget in notes; no recap within 48 hours.Concept #7: Mixed roles get blended weights (e.g., 30% AM / 70% vCIO)Typical MSP cases solved? Small teams wear multiple hats; incentives pull in different directions.How to apply? One plan, one calculator: Payout = 0.3 ? AM plan + 0.7 ? vCIO plan (example).? Keep thresholds identical to the role plans; publish the split on the scorecard.? Blends must follow RACI credit rules (e.g., NRR counted toward AM component; roadmap/Alignment toward vCIO component).Practical examples? “Strategy Consultant (AM 30% / vCIO 70%)”: same quarterly cadence; AM metrics (GRR/NRR) blended with vCIO metrics (portfolio NRR, OKR milestones, Alignment trend).What to measure? Actual account mix vs. intended split; payout alignment with time spent by segment.Common pitfalls? Two separate plans and two payouts.? Double-counting expansion across AM and vCIO.Concept #8: Ground base salary in MSP benchmarks; let this blueprint govern the variableTypical MSP cases solved? Debates about “fair base” derail the comp conversation.? Using SaaS salary data that doesn’t fit MSP margins.How to apply? Use MSP/TSP market reports for base ranges by role and region; review annually.? Keep variable logic here segment-aware and outcome-tied; don’t over-engineer.Practical examples (typical targets; tune to your margins/region)? TAM: 10–15% variable.? CSM/AM: 15–25% variable.? vCIO: 10–20% variable (annual, tracked quarterly), no deal commission.? Specialists (vCISO/vCTO when used): match vCIO style—portfolio outcomes, not per-deal commission.What to measure? Offer acceptance vs. market; retention of high performers; variable as a % of gross margin.Common pitfalls? Changing the base mid-year to fix behaviour (use variable weights/thresholds instead).? Setting the variable so high encourages short-term pushes over long-term retention.
Implementation ProcessAligning incentives to client outcomes with segment-aware, health-guardrail scorecardsStep 1 — Define 3–4 outcomes per role (one-page scorecards)Owner: CS Lead with FinanceInputs: 5.1 Roles, 5.2 Responsibilities, 5.3 Enablement, current segment mix (A/B/C/D), revenue targetsAction:? Pick 3–4 metrics max for each role and write plain-English definitions + Green/Yellow/Red thresholds.? AM/CSM: GRR/GDR, NRR/NDR, Health guardrail (Engagement/CX not Red), QBR evidence present.? vCIO: Portfolio NRR/NDR (A/B accounts), roadmap/OKR milestones accepted in QBRs, Service Level Alignment trend.? TAM: SLA/resolution trend, Adoption/DMI delta, lifecycle completeness.? Add a Mixed Role line (e.g., “30% AM / 70% vCIO”) so blended plans are just weighted averages.? Put everything on one page per role.? Include “decision latency” and Exec QBR attendance (A-segment) as quality modifiers pulled from the KPI sheet.Acceptance:? ≤4 metrics per role, each with a clear definition and G/Y/R thresholds.? Anyone can explain the scorecard in 2 minutes.Output: Role scorecards v1 (one-pagers).Why this matters: Locks “pay for outcomes” and keeps advisory/commercial/quality levers role-clear (Concepts #1, #2).Step 2 — Tie scorecards to segments and set payout cadencesOwner: CS LeadInputs: Segment rules (A/B/C/D), meeting cadence, margin targets, Client Segmentation (Appetite ? Maturity) worksheetAction:? Create a simple “Segment ? Weights” table per role (D/C/B/A rows; weights for each metric as columns).? Set the salary/variable mix by segment (e.g., D is more salary-heavy; A is tied to portfolio outcomes).? Set payout cadence: AM/CSM/TAM quarterly; vCIO annual (tracked quarterly).? Define eligibility basics (proration for new hires, leave, partial quarter).? Copy the “Definition of Done by segment” from 5.2 into the Threshold Library to standardize Green.Acceptance:? One page maps segments to weights and cadence; no exceptions needed to run payroll.Output: Segment?Weight Map (posted next to scorecards).Why this matters: Aligns incentives to client maturity and effort without creating different plans per client (Concept #3).Step 3 — Build one calculator and the Green/Yellow/Red thresholdsOwner: Finance (with CS Lead)Inputs: Scorecards + Segment?Weight Map + KPI thresholds (exec attendance, decision latency, adoption depth)Action:? Make a single spreadsheet (or Google Sheet) with tabs:1. Threshold Library (role metrics with G/Y/R),2. Role Calcs (AM/CSM, TAM, vCIO),3. Mixed Roles (blend = weight ? role plan),4. Person Summary (per-person payout).? Use a transparent formula, e.g.: Paid Variable = Target Bonus ? (0.5 ? %Green + 0.25 ? %Yellow)? Encode guardrails: e.g., if Engagement = Red for 2+ months, expansion from that account doesn’t count toward NRR this quarter (auto-flag).? Preload example GRR/NRR math so Finance and CS calculate the same way.? Add A-segment gates: Exec attendance <95% or decision latency >14 days ? defer expansion credit until resolved.Acceptance:? Data entry <30 minutes/month; the sheet returns one payout number per person.? Anyone can audit where a number came from in 3 clicks.Output: Compensation Calculator v1.Why this matters: Removes disputes and keeps the plan compute-light (Concepts #4, #5, #7).Step 4 — Map metrics to data sources and set the QBR “credit gate”Owner: CS Ops-Lite (or Finance if Ops-Lite doesn’t exist) Inputs: CS tool/PSA/CRM/Billing exports, Health dashboard, QBR/JSP-Lite templateAction:? Create a one-page Data Map: GRR/NRR ? which export/fields; Health ? which indicators; SLA/Adoption ? which reports.? Schedule a monthly snapshot day; save CSVs to a shared folder.? Add a “credit gate” block to the QBR template: a decision only counts when notes show decision, owner, date, and budget.? Add a short “Where numbers come from” appendix to the calculator (field names and links).? State explicitly that digital QBRs count if credit-gate fields are present and recap ≤48h.Acceptance:? Every metric has one link to its source; QBR evidence fields exist and are used.Output: Data Map + QBR Credit Gate guide.Why this matters: Keeps credit tied to outcomes customers actually accepted in QBRs (Concept #6).Step 5 — Set a lightweight governance rhythmOwner: CS Lead (Finance invited for 10 minutes)Inputs: Calculator snapshots, Health view, exceptions listAction:? Monthly (30–45 min): review each person’s G/Y/R mix, note coaching/enablement needs, and confirm any Health guardrails triggered.? Quarterly: close numbers after the QBR cycle ends; approve payouts for AM/CSM/TAM; review vCIO progress (pay annually).? Annually: adjust thresholds/weights only once; don’t change rules mid-year.? Review A-segment attendance/latency flags as part of the quarterly close before granting expansion credit.Acceptance:? Reviews happen on the calendar, payouts are on time, and there are no ad-hoc plan edits in mid-quarter.Output: Calendar holds + a 1-page “Comp Review Notes” per quarter.Why this matters: Predictable reviews drive behaviour and reduce noise (Concept #5).Step 6 — Pilot ? Parallel Run ? Go-LiveOwner: CS Lead with Finance Inputs: Steps 1–5 completedAction:? Pilot one quarter with AM/CSM on B/C segments (10–20 accounts).? Parallel run one more quarter (calculate but don’t pay) to tune thresholds and the Health guardrail.? Go-live in the following quarter; publish the final plan and stop exceptions.? Include at least one A-segment account in parallel run to validate exec-attendance and latency gates.Acceptance:? Pilot and parallel results were documented; there were fewer than two threshold tweaks before they went live.Output: Signed Compensation Plan v1.0 + archived pilot sheets.Why this matters: Changes behaviour safely without whiplash (Concepts #1–#5).Step 7 — Publish the starter kit so everyone can self-serveOwner: CS LeadInputs: Final plan, calculator, templatesAction:? Post a simple pack in your workspace:? Scorecard templates (AM/CSM, vCIO, TAM, Mixed).? Threshold Library by segment (what’s Green/Yellow/Red).? QBR note template with the credit-gate block.? “Where numbers come from” one-pager (exports/fields).? FAQ (eligibility, proration, mixed roles, dispute window).? Add a 10-minute Loom walking through a worked example.? Add a “Credit Gate Quick Check” slide for digital touches (what qualifies / what doesn’t).Acceptance:? New hires can understand their plan in one sitting; managers can run the math solo.Output: Compensation Starter Kit v1 (shared folder + links in the calculator).Why this matters: Keeps the system durable and low-touch as you grow (Concepts #2, #7, #8).
AppendixHow does it connect to the Client Business Goal levels?LevelCompensation Focus1.1 Technology SupportSalary-heavy with a small SLA/Service Quality variable and a simple CX/Engagement guardrail. Renewal hygiene only, no activity pay.1.2 Technology EnablementIntroduces GRR/GDR with a Health guardrail (Engagement/CX) and cadence discipline. No CSAT-only bonuses; evidence comes from QBR notes.1.3 Technology ModernizationVariable tied to Adoption/Health (e.g., DMI/adoption trend), initiative approvals and budget cadence, with QBR evidence (decision, owner, date).1.4 Business TransformationGoals-based comp is tied to portfolio outcomes (NRR/NDR), roadmap/OKR progress, and alignment. Advisory roles remain non-commissioned.1.5 Business InnovationStrategic levers: portfolio-level NRR/NDR, OKR contribution, and co-managed innovation milestones for Segment A accounts, evidenced in Executive QBRs.Segment A target box (align with KPI workbook): exec attendance ≥95%; decision latency ≤14 days; adoption depth ≥85%; portfolio NRR ≥120%.How does it connect to the other parts?? 1. Client Business Goal – Comp weights shift with client maturity: D focuses on stability (SLA/CX guardrail), C on adoption and basic approvals, B on roadmap/budget progress, A on portfolio outcomes and OKR progress.? 2. Customer Success Health – A small shared Health component (Engagement, Adoption/DMI, Service Quality, Alignment) acts as an early, actionable guardrail.? 3. Customer Success Delivery – Rewards are tied to outcomes evidenced in QBRs/JSP-Lite (decision, owner, date, budget), not meeting or ticket volume.? 4. Customer Success Process – Cadence adherence and simple playbook follow-through can be lightly incentivized, especially in early maturity.? 5. Customer Success People – Mirrors Roles & Responsibilities: AM/CSM = commercial (GRR/GDR, NRR/NDR), vCIO = advisory with portfolio outcomes (no deal commission), TAM = quality/adoption. Uses Enablement artifacts (QBR kit + JSP-Lite, recap ≤48h) as the credit gate.? 7. Customer Success Strategy – Segment-aware comp prevents over-servicing low-margin tiers and aligns incentives where strategic impact is realistic.Data & RACI alignment: metric ownership/credit follows the RACI map from 5.1/5.2; digital vs. live format does not change credit if the gate is met.Product Links / Tooling SupportNot yet available in LMx. This blueprint supports future functionality such as compensation tracking dashboards, CS performance analytics, or bonus/variable pay modelling based on Health Score and initiative outcomes.
?? 5.4 Governance
5.4 GovernanceOverviewWhat is the objective?Why is it important?As an MSP, why do I need to do this?What is the Customer impact?Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: Role & Responsibility Clarity (RACI-by-Segment one-pager)Concept #2: Process & Campaign Governance (from intake ? close)Concept #3: Health ? Playbooks Automation (alerts create tasks)Concept #4: Data & Reporting Cadence (one source of truth)Concept #5: Tooling Governance (declare the stack & handoffs)Concept #6: Lightweight OKRs that fit MSP CS (quarterly)Concept #7: Meeting Rhythm that enforces accountabilityImplementation ProcessStep 1 — Publish RACI-by-Segment (the one-pager set)Step 2 — Standardize Process & Campaign Governance (Pre-Flight ? In-Flight ? Close-Out)Step 3 — Fix Data & Reporting Cadence (one source of truth)Step 4 — Tooling Governance (declare the stack & handoffs)Step 5 — Health ? Playbooks Automation (alerts create tasks)Step 6 — Lightweight OKRs (quarterly, outcome-based)Step 7 — Internal Meeting Rhythm (short, repeatable, useful)Step 8 — Quarterly Governance Review (tune & scale)30–60–90 Day Rollout (for a 1–5 person CS team)Final Output: Your Governance Starter Kit (deliverables)AppendixHow does it connect to the Client Business Goal levels?How does it connect to the other parts?Product Links / Tooling Support
OverviewWhat is the objective?To create a lightweight, segment-aware operating system that keeps Customer Success coordinated, measurable, and improving across your MSP. Governance defines how roles stay accountable, how processes and “campaigns” (e.g., security rollouts) are run, which data is trusted and reviewed, what tools are used, how OKRs are set and tracked, and how internal meetings drive action—so QBRs, roadmaps, and Health work the same way for every client, every quarter.Align governance explicitly to the CS north star: NRR/NDR and GRR/GDR are treated as equivalent aliases in all reports, gates, and decisions.Digital touches (email + 3-min video, digital QBR) are fully valid if “credit-gate” fields are present; format does not change ownership or evidence rules.Why is it important?? Prevents “random acts of CS”: the same playbooks, evidence, and decisions are in every QBR—backed by agreed metrics and owners. ? Turns Health into action: changes in Engagement, Adoption/DMI, CX, or Alignment automatically trigger CTAs/plays, not debates. ? Protects strategic conversations: advisory roles (e.g., vCIO) are measured on portfolio outcomes and OKRs—not ticket volume or deal commissions. ? Scales a small CS team: a clear cadence and CS Ops habits reduce heroics and keep execution consistent as you grow.? Ensures RACI from 5.1/5.2 is visible in every forum (Accountable + named Backup) and that Compensation (5.3) crediting follows those same owners.As an MSP, why do I need to do this?? Make QBRs decisive, not performative: standard agendas, decision logs, and follow-ups tie every recommendation to business outcomes.? Run service “campaigns” cleanly: before you push a stack change (e.g., MFA), align owners, success criteria, timing, and the joint client message.? See the truth weekly/monthly: one Health + retention view (GRR/NRR) with simple Green/Yellow/Red rules—no spreadsheet archaeology.? Keep tools from owning you: declare the handful of systems of record (CS tool/PSA/CRM, Health, files) and the reports each one must produce.? Set and keep OKRs: lightweight CS OKRs drive quarterly focus across A/B clients (strategy) and C/D clients (stability/adoption).? Adopt KPI gates from the attachments: Segment A exec attendance ≥95% and decision latency ≤14 days; track and enforce via the governance rhythm.What is the Customer impact?? Clear, repeatable experience: clients see the same reliable rhythm—prep ? QBR ? decisions ? delivery—regardless of who attends. ? Faster value realization: adoption gaps surface early; following initiatives are approved sooner; outcomes are documented and revisited.? Executive-level confidence: QBRs focus on results and risk, not activity lists—building trust and renewal readiness.? No friction from format changes: digital or live, the same standards and owners apply.
Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: Role & Responsibility Clarity (RACI-by-Segment one-pager)When account work “floats” between AM/CSM, TAM, and vCIO, tactical items pile onto senior people, strategic A/B accounts slip; onboarding and QBRs become personality-driven instead of predictable. A simple, segment-specific RACI makes decision rights explicit and keeps senior roles focused on the right clients. Publish a single living page per segment that names the Accountable owner for each recurring deliverable (QBR, Roadmap, Budget, Adoption/DMI review), plus Responsible/Consulted/Informed. This mirrors how mature MSPs divide AM vs. vCIO work and how QBR/vCIO motions are meant to run.Include a Named Backup for every Accountable, per 5.1, and cross-reference the CS Function Role Mapping so compensation crediting in 5.3 follows the same owner.Practical example? Segment C: QBR ? ? CSM (Accountable), TAM (Consulted – lifecycle inputs), AM (Consulted – commercial)? Adoption/DMI ? CSM (Accountable – initiative follow-through), TAM (Responsible – assessment/config inputs)? Segment A/B: Roadmap & Budget ? vCIO (Accountable), CSM (Responsible – cadence & approvals), AM (Consulted – commercial), TAM (Consulted – risk/tech).? Put the four RACIs (A, B, C, D) in your playbooks; review quarterly and align the A-owner to compensation measures.Concept #2: Process & Campaign Governance (from intake ? close)Many MSPs run “random acts of projects” — stack upgrades or security pushes start without shared messaging, owners, or success criteria; QBRs list activity but not decisions or next steps. Standardize every portfolio initiative with Pre-Flight ? In-Flight ? Close-Out so campaigns are consistent across segments and traceable in QBRs. This matches proven vCIO/QBR workflows (assessments, exec summaries, roadmap, budgets) used by strategic MSPs.Use the 5.2 “Definition of Done” by segment as acceptance criteria (e.g., B: 1–2 approvals + budget frame; A: ≤2 exec decisions + OKR link).Enforce the QBR “credit-gate”: decision, owner, date, and budget must be present in the notes/JSP-Lite—digital and live formats treated equally.Practical example? Pre-Flight (30 min): define target segments, talk tracks, service-catalog item, RACI, timeline, and success criteria.? In-Flight (weekly 15 min): count initiatives created/approved/delivered, clear blockers, confirm owners.? Close-Out: document outcomes, update the playbook & service-catalog entry.? QBR credit gate: expansion/roadmap credit counts only if the QBR note shows owner + date + budget.Concept #3: Health ? Playbooks Automation (alerts create tasks)Health signals often sit in a dashboard no one opens. Dips in CX, Engagement, Adoption/DMI, or Alignment should automatically create tasks with clear owners and due dates—so the right person runs a small, repeatable play without debate. This aligns with Enablement Concept #4 and keeps actions fast and consistent.Treat Service Quality as a TAM-owned input feeding Adoption/Alignment (do not add a sixth Health dimension).Track “First Action SLA <72h” on all triggered CTAs.Practical exampleDefine four core triggers (automation-first) and two optional ones. Each trigger = Owner + Due-by window + 3–4 step play + expected output.? Engagement down (missed two touchpoints or no decision in 30 days) Owner: CSM · Due: 72h Play: send 2-line recap ? propose 30-min reset ? add/mobilize the exec if missing. Output: reset booked; JSP-Lite updated; next approval attempt scheduled.? CX down (negative pulse) Owner: CSM · Due: 48h Play: “We own the miss” call ? write 3-point fix plan ? book 14-day check-in. Output: plan logged; client acknowledged; follow-up on calendar.? Adoption/DMI below threshold (e.g., MFA <60% or endpoint compliance <80%) Owner: TAM · Due: 5 days Play: run 3-step remediation ? 15-min ops sync ? pre-approve one quick win before next QBR. Output: mini-initiative opened with owner/date; risk reduced.? Alignment low (“roadmap not relevant”) Owner: vCIO · Due: 7 days Play: 20-minute goal check ? re-map to business goals ? resequence/cut items. Output: refreshed roadmap; next decision checkpoint booked.? Optional (use if helpful)? Missed SLA threshold ? TAM · Due: 5 days · Play: root-cause + client comms ? Output: fix plan sent.? Stakeholder change ? CSM · Due: 10 days · Play: new exec intro + value recap ? Output: sponsor confirmed.Segment nuance? D/C: prioritize quick-win catalog items (low lift).? B: Add a budget frame to each ask.? A: Ensure executive sponsor is present; keep approvals to a maximum of two.How to implement? Create the four automation rules in your PSA/CRM/CS tool with owner, due date, and the play’s task checklist pre-filled; keep the two optional rules in draft for later.? Prewrite email/snippet text so plays are plug-and-play.? Add a “First Action SLA <72h” widget to the CS dashboard.What to measure: Time-to-first-action; resolution within one cadence cycle; score rebound by following review.Common pitfalls: Assigning to “the team” instead of a named owner; vague due dates; too many rules; no defined output.Concept #4: Data & Reporting Cadence (one source of truth)Weekly firefighting happens because data is scattered across PSA, sheets, and inboxes; teams don’t share one trustworthy view of Health, QBR completion, or initiative status. Pick systems of record and set a weekly + monthly reporting rhythm everyone uses: PSA for tickets/projects, CS/Health workspace for CX/Engagement/Adoption/Alignment, and a simple finance roll-up for GRR/NRR. MSP best practice is to anchor operational truth in the PSA and layer CS/health and finance views on top.Add two KPI gates portfolio-wide (from the KPI workbook): (1) Executive attendance rate in Segment A; (2) Decision latency from proposal to approved decision; display both on the Monthly Portfolio dashboard.Normalize NRR/NDR and GRR/GDR in reporting (one label in UI, both accepted in inputs).Flag qualifying digital QBRs identically if credit-gate fields are present and recap ≤48h.Practical example? Weekly CS Ops (30 min): top 10 accounts by Health delta; assign the matching playbook; confirm due dates.? Monthly portfolio (60 min): Segment A/B/C/D dashboard — GRR/NRR trend, QBR completion %, Adoption/DMI trend, open initiatives by stage.Concept #5: Tooling Governance (declare the stack & handoffs)Notes, approvals, and assets often land in the wrong place, so nothing reconciles. Publish a one-page “What lives where”: PSA = tickets/projects/SLA; CRM = contacts/opps; CS/Health = scores, CTAs, playbooks; Documentation = SOPs/diagrams. Map handoffs so QBR notes and approvals flow into the right system (automation if possible, checklist if not). Consolidating around PSA/CRM/CS tools is the norm for MSPs, and reporting is kept reliable.Embed three template blocks everywhere: (a) RACI stamp (Accountable + Backup), (b) Stakeholder block (Name · Role · Decision right), (c) Credit-gate fields (decision, owner, date, budget).Store JSP-Lite and digital recaps in the same system of record as live QBRs.Practical example (ready to copy)? Add a 5-item data hygiene checklist to every QBR/roadmap template: (1) attendees recorded (CRM), (2) Health snapshot filed (CS tool), (3) decisions + owners (PSA project/initiative), (4) budget placeholder (PSA/finance), (5) next cadence set (calendar).? Audit one account per segment monthly; fix gaps before quarter end.Concept #6: Lightweight OKRs that fit MSP CS (quarterly)Goals often become activity lists (e.g., “do more meetings”) instead of outcomes tied to retention and modernization. Use quarterly, lightweight OKRs at team and role level (1–3 Objectives; 2–4 measurable KRs), scored monthly; expect ~70% success as a healthy stretch. This format is widely adopted because it aligns day-to-day execution to customer outcomes without a heavy process. Link at least one KR per quarter to NRR/GRR movement and one to decision latency/exec attendance where applicable (Segments A/B).Practical example (ready to copy)? Team OKR (Q): “Increase portfolio retention confidence.”? KR1: QBR completion ≥95% in A, ≥90% in B/C.? KR2: +8-pt average Adoption/DMI gain in C accounts with open initiatives.? Role OKR (vCIO, A/B): “Advance strategic outcomes.”? KR1: ≥75% of approved roadmap items delivered on time.? KR2: Exec CX +5 points in A accounts.Concept #7: Meeting Rhythm that enforces accountabilityInternal reviews are irregular, so playbooks stall and risks linger until renewal. Set a simple, repeatable cadence that clears blockers and keeps Health-triggered CTAs moving, tied to your QBR rhythm. MSP guidance emphasizes predictable review forums around QBR content and AM/vCIO handoffs.Add “credit-gate check” to Weekly AM/CSM and Monthly Portfolio agendas; treat digital and live sessions the same.Review any A-segment exec-attendance or latency breaches before counting expansion in the quarter.Practical example? Weekly AM/CSM (30 min): next 14 days of QBRs — agenda, assets, “ask,” and follow-ups assigned.? Weekly CS Ops (20 min): data freshness check, trigger audits, field corrections.? Monthly Segment Review (60 min): heatmap (Health, GRR/NRR, backlog); reassign owners; launch/close campaigns.? Quarterly Portfolio (90 min): OKR score, playbook updates, compensation calibration based on agreed metrics.
Implementation ProcessStep 1 — Publish RACI-by-Segment (the one-pager set)Goal: End role drift; make accountability visible for every recurring CS deliverable.Owner: CS Lead (with AM/CSM, TAM, vCIO input)Do this? Create four single-page RACIs (Segments A, B, C, D). For each deliverable (QBR, Roadmap, Budget, Adoption/DMI Review, Initiative Intake, Decision Log), mark A/R/C/I across TAM, AM/CSM, vCIO, and Specialists.? Keep A/B strategic: vCIO is Accountable for Roadmap/Budget in A/B; C/D tactical: TAM is Accountable for Adoption/DMI in C/D.? Post the four pages inside your playbooks and share them on the team channel.? Add a Named Backup in every RACI cell and mirror the CS Function Role Mapping; ensure 5.3 crediting references the same Accountable.Definition of done? RACI (A–D) published that each A (Accountable) owner has a matching metric on their scorecard (ties to Compensation).Step 2 — Standardize Process & Campaign Governance (Pre-Flight ? In-Flight ? Close-Out)Goal: Make initiatives (e.g., MFA rollout, stack upgrades) repeatable and traceable.Owner: CS Lead (vCIO leads for A/B; CSM for C; TAM for D).Do this? Pre-Flight (template): target segments, value story and talk tracks, service-catalog entry, RACI, timeline, success criteria.? In-Flight (15-min weekly huddle): initiated/approved/delivered counts, blockers, and subsequent owner.? Close-Out: outcomes vs. plan; update the playbook and the catalog item; capture lessons learned.? Add a QBR credit gate: an initiative “counts” only if the QBR Decision Log shows owner + date + budget.? Use 5.2 “Definition of Done by segment” to set Green thresholds for each campaign.Definition of done? One unified campaign template + live tracker; last QBRs show decisions captured.Step 3 — Fix Data & Reporting Cadence (one source of truth)Goal: Everyone sees the same Health and portfolio reality weekly and monthly.Owner: CS Ops (or the CS Lead if Ops doesn’t exist)Do this? Declare Systems of Record:? PSA: tickets, projects, SLA metrics, initiative tasks? CS/Health workspace: CX, Engagement, Adoption/DMI, Alignment, Health triggers & CTAs? CRM/Finance: stakeholders, GRR/NRR roll-up? Ship two views and stick to them:? Weekly CS Ops (30 min): top Health deltas (G/Y/R), playbook assigned, due date set.? Monthly Portfolio (60 min): Segment A/B/C/D dashboard — GRR/NRR trend, QBR completion %, Adoption/DMI trend, open initiatives by stage.? Add KPI tiles for A-segment exec attendance and decision latency; normalize NRR/NDR and GRR/GDR labels.? Mark digital QBRs as “credit-gate met” when fields + ≤48h recap are present.Definition of done? Dashboards exist; meetings are on the calendar; the last 2 weeks show Health deltas ? CTAs with owners.Step 4 — Tooling Governance (declare the stack & handoffs)Goal: Notes/approvals land in the right place; nothing gets lost between tools.Owner: CS Ops (with CS tool/PSA/CRM admin)Do this? Publish a one-page “What lives where” map for PSA, CRM, CS/Health, and Documentation.? Add a 5-item data-hygiene checklist to every QBR/Roadmap template:1. Attendees recorded (CRM)2. Health snapshot attached (CS tool)3. decisions + owners logged (CS tool/PSA)4. budget placeholder (CS tool/PSA/Finance)5. Next cadence booked (calendar)? Automate where possible; use a simple checklist where not.? Embed RACI stamp, Stakeholder block, and Credit-gate fields on slide 1 / agenda header; store JSP-Lite alongside digital recaps.Definition of done? The map was published; one account per segment was audited monthly, and gaps were fixed before the quarter end.Step 5 — Health ? Playbooks Automation (alerts create tasks)Goal: Turn Health from a dashboard into action without heroics.Owner: CS Ops (rules) + Role owners (execution)Do thisStand up four core, automation-first triggers and keep two optional ones ready. Each trigger auto-creates a CTA with owner, due-by, and checklist:? Engagement down (missed two touchpoints / no decision in 30 days) Owner: CSM · Due: 72h Play: 2-line recap ? propose 30-min reset ? add/mobilize exec if missing. Output: reset booked; JSP-Lite updated; next approval attempt scheduled.? CX down (negative pulse) Owner: CSM · Due: 48h Play: “We own the miss” call ? 3-point fix plan ? 14-day check-in. Output: plan logged; client acknowledged; follow-up on calendar.? Adoption/DMI below threshold (e.g., MFA <60% or endpoint <80%) Owner: TAM · Due: 5 days Play: 3-step remediation ? 15-min ops sync ? pre-approve one quick win. Output: mini-initiative opened with owner/date; risk reduced.? Alignment low (“roadmap not relevant”) Owner: vCIO · Due: 7 days Play: 20-minute goal check ? re-map to business goals ? resequence/cut items. Output: refreshed roadmap; next decision checkpoint booked.? Optional (use if helpful)? Missed SLA threshold ? TAM · Due: 5 days · Play: root-cause + client comms.? Stakeholder change ? CSM · Due: 10 days · Play: new exec intro + value recap.Review trigger effectiveness monthly in the Portfolio review; tune thresholds or plays based on completion rates and rebound.Track First-Action SLA and completion by owner; keep Service Quality as TAM input, not a separate Health dimension.Definition of doneTriggers are live; new CTAs appear automatically with owners and due dates; completions are visible in the Monthly Portfolio dashboard; average time-to-first-action is under 72 hours. Step 6 — Lightweight OKRs (quarterly, outcome-based)Goal: Keep the team focused on outcomes that predict retention and progress.Owner: CS Lead (team OKR) + each role (role OKR)Timebox: 2 hours per quarter to set; 30 minutes monthly to scoreDo this? Set 1–3 Objectives per team/role; 2–4 Key Results each; score monthly.? Examples:? Team (Q): “Increase portfolio retention confidence.”? KR: QBR completion ≥95% in A, ≥90% in B/C? KR: +8-pt avg. Adoption/DMI gain in C accounts with open initiatives? vCIO (A/B): “Advance strategic outcomes.”? KR: ≥75% of approved roadmap items delivered on time? KR: Exec CX +5 points in A accounts? Add KR templates for A-segment exec attendance and decision latency to ensure governance enforces KPI gates.Definition of done? OKRs were published; green/yellow/red status was visible and discussed in the monthly portfolio review.Step 7 — Internal Meeting Rhythm (short, repeatable, proper)Goal: Clear blockers, prepare QBRs, and keep CTAs moving—without meeting bloat.Owner: CS LeadTimebox: Schedule once; run foreverDo this? Weekly AM/CSM (30 min): next 14 days of QBRs — agenda, assets, “ask,” follow-ups assigned.? Weekly CS Ops (20 min): data freshness, trigger audits, field corrections.? Monthly Segment Review (60 min): heatmap (Health, GRR/NRR, backlog); reassign owners; launch/close campaigns.? Quarterly Portfolio (90 min): OKR score, playbook updates, compensation calibration on agreed metrics.? Add “Credit-gate check” to Weekly AM/CSM and Monthly Segment Review; confirm digital sessions meet the same gate.? Before quarterly close, review any A-segment attendance/latency flags; defer expansion credit until resolved.Definition of done? Meetings on calendar with agendas; action logs show owners & dates; aging CTAs decrease.Step 8 — Quarterly Governance Review (tune & scale)Goal: Keep the operating system current as segments shift and team capacity changes.Owner: CS Lead + LeadershipTimebox: 60–90 minutes per quarterDo this? Refresh RACI-by-segment (any shifts A?B?C?D?).? Check trigger effectiveness (fewer escalations? faster approvals?).? Update campaign templates and service-catalog entries with lessons learned.? Review comp alignment: Are accountable owners measured based on the proper outcomes?? Update the Threshold Library (exec attendance, decision latency, adoption depth) from the KPI workbook; keep aliases NRR/NDR & GRR/GDR consistent.Definition of done? Updated artifacts were published; next quarter’s OKRs were set, and improvement actions were assigned.30–60–90 Day Rollout (for a 1–5 person CS team)? Days 1–30: Steps 1–3 (RACI, Campaign framework, Reporting cadence) live; first Weekly & Monthly reviews running.? Days 31–60: Steps 4–5 (Tooling map, Health triggers) activated; first CTAs auto-created; two campaign pilots run.? Days 61–90: Step 6–7 (OKRs + Meeting rhythm) fully adopted; Step 8 (Quarterly review) executed; tune thresholds and RACIs.? Include at least one A-segment account to validate exec-attendance and latency gates in the first 90 days.Final Output: Your Governance Starter Kit (deliverables)? RACI-by-Segment one-pager set (A/B/C/D)? Campaign runbook (Pre-Flight / In-Flight / Close-Out) + live tracker? Systems-of-Record map + QBR/Roadmap data-hygiene checklist? Weekly CS Ops and Monthly Portfolio dashboards + agendas? Health ? Playbooks trigger list (owners, due-by windows)? Quarterly OKRs (team + role) and internal meeting rhythm pack? Threshold Library & Data Map (incl. exec attendance, decision latency, adoption depth; alias normalization NRR/NDR & GRR/GDR)? Credit-gate guide for live/digital QBRs (fields + ≤48h recap) and Stakeholder/Invite logic blocksThis gives you a lean but complete operating system that keeps roles coordinated, Health actionable, and QBRs decisive—built to fit MSPs with small CS teams and a mixed A–D client portfolio.
AppendixHow does it connect to the Client Business Goal levels?LevelGovernance Focus1.1 Technology SupportInformal, founder-driven oversight; minimal process or documentation.1.2 Technology EnablementBasic meeting tracking, health reviews, and SOP adherence begin.1.3 Technology ModernizationDefined CS roles and cadences; visibility into client progress and initiative backlog.1.4 Business TransformationGovernance frameworks include stakeholder mapping, risk tracking, and delivery scorecards.1.5 Business InnovationGovernance includes joint planning, OKR alignment, and executive-level steering committees.A-segment add-ons: enforce exec attendance ≥95% and decision latency ≤14 days as portfolio gates; show both on the Monthly Portfolio dashboard.How does it connect to the other parts?? 1. Client Business Goal – Governance evolves with client maturity. As goals shift from reactive IT to business innovation, oversight expands to include initiative ROI, department alignment, and cross-functional impact reviews.? 2. Customer Success Health – Governance provides the structure for regular Health Score reviews and interventions. Without this, risk signals may go unnoticed or unresolved.? 3. Customer Success Delivery – Supports consistency in deliverables (e.g., reports, strategy, budgets) through standardized approval, presentation, and review workflows.? 4. Customer Success Process – Governance ensures that meetings, assessments, and initiatives follow SOPs, cadence rules, and intake procedures. It’s the “managerial layer” that enforces process quality. 5. Customer Success Compensation – Governance enforces the credit-gate and KPI gates so compensation credit follows RACI owners and only counts evidence-backed outcomes (live or digital).? 6. Customer Success People – Clarifies leadership, decision-making rights, and escalation paths across CS roles (e.g., Account Manager, CS Manager, vCIO). Supports team performance management and internal communication.? 7. Customer Success Strategy – Strategy cannot scale without governance. This includes role-based scorecards, team capacity models, and alignment with segmentation, service levels, and playbooks. Use the Segmentation Playbooks Worksheet and Client Segmentation (Appetite ? Maturity) to drive which governance gates apply by tier.Product Links / Tooling SupportNot currently available in LMx. Governance support may emerge through future features, such as CS playbook adherence tracking, team dashboards, approval workflows, or role-based delivery accountability.Future module wishlist: auto-tracking of exec attendance/decision latency; alias-aware NRR/GRR widgets; digital-QBR credit-gate prompts.
?? 5.5 Personal Relationship
5.5 Personal RelationshipOverviewWhat is the objective?Why is it important?As an MSP, why do I need to do this?What is the Customer impact?Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: Map Role ? Stakeholder by Segment (A–D) and make multithreading the defaultConcept # 2: Relationship rhythm by segment, with digital touches for C/D (format can flex; RACI cannot)Concept #3: Make Decision Velocity the primary relationship KPI (use JSP-Lite + QBR “credit gate”)Concept #4: Turn Health dips into automated relationship plays (alerts create tasks with owners & due dates)Concept #5: Persona-based messaging with pre-/post-comms templates (short, decisive, repeatable)Concept #6: Named Backup & continuity for every relationship (OOO, turnover, sponsor change)Concept #7: Build executive sponsorship in A/B (OKR-linked story, CFO in the room, two decisions max)Implementation ProcessStep 1 — Stakeholder Map & RACI-sync (per account, one page)Step 2 — Relationship Cadence & Meeting Mix (A–D)Step 3 — Persona-based Templates (pre-read, 3 slides, recap)Step 4 — Health ? Relationship Plays Automation (CTAs with owners & due dates)Step 5 — Decision Velocity & QBR “Credit Gate”Step 6 — Continuity: Named Backup, OOO, Sponsor-Change PlayStep 7 — Executive Sponsorship in A/B (OKR link, CFO present, ≤2 decisions)Step 8 — Digital CS for C/D (cohort send, quick-win catalog)Step 9 — Metrics, Reporting & Feedback (weekly/monthly)30–60–90 Day Rollout (for a 1–5 person CS team)AppendixHow it connects to the Client Business Goal levelsHow does it connect to the other parts?
OverviewWhat is the objective?Build a deliberate, segment-aware (A–D) relationship system where trust and “multi-threading” are managed—not left to chance. The objectives are to:? Ensure the right MSP role meets the right client stakeholder (TAM ? IT/Ops, CSM ? Ops/Admin/Team Leads, AM ? Budget Holder/Owner/CFO, vCIO/vCxO ? CEO/CFO).? Run a predictable touch rhythm (digital + live) matched to segment cadence and budget.? Measure relationship health (Engagement/CX, decision latency, execution follow-through, executive participation).? Make sponsor/contact changes low-risk (named backups, handover plays).? Tie all of this directly to the NRR/NDR and GRR/GDR north stars via the Growth Loop: Discover ? Align ? Deliver ? Measure.Why is it important?Even great strategy stalls without strong, multi-threaded relationships. A role-matched, repeatable relationship system:? Accelerates approvals and budget decisions (clear asks, the right people in the room).? Reduces escalation time and surprise risk through steady, relevant communication.? Survives personnel changes (executive sponsor or admin turnover).? Makes value visible at business, finance, and IT levels—lifting renewals and right-sized expansion (GRR/NRR).As an MSP, why do I need to do this?Because a small team must deliver a “big-company” experience consistently:? Role–stakeholder fit from 5.1: CSM is Accountable for relationship rhythm & Health; AM is Accountable for commercial; vCIO holds executive alignment; TAM anchors service quality and adoption inputs.? Touch mix by segment: executive pre-briefs and Executive QBRs in A; cadence-driven QBRs in B/C; digital quarterly touch + Service Reviews in C/D.? Ready-to-run relationship playbooks: new-sponsor onboarding, “we own the miss” recovery, decision-reset, and celebration/recognition.? Stakeholder map + preference card in PSA/CRM/CS: role, influence, decision rights, channel, frequency, backups.? Measurement that matters: Engagement/CX, decision latency, executive-attendance rate (A), recap ≤48h and follow-through ≤72h; Service Quality is a TAM-owned input that feeds Adoption/Alignment (not a separate Health dimension), reviewed in Service Reviews and surfaced in QBRs.? Tight alignment with 5.2 Enablement (kits, JSP-Lite), 5.4 Governance (RACI, triggers, cadence), and 5.3 Compensation (clear owners tied to outcomes).What is the Customer impact?For customers, the relationship feels:? Human and predictable (we show up with purpose, not at random).? Relevant (operational conversations with IT/Ops; outcome and value with executives).? Efficient (few but focused touches; 1–2 decisions per QBR; recap within 48 hours).? Resilient (if one contact steps out, the named backup already has context).? Transparent (a shared, easy-to-follow Joint Success Plan – Lite with owners and dates).Net effect: faster progress, fewer misunderstandings, higher trust—reflected in stronger renewals and expansion (GRR/NRR).
Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: Map Role ? Stakeholder by Segment (A–D) and make multithreading the defaultWhy it mattersWrong audience = no decision. One-contact risk = churn risk. Multithreading stabilizes engagement and speeds approvals.How to apply (use 5.1 RACI + your stakeholder map):? TAM ? IT/Ops (Service Review, lifecycle/adoption inputs).? CSM ? Ops/Admin/Team Leads (QBR cadence, decisions, follow-through).? AM ? Budget holder/Owner/Procurement (renewal, pricing, terms).? vCIO/vCxO ? CEO/CFO/MD (strategy, OKRs, prioritization).? vCISO ? Risk/Compliance, vCTO ? Tech-savvy exec/Architect (A, sometimes B).? Minimum 3 active threads per account (Ops, Finance/Owner, IT). Keep them current in the one-page stakeholder map (name, role, influence, channel, cadence, backup).Practical exampleSegment C QBR invite list template: CSM (Accountable), TAM (Consulted – lifecycle), Ops Lead (decision-maker), AM (commercial context, 1 slide).MeasureMultithread depth (# stakeholders/account), Executive Attendance Rate (A), “Right-person-in-room” %, Stakeholder map freshness.PitfallsToo many attendees; vCIO showing up in C/D by habit; stakeholder map not updated after staff changes.Concept # 2: Relationship rhythm by segment, with digital touches for C/D (format can flex; RACI cannot)Why it mattersConsistent rhythm builds trust and keeps decisions flowing without burning senior capacity.How to apply (align with 5.1 & 5.2 cadences):? A: Annual Strategy + 1–3 Exec QBRs (budget permitting). vCIO Accountable, CSM Responsible.? B/C: Annual Strategy + 1–3 QBRs. CSM Accountable (B: vCIO consulted; C: TAM consulted).? D: Annual IT Strategy + monthly/quarterly Service Reviews. TAM Accountable.? For C/D, add digital touch each quarter: email + 3-min screen-recorded video + “book-a-slot” link + SLA/DMI snapshot.? You may shorten formats when budgets are tight, but keep the same Accountable/Backup (RACI does not change with format).Practical exampleD-cohort (15 accounts) quarterly batch video: personalize first line + one next ask, attach SLA trend & lifecycle EOL list, embed booking link.MeasureTouch compliance %, QBR completion %, open/click/book rates (C/D), decisions/QBR.Pitfalls “Update” meetings with no decision; dropping the named owner when switching to digital.Concept #3: Make Decision Velocity the primary relationship KPI (use JSP-Lite + QBR “credit gate”)Why it mattersSlides don’t renew; decisions do. Fast approvals compress value realization and expansion timelines.How to apply (use the 3-slide kit from 5.2):1. Health snapshot (CX, Engagement, Adoption/DMI, Service Quality, Alignment).2. Roadmap/Initiatives (progress, blockers, new asks).3. Decisions & Next Steps — max 2, each with owner/date/budget.? Keep a one-page JSP-Lite as the single source of truth.? Apply the QBR credit gate from 5.4: expansion counts only if the decision is captured with owner/date/budget.Practical exampleSegment B QBR: CSM opens with Health & status ? vCIO sequences roadmap and ties to business outcomes ? 2 approvals landed ? recap ≤48h, tasks ≤72h, next decision date booked.MeasureDecision Latency (days/approval), Approvals per QBR, Recap ≤48h %, Next decision date set %.PitfallsNo decision request; missing owner/date/budget; recap not sent within 48h.Concept #4: Turn Health dips into automated relationship plays (alerts create tasks with owners & due dates)Why it mattersDashboards don’t fix risk—plays do. Automation keeps actions fast and consistent.How to apply (wire the four standard triggers from 5.4):? Engagement down (missed 2 touchpoints / no decision in 30 days) ? Owner: CSM · Due: 72h Play: 2-line recap ? propose 30-min reset ? add exec if missing ? update JSP-Lite.? CX down (negative pulse/complaint) ? Owner: CSM · Due: 48h Play: “we own the miss” call ? 3-point fix plan ? 14-day check-in.? Adoption/DMI below threshold (e.g., MFA <60% or endpoint <80%) ? Owner: TAM · Due: 5d Play: 3-step remediation ? 15-min ops sync ? pre-approve 1 quick win before next QBR.? Alignment low (“roadmap not relevant”) ? Owner: vCIO · Due: 7d Play: 20-min goal check ? resequence/cut ? schedule decision checkpoint.? Optional: Missed SLA threshold (TAM, 5d), Stakeholder change (CSM, 10d).Practical exampleC account Adoption –15%: TAM runs remediation; CSM owns 60-day follow-through with weekly 15-min sync until back to baseline.MeasureTime-to-first-action (<72h), rebound by next cadence, closed plays count.PitfallsAssigning to “the team,” vague due dates, too many rules launched at once.Concept #5: Persona-based messaging with pre-/post-comms templates (short, decisive, repeatable)Why it mattersRight message to the right persona reduces meeting time and increases approvals.How to apply (store in 5.2 Live-of-Work packs):? Talk tracks (2–3 prompts/role)? vCIO: value vs OKR, trade-offs, sequencing.? CSM: decision today, owners/dates, cadence/reset.? TAM: risk, lifecycle hygiene, adoption next step.? AM: renewal horizon, terms impact, budget window.? Templates? Pre-read (72–48h): subject, 3 bullets (last outcomes; today’s 1–2 proposed approvals; what happens next), deck link.? Recap (≤48h): summary, decisions (owner/date/budget), CTAs (≤72h in system), next meeting date.? “Approve by reply” snippet for C/D quick wins.Practical exampleA Exec QBR pre-read:1. Two outcomes since last exec session,2. Two proposed approvals (with budget ranges),3. Next milestone if approved.MeasurePre-read open rate, Recap ≤48h %, “approve by reply” conversions (C/D).PitfallsTech jargon for execs; newsletter-style updates with no ask; recaps that restate slides but miss owners/dates.Concept #6: Named Backup & continuity for every relationship (OOO, turnover, sponsor change)Why it mattersPeople move. Continuity preserves momentum and confidence.How to apply (bake into 5.1/5.4):? Name a Backup per account on the RACI sheet; show it on every agenda.? OOO handoff: calendar note + who covers which thread (IT/Ops, Finance/Owner, Exec).? Stakeholder change trigger (from 5.4): CSM · Due 10 days ? intro to new sponsor, 1-page value recap, confirm decision rights.Practical exampleAM leaves: within 24h send “Meet your team” intro (vCIO/CSM/TAM), book a 30-min relationship reset within 7 days, confirm the renewal window.MeasureHandoff time (trigger ? intro), “New Sponsor Onboarded ≤10 days” %, open relationship risks.Pitfalls “Backup = the team,” no reset call, old narrative copy-pasted for a new sponsor.Concept #7: Build executive sponsorship in A/B (OKR-linked story, CFO in the room, two decisions max)Why it mattersExecutive attention is scarce. Tie technology to business outcomes or lose momentum.How to apply (align with 5.1, 5.2, 5.3):? vCIO leads the OKR-linked narrative; CSM captures two decisions, owners, and dates.? Always include CFO/Budget holder when funding is implied.? Annual Strategy + 1–3 Exec QBRs; keep the agenda “outcomes first.”Practical exampleA account OKR: “Reduce downtime 40%.”? vCIO: resequence roadmap (DR drill, hardening) with value math.? CSM: Decision #1 approve DR test, Decision #2 adopt MFA policy; book checkpoint.? AM: note renewal timing; align pricing window.MeasureExecutive Attendance Rate, OKR-linked decisions count, time-to-budget checkpoint, Alignment colour trend.PitfallsvCIO sliding into sales mode (conflicts with 5.3), >2 decisions per exec session, skipping CFO when budget is needed.
Implementation ProcessStep 1 — Stakeholder Map & RACI-sync (per account, one page)Goal: Make multithreading explicit and name the Accountable/Backup for the relationship.Owner: CSM (inputs from TAM, AM, vCIO)Inputs: 5.1 RACI-by-segment, Client Segmentation Worksheet (A–D), CS Function Role Mapping, CRM contactsAction:? Build a one-pager: Name · Role · Influence (D/M/I) · Channel · Cadence · Backup.? Maintain ≥3 active threads per customer (IT/Ops, Budget/Owner, Executive).? Pair decision-makers to the right MSP role (TAM?IT, CSM?Ops, AM?Budget holder, vCIO?CEO/CFO).? Mirror 5.1 RACI (Accountable + Named Backup) and sync to CRM.Acceptance / DoD: One page per account shows ≥3 threads, decision-maker(s), named Backup, last-updated date.Output: “Stakeholder Map v1” stored in the account workspace and linked from agendas.Step 2 — Relationship Cadence & Meeting Mix (A–D)Goal: A predictable rhythm matched to segment and 5.1/5.2.Owner: CSM (calendar & invites). Support: TAM (C/D), vCIO (A/B)Inputs: Segmentation Worksheet, 5.2 meeting kits & templatesAction:? A: Annual Strategy + 1–3 Executive QBRs (budget-dependent) — vCIO Accountable, CSM Responsible.? B/C: Annual Strategy + 1–3 QBRs — CSM Accountable (B: vCIO consulted; C: TAM consulted).? D: Annual IT Strategy + monthly/quarterly Service Reviews — TAM Accountable.? Switch on digital touch for C/D (quarterly email + 3-min screen-recorded video + book-a-slot link + SLA/DMI snapshot).? Format can shorten; Accountable/Backup never changes (RACI stays fixed).Acceptance / DoD: Two quarters scheduled in calendar; QBR/Review templates attached; 48–72h pre-flight check confirms decision-maker attendance.Output: Segment-specific calendar + invite lists.Step 3 — Persona-based Templates (pre-read, 3 slides, recap)Goal: Short, decision-led messages per stakeholder persona.Owner: CSM (template steward: A/B = vCIO; C = CSM; D = TAM)Inputs: 5.2 QBR Kit + JSP-Lite, talk tracks, checklistsAction:? Use the 3-slide deck for all meetings: Health ? Roadmap ? Decisions (max 2; owner/date/budget).? Ship Pre-read (72–48h) and Recap ≤48h templates by segment/persona.? Add “Approve by reply” snippet for C/D quick-wins.? Pin all templates in the PSA/CRM account (≤2 clicks).Acceptance / DoD: Prep ≤60 minutes; every session has a pre-read & recap; JSP-Lite updated.Output: Linked template pack across all accounts.Step 4 — Health ? Relationship Plays Automation (CTAs with owners & due dates)Goal: Turn risk signals into fast action, not debate.Owner: CS Ops-Lite / CSM (rules). Execution: CSM/TAM/vCIOInputs: 5.4 trigger list, Health model (CX, Engagement, Adoption/DMI, Service Quality as TAM input feeding Adoption/Alignment, Alignment)Action (4 mandatory, 2 optional):? Engagement down ? CSM, 72h: 2-line recap ? 30-min reset ? add the exec ? update JSP-Lite.? CX down ? CSM, 48h: “we own the miss” call ? 3-point fix plan ? 14-day check-in.? Adoption/DMI low ?
