TAM, 5 days: 3-step remediation ? 15-min ops sync ? pre-approve one quick win.? Alignment low ? vCIO, 7 days: 20-min goal check ? re-map to business goals ? resequence/cut.? Optional: Missed SLA (TAM, 5 days) · Stakeholder change (CSM, 10 days).Acceptance / DoD: CTAs auto-created with named owner + due; time-to-first-action <72h.Output: Live trigger table + monthly rebound report.Step 5 — Decision Velocity & QBR “Credit Gate”Goal: Increase decision speed; only credit approved, evidenced decisions.Owner: CSM (JSP-Lite), vCIO (A/B storyline), AM (commercial notes)Inputs: 5.2 JSP-Lite, 5.4 credit-gate note block, KPI sheetAction:? End each session with ≤2 approvals ? log owner/date/budget ? update JSP-Lite.? Track Decision Latency (days per approval) and set the next decision date.? Count expansion (NRR/NDR) only after the credit gate is satisfied.Acceptance / DoD: Approvals/QBR ≥1 (A/B target = 2); Recap ≤48h; CTAs created ≤72h.Output: Decision log + monthly Decision Velocity chart.Step 6 — Continuity: Named Backup, OOO, Sponsor-Change PlayGoal: Keep momentum during absences or stakeholder turnoverOwner: CSM (coordination). Support: People/CS LeadInputs: 5.1 RACI (Backup), Governance triggersAction:? Maintain a Named Backup on every account (visible on agenda cover).? OOO handoff: who covers each thread (IT/Ops, Budget/Owner, Exec).? Stakeholder-change trigger (CSM, 10 days): new sponsor intro, 1-page value recap, confirm decision rights.Acceptance / DoD: OOO/exit notice sent ≤24h; ≤10 days sponsor reset call held.Output: Handoff note + refreshed stakeholder map.Step 7 — Executive Sponsorship in A/B (OKR link, CFO present, ≤2 decisions)Goal: Win and keep executive focus.Owner: vCIO (storyline), CSM (cadence & decisions), AM (budget/renewal context)Inputs: A/B Roadmap & OKRs, QBR Kit, 5.3 compensation guardrailsAction:? A/B: vCIO runs the OKR-linked story; CFO/budget holder present whenever money is needed.? Send pre-read 72–48h; cap at two decisions; book the next decision checkpoint.? CSM logs decisions; AM flags renewal window.Acceptance / DoD: Executive Attendance Rate improves; every exec session lands 1–2 approvals.Output: OKR-linked decision list + budget checkpoint.Step 8 — Digital CS for C/D (cohort send, quick-win catalog)Goal: Protect margins while keeping rhythm and perceived value high.Owner: CSM (content), TAM (data), approver: CS LeadInputs: SLA/DMI reports, quick-win catalog, 5.2 digital kitAction:? Quarterly cohort video (3 minutes) + personalized first line + 1 next ask + book-a-slot link.? Attach SLA trend, lifecycle/EOL, and a 2-question micro-survey.? Pilot with 10–15 accounts; then scale.Acceptance / DoD: Open ≥60%, Book ≥10%, ≥1 quick-win approved per cohort.Output: Documented digital flow + results snapshot.Step 9 — Metrics, Reporting & Feedback (weekly/monthly)Goal: Shared reality and fast course-correction.Owner: CS Ops-Lite / CSM LeadInputs: KPI worksheet, 5.4 reporting rhythm, 5.3 guardrailsAction:? Weekly CS Ops (30 min): Top Health deltas, assign plays, confirm dues.? Monthly Portfolio (60 min): Approvals/QBR, Decision Latency, Executive Attendance, Multithread Depth (# active threads with decision rights), QBR completion, GRR/NRR trend.? Flag when Health guardrails trigger (e.g., Engagement Red 2+ months ? expansion from that account does not count toward NRR this quarter; credit returns when back to Yellow/Green and a QBR resets next steps).Acceptance / DoD: Dashboard live; the last 2 weeks show Health deltas ? CTAs with owners; numbers end arguments.Output: Monthly Relationship Scorecard (team + segment view).30–60–90 Day Rollout (for a 1–5 person CS team)? Days 0–30: Steps 1–3 live (stakeholder map, cadence, templates). Pilot 3 A/B accounts and 5 C/D accounts.? Days 31–60: Steps 4–6 live (triggers, credit gate, Backup/OOO). First digital cohort for C/D.? Days 61–90: Steps 7–9 fully adopted (exec sponsorship routine, monthly scorecard, guardrails in effect). Tune thresholds.

? Archived: Roles
5.1 RolesOverviewWhat is the objective?Why is it important?As an MSP, why do I need to do this?What is the Customer impact?Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: Overview of CS RolesConcept #2: Account Assignments: Building Durable, Multi-Threaded RelationshipsConcept #3: Roles Should Follow the Client, Not the Org ChartConcept #4: Distinct Roles Create Scalable, High-Trust EngagementConcept #5: Role Clarity Is the Foundation for Accountability and GrowthConcept #6: CS Health Reveals Role Misalignment—Or MasteryConcept #7: Roles Are the Starting Point for the Whole People DisciplineImplementation ProcessDefining Roles for Scalable, Segment-Aware EngagementStep 1: Design Roles Based on Client Segments and Business GoalsStep 2: Assign Role Ownership for Key CS DeliverablesStep 3: Operationalize Roles Through Playbooks and Process AlignmentStep 4: Use CS Health as a Feedback Loop to Optimize Role CoverageStep 5: Review Roles Quarterly and Scale with Client & Team MaturityFinal Output: A Role-Aligned Customer Success SystemAppendixHow does it connect to the Client Business Goal levels?How does it connect to the other parts?Product Links / Tooling Support
OverviewWhat is the objective?To define the key Customer Success roles within the MSP that support effective delivery, strategic alignment, and client satisfaction. As clients mature and their goals evolve, the MSP must adapt by assigning roles that match their complexity, expectations, and engagement model. Role clarity ensures that the right people engage with the right clients at the right time, with the right level of depth, and that relationship coverage is resilient rather than dependent on a single person.Why is it important?? Clear roles prevent overlap, gaps, and confusion among clients.? Role specialization enables the delivery of scalable, high-quality services.? Supports predictable engagement models across client segments.? Aligns CS efforts with business outcomes, not just technical support.? Ensures human capital is aligned with the MSP’s delivery maturity and customer expectations.? Reduces the risk of relationship loss when team members or client stakeholders change, through multi-threaded relationship mapping.As an MSP, why do I need to do this?? Improves internal coordination between CS, sales, and service teams.? Helps match talent to client maturity and segment needs.? Supports hiring and onboarding by defining expectations and scope.? Enables better prioritization and accountability within CS operations.? Guides staffing decisions and skill development based on assessment of the gaps between current roles and desired customer experience.? It provides a clear path for scaling from a small team where one person wears multiple hats to a mature, multi-role CS structure.What is the Customer impact?? Clients interact with clearly defined contacts (e.g., CSM, TAM, vCIO) for specific needs.? Builds trust through consistent, role-aligned engagement.? Reduces confusion over who to contact for what, especially as complexity increases.? Enables higher-quality conversations focused on outcomes rather than just issues.? Ensures there are always multiple contact points so that no single relationship break jeopardizes client trust.Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: Overview of CS RolesEffective Customer Success (CS) is pivotal for Managed Service Providers (MSPs) aiming to align technology investments with client business outcomes. 1. Technical Account Manager (TAM)? Type: Tactical | Technology-focused? Core Responsibilities:? Ensuring operational stability, lifecycle management, and technology standards.? Proactive management of client technical infrastructure.? Required Skills? Technical proficiency in IT infrastructure and service delivery.? Strong organization and detail-oriented problem-solving skills.? Familiarity with industry-standard frameworks (e.g., ITIL, lifecycle management).? Job-To-Be-Done? Internal: Ensures operational consistency and technology quality, reducing client incidents.? Client: Provides reliability and proactive technical management, maintaining client confidence.? What makes them successful? Follows technical standards and MSP best practices? Proactively identifies risks and improvement areas? Communicates clearly with both technical and non-technical people? Keeps client systems aligned with lifecycle and compliance goals? What makes them less effective? Reacts to tickets instead of planning proactively? Over-complicates technical recommendations? Avoids client conversations or hides behind tools? Misses structured reviews or cadence
2. Account Manager (AM)? Type: Tactical | Business-focused? Core Responsibilities:? Managing client relationships, renewals, and communication.? Coordinating proposals, budgets, and client satisfaction.? Required Skills? Experience in account management, sales coordination, or customer relationship roles.? Exceptional communication, negotiation, and client relationship management skills.? Comfortable translating technical outcomes into business language.? Job-To-Be-Done? Internal: Ensures account stability, renewals, and effective internal coordination.? Client: Provides clear communication, trusted partnership, and strong relationship management.? What makes them successful? Maintains consistent, high-touch client communication? Understands the business value of renewals and upsells? Coordinates internal delivery teams and sets client expectations? Tracks health, satisfaction, and contract timelines? What makes them less effective? Focuses only on the relationship without strategic impact? Misses renewal dates or fails to grow accounts? Avoids tough conversations about scope or pricing? Lacks awareness of technical delivery status
3. Customer Success Manager (CSM)? Type: Tactical ? Strategic | Business-focused? Core Responsibilities:? Own Customer Health (CX, Engagement, Adoption, Alignment) and keep the cadence (QBR in B/C) on track.? Orchestrate initiatives: capture decisions, create/drive follow-ups, update roadmap/success plan.? Prepare and de-risk Strategy/Executive QBRs for A: pre-work, storyline, outcomes, next steps.? Signal risk early (low engagement/adoption), trigger playbooks, and coordinate internal roles (TAM, vCIO, PM).? Maintain clean records (LMx/CRM): meeting notes, approvals, health changes, stakeholder map.? Required Skills? Facilitation & stakeholder management; business storytelling; light financial literacy (budgets/ROI).? Data literacy on Health/Adoption; strong follow-through and task coordination.? Job-To-Be-Done? Internal: Keep the rhythm and translate Health signals into actions that move the roadmap.? Client: Make meetings valuable, keep promises visible, and turn discussions into approved outcomes.? What makes them successful? Runs a predictable cadence; sends clear summaries and closes actions.? Aligns proposals and initiatives to stated goals; multi-threads relationships.? Keeps LMx/CRM tidy; escalates early when engagement or adoption drops.? What makes them less effective? Over-indexes on slides vs. decisions; misses follow-ups.? Avoids healthy pushback or hard prioritization.? Poor data hygiene; health signals aren’t captured or acted on.? Segment calibration? D/C: Focus on Service Review inputs, basic QBR (C), initiative intake, adoption nudges.? B: Own QBRs, pace initiatives, prep Strategy Planning.? A: Co-pilot Executive QBRs with vCIO; drive exec-level follow-through and cross-dept coordination.
4. Virtual Chief Information Officer (vCIO)? Type: Strategic | Business-focused? Core Responsibilities:? Aligning technology strategy with client business objectives.? Strategic planning, budgeting, and executive engagement.? Required Skills? Proven experience in strategic technology leadership and business alignment.? Deep understanding of business operations and financial planning.? Strong analytical, strategic thinking, and executive presentation abilities.? Job-To-Be-Done? Internal: Drives strategic client growth, translating technical service delivery into business outcomes.? Client: Aligns technology strategy with business objectives, ensuring ROI on technology investments.? What makes them successful? Builds trust with client decision-makers? Creates clear, strategic roadmaps tied to business goals? Plans long-term initiatives and technology budgets? Connects IT strategy to tangible business outcomes? What makes them less effective? Stays too tactical or overlaps with TAM work? Uses too much tech jargon with business leaders? Doesn’t tie roadmap to tangible business benefits? Doesn’t involve clients in roadmap decisions
5. Virtual Chief Technology Officer (vCTO)? Type: Strategic | Technology-focused? Core Responsibilities:? Guiding technology architecture, emerging tech, and infrastructure strategies.? Ensuring proactive technology innovation and long-term infrastructure planning.? Required Skills? Extensive experience with advanced IT architecture, technology evaluation, and innovation planning.? Expertise in emerging technologies, cloud solutions, and infrastructure planning.? Capability to advise and translate complex technology scenarios into clear strategies.? Job-To-Be-Done? Internal: Maintains cutting-edge technology strategies, positioning the MSP as a technology leader.? Client: Provides future-proofed technology guidance, reducing risk and enhancing innovation capabilities.? What makes them successful? Drives innovation and technical strategy? Aligns technology decisions with future business needs? Works closely with vCIO and TAM to balance vision and execution? Leads conversations on AI, integrations, and modernization? What makes them less effective? Gets lost in deep tech or abstract ideas? Avoids client-facing communication? Ignores the practical maturity level of the client? Doesn't align with service and support delivery
+1 Emerging Role: Virtual Chief Information Security Officer (vCISO)? Type: Strategic | Business & Technology-focused? Core Responsibilities:? Leading cybersecurity strategy, risk management, and compliance.? Bridging technical security practices with strategic business outcomes.? Required Skills? Comprehensive background in cybersecurity management, compliance, and risk assessment.? Certification (e.g., CISSP, CISM) and understanding of compliance frameworks (GDPR, HIPAA, ISO 27001, etc.).? Proven capability in strategic security advisory roles.? Job-To-Be-Done? Internal: Strengthens security posture and compliance, and reduces client exposure to cybersecurity threats.? Client: Delivers peace of mind, strategic compliance, and actionable cybersecurity strategies aligned with business risk management.? What makes them successful? Understands industry-specific risks and compliance needs? Builds confidence with clear, calm security advice? Helps clients prioritize and invest wisely in security? Aligns security with business risk and continuity? What makes them less effective? Leads with fear or overly technical language? Focuses only on tools, not business impact? Doesn’t give clear steps or priorities? Works in isolation from the rest of the CS team
Concept #2: Account Assignments: Building Durable, Multi-Threaded RelationshipsWhy This MattersMany MSPs unknowingly build fragile client relationships by relying too heavily on one person on either side. If a key employee at the MSP or the client leaves, the relationship can become unstable or even fall apart. Strong account assignment planning prevents this.To build resilient, scalable client relationships, MSPs must assign roles based on purpose, not personality. The goal is to create multiple connection points—so the relationship doesn’t depend on any single individual.How Small, Mid, and Large MSPs Handle Account AssignmentsIn small MSPs, one person often plays multiple roles—such as acting as the TAM, AM, and even vCIO. While this may be practical at first, it limits scalability and risks the relationship if that person leaves.Mid-sized MSPs begin to divide responsibilities. A TAM may handle technical alignment, while an AM manages the relationship. A shared vCIO may provide strategic guidance across several accounts. This starts to build the foundation for a multi-threaded model.Large MSPs can assign each client or segment dedicated TAMs, AMs, and vCIOs. Roles like vCISO or vCTO are introduced in more mature accounts to guide security or technology strategy. These MSPs are well-positioned to mirror their clients’ internal structures and maintain multiple relationships across levels.Aligning MSP Roles with Client StakeholdersEach MSP role should be intentionally connected to a specific type of client stakeholder:? TAMs typically connect with the client’s IT contact or operational lead. They ensure technical standards, system health, and issue resolution.? AMs engage with operations managers or general administrators. They handle renewals, feedback, and relationship quality.? vCIOs partner with senior business stakeholders like CEOs or CFOs to guide strategic planning and technology alignment.? vCISOs focus on compliance officers or executive leaders responsible for risk and data protection.? vCTOs are best paired with technically-minded executives or advisors to discuss future innovation and architectural planning.Every important client stakeholder should have someone at the MSP who “owns” that relationship and understands their perspective.How to Build Multi-Threaded Relationships1. Don’t Rely on One Person Avoid assigning only one MSP contact per client. Assign at least two team members—such as a TAM and an AM—to ensure coverage across both technical and business needs.2. Match Roles by Function, Not Just Familiarity Assign roles based on what the client stakeholder is responsible for. For example, a CFO doesn’t want to talk about backups—they want to hear about budget, risk, and business outcomes. That’s a conversation for a vCIO, not a TAM.3. Use the Right Level of Seniority Senior client stakeholders should speak with senior MSP roles. A CEO should meet with a vCIO, not a technician. This helps build credibility and trust.4. Track Who Knows Who Keep a record of all meaningful client contacts and the roles at your MSP that support them. This makes transitions easier if someone leaves and ensures you cover all strategic areas.5. Build in Redundancy Ask yourself: “If our AM left today, would we still know what’s happening in this account?” Proactively introduce backup team members in key meetings and cross-train them on the account context.With the right assignment strategy, MSPs create stronger, more resilient client relationships. You reduce the risk of disruption from staff changes, increase trust across multiple levels, and improve both service delivery and strategic alignment. This approach helps you move from being a helpful vendor to a trusted, long-term partner.
Concept #3: Roles Should Follow the Client, Not the Org ChartThe most common mistake MSPs make when defining Customer Success roles is building them around internal org charts instead of client needs. The best role design starts with the client experience: what kind of insight, ownership, and engagement does a client expect at this business goal level?A Segment C client (typically at Business Goal Level 2) may only require one consistent point of contact, generally focused on managing services and providing limited scoping or enablement. In contrast, a Segment A client (Business Goal Level 5) expects multi-stakeholder collaboration, strategic initiative co-planning, and long-term business alignment. That’s why role assignment should scale with segmentation—based on client maturity, strategic appetite, and Business Goal, not just revenue or team availability.This doesn’t always require hiring new people. In smaller MSPs, a single team member may wear multiple hats. What matters is that each segment receives the appropriate clarity of role and engagement rhythm, so expectations are met and trust can grow.Concept #4: Distinct Roles Create Scalable, High-Trust EngagementEach Customer Success role serves a unique function in translating MSP capability into client value. When roles are clearly defined and consistently assigned, the result is improved delivery and increased client trust. Common roles include:? TAM (Technical Alignment Manager): Ensures delivery quality and tech standardization. Anchored in operational excellence.? AM / CSM (Account Manager / Customer Success): Owns health, roadmap coordination, and internal advocacy. Focused on value realization and risk mitigation. In small MSPs, one person often wears both hats—keep the RACI separate: commercial = AM (Accountable); health/cadence = CSM (Accountable).? vCIO / Strategic Advisor: Shapes multi-year planning, business alignment, and OKR-linked initiatives. Focused on long-term transformation.? Specialist Roles (e.g., vCISO, AI Consultant, BI Advisor): Deployed at higher levels to support niche business goals and innovation agendas.Each Customer Success deliverable—Reports, Proposals, Assessments, Roadmaps, Budgets, Meetings—should have an assigned owner by segment. Role specialization ensures that deliverables are executed and championed by the right person, at the right time, with the right intent.In all cases, keep AM and CSM roles distinct in the RACI: AM is Accountable for commercial/renewal outcomes, while CSM is Accountable for health and cadence management.Concept #5: Role Clarity Is the Foundation for Accountability and GrowthWithout clear roles, Customer Success turns into task triage. Who is responsible for follow-up from a roadmap meeting? Who confirms initiative approval? Who ensures the strategic story is carried through to the next QBR?Clear role design enables:? Defined ownership of each CS motion by segment? Internal accountability for performance and outcomes? Repeatable engagement patterns that clients learn to rely on? A foundation for CS compensation, progression, and performance metricsThis role structure not only organizes delivery but also unlocks career progression for CS staff. A TAM supporting Segment C clients may advance toward a vCIO role in Segment A accounts. That progression can be structured with maturity-aligned responsibilities, success metrics, and incentives, linking performance to customer impact.Concept #6: CS Health Reveals Role Misalignment—Or MasteryWhen Customer Success Health metrics dip—whether in Engagement, Technology Adoption, or Service Alignment—it’s often not a product problem. It’s a role misalignment problem.Clients in Segment A (high maturity, high appetite) expect strategic engagement. If they receive only basic technical coordination, you’ll see early warning signs in CS Health scores. Conversely, over-assigning complex roles to low-touch accounts can drain resources without benefit.Because CS Health is measurable and continuous, it becomes a real-time feedback loop for role design and development. It tells you:? Which roles are driving adoption and sentiment? Where clients feel unsupported or overwhelmed? Whether roles are producing business impact aligned with the Client Business GoalCS Health data closes the loop between role design and customer outcomes. If it’s not measured, rhythm breaks down, and segmentation slips.Health metrics (CX, Engagement, Adoption, Alignment) should be explicitly tied to role accountability in dashboards, so that dips always map back to a named role owner for review and correction.Concept #7: Roles Are the Starting Point for the Whole People DisciplineDefining roles isn’t just HR documentation—it’s the foundation for the rest of the People discipline:? 6.2 Responsibilities: clarify who does what for which segment.? 6.3 Enablement ensures that every role has the tools and guidance to deliver.? 6.4 Compensation ties measurable success to reward and progression.? 6.5 Governance tracks coverage, performance, and capacity across the CS team.When these are aligned, MSPs unlock scalable, resilient Customer Success capacity. When they’re missing or misaligned, performance stalls—even with great intentions.
Implementation ProcessDefining Roles for Scalable, Segment-Aware EngagementThe Roles Implementation Process ensures that MSPs define, assign, and operationalize Customer Success roles based on client maturity, appetite, and Business Goal level. This process creates the foundation for delivering consistent value, enabling strategic alignment, and tracking impact through role clarity and accountability.Step 1: Design Roles Based on Client Segments and Business GoalsStart by mapping roles to each client segment, using segmentation and Client Business Goal levels to calibrate role depth and complexity:SegmentGoal LevelPrimary Roles InvolvedPurposeA4-5vCxO, Strategic Advisor, SMEs (e.g., vCISO for risk/compliance; vCTO for architecture/innovation)Drive innovation, OKRs, and cross-departmental planningB3vCIO, CS ManagerEnable business alignment and initiative executionC2TAM, AM/CSMEnsure operational quality, stack alignment, and roadmap deliveryD1TAM, Owner/FounderMaintain service visibility, reinforce stabilityRole depth should scale by both strategic ambition and delivery needs—not simply by contract size. Smaller MSPs may assign multiple roles to a single person, but role functions must remain distinct and visible.Step 2: Assign Role Ownership for Key CS DeliverablesAlways name an Accountable role and a Backup for every deliverable. Clarify which roles are RACI owners (Accountable = single named owner) for each deliverable, and add a named Backup per account for continuity.? TAM/SDM ? Service Reviews (Lead), Health inputs, basic assessments (A/R).? AM/CSM ? QBR (Lead in B/C), Engagement tracking, initiative intake (A).? vCIO/Strategic Advisor ? Executive QBRs (Lead in A) and annual Strategy Planning (Lead A/B/C), budget framing (A).? Specialists/SMEs (vCISO, vCTO) ? consulted on security/architecture where relevant (C).Map each RACI owner to the matching client stakeholder (e.g., vCIO ? CEO/CFO; AM/CSM ? Ops/Admin; TAM ? IT lead).Create a role-to-segment engagement matrix. This becomes the foundation for planning team coverage, onboarding paths, and accountability during cadence-based execution. The deliverable owner should also be the relationship owner for the corresponding client stakeholder. For every deliverable and meeting, assign a RACI owner (Accountable) and a named Backup per account to guarantee continuity (no ‘the team’ owners).? Annual Strategy Planning (A/B/C) — Accountable: vCIO; Responsible: CSM (prep & follow-up); Consulted: AM; Informed: TAM.? Executive QBR (A) — Accountable: vCIO; Responsible: CSM; Consulted: AM; Informed: TAM/SMEs.? QBR (B/C) — Accountable: CSM; Consulted: AM; Informed: vCIO (B), TAM (C).? Service Review (C/D) — Accountable: TAM; Consulted: AM/CSM (if scope/cadence changes); Informed: vCIO (C).? Renewal & Pricing — Accountable: AM; Consulted: CSM; Informed: vCIO.? Health Dashboard & Alerts (CX/Engagement/Adoption/Alignment) — Accountable: CSM; Responsible (inputs): TAM; Informed: AM, vCIO.The deliverable owner is also the relationship owner for the matching client stakeholder.Step 3: Operationalize Roles Through Playbooks and Process AlignmentFor every meeting type, set Trigger ? Prep ? Lead ? Follow-up with a RACI owner and Backup:? Strategy Planning (annual, A/B/C): Lead = vCIO/Strategic Advisor; Backup = CSM.? Executive QBR (A): Lead = vCIO/Strategic Advisor; Backup = CSM. Target 3/yr if budget permits.? QBR (B/C): Lead = AM/CSM; Backup = vCIO. 1–3/yr depending on budget.? Service Review (C/D): Lead = TAM; Backup = AM/CSM. Monthly/quarterly or trigger-based.Ensure each role is embedded in process flows. ? Assign meeting ownership by segment and type (e.g., vCIO ? Strategy Meeting; TAM ? Service Review)? Define initiative lead role per segment (e.g., CSM for C-level clients; TAM for D-level)? Link roles to reporting: who presents which reports, and to whom?? Align intake responsibilities: Discovery and Assessment prep should have named role owners.This alignment reduces confusion, increases consistency, and ensures roles are actioned—not just labelled.Step 4: Use CS Health as a Feedback Loop to Optimize Role CoverageTrack Engagement, CX, and Alignment scores to detect whether roles are misaligned with client expectations. Examples:? Low CX in Segment A ? Possibly lacking strategic facilitation (assign or improve vCxO coverage)? Low Adoption in Segment C ? Potential misfit between TAM and roadmap follow-through? Missed Initiatives or Roadmaps ? Likely absence of CSM ownership or cadence planningCreate internal Health + Role dashboards to monitor which roles produce results and where refinement or support is needed.Step 5: Review Roles Quarterly and Scale with Client & Team MaturityAs clients mature, their role expectations shift. Conduct quarterly role reviews across the CS portfolio:? Promote TAM ? AM/CSM ? Strategic Advisor as engagement complexity rises? Reassign clients based on role bandwidth, Health data, or Business Goal level changes? Use playbook coverage and deliverable execution to identify team gaps? Tie role progression to enablement and compensation plans (see 5.3 and 5.4)Establish recurring CS leadership checkpoints to review each role category's segment-role alignment, escalation patterns, and staffing capacity.Final Output: A Role-Aligned Customer Success SystemWhen implemented correctly, the MSP will have:? Clear role definitions calibrated to client segments and goal levels? Assigned ownership of all strategic and operational CS deliverables? Embedded roles across the CS lifecycle (Discovery, Roadmap, Meeting, Budget)? Measurable accountability tied to Customer Success Health? A scalable role system that evolves with both the team and the client baseThis implementation process ensures that CS roles become levers of trust, execution, and strategic growth—not bottlenecks of confusion or burnout.
AppendixHow does it connect to the Client Business Goal levels?LevelRole CompositionMSP Archetype0.0 DIY ITNo formal roles; clients self-manage, call for reactive support onlyDIY IT1.1 Technology SupportThe Owner/Founder fills all roles. Reactive support from Helpdesk or Techs.Break-Fix MSP1.2 Technology EnablementTAMs or Service Delivery Managers are introduced for structured delivery.Proactive MSP1.3 Technology ModernizationDedicated AMs and vCIOs take ownership of client outcomes.Full-Service MSP1.4 Business TransformationStrategic Business Advisors, CS Managers, and possibly vCISO roles introduced.Strategic Partner MSP1.5 Business InnovationAdvanced vCxO roles and SME contributors (e.g., BI, AI, ERP, ISO) support transformation and innovation.Transformation / Innovation MSPHow does it connect to the other parts?1. Client Business Goal – Role specialization evolves with client maturity and appetite. Higher levels require strategic, consultative roles, while foundational levels may only require reactive technical support.2. Customer Success Health – CX, Engagement, and Service Level metrics inform whether current roles are sufficient or need adjustment. Role depth influences perception, participation, and satisfaction.3. Customer Success Delivery – Certain deliverables (e.g., Strategy, Roadmap) require specific roles, such as vCIO or Strategic Advisor, to be effective. Role ownership helps ensure deliverables are understood and actionable.4. Customer Success Process – Roles must be aligned with intake, meeting, and initiative workflows. Poor alignment can lead to dropped handoffs or unclear ownership of customer service activities.7. Customer Success Strategy – Segmentation and SOPs dictate role engagement by client tier. Strategy must account for role bandwidth, specialization, and scalability across segments.Product Links / Tooling SupportNot currently tied to a specific LMx product feature. Role modelling is part of MSP organizational design and delivery planning. Future tooling may support role-to-client alignment, role competency mapping, and visibility at the engagement level.

OverviewWhat is the objective?Define clear, segment-aware (A–D) responsibilities for each CS role (TAM, AM/CSM, vCIO/vCTO, vCISO), directly tied to core CS deliverables (Reports, Assessments, Roadmaps, Budgets, Meetings). Use a simple RACI-by-segment one-pager per account to make ownership explicit (with a named Backup for continuity) and map each responsibility to the right client stakeholder.Why is it important?? Removes overlap and gaps by naming one Accountable owner per deliverable/process.? Prevents dropped handoffs; speeds decisions and follow-ups.? Makes Health signals actionable at the role level (who fixes what).? Scales cleanly with MSP size without changing the logic.As an MSP, why do I need to do this?? Build a Responsibility Matrix (RACI) per segment (A–D): role ? deliverable ? client stakeholder ? RACI + Backup.? Tie responsibilities to concrete process points (who triggers, preps, leads, follows up).? Keep AM vs CSM distinct in RACI (even if one person wears both hats):? Commercial (renewal/pricing/proposals) = AM (Accountable)? Health/Cadence (CX, Engagement, Adoption, Alignment) = CSM (Accountable)? Define a progression path (TAM ? CSM/AM ? Advisor ? vCxO) linked to responsibility depth.What is the Customer impact?? Right-level conversations (CEO/CFO ? vCIO; IT lead ? TAM), faster decisions, resilient coverage (Backup), predictable cadence and follow-through ? higher trust..Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: Segment-Aware “Responsibility Packs” per Role (A–D)One-size-fits-all role definitions create ambiguity, missed handoffs, and wasted senior time on tactical work. Pack responsibilities by role and segment (4–6 outcome responsibilities per role per segment) so ownership matches client readiness.? Segment D (Goal 1 – Technology Support): TAM/Owner ? SLA rhythm, lifecycle hygiene. Meeting focus: Service Reviews + Annual IT Strategy Meeting (D).? Segment C (Goal 2 – Technology Enablement): TAM + AM/CSM split: service alignment vs cadence/reporting & initiative intake. The meeting?? focus: Service reviews, QBR (C), and annual strategy planning (C).? Segment B (Goal 3 – Technology Modernization): vCIO + CSM ? roadmap, budget framing, initiative pacing. The meeting focus is QBR (B) and Annual Strategy Planning (B).? Segment A (Goals 4–5 – Business Transformation & Innovation): vCxO/Advisor anchors OKR-linked strategy; CSM runs executive cadence. The meeting focus is Executive QBR (A) (up to 3/yr if the budget allows it) + Annual Strategy Planning (A).Health focus by segment: D ? Service Quality + baseline Engagement; C ? Adoption + Engagement; B ? Service Level Alignment + Engagement + sustained Adoption; A ? exec-level CX + Alignment + transformation-grade Service Quality.Practical examples? C: TAM owns lifecycle assessment inputs + service alignment; CSM owns QBR (C) delivery and initiative intake.? B: vCIO owns roadmap + budget; CSM runs cadence and progress reporting..Concept #2: One Owner End-to-End (RACI Accountable) + Named BackupWhen “the team” supposedly owns a deliverable, handoffs get fuzzy, follow-ups slip, and meetings drift without decisions. Make ownership explicit by assigning one RACI Accountable per deliverable/process and one named Backup per account. The same person can wear multiple hats in a small MSP, but RACI must remain separate: AM = commercial Accountable, CSM = health/cadence Accountable.How to set it up? One Accountable, consistently: Exactly one named owner per deliverable or meeting type, per account.? Named Backup: Visible on agendas and in your CS tool//PSA/CRM so continuity is automatic (OOO, turnover, load).? RACI stamp on every agenda/template: Accountable | Responsible (prep/follow-up) | Consulted | Informed | Backup.? Follow-up SLAs: Summary within 48h, tasks in system within 72h, approvals chased within 7–10 days.? Cadence & format flex by budget: Keep the Accountable even if you switch from a full QBR to a shorter session or a “deck + 3-minute screen-recorded video + 30-min call.”Meeting ownership (names and cadence aligned to Roles)? Annual Strategy Planning (A/B/C)? Accountable: vCIO / Strategic Advisor? Responsible (prep & follow-up): CSM? Consulted: AM (commercial), TAM (technical risks)? Informed: SMEs as needed? Backup: CSM? Output: updated roadmap, OKR links, top 2–3 initiatives with dates/owners.? Executive QBR (A) — up to 3/year if budget permits? Accountable: vCIO / vCxO? Responsible: CSM? Consulted: AM, SMEs (security/architecture/etc.)? Informed: TAM? Backup: CSM? QBR (B/C) — 1–3/year based on budget? Accountable: CSM? Consulted: AM (renewal/terms), vCIO (B), TAM (C)? Informed: SMEs as needed? Backup: vCIO (B) or AM (C)? Service Review (C/D) — monthly/quarterly or trigger-based? Accountable: TAM? Consulted: AM/CSM (only if scope/cadence changes)? Informed: vCIO (C)? Backup: AM/CSMCommercial vs. health/cadence (RACI line you’ll keep everywhere)? Renewal & Pricing: Accountable AM, Consulted CSM, Informed vCIO.? Customer Health & Alerts (CX, Engagement, Adoption, Alignment): Accountable CSM, Responsible for inputs TAM, Informed AM, vCIO.Documentation you use? One-page RACI by segment (A–D) per account: list each deliverable with A/R/C/I + Backup.? The RACI field is in every agenda (top-right corner).? The decision log is linked to the roadmap/success plan (who decided, what, when, and next date).Practical examples (ready to copy)? Segment B QBR? RACI: Accountable CSM, Consulted vCIO & AM, Informed TAM, Backup vCIO.? Prep: CSM pulls Health & initiative status; vCIO adds roadmap context; AM tags renewal horizon.? Follow-up: CSM summary in 48h, 2 CTAs in LMx within 72h, next date booked.? Segment A Executive QBR? RACI: Accountable vCIO, Responsible CSM, Consulted AM + SMEs, Informed TAM, Backup CSM.? Output: two exec-level outcomes (e.g., OKR tie-in, cross-dept initiative), next decision date.? Segment C Service Review? RACI: Accountable TAM, Consulted CSM (if cadence/scope change), Informed AM, Backup CSM.? Output: lifecycle gaps + one small approval; CSM nudges adoption owners.Concept #3: Map Responsibilities to the Right Client StakeholdersApprovals stall when you talk to the wrong audience. Keep every conversation relevant—and faster—by pairing MSP roles to the matching client stakeholders and embedding that map into your responsibilities and meeting plans.The simple mapping (use this on your one-pager)? TAM ? IT Lead / Operations — service quality, SLA/lifecycle, adoption nudges.? CSM ? Ops / Admin / Team Leads — cadence, decisions, initiative follow-through, Health.? AM ? Budget Holder / Procurement / Owner-Manager — renewals, pricing, terms, upsell timing.? vCIO / vCxO ? CEO / MD / CFO — strategy, roadmap, OKRs, prioritization, value narrative.? vCISO ? Compliance / Risk / Exec Sponsor — risk posture, controls, audits.? vCTO ? Tech-savvy Exec / Architect — architecture, modernization, innovation.How to operationalize it? Stakeholder map in LMx/CRM (one page): names, roles, influence (D/M/I), preferred channel, cadence, backups.? Invite list by meeting archetype (baked into templates):? Annual Strategy Planning (A/B/C): CEO/CFO + vCIO (A), Ops + CSM included for follow-through.? Executive QBR (A): vCIO + CEO/CFO + CSM; AM only for commercial context.? QBR (B/C): CSM + Ops/Admin; add vCIO (B) for roadmap blocks; TAM (C) for lifecycle items.? Service Review (C/D): TAM + IT/Ops; CSM attends only if cadence/scope changes.? Pre-flight check (48–72h prior): confirm the decision-maker is present; otherwise rescope (shorter session + book a decision call with the right exec).? Aftercare: Decisions are logged to the success plan/roadmap, tasks are assigned to the people who are in the room, and renewal timing is noted for AM.Segment-aware meeting aim (who must be in the room)? A (4–5): Executive relevance is non-negotiable ? CEO/CFO + vCIO/vCxO in Executive QBRs; CSM ensures outcomes and next steps are locked.? B (3): Move decisions faster ? Ops + CSM for QBR; vCIO joins roadmap segments; invite budget holder when approvals are expected.? C (2): Keep it operational ? IT/Ops + TAM for Service Reviews; CSM handles cadence and captures initiative intake.? D (1): Keep it simple ? Owner/Manager + TAM annually; otherwise Service Reviews with IT/Ops.Templates that make this stick? Agenda header: “Stakeholders for this session (Name, Role, Why here, Decision right)”.? Slide 1: “What we need from you today” (approve X, choose Y, confirm date Z).? Email pre-read: 3 bullets (last outcomes, today’s decisions, what happens next).Practical examples (ready to copy)? B-segment Roadmap + Budget Checkpoint? Attendees: vCIO + CSM + Ops Lead + Budget Holder (Owner/CFO).? Flow: CSM (cadence & status) ? vCIO (sequence & value) ? Budget holder (approve 1–2 items).? Output: approvals captured; next decision date; renewal note to AM.? C-segment Quarterly Review (QBR)? Attendees: CSM + Ops/Admin, TAM for lifecycle portion.? Flow: CSM (Engagement & initiative status) ? TAM (adoption/lifecycle gaps) ? CSM (one small approval).? Output: one approved initiative; tasks in LMx; 90-day date booked.? A-segment Executive QBR? Attendees: vCIO / vCxO + CEO/CFO + CSM; AM consulted if commercial topics arise.? Flow: vCIO (value recap vs. OKRs) ? decisions (2 max) ? CSM (next steps, owners, dates).? Output: exec-level outcomes; risks noted for vCISO/vCTO if relevant; follow-through meetings set.? D-segment Annual IT Strategy? Attendees: Owner/Manager + TAM.? Flow: TAM (SLA/asset hygiene, 12-month priorities) ? pick one improvement ? agree on a simple date/budget.? Output: A single upgrade is scheduled; Service Reviews will handle the rest.Concept #4:  Responsibility = Process Ownership (Trigger ? Prep ? Lead ? Follow-Up)Fragmented task lists create invisible gaps. Make ownership visible and end-to-end for every CS motion using a simple arc: Trigger ? Prep ? Lead ? Follow-Up, with a single RACI Accountable and a named Backup per account. Stamp this at the top of every agenda/template so no one has to guess.Apply by meeting type (aligned to Roles & cadence):? Annual Strategy Planning (A/B/C)? Accountable: vCIO / Strategic Advisor? Responsible (prep & follow-up): CSM? Consulted: AM (commercial context), TAM (technical risks)? Backup: CSM? Outputs: Updated roadmap, OKRs link, and next 2–3 initiatives with dates.? Executive QBR (A) — up to 3/year if budget permits? Accountable: vCIO / vCxO? Responsible (prep & follow-up): CSM? Consulted: AM, SMEs (as needed)? Backup: CSM? Outputs: exec-level progress, decisions, approvals, and a refreshed success plan.? QBR (B/C) — 1–3/year based on budget? Accountable: CSM? Consulted: AM, vCIO (B), TAM? Informed: SMEs as needed.? Service Review (C/D) — monthly/quarterly or trigger-based? Accountable: TAM? Consulted: AM/CSM (only if scope/cadence changes)? Backup: AM/CSM? Outputs: SLA & lifecycle hygiene, risks, ticket trends, adoption nudges.Make it operational with lightweight guardrails:? Agenda header “RACI stamp” (Accountable | Backup | Consulted | Informed).? Follow-up SLA: summary in 48h, tasks in CS tool//PSA in 72h, approvals chased within 7–10 days.? Templates: every deck/report starts with “Owner (A), Backup, Next review date”.? Handoff notes: a one-page “decision log” linked to the roadmap/success plan.Practical examples (ready to copy):? Segment B QBR (CSM Accountable)? Trigger: QBR due in 30 days (auto-notice).? Prep: CSM pulls Health & initiative status; vCIO adds roadmap notes.? Lead: CSM runs the meeting; vCIO handles roadmap questions.? Follow-Up: CSM sends 48h summary, creates 2 CTAs, books next date.? Segment C Service Review (TAM Accountable)? Trigger: monthly SLA review.? Prep: TAM updates lifecycle gaps; CSM adds any engagement risks.? Lead: TAM walks tickets/SLA/adoption; asks for one small approval.? Follow-Up: TAM logs decisions; CSM nudges adoption task owners.Concept #5: Use Health to Tune Responsibilities (Measure ? Signal ? Adjust)When Health dips, don’t swap tools—retune RACI ownership. Treat CX, Engagement, Adoption, and Service Level Alignment as routing signals that decide who leads what for the next cycle.Simple playbook:1. Measure weekly (portfolio board) and before each meeting.2. Signal thresholds (example):? Engagement < target for two cycles ? CSM escalates cadence reset.? Adoption ? 10–20% in C ? TAM deep-dives assessments; CSM owns follow-up.? CX risk in A ? vCIO/vCxO must own the next Executive QBR agenda.3. Adjust ownership for one quarter, then revert or lock in.By segment—typical retunes:? A (4–5): Low CX or unclear exec value ? vCxO/vCIO leads next Executive QBR; CSM tightens pre-work & decision capture; AM consulted on commercial impacts only.? B (3): Slipping decision velocity ? CSM remains Accountable for cadence, vCIO co-leads roadmap block until two approvals land.? C (2): Adoption stalls ? CSM becomes Accountable for initiative follow-through for 60 days; TAM focuses on lifecycle inputs and risk notes.? D (1): SLA noise ? TAM is kept accountable; CSM joins only if scope/cadence needs to change.Lightweight governance:? Health + Role board (columns: Segment, Health signal, Who is Accountable now, When we revert).? Green target: 80% of accounts “on target” mid-year; review exceptions monthly.Practical examples (ready to copy):? A account, CX amber ? Next Executive QBR: Accountable vCIO, Responsible CSM; add “Value recap” slide, confirm two executive-level outcomes; CSM books a 30-min follow-through within 7 days.? C account, Adoption down 15% ? CSM Accountable for two initiatives; TAM updates DMI and provides config notes; weekly 15-min sync until back to baseline.? Any segment missed approvals twice ? CSM is accountable for resetting cadence (shorter QBR, clear CTAs); AM is consulted if renewal timing collides.Concept #6: Same Logic as You Grow (Small ? Mid ? Large MSP)Growth and budget shifts shouldn’t force a redesign. Keep the same responsibility logic and split it cleanly as your portfolio and CS budget evolve—precisely as defined in 5.1 Roles.Calibration rules (match Roles 1:1):? AM vs CSM stays separated in RACI even if one person covers both day-to-day.? Commercial (renewals, pricing, proposals) = AM Accountable? Health & Cadence (CX, Engagement, Adoption, Alignment) = CSM Accountable? Meeting mix by segment & budget? A: 1? Annual Strategy Planning + up to 3 Executive QBRs (budget-dependent).? B/C: 1? Annual Strategy Planning + 1–3 QBRs (budget-dependent).? D: 1? Annual IT Strategy Meeting + Service Reviews.? Specialists (vCISO, vCTO) join Segment A when justified by risk/innovation—not by habit.? If budget tightens: keep Accountables, downgrade format (e.g., QBR ? concise deck + 3-min screen-recorded video + 30-min call), but do not drop the owner.Quarterly RACI refresh (fast checklist):1. Per segment, verify each deliverable’s Accountable + Backup.2. Remove senior roles from C/D unless needed; add vCIO/vCxO to A if CX/Alignment lags.3. Confirm AM=commercial and CSM=health/cadence in all agendas and templates.4. Tie any changes to Enablement updates (talk tracks, checklists) and Compensation levers.Practical examples (ready to copy):? Budget cut in a B account ? Keep CSM Accountable for QBR; switch to shorter QBR cadence with one approval per cycle; vCIO consulted only for roadmap decisions.? C account grows into B ? Add Annual Strategy Planning (Accountable vCIO), keep CSM Accountable for QBRs; introduce one roadmap initiative per quarter.? A account adds security scope ? Invite vCISO as consulted to Executive QBR; vCIO remains Accountable; CSM owns follow-up and risk register updates.
Implementation ProcessOperationalizing Responsibilities for Scalable, Segment-Aligned CS ExecutionGoal: turn role definitions into clear, segment-aware ownership with smooth handoffs, the right people in the room, and Health-driven adjustments.Step 1: Build the one-page Responsibility Matrix (by segment A–D)Create a single page per segment that lists every recurring CS deliverable and its RACI per account, plus a named Backup.Deliverables to include? Annual Strategy Planning (A/B/C)? Executive QBR (A)? QBR (B/C)? Service Review (C/D)? Assessments / DMI inputs? Reports (creation & delivery)? Initiatives & Budget drafting? Health Dashboard & Alerts? Renewal & PricingRACI quick rules? Exactly one Accountable per item.? Always list a Backup (person, not “the team”).? Keep AM vs. CSM split even if one person holds both titles:? Commercial = AM (Accountable)? Health/Cadence = CSM (Accountable)Starter example (copy into your template)? Annual Strategy Planning (A/B/C) ? A: vCIO | R: CSM | C: AM | I: TAM | Backup: CSM? Executive QBR (A) ? A: vCIO | R: CSM | C: AM, SMEs | I: TAM | Backup: CSM? QBR (B/C) ? A: CSM | C: AM; vCIO (B), TAM (C) | I: SMEs | Backup: vCIO (B) / AM (C)? Service Review (C/D) ? A: TAM | C: AM/CSM (if scope/cadence changes) | I: vCIO (C) | Backup: CSM? Renewal & Pricing ? A: AM | C: CSM | I: vCIO | Backup: AM delegate? Health Dashboard & Alerts ? A: CSM | R (inputs): TAM | I: AM, vCIO | Backup: AMStep 2: Stamp RACI into every meeting and deliverable templateAdd a tiny RACI block to the top-right of agendas, notes, and report covers so ownership is visible in every interaction.Agenda header (paste this)? Accountable | Responsible | Consulted | Informed | Backup? Decisions needed today (max 2): …? Who decides: Name/Role? Follow-up SLA: Summary in 48h; CTAs in system in 72h; approvals chased within 7–10 daysDocumentation habit? Log decisions to the Success Plan/Roadmap (not just email).? Assign named owners + dates for each CTA in your CS tool//PSA/CRM.? Book the next date before the call ends.Step 3: Tie responsibilities to the right stakeholders and cadenceUse the role-to-stakeholder map and the segment cadence rules from Roles.Who talks to whom? TAM ? IT/Ops (service, lifecycle, adoption nudges)? CSM ? Ops/Admin/Team Leads (cadence, decisions, follow-through, Health)? AM ? Owner/Procurement/Budget holder (renewal, pricing, terms)? vCIO/vCxO ? CEO/CFO (strategy, OKRs, prioritization)? vCISO ? Compliance/Risk | vCTO ? Tech-savvy exec/architectCadence by segment (name meetings correctly)? A (4–5): Annual Strategy Planning + Executive QBR (up to 3/year if budget permits)? B/C (3 / 2): Annual Strategy Planning + QBR (1–3/year based on budget)? D (1): Annual IT Strategy only; use Service Reviews for operational rhythmPre-flight check (48–72h before)? Confirm decision-maker attendance; if missing, switch to a shorter update and book a decision call with the right exec.? Keep the invite list lean and role-matched.Step 4: Bake responsibilities into simple, repeatable playbooksTurn each deliverable into a 4-step mini-playbook with explicit ownership.Trigger ? Prep ? Lead ? Follow-up (examples)? QBR (B/C)? Trigger: CSM (Health window/cadence)? Prep: CSM (status & slides), vCIO (B roadmap), TAM (C lifecycle)? Lead: CSM (Accountable)? Follow-up: CSM (summary/CTAs), AM (commercial notes)? Executive QBR (A)? Trigger: CSM (exec cadence)? Prep: CSM (storyline & outcomes), vCIO (value/OKR link), AM (commercial horizon)? Lead: vCIO (Accountable)? Follow-up: CSM (actions/dates), AM (renewal timing), vCIO (risks to next Strategy checkpoint)? Service Review (C/D)? Trigger: TAM (SLA/lifecycle)? Prep: TAM (tickets, adoption, asset gaps)? Lead: TAM (Accountable)? Follow-up: TAM (technical CTAs), CSM (if cadence/scope changes)? Renewal & Pricing? Lead/Accountable: AM; Consulted: CSM; Informed: vCIOPut these 4-step strips on the agenda footer so no one wonders who does what next.Step 5: Use Customer Success Health to adjust ownership quicklyTreat Health as routing signals for responsibility fixes, not just reports.Fast adjustments? Low Engagement (any segment): CSM runs re-engagement play (short update + decision call) and keeps Accountable until green.? Low Adoption (C): Keep TAM responsible for assessment inputs, and make CSM accountable for follow-through (weekly nudges for 60 days).? Low CX (A): Add/strengthen vCIO/vCxO presence in the next Executive QBR; CSM keeps actions tight.? Missed initiatives (any): Reset cadence; CSM Accountable for follow-up SLA; escalate to vCIO if decisions slip >30 days.Simple dashboard? One sheet per segment: Owner | Backup | Last meeting | Next date | Health (CX/Eng/Adopt/Align) | Risks | Next action.? Review weekly inside the CS team; escalate exceptions in your internal governance huddle.Step 6: Quarterly review and scale without changing the logicEvery quarter, run a short Responsibilities Review to keep the system sharp:Checklist? Is Accountable still the proper role by segment? (Avoid senior over-servicing C/D)? Are Backups named and present in key calls?? Are AM (commercial) and CSM (health/cadence) still clearly split in RACI?? Are Strategy/QBR/Service Review counts aligned to budget and segment rules?? Do we need to introduce vCISO/vCTO in A accounts?? Any role progression we can unlock (TAM ? CSM ? Advisor)?Update the one-page matrices, agendas, and playbooks and keep going.“Done” looks like this? Every deliverable has one Accountable, a named Backup, and a visible RACI on the agenda.? Meeting names and cadences match the segment rules (Strategy Planning / Executive QBR / QBR / Service Review).? Stakeholder mapping ensures the right people are in the room, every time.? Follow-ups hit the 48h/72h/7–10d rhythm and live in the Success Plan/Roadmap.? Health triggers change responsibilities or add coverage—you can see that on a single sheet.
AppendixHow does it connect to the Client Business Goal levels?LevelKey Responsibilities by Role1.1 Technology SupportThe owner/technician handles all reactive support, ticket escalations, and basic client communication.1.2 Technology EnablementTAMs handle delivery coordination, basic onboarding, and hardware/software rollouts. SDM may oversee client SLAs.1.3 Technology ModernizationvCIOs lead strategic planning, AMs manage cadence and reporting, TAMs support initiative execution.1.4 Business TransformationStrategic Advisors lead planning, CS Managers coordinate initiatives, and vCISOs assess risk and compliance.1.5 Business InnovationvCxOs oversee innovation portfolios, SME partners deliver advanced insights, and cross-functional coordination is formalized.Goal Level / SegmentPrimary role ownersOwnership emphasisHealth emphasisTypical cadence (aligned to Roles)D (Goal 1 - Technology Support)TAM / OwnerSLA stability, lifecycle hygiene, and incident follow-throughService Quality, baseline EngagementAnnual IT Strategy; Service Reviews monthly/quarterly or trigger-basedC (Goal 2 -  Technology Enablement)TAM + AM/CSMAssessments input, service alignment, reports, and initiative intakeTechnology Adoption, EngagementAnnual Strategy Planning + QBR (1–3/yr based on budget); Service Reviews as neededB (Goal 3 - Technology Modernization)vCIO + CSMRoadmap, budget framing, initiative pacing, decision velocityService Level Alignment, Engagement, and Sustained AdoptionAnnual Strategy Planning + QBR (1–3/yr based on budget)A (Goals 4 - Business Transformation and 5 Business Innovation)vCxO/Strategic Advisor + CSMOKR linkage, executive cadence, cross-dept programsExec-level CX, Alignment, transformation-grade Service QualityAnnual Strategy Planning + Executive QBR (up to 3/yr if budget permits)How does it connect to the other parts?? 1. Client Business Goal – Responsibilities evolve as the client moves up in maturity and appetite. Tactical roles dominate early stages, while strategic, planning, and innovation responsibilities emerge at higher levels.? 2. Customer Success Health – Role responsibilities directly impact CS Health metrics: Account Managers (AMs) and Customer Success Managers (CSMs) influence Engagement and Customer Experience (CX); vCIOs drive Technology Adoption and Service Level Alignment; Technical Account Managers (TAMs) and Technical Specialists (Techs) affect Service Quality.? 3. Customer Success Delivery – Each deliverable (e.g., Budgets, Roadmaps, Proposals) requires clear ownership to ensure they are appropriately produced, presented, and followed up on.? 4. Customer Success Process – Responsibilities dictate who triggers, prepares, leads, and follows up in each SOP/playbook and ensure cadence adherence (Strategy Planning, Executive QBR/QBR, Service Review).? 5. Customer Success People – Responsibilities reflect the finalized Roles model and RACI usage. Keep AM and CSM distinct in RACI even if one person holds both titles (commercial = AM Accountable; health/cadence = CSM Accountable).? 7. Customer Success Strategy – Segmentation, SOPs, and capacity models require role-specific responsibilities to be well-defined. This allows the CS strategy to scale across segments without confusion or duplication.Product Links / Tooling SupportNone currently. However, this blueprint provides a foundational structure for future LMx role-based functionality, such as responsibility matrices, checklists, and accountability dashboards linked to CS process steps.
?? 6. CS Technology
6. CS Technology[11]Building a Unified, Automation-First Customer Success EngineCS Technology includes five key blueprints:6.1. Strategy6.2. Health6.3. Deliverables6.4. People6.5. ProcessIn SummaryBuilding a Unified, Automation-First Customer Success EngineCS Technology weaves seamlessly through the entire Customer Success system, ensuring that behind every data point, workflow, and human interaction lies a reliable, modular technology foundation. While CS Strategy defines the portfolio-level logic, CS Technology ensures that the the strategy operates in real-time, is fully automated, and is powered by AI.“Technology is the engine that transforms Customer Success strategy into a repeatable, scalable reality.”An advanced CS Technology stack enables MSPs to quickly and flexibly answer questions such as:? How do we ingest and consolidate customer data in real time?? Which AI models predict churn, recommend next-best actions, or generate deliverables?? How do we modularly select and integrate new playbook orchestration engines, analytics layers, or generative AI components?? How can we ensure that CSMs can focus on human-to-human interactions while the system handles all manual tasks behind the scenes?As a client moves from the “D segment” (low maturity, low appetite) to the “A segment” (high maturity, high appetite), CS Technology likewise evolves—from the simplest scripted automations to API-driven, AI-powered self-healing engines.Technology Maturity Evolves with Client MaturityAs clients progress through the Client Business Goal levels (Segment D ? Segment A), the CS Technology stack evolves accordingly:? Segment D (Goal 1): Script-based automations generate light-touch deliverables, simple discovery forms, and threshold-based alerts.? Segment C/B (Goals 2–3): ML models refine Health scores and automate mid-cycle segmentation, dynamic playbook execution, and initiative delivery. Event-based triggers activate specific deliverables, governance workflows, and stakeholder roles.? Segment A (Goals 4–5): Fully orchestrated AI-driven execution, including generative reports, adaptive cadence recalibration, strategic resource reallocation, and self-healing initiative loops—all triggered by real-time data conditions.
CS Technology includes five key blueprints:6.1. StrategyWhat it is:A product-agnostic, API-first architecture blueprint that defines how data ingestion (e.g., PSA, CRM, MRR feeds, RMM), centralized storage (data lake/warehouse), ML/AI inference (Segmentation, Engagement Strategy, CS Playbook), workflow orchestration, and dashboards interconnect. It establishes a modular foundation, allowing every new data source or AI model to plug in without requiring the rewriting of core logic. Once raw Health, Deliverables, People, and Process data are loaded into the data lake and consolidated, AI-powered engines automatically generate Segmentation recommendations, Engagement Strategy plans, and CS Playbook drafts in real-time.How it evolves: ? Monolithic Scripts ? Point-to-point ETL jobs and basic scripts.? Modular Microservices ? Separate ingestion service, feature store, model registry, and inference API, each exposing a standard REST or event-stream endpoint.? Plug-in Ecosystem ? Low-code/No-code orchestration, versioned AI microservices, and feature stores that can be swapped or retrained independently. The workflow engine then routes AI outputs to update downstream Health, Deliverables, People, and Process modules without manual intervention.Why it matters:? Scalability: Ensures rapid integration of new data sources or models without rewrites.? Flexibility: Supports rule-based and AI-driven segmentation across all segments.? Speed to Market: New engagement plans and playbooks auto-deploy on health changes.Business Goal connection:? Segment D (Goal 1): Basic ingestion pipelines stream raw Health data into the data lake, triggering light alerts.? Segment C/B (Goals 2–3): Composite scores drive dynamic playbooks and proposal logic.? Segment A (Goals 4–5): Real-time inference orchestrates multi-role, outcome-driven strategy.6.2. HealthWhat it is:An AI-powered framework that synthesizes usage metrics, support ticket trends, survey feedback (NPS/CSAT), financial signals, and telemetry into five sub-scores: CX, Technology Adoption, Engagement, Service Quality, and Service Level Alignment. These roll up into a composite CS Health Score that maps to the Client Business Goal quadrant.How it evolves:? Manual Dashboards ? CSMs manually pull usage dashboards and correlate support volumes in spreadsheets.? Rule-Based Alerts ? Static thresholds (e.g., “usage < 20%”) fire email alerts and tasks, and sub-scores are tracked separately.? ML-Driven Health ? Churn-predictor models and clustering algorithms dynamically update segment boundaries, refine sub-score weightings, and trigger context-aware alerts.? Automated Scheduling/Triggers ? When an anomaly or risk pattern is detected (e.g., “Engagement < 70%” or “Alignment < 75%”), the system automatically schedules the next appropriate touchpoint (e.g., adjusting the engagement cadence or queuing a follow-up task) rather than simply notifying the CSM.Why it matters:? Detects early risk signals before escalation.? Aligns engagement strategy to real-time client conditions.? Creates a transparent, composite maturity/appetite view. Business Goal connection:Segment D (Goal 1): Monitors basic CX/adoption/SLA signals.Segment C/B (Goals 2–3): ML detects mid-cycle engagement drops and quadrant shifts.Segment A (Goals 4–5): Triggers proactive executive playbook delivery based on CX or alignment fluctuations.Business Goal connection:? Segment D (Goal 1): Minimal Health metrics: basic usage thresholds, simple adoption checks, and standard quality signals. Alerts prompt the TAM to review or tweak light-touch playbooks (e.g., “Service Quality < 80% ? revisit incident-escalation workflow”).? Segment C (Goal 2) and Segment B (Goal 3): ML models continuously refine sub-scores and the composite Health Score. Mid-cycle anomaly detection (e.g., “Engagement < 70%” or “Adoption < 60%”) automatically triggers a playbook review, refreshing the QBR structure or deploying targeted in-app guidance. Alerts also flag quadrant shifts (e.g., moving from Goal 2 ? 3), updating segmentation and engagement cadence.? Segment A (Goals 4–5): Fully integrated triggers: if an at-risk pattern emerges (e.g., “CX dips < 90%” or “Alignment < 75%”), the system queues the strategic playbook for a senior CSM or vCIO and notifies stakeholders with AI-generated next steps. Quadrant shifts (e.g., from Goal 3 ? 4) immediately update the client’s segment and adjust future engagement strategy.By progressing from manual dashboards and static thresholds to ML-driven insights and automated scheduling/triggers, this Health blueprint enables MSPs to detect emerging risks in real-time, allocate resources more efficiently, and maintain a single, transparent source of truth for each client’s maturity and appetite.
6.3. DeliverablesWhat it is:A structured methodology for generating automated, trigger-based, and AI-enhanced outputs that reflect Customer Success execution. Deliverables are created from the MSP’s CRM, PSA, RMM, or other IT management tools, and transform raw, structured data (e.g., usage logs, support tickets, financial records) into clear, decision-ready artifacts:? Reports (Executive Overview, Technical Summary, CSM-Internal Decks)? Proposals (scope, pricing, architectural diagrams)? Budgets (1–2 year financial forecasts aligned to roadmap milestones)? Client Strategy Documents (integrated narrative of goals, risks, and action plans)? Roadmaps (Gantt charts, swimlane views, “what-if” scenario planning)How it evolves:? Manual Collation ? CSMs copy and paste charts and tables into PPT/Word.? Semi-Automated Templates ? ETL pipelines populate slide masters with data; CSMs still write narratives.? Trigger-Based Assembly ? Templates are automatically populated when events occur (e.g., QBR due, stakeholder change).? AI-Driven Generation ? Generative AI drafts narrative text (e.g., “Key Achievements,” “Next Steps”) and auto-creates slide decks, budgeting spreadsheets, and roadmap visuals.? Autonomous Distribution ? Deliverables are automatically versioned, logged, and shared live or digitally—based on predefined cadence or CS Process triggers.Why it matters:? Consistency & Branding: Every report and proposal follows the same brand template, eliminating formatting errors.? Speed & Responsiveness: Last-minute data updates instantly produce an updated deck without manual effort.? Data-Driven Storytelling: Deliverables reflect CS Health signals and support decisions with narrative, visual, and financial clarity.? Engagement Moment: Deliverables become structured touchpoints—presented live when possible, not just emailed outputs.Business Goal connection:? Segment D (Goal 1): Operational snapshots (e.g., “last month’s usage, open ticket count”).? Segment C (Goal 2) & Segment B (Goal 3): Executive-ready summaries with ROI modelling (e.g., “We saved €X by reducing support costs by Y%”).? Segment A (Goals 4–5): Full strategic assets: integrated narrative, multi-scenario budgeting, and high-level roadmap tied directly to business KPIs.6.4. PeopleWhat it is:An AI-driven “people wizard” that codifies all Customer Success roles—from Junior CSM and Econ Manager to Senior CSM, vCIO, vCISO—and automatically generates:? Role Descriptions & Responsibility Matrices (mapping skills and tasks to each role)? Enablement Content (email templates, slide decks, playbook snippets, case studies) tailored to each role’s skillset and the MSP’s service catalog? Compensation Proposals (salary ranges, bonus structures, incentives based on KPI targets, regional benchmarks, and internal policies)? Governance & Cadence Frameworks (meeting schedules, portfolio reviews, segment-reclassification routines, and centralized source-of-truth documents)? Health Role Mapping & Accountability Models (automatically assigns CS Health metrics—CX, Engagement, Adoption, Quality, Alignment—to appropriate roles based on client segment and CS motion stage)How it evolves:? Static Job Descriptions ? Manually maintained PDFs/Word docs with basic responsibilities.? Template-Driven Wizards ? Spreadsheet templates map skills to tasks, but updates require manual edits.? AI-Enhanced Dynamic Models ? Role profiles reside in JSON/YAML; AI continuously matches actual team skill sets to required responsibilities and flags missing roles (e.g., “No vCISO assigned for cybersecurity-heavy Segment A clients”).? Continuous Adaptive Enablement ? As new services or “high-touch/low-touch” segment definitions emerge, the system instantly regenerates role requirements and training assets.? Dynamic Health Escalation Rules ? Health Score signals (e.g., low Engagement or stalled Adoption) trigger auto-reassignment, additional role activation (e.g., vCIO re-entry), or Enablement workflows.Why it matters:? Clarity & Alignment: Every CSM and extended CS role knows precisely what they own, what they don’t, and how they should be compensated—and this evolves as the MSP’s service catalog or client mix changes.? Skill-Based Assignment: AI ensures that high-complexity tasks (e.g., designing an AI pilot) are assigned to senior staff, while routine tasks (e.g., scheduling or basic reporting) are assigned to junior or economic manager roles.? Faster Onboarding: New hires receive an AI-curated role profile, email templates, slide decks, and a personalized enablement curriculum tailored to their existing skill set and the MSP’s portfolio strategy.? Health-Driven Role Optimization: Role value is validated against CS Health impact—when CX drops, Engagement wanes, or Alignment fails, the system learns which roles performed well and which need realignment or support.Business Goal connection:? Segment D (Goal 1): Lean teams—junior CSMs handling standardized, low-touch engagements.? Segment C (Goal 2) & Segment B (Goal 3): Layered roles—Senior CSMs own mid-market playbooks; vCIO/vCISO provide specialized guidance.? Segment A (Goals 4–5): Full-stack teams—dedicated security specialists, data scientists, and enablement leads produce custom artifacts for high-touch, co-innovation clients.All Segments: Health Score signals (especially in Engagement and Adoption) serve as feedback loops, triggering training, role handoffs, or escalation pathways based on real-world performance trends.
6.5. ProcessWhat it is:A centralized rules engine and event-bus orchestration framework that codifies every CS process into reusable, versioned workflows:? Meeting Scheduling & Trigger Automation (pre-defined cadences vs. event-driven exceptions)? Discovery & Assessment Intake (AI-assisted, profile-specific questionnaires assembled using structured client data)? Meeting Conduct & Documentation (auto-generated agendas, initiative capture from meeting notes, real-time transcription, and sentiment analysis)? Initiative & Project Lifecycle Management (task generation, roadmap alignment, and AI-enhanced summary preparation)? Governance Cadence (trigger-based escalation rules and cadence tracking, including monthly CSM syncs, quarterly QBR prep, and annual portfolio reviews)How it evolves:? Manual Handoffs ? CSMs individually manage calendars, send discovery links, and manually track next steps.? Scripted Workflows ? Basic low-code tools (Zapier, Power Automate) handle email reminders and simple status changes.? Orchestrator + AI ? An event-driven orchestration engine uses structured inputs (e.g., CRM, PSA, RMM, or other IT management tools) to trigger the right CS processes—like Discovery or Assessment—based on timeline or KPI change.? Full-Stack Governance ? Governance execution is fully automated and auditable. AI-enhanced routines personalize execution logic and identify missed actions (e.g., unviewed reports, stale roadmaps).Why it matters:? Closed-Loop Execution: Every trigger—whether a calendar cadence or a usage anomaly—resolves into a scheduled meeting, a task assignment, or a remediation workflow. No open loops.? Scalability & Auditability: Every process step is defined as code, version-controlled, and auditable—crucial for compliance and quality assurance in fast-growing MSPs.? Personalized & Adaptive Execution: AI prepares Discovery and Assessment flows, extracts initiatives, and ensures the proper process happens at the right time, regardless of engagement level.Business Goal connection:? Segment D (Goal 1): Fixed cadences—monthly check-ins and simple discovery surveys.? Segment C (Goal 2) & Segment B (Goal 3): Hybrid orchestration—quarterly business reviews supplemented by event-triggered deep dives (e.g., security assessment if the “Cybersecurity” survey flags a high risk).? Segment A (Goals 4–5): Fully dynamic loops—continuous discovery, real-time meeting generation on any KPI threshold crossing, and self-healing playbooks that reassign tasks and adjust roadmaps instantly.In SummaryCS Technology is the backbone that turns a Customer Success strategy, processes, deliverables, people, and health monitoring into a coherent, automated, AI-driven machine. When implemented well, it ensures:? Every Data Source Flows Smoothly into a unified data lake, feeding real-time health scores, analytics, and AI models.? Every AI Model Is Easily Swappable (churn prediction, next-best action, generative narratives) without rewriting core workflows.? Every Deliverable (Report, Proposal, Budget, Strategy Document, Roadmap) Is Auto-Generated with the latest data and AI-generated narratives—freeing CSMs to customize and personalize.? Every Role and Responsibility Is Defined by skillset and seniority, with AI automatically matching tasks to the right people and flagging gaps.? Every process is code-powered (scheduling, discovery, assessment, and initiative lifecycle), versioned, monitored, and continuously optimized by AI.As clients progress from Segment D (Goal 1) through Segment C (Goal 2), Segment B (Goal 3), to Segment A (Goals 4–5), CS Technology ensures they seamlessly “level up” from simple scripts and static PDFs to real-time AI insights and autonomous remediation—without a single manual pivot. It is the discipline that ensures human-first interactions remain at the core, while automation and AI power the engine beneath.
?? 6.1 Strategy
6.1 Strategy OverviewWhat is the objective?Why is it important?As an MSP, why do I need to do this?What is the Customer impact?Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: Continuous, AI-Driven SegmentationConcept #2: Engagement Strategy as a System, Not a ScheduleConcept #3: Playbooks Are Digital Workflows, Not PDFsConcept #4: Service Catalog as a Recommendation EngineConcept #5: Standardization as an Enforceable MetricConcept #6: Service Catalog as a Dynamic Source of TruthApplication ProcessStep 1: Map and Normalize All Client, Financial, and Service DataStep 2: Segment Clients Using a Dual-Axis (Value & Readiness) ModelStep 3: Define and Allocate Engagement Strategies by Segment and CapacityStep 4: Deploy, Select, and Tailor Playbooks for Consistent ExecutionStep 5: Map and Recommend Service Catalog Items to Segments and InitiativesStep 6: Monitor and Enforce Standardization Across the PortfolioStep 7: Expose Real-Time Dashboards, Alerts, and InsightsStep 8: Continuous Review, Feedback, and GovernanceAppendixHow does Strategy connect to Client Business Goal levels?How does Strategy connect to other CS disciplines?
OverviewWhat is the objective?The objective of the CS Technology Strategy is to operationalize every core pillar of the Customer Success Strategy—Segmentation, Engagement Strategy, Playbooks, Service Catalog, and Standardization—within a unified, data-driven, API-first architecture. This enables MSPs to deliver scalable, automated, consistent CS execution across the client base. The technology stack ensures that every decision—from segmentation to playbook delivery—is based on the same shared data layer, logic, and system. Hence, each client receives the experience best matched to their segment, business goals, and maturity.Every strategic output—segmentation, engagement plans, playbooks, service recommendations, and stack alignment metrics—is dynamically generated and benchmarked against an integrated Service Catalog and Stack Catalog. This ensures that every assessment, proposal, and roadmap is grounded in catalog-driven offerings and objective stack alignment. At the same time, segmentation, engagement, and playbook logic remain equally foundational to all CS workflows.Concretely, the system automatically generates:? Segmentation recommendations (using MRR plus Composite Health [Maturity/Appetite] scores),? Engagement Strategy plans (prescribing the frequency, format, and depth of touchpoints for each segment),? CS Playbook drafts (tailored workflow templates and trigger conditions for each client and scenario),? Service Catalog mapping and recommendations (ensuring that every segment, initiative, and proposal references a structured catalog of ongoing and project services—providing a “single source of truth” for what is delivered at each level),? Standardization and stack alignment metrics (tracking portfolio-wide compliance with defined technology and process standards and surfacing actionable gaps to drive roadmap and initiative planning).These outputs are continuously refreshed and drive the downstream modules of Customer Success Health, Delivery, People, and Process—ensuring that every client receives the right level of engagement and support, grounded in standardized operations and personalized business context.Why is it important?A unified, architecture-driven strategy ensures that all core Customer Success processes—client segmentation, engagement cadence, playbook execution, service catalog mapping, and standardization—are orchestrated from the same real-time data and logic. This eliminates silos, prevents duplication, and accelerates strategic decision-making across the entire client base.With this approach, segmentation is always up to date, engagement rhythms are automatically adjusted for each segment, playbooks are tailored and triggered based on real signals, service catalog options are proactively surfaced and recommended, and the standardization of technology and services ensures that execution is consistent and scalable. Only reduces the risk of over-serving low-potential clients or under-investing in high-value accounts and increases the quality, predictability, and business impact of every CS initiative.As an MSP, why do I need to do this?Without a technology-driven, blueprint-aligned CS strategy, MSPs are forced to manually segment clients, improvise engagement routines, build one-off playbooks, and create ad hoc proposals—leading to inefficiencies, errors, and inconsistent experiences. By adopting this system, you can:? Automatically segment and re-segment clients as their value, maturity, or goals change,? Deliver engagement strategies and playbooks that precisely fit each segment’s real needs and readiness,? Map proposals and initiatives directly to the exemplary service catalog items.? Enforce and benefit from a portfolio-wide standard technology stack and delivery model.This enables you to scale your CS operation, launch new services or playbooks quickly, reduce onboarding and training overhead, and ensure that every client interaction aligns with their business objectives and operational standards.What is the Customer impact?Clients experience a CS process that is transparent, personalized, and proactive:?
