They receive only the services, engagement rhythms, and playbook-driven support relevant to their segment, business goal, and maturity,? They can clearly see what is included in their service package and what opportunities exist for growth, thanks to a transparent service catalog,? They benefit from predictable quality, faster delivery, and fewer handoffs or errors due to a standardized technology stack and service approach,? They always have a clear path to improvement or innovation since every risk or opportunity is automatically mapped to a concrete initiative or catalog item and supported by tailored playbooks.This results in higher satisfaction, more productive business conversations, and a strengthened partnership between the client and MSP, driving retention and shared success..
Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: Continuous, AI-Driven SegmentationPractical Recommendation: Implement automated segmentation with an AI model that uses live data from your CS tool, CRM, PSA, and CS Health scoring. Ensure segmentation logic (both MRR banding and business goal scoring) is visible in a dashboard and auto-updates as clients move. Set up rules for any significant Health change (e.g., adoption drop or engagement boost) to trigger an immediate re-segmentation and workflow update.Tech Tip: Use your data lake to pull composite health scores and MRR, then automate segment assignments with scheduled or real-time jobs (e.g., a scheduled Python script, workflow automation tool, or a BI platform with custom logic). Integrate segment tags into every client record across all systems.Concept #2: Engagement Strategy as a System, Not a SchedulePractical Recommendation: Define engagement templates for each segment (frequency, meeting type, roles, prep steps). Build these into your workflow engine so that the engagement cadence and role assignment are automatically updated when a client moves the segment. Regularly check your CS team’s available hours against the planned engagement load—use this to inform hiring or to re-balance engagement levels.Tech Tip: Leverage your calendar API and workflow tool to auto-schedule recurring meetings for each client based on their segment. Build engagement capacity dashboards in your BI/reporting platform to visualize workload and spot imbalances.Concept #3: Playbooks Are Digital Workflows, Not PDFsPractical Recommendation: Document and digitalize your top CS playbooks for each segment and key lifecycle event (e.g., onboarding, roadmap review, QBR, health drop). Build playbook steps as checklists or tasks in your workflow engine so execution and completion can be monitored and reported. Trigger playbook assignment via automation, not just manual selection—e.g., missed engagement, low health score, or segment change.Tech Tip: Use a workflow automation platform (Zapier, Power Automate, or similar) or custom tool to create digital playbook templates. Ensure each playbook step is mapped to a CS tool, CRM or PSA activity and completion updates are tracked automatically. Build dashboards for playbook completion rates and bottlenecks.Concept #4: Service Catalog as a Recommendation EnginePractical Recommendation: Tag each service catalog item with the relevant segments and business goal levels (e.g., "Segment B / Goal 3: Cloud Migration Assessment"). Regularly review clients’ current services versus the catalog to highlight gaps and suggest initiatives or projects automatically. Build proposal templates that directly pull in catalog items and initiative scopes so sales and CS teams don’t have to reinvent proposals.Tech Tip: Use your BI/reporting or CRM platform to run catalog gap analysis—auto-generate "service opportunity" lists for each client. Integrate catalog items into your quoting and proposal tool (e.g., with a shared item library or API), so recommendations are embedded in every initiative.Concept #5: Standardization as an Enforceable MetricPractical Recommendation: Define your standard stack (by service category and vendor) and tag every client and service instance for compliance. Set up automated stack conformance checks—identify and flag deviations, then automatically suggest remediation playbooks (e.g., "Switch backup to standard platform," "Enable MFA"). Tie non-standard stack elements to health scoring so they impact CS metrics and trigger initiative planning. Build a stack compliance dashboard—use your RMM, PSA, or custom inventory tool to check deployed technologies against your standard list. Set up automated alerts for exceptions. Use these exceptions to trigger automated initiative or roadmap item creation in your CS/project management platform.Concept #6: Service Catalog as a Dynamic Source of TruthPractical Recommendation: Establish a centralized service catalog that is structured according to segment and business goal level. For every proposal, assessment, and QBR, compare actual client services to the catalog and use gap analysis to trigger new initiatives, project recommendations, or renewal proposals. Regularly update catalog items with feedback from playbook outcomes, client requests, and market changes.Tech Tip:Integrate the catalog with your proposal and roadmap tools using APIs or shared templates. Automate “catalog gap” detection and embed suggested upsell/cross-sell opportunities into your CS dashboard. Ensure all team members reference the catalog for every deliverable and playbook trigger.
Application ProcessStep 1: Map and Normalize All Client, Financial, and Service DataIntegrating all core systems—PSA, CRM, RMM, financial, calendar, and any legacy data sources—into a central, versioned data lake. Standardize all client identifiers, service records, contract values (MRR), health scores, playbook histories, and catalog adoption data. This unified, normalized foundation allows every other CS Strategy pillar (segmentation, engagement, playbooks, catalog, standardization) to use the same accurate information for both automation and reporting.Step 2: Segment Clients Using a Dual-Axis (Value & Readiness) ModelApply a two-level segmentation logic, as defined in the Segmentation blueprint:? Primary segmentation by Client Business Goal (using maturity and appetite scores calculated from CS Health and discovery data),? Secondary segmentation by financial value (MRR bands).Clients are automatically placed into the right segment (A–D) and band, which drives all downstream engagement, playbook, catalog, and standardization decisions. Segment assignments are continuously reviewed and updated as client health, engagement, or business goals evolve.Step 3: Define and Allocate Engagement Strategies by Segment and CapacityFor each client segment and MRR band, establish engagement cadence, interaction format, meeting types, and assigned roles (vCIO, CSM, TAM), following the Engagement Strategy blueprint.? Calculate and allocate CS team capacity based on real client distribution and internal resource availability,? Balance proactive (planned) vs. reactive (ad hoc) CS work for each segment,? Adjust engagement investment as needed to stay within operational limits and ensure strategic clients receive priority.These engagement plans are versioned, monitored, and dynamically adapted as health and segment data changes.Step 4: Deploy, Select, and Tailor Playbooks for Consistent ExecutionSelect and personalize CS playbooks for each client and segment, based on current engagement strategy, health triggers, and catalog usage, in line with the Playbooks blueprint:? Trigger playbooks automatically based on cadence, risk signals, or business milestones (e.g., roadmap review, health drop, assessment finding),? Assign the correct roles for delivery,? Monitor completion and outcome, feeding the results into the system for analysis and improvement.Playbook coverage is regularly reviewed to ensure up-to-date, repeatable workflows support every segment and service level.Step 5: Map and Recommend Service Catalog Items to Segments and InitiativesFor each client, map current services and identify gaps by referencing the Service Catalog:? Proactively recommend catalog items (ongoing or project-based) that align with the client’s business goals and segment readiness,? Integrate catalog options into all proposals, initiatives, and playbooks,? Track adoption, upsell/cross-sell, and renewal opportunities using catalog-linked dashboards. Catalog recommendations and usage patterns are reviewed regularly to surface service gaps, emerging needs, and opportunities for standardization.Each assessment, onboarding, or QBR automatically benchmarks the client’s actual and contracted services against the Service Catalog for their segment and maturity level. Detected gaps are converted into actionable project or proposal recommendations, ensuring every client engagement is catalog-driven. Service Catalog mapping also supports proactive playbook selection and ensures deliverables are consistent.Step 6: Monitor and Enforce Standardization Across the PortfolioAssess each client’s alignment to the standardized technology stack and service delivery model, as defined in the Standardization blueprint:? Flag non-standard configurations, technologies, or services,? Prioritize standardization initiatives based on risk, client maturity, and business opportunity,? Integrate standardization metrics into health scoring, roadmap planning, onboarding, and reporting. Use stack conformance data to drive ongoing improvement and future roadmap priorities.Use a living Stack Catalog (preferred tools, configurations, and standards) to benchmark every client environment for onboarding, QBRs, and roadmap planning. All non-standard items are flagged, and automated initiatives or playbooks are generated to close stack gaps. Stack alignment scores are integrated with health scoring and appear in dashboards and reporting.Step 7: Expose Real-Time Dashboards, Alerts, and InsightsProvide dedicated dashboards for every CS Strategy pillar:? Segmentation status and movements,? Engagement cadence and CS capacity utilization,? Playbook execution and completion,? Service catalog coverage and gaps,? Standardization compliance and exceptions.Set up automated alerts for key events—segment drift, engagement drops, missed playbooks, catalog gaps, or non-standard stack risks—so the CS team can act proactively.Step 8: Continuous Review, Feedback, and GovernanceOn a regular cadence (e.g., monthly/quarterly), review performance data, client feedback, health trends, and operational capacity:? Update segmentation logic and business goal mapping as new data emerges,? Refine engagement models and playbook workflows based on real outcomes,? Expand and evolve the service catalog and standard stack as market or technology shifts require,? Document and communicate all version changes through formal governance reviews, ensuring cross-functional buy-in and operational clarity.This cycle ensures the CS Technology Strategy is not static but a living system that continuously improves alignment between client needs, business strategy, and operational delivery.
AppendixHow does Strategy connect to Client Business Goal levels?Client Business Goal LevelCS Strategy FocusDownstream Impact1. Technology SupportThe strategy focuses on precise segmentation (Segment D) and minimal, cost-effective engagement cadence. The default is a “keep-the-lights-on” mode, prioritizing operational stability, basic visibility, and fast issue resolution, not strategic planning.All CS Health metrics and Processes are centred around SLA tracking, ticket response, and baseline service quality. Meeting rhythm is minimal (annual/ad hoc). Initiatives and Deliverables are basic, standardized reports and immediate problem-resolution actions.2. Technology EnablementStrategy introduces structure: for Segment C clients, quarterly QBRs, simple project/initiative-based roadmaps, and straightforward TAM/SDM role assignment become standard.CS Health places greater weight on technology adoption and engagement trends. The process includes routine discovery intake and assessments, which support client progression and maturity. Deliverables start to include project proposals and basic stack alignment reporting.3. Technology ModernizationStrategy enables roadmap-driven operation for Segment B clients: formal QBRs, dedicated AM/vCIO involvement, and all initiatives, assessments, and deliverables focused on modernization and lifecycle alignment.CS Health now evaluates all five dimensions (CX, Engagement, Adoption, Alignment, and Service Quality). The process shifts to quarterly or more frequent assessments and roadmap reviews. Deliverables cover detailed strategic documentation and complex initiatives.4. Business TransformationStrategy at this level aligns with Segment A clients’ business goals: annual strategic planning, quarterly reviews, monthly executive meetings, department-level alignment, cross-functional initiatives, all supported by vCIO/Strategic Advisor roles.CS Health incorporates business outcome indicators and stakeholder engagement. Process mandates Discovery + Assessment + Meeting + Initiative rhythm. Deliverables are outcome-oriented; People discipline drives cross-department communication and enablement.5. Business InnovationThe strategy supports co-innovation: clients actively participate in strategic, OKR-based planning, innovation programs, and advanced analytics/AI roadmaps. Segmentation and Engagement Strategies are dynamic, with multiple stakeholders and continuous steering.CS Health and Process now track multi-level, cross-department alignment, adoption, and engagement. Deliverables provide innovation roadmaps and advanced outcome reporting. People discipline includes vCxO, innovation leads, and specialist teams with ongoing enablement and governance.How does Strategy connect to other CS disciplines?? Client Business Goal: Strategy is fundamentally anchored in the Client Business Goal framework—every aspect of segmentation, engagement, playbook logic, and service catalog mapping is driven by the client’s maturity and appetite. Strategic planning is reviewed annually to align with evolving business goals and segment changes.? CS Strategy: The 6.1 Strategy blueprint operationalizes all five pillars: dynamic segmentation, targeted engagement strategy, standardized playbooks, catalog-driven initiative planning, and enforceable standardization. Every strategic workflow begins and ends with this unified logic.? CS Health: Strategy and Health are tightly integrated: segmentation changes, subscore movements, or drops in engagement can trigger an immediate strategic response (e.g., new playbook, cadence change, or initiative). Health metrics provide continuous feedback loops for strategy refinement.? CS Deliverables: Strategy defines the deliverable standards for each segment, including what reports, roadmaps, budgets, and other outputs are required and how they are aligned to playbooks, meetings, initiatives, and roadmap milestones. Deliverables become more sophisticated as client business goals and segment levels advance.? CS Process: Strategy sets the process logic—every workflow (Discovery, Assessment, Meeting, Initiative) is triggered, prioritized, and executed based on the segmentation, engagement rhythm, and playbook standards defined at the strategy level. Process cadence and complexity always map to the client segment.? CS People: Strategy determines resource allocation, team enablement, governance, and role assignment. For Segment A/B clients, this means cross-functional, strategic teams; for C/D segments, more streamlined TAM/AM delivery. The strategy routinely reviews people allocation and competencies to ensure the team structure matches client needs and business goals.
?? 6.2 Health
6.2 HealthOverviewWhat is the objective?Why is it important?As an MSP, why do I need to do this?What is the Customer impact?Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: Client Experience (CX) Is the First Appetite Signal (High Impact)Concept #2: Technology Adoption Is a Maturity Signal (Lower Business Impact)Concept #3: Engagement Is an Appetite/Maturity Hybrid SignalConcept #4: Service Quality Is a Maturity Signal (Lower Strategic Impact)Concept #5: Service Level Alignment Is a Hybrid Signal (High Strategic Impact)Implementation ProcessStep 1: Establish Data Feeds for All Health DimensionsStep 2: Define Scoring Models for Each DimensionStep 3: Build the Composite Health EngineStep 4: Continuous Monitoring, Refinement & Governance4. Aspect: Engagement Strategy vs. CS PlaybookAppendixHow does it connect to Client Business Goal levels?How does it connect to the other disciplines?Product Links / Tooling Support
OverviewWhat is the objective?The CS Technology Health methodology defines a product-agnostic, API-first approach within the larger Customer Success ecosystem. In this model, an average mid-tier MSP managing 100 or more clients cannot rely on offline spreadsheets or manual reports to stay up-to-date. Instead, diverse data sources—such as PSA, CRM, MRR feeds, RMM, and other IT-management tools—stream raw information about Strategy, Deliverables, People, and Processes into a centralized data lake or warehouse. Once data is consolidated, AI-powered engines automatically compute a real-time composite Health Score by consolidating signals around client experience, technology adoption, engagement, service quality, and service level alignment. Those AI-generated Health outputs become the strategic instructions for downstream Strategy, Deliverables, People, and Process modules (e.g., triggering segmentation updates, playbook adjustments, or resource reallocation).Why is it important?? Health Score as the single source of truth: a continuously updated composite prevents reactive firefighting by surfacing risks early and revealing shifts in client appetite or maturity (quadrant changes).? Multi-dimensional insight: each sub-score (CX, adoption, engagement, quality, alignment) signals appetite (strategic intent) or maturity (operational stability), allowing MSPs to distinguish between technical/operational risks and strategic/business risks.? Alert-driven guidance: Rather than auto-scheduling fix-it meetings, Health generates intelligent alerts that guide stakeholders to review or adjust playbooks. Alerts also flag quadrant shifts, allowing segmentation and engagement strategies (handled by the Strategy module) to be updated accordingly.As an MSP, why do I need to do this?? Client Experience (CX) ? Appetite (Strategic) Signal: A decline in CX indicates eroding trust and strategic misalignment, with high impact on business outcomes.Technology Adoption ? Maturity (Operational) Signal: a drop in adoption highlights foundational or technical gaps—lower immediate business impact but high operational risk.? Engagement ? Appetite/Maturity Hybrid Signal: low engagement can signal either operational stagnation (low maturity) or strategic shift (high appetite) if executives disengage.? Service Quality ? Maturity (Operational) Signal: Poor service quality indicates inconsistent execution—high operational risk, lower direct strategic impact.? Service Level Alignment ? Hybrid, Leaning Strategic Signal: Misalignment indicates that delivered services no longer align with the client’s evolving business goals—high risk for churn or lost growth.What is the Customer impact?? Segment D (Goal 1): basic monitoring: simple CX checks, minimal adoption tracking, standard quality checks. Alerts direct the TAM to review light-touch playbooks (e.g., “Quality < 80% ? revisit incident-escalation playbook”).? Segment C (Goal 2): Rule-based and occasional ML anomaly detection. Alerts generate opportunities to refine quarterly playbooks (e.g., “Engagement < 70% ? adjust QBR structure”).? Segment B (Goal 3): biweekly/monthly ML-supported monitoring. Alerts route to senior CSM or vCIO to fine-tune strategic playbooks (e.g., “Alignment < 70% ? update roadmap playbook”).? Segment A (Goals 4–5): Continuous ML inference provides early warning of appetite or maturity shifts (quadrant changes). Alerts guide executive-level playbook tuning (e.g., “CX dips < 90% ? review executive engagement framework”) without auto-scheduling meetings.
Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: Client Experience (CX) Is the First Appetite Signal (High Impact)? Definition: CX measures how the client perceives the overall service journey, encompassing communication clarity, responsiveness, meeting relevance, and trust. It directly reflects the client’s appetite: high CX means the client feels value and is primed for deeper engagement; low CX signals strategic misalignment.? How it works:? Surveys & Sentiment Analysis: After each meeting, a short CSAT/NPS survey is triggered via the CRM; recorded calls feed an NLP sentiment engine to identify positive and negative phrase frequencies.? Quadrant Insight:? Sustained CX decline reduces appetite, potentially shifting the client toward a lower quadrant of the market.? High CX in a mid-maturity client suggests readiness to move up (e.g., from Goal 3 to Goal 4)? Why it matters:CX is the earliest strategic signal. An alert on falling CX prompts review of engagement-style playbooks (e.g., “Revise QBR agenda,” “Adjust leadership participation”) rather than automatically scheduling a remedial call.Concept #2: Technology Adoption Is a Maturity Signal (Lower Business Impact)? Definition: Adoption measures real-world usage of MSP-recommended technologies; deployed solutions must be actively used. This is primarily an operational (maturity) signal—lower immediate business impact, but critical for long-term stability.? How it works: Category & Insight Definition: Break each primary technology domain (Security, Collaboration, Cloud, etc.) into weighted, measurable insights (e.g., “MFA enabled on 90% of users” = 10 points, “endpoint AV compliance” = 10 points). Compliance Calculation: For each insight:1. earned points = (actual % / target %) ? insight points2. Aggregate Score: Sum all earned points, divide by total possible points, normalize to 0–100. Segment Thresholds:? D (Goal 1): < 50 ? “At Risk”; 50–70 ? “Partial”; > 70 ? “Stable.”? C (Goal 2): < 60 ? “At Risk”; 60–80 ? “Partial”; > 80 ? “Stable.”? B (Goal 3): < 70 ? “At Risk”; 70–90 ? “Partial”; > 90 ? “Stable.”? A (Goals 4–5): < 90 ? “Watch”; ≥ 90 ? “Operational Excellence.”? Why it matters: Low adoption points to gaps in foundational usage. Alerts on adoption drops prompt the onboarding and enablement team to revise their training or onboarding playbooks.Concept #3: Engagement Is an Appetite/Maturity Hybrid Signal? Definition: Engagement quantifies how consistently and meaningfully clients participate in CS processes, including check-ins, roadmap reviews, and strategic planning. It signals operational stability when documented touchpoints are routine, and strategic intent when deeper, executive-level interactions occur.? How it works:? Cadence Adherence (30%): % of scheduled touchpoints held on time? Role Participation (20%): % of required stakeholders (execs/tech leads) attending? Decision Velocity (25%): Average days between proposal delivery and client approval (faster = higher appetite)? Activity Level (25%): Number of initiative-related interactions per quarter? Quadrant Insight: Low engagement + low adoption ? support focus (Goal 1, remains D quadrant). High engagement without corresponding adoption ? aspirational but underperforming (possibly B quadrant). High engagement + high CX ? strategic partner (Goal 4–5, A quadrant).? Why it matters: When engagement falls below the segment threshold (e.g., < 70% for a B-segment client), an alert triggers a review of the Engagement Strategy playbook (e.g., “Adjust meeting frequency or format”).Concept #4: Service Quality Is a Maturity Signal (Lower Strategic Impact)? Definition: Service Quality measures how reliably the MSP fulfills operational commitments, such as SLA compliance, on-time project milestones, and incident resolution. It’s primarily an operational (maturity) signal; low immediate strategic impact but high operational trust.? How it works: Quantitative (60%):? SLA Compliance (25%): % of tickets closed within SLA? On-Time Delivery (25%): % of milestones completed on schedule? Incident Recurrence (10%): % of issues reopened within 30 days (lower is better)? Qualitative (40%): Post-delivery client feedback on professionalism and clarity; internal governance audit scores. Segment Thresholds:? D (Goal 1): < 60 ? “At Risk”; 60–80 ? “Stable”; > 80 ? “Trusted.”? C (Goal 2): < 70 ? “At Risk”; 70–90 ? “Stable”; > 90 ? “Trusted.”? B (Goal 3): < 80 ? “At Risk”; 80–95 ? “Stable”; > 95 ? “Reliable.”? A (Goals 4–5): < 95 ? “Watch”; ≥ 95 ? “Exemplary.”? Why it matters: Poor service quality erodes operational trust. A service-quality alert prompts a review of the Service Quality playbook (e.g., incident escalation procedures) rather than auto-scheduling a meeting.Concept #5: Service Level Alignment Is a Hybrid Signal (High Strategic Impact)? Definition: Service Level Alignment measures how closely delivered services match the client’s current business goals, maturity, and appetite. It combines operational precision (maturity) with strategic fit (appetite), making it a leading indicator of retention and growth risk.? How it works: Strategic Fit (50%): Degree to which active services align to documented client objectives (validated via governance discussions). Scope Match (30%): Comparison of contracted service catalog versus actual consumed services. Client Perception (20%): Post-meeting survey (“Did our roadmap address your top priorities?”). Segment Thresholds:? D (Goal 1): < 50 ? “Misaligned”; 50–70 ? “Partial”; > 70 ? “Aligned.”? C (Goal 2): < 60 ? “Misaligned”; 60–85 ? “Partial”; > 85 ? “Aligned.”? B (Goal 3): < 70 ? “Misaligned”; 70–90 ? “Partial”; > 90 ? “Aligned.”? A (Goals 4–5): < 90 ? “Watch”; ≥ 90 ? “Fully Aligned.”? Why it matters: Misalignment between services and client goals is a high-risk signal. An alignment alert triggers a leadership review of the Service Level Alignment playbook (e.g., adjusting service tiers or updating contract language), not an automatic meeting.
Implementation ProcessStep 1: Establish Data Feeds for All Health Dimensions1. Client Experience (CX): Post-meeting CSAT/NPS surveys triggered via CRM/API; recorded call transcripts processed by an NLP sentiment engine; milestone-triggered feedback forms automatically sent after key deliverable reviews.2. Technology Adoption: Telemetry ingestion from PSA and IT management tools (e.g., endpoint protection logs, MFA enrollment logs); configuration compliance checks via RMM tools (e.g., patch status, backup success); usage reports from collaboration or cloud platforms pulled via API into a central data pipeline.3. Engagement: Calendar logs (Microsoft Graph, Google Calendar APIs) capture invitations, acceptances, and attendance; CRM events track proposal sends and approvals to measure decision velocity; PSA events are triggered when a support ticket is opened immediately after a scheduled session, indicating a potential engagement gap.4. Service Quality: SLA compliance data pulled from PSA (ticket open/close timestamps); project management tool events (e.g., “milestone completed”) imported via API; governance checklists and audit forms capturing qualitative feedback after each major delivery.5. Service Level Alignment: Contracted service catalog stored in CRM compared to actual consumed service logs; governance meeting notes ingested (via a shared repository or structured form) to capture alignment decisions; post-QBR alignment-check surveys sent (“Did our roadmap address your priorities?”).All feeds should flow into a centralized streaming infrastructure (e.g., Kafka, Amazon Kinesis, Google Pub/Sub) for real-time processing.Step 2: Define Scoring Models for Each Dimension1. CX Score (0–100):? Quantitative (60%): post-meeting CSAT (weighted by segment); survey response rate (low rate signals risk); NLP sentiment score from call transcripts (negative phrase frequency).? Qualitative (40%): thematic analysis of open feedback (“too technical,” “lack of direction”); structured flags (e.g., “executive expressed dissatisfaction”).? Segment Thresholds: ? D (Goal 1): < 50 ? “At Risk”; 50–70 ? “Watch”; > 70 ? “Healthy.” ? C (Goal 2): < 60 ? “At Risk”; 60–80 ? “Watch”; > 80 ? “Healthy.” ? B (Goal 3): < 70 ? “At Risk”; 70–90 ? “Watch”; > 90 ? “Healthy.” ? A (Goals 4–5): adaptive ML thresholds; significant deviation ? “Critical.”2. Technology Adoption Score (0–100):? Category & Insight Definition: for each primary technology domain, assign weighted insights (e.g., “MFA enabled on 90% of users” = 10 points, “endpoint AV compliance” = 10 points).? Compliance Calculation: earned points = (actual% % / target %) ? insight points.? Aggregate Score: sum all earned points, divide by total possible points, normalize to 0–100.? Segment Thresholds: ? D (Goal 1): < 50 ? “At Risk”; 50–70 ? “Partial”; > 70 ? “Stable.” ? C (Goal 2): < 60 ? “At Risk”; 60–80 ? “Partial”; > 80 ? “Stable.” ? B (Goal 3): < 70 ? “At Risk”; 70–90 ? “Partial”; > 90 ? “Stable.” ? A (Goals 4–5): < 90 ? “Watch”; ≥ 90 ? “Operational Excellence.”3. Engagement Score (0–100):? Metrics & Weights: cadence adherence (30%): % of scheduled touchpoints held on time; role participation (20%): % of required stakeholders (execs/tech leads) attending; decision velocity (25%): average days from deliverable to approval (faster = higher score); activity level (25%): number of initiative-related interactions per quarter.? Segment Thresholds: ? D (Goal 1): < 50 ? “Low”; 50–70 ? “Medium”; > 70 ? “Healthy.” ? C (Goal 2): < 60 ? “Low”; 60–80 ? “Medium”; > 80 ? “Healthy.” ? B (Goal 3): < 70 ? “Low”; 70–90 ? “Medium”; > 90 ? “Healthy.” ? A (Goals 4–5): adaptive ML thresholds; sudden drop ? “Critical.”4. Service Quality Score (0–100):? Quantitative (60%): SLA compliance (25%): % of tickets closed within SLA; on-time delivery (25%): % of milestones delivered on schedule; incident recurrence rate (10%): % of issues reopened within 30 days (inverted scale).? Qualitative (40%): post-delivery client feedback on clarity and professionalism; internal governance audit scores.? Segment Thresholds: ? D (Goal 1): < 60 ? “At Risk”; 60–80 ? “Stable”; > 80 ? “Trusted.” ? C (Goal 2): < 70 ? “At Risk”; 70–90 ? “Stable”; > 90 ? “Trusted.” ? B (Goal 3): < 80 ? “At Risk”; 80–95 ? “Stable”; > 95 ? “Reliable.” ? A (Goals 4–5): < 95 ? “Watch”; ≥ 95 ? “Exemplary.”5. Service Level Alignment Score (0–100):? Alignment Dimensions & Weights: strategic fit (50%): degree active services align with documented client objectives (governance validation); scope match (30%): contracted services vs. actual consumed services; client perception (20%): post-engagement survey (“Did we address your priorities?”).? Segment Thresholds: ? D (Goal 1): < 50 ? “Misaligned”; 50–70 ? “Partial”; > 70 ? “Aligned.” ? C (Goal 2): < 60 ? “Misaligned”; 60–85 ? “Partial”; > 85 ? “Aligned.” ? B (Goal 3): < 70 ? “Misaligned”; 70–90 ? “Partial”; > 90 ? “Aligned.” ? A (Goals 4–5): < 90 ? “Watch”; ≥ 90 ? “Fully Aligned.” Step 3: Build the Composite Health Engine1. Data Ingestion & Consolidation: Stream consolidated metrics for each dimension through a central pipeline (Kafka, Amazon Kinesis, Google Pub/Sub). Map each raw value to a 0–100 scale using the segment-specific thresholds above.2. Compute Composite Health Score: Formula: Composite Health Score = (CX ? 20%) + (Adoption ? 20%) + (Engagement ? 20%) + (Quality ? 20%) + (Alignment ? 20%). Adjust weights dynamically per segment (e.g., A-segment may weight Alignment and CX at 25% each). Recompute in real-time whenever new data arrives or ML models are updated.3. Derive Appetite/Maturity & Client Business Goal Level: Indices Computation: Maturity Index = (Adoption ? 0.4) + (Quality ? 0.3) + (Engagement ? 0.2) + (Alignment ? 0.1). Appetite Index = (CX ? 0.4) + (Engagement ? 0.3) + (Adoption ? 0.2) + (Alignment ? 0.1). Quadrant Mapping: plot Maturity vs. Appetite on a 5?5 grid to assign a “Client Business Goal Level” (1–5). When index values cross thresholds, generate an alert indicating a quadrant shift (e.g., Goal 2 ? 3). Downstream Update: automatically update the client’s segment and goal in the segmentation service so that Engagement Strategy and role assignments adapt accordingly.4. Alert Generation (Playbook Review Triggers): For each dimension crossing its risk threshold (e.g., B-segment CX < 60), create a high-priority alert. Alert Payload: triggered dimension (e.g., “Engagement < 70”); current Composite Health Score and all sub-scores; recommended playbook(s) to review (e.g., “Revise QBR agenda,” “Update onboarding/training workflow”); suggested owner roles (TAM, Senior CSM, vCIO) based on segment and dimension. Route alerts to the appropriate role queues via CRM or ticketing systems. Do not auto-schedule any new meetings; instead, prompt stakeholders to review and revise playbooks or processes.5. API Integrations (PSA, IT Management, CRM): PSA Integration: retrieve ticket status, SLA compliance, and incident logs to feed Service Quality and Scope Match scores. IT Management Tools: ingest endpoint compliance, patch status, MFA logs, and collaboration tool usage to feed Technology Adoption scores. MSP CRM: pull meeting schedules and attendance data for Engagement scoring; capture proposal sends/approvals for Decision Velocity; harvest survey responses and sentiment flags for CX. All API feeds flow into the Health data pipeline, ensuring that the appetite and maturity indices update dynamically.Step 4: Continuous Monitoring, Refinement & Governance1. Monthly Health Review Dashboard: Display distribution of clients across Health Score bands (0–20, 21–40, 41–60, 61–80, 81–100) by segment; break down sub-scores (CX, adoption, engagement, quality, alignment) by segment and track month-over-month trends; monitor quadrant shifts (e.g., percentage of clients moving from Goal 2 ? 3) and validate business outcomes.2. Feedback & Model Retraining: CSM Input: after responding to an alert, CSMs record the outcome (“Alert reviewed, playbook refined, next review in 30 days”). This feedback refines alert precision and reduces noise. Data Science Team: quarterly retraining of ML models used for anomaly detection or appetite/maturity indexing; incorporate labelled outcomes to minimize false positives/negatives.3. Threshold & Weight Adjustments: If Segment D accounts experience > 15% false alerts in a month, adjust rule-based thresholds or reweight sub-scores accordingly. If Segment A accounts repeatedly trigger “pseudo-misalignment” alerts (e.g., minor scope differences), revisit the alignment scoring formula to reduce noise.
AppendixHow does it connect to Client Business Goal levels?Goal LevelHealth Focus & Expected ActionOutcome1. Goal (Segment D)– CX: Simple post-support CSAT.Adoption: Typically < 50.Engagement: Quarterly check-ins; ≥ 60% cadence.Quality: SLA ≥ 90%.Alignment: Basic support; ≥ 50% alignment.– Alert Action: TAM receives a low-risk alert to review light-touch playbooks (“Quality < 80%” ? “revise incident escalation playbook”).– Result: Stable, predictable operations.2. Goal (Segment C)– CX: Combined CSAT + sentiment; moderate thresholds.Adoption: 50–70.Engagement: Monthly check-ins; ≥ 70% cadence.Quality: ≥ 85% on time.Alignment: ≥ 60% roadmap fit.– Alert Action: Rule/ML alert; TAM/SDM reviews (“Engagement < 70%” ? “refine QBR playbook”).– Result: Proactive correction, reduced churn risk.3. Goal (Segment B)– CX: High bar (≥ 70); ML anomaly detection.Adoption: 70–90.Engagement: Biweekly/monthly strategic sessions; ≥ 80% cadence.Quality: ≥ 90% on time, low recurrence.Alignment: ≥ 70%, quarterly strategic alignment.– Alert Action: ML-driven alert; Senior CSM + vCIO conduct a playbook-tuning session (e.g., “Alignment < 70%” ? “update strategic alignment playbook”).– Result: Proactive risk mitigation, deeper strategic engagement.4–5. Goal (Segment A)– CX: Near-perfect; adaptive ML thresholds.Adoption: ≥ 90%; continuous improvement.Engagement: Weekly/biweekly OKR-aligned sessions; ≥ 90% attendance.Quality: ≥ 95% on time; audit score ≈ 5/5.Alignment: ≥ 90%, continuous fine-tuning.– Alert Action: Top-priority alert to Strategic Advisor + vCxO (e.g., “CX dips < 90%” ? “review executive engagement framework”).– Result: Fully proactive, strategic partner collaboration.How does it connect to the other disciplines?? CS Strategy: Health alerts trigger dynamic re-segmentation. A client whose Maturity/Appetite indices reach Goal 3 moves to a higher segment, updating the Engagement Strategy and role assignments.? CS Deliverables: Health alerts can create “deliverable tasks” (e.g., “prepare updated roadmap,” “share adoption gap analysis”) instead of automatically scheduling a meeting.? CS People: Each alert includes recommended owner roles (TAM, Senior CSM, vCIO, vCxO), ensuring experienced stakeholders handle strategic-level issues.? CS Process: Health alerts serve as triggers for process workflows—e.g., “low adoption” alert activates an “Adoption Playbook Review” task.? CS Technology: The Health engine sits at the core of the tech stack—API integrations feed ML models and dashboards, driving all five CS methodologies with timely and reliable data.Product Links / Tooling Support
?? 6.3 Deliverables
6.3 DeliverablesOverviewWhat is the objective?Why is it important?Why do I need to do this as an MSP?What is the Customer impact?Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: Deliverables Are Execution, Not StrategyConcept #2: Deliverables Are Shareable, Visible ValueConcept #3: Deliverables Are Triggered, Not Ad HocConcept #4: Built with Automation, Templates, and AIConcept #5: Deliverables Reflect and Inform CS HealthImplementation ProcessStep 1: Determine the Type and Frequency of DeliverablesStep 2: Aggregate Data from Structured SourcesStep 3: Select Template and Configure ComponentsStep 4: Use AI to Generate Narrative and VisualsStep 5: Present or Deliver and Log the InteractionStep 6: Trigger Downstream Events Based on DeliveryAppendixHow does it connect to Client Business Goal levels?How does it connect to other parts?
OverviewWhat is the objective?The Customer Success Deliverables methodology defines a product-agnostic, API-first architecture for generating and distributing CS outputs at scale. In a modern MSP, manually crafted reports are no longer sustainable: instead, diverse data sources—such as PSA, CRM, MRR feeds, RMM, and other IT-management tools—stream information on Strategy, Health, People, and Process into a centralized data layer. Once consolidated, automation and AI engines generate five core outputs in real time:? Reports: concise, visually structured summaries of client performance, risk, and outcomes? Proposals: actionable, client-specific recommendations for remediation, improvement, or new initiatives? Budgets: forward-looking forecasts, renewals, and cost analyses that enable financial planning? Strategy documents: structured, client-driven plans that link assessment insights and business goals to CS execution? Roadmaps: time-based, milestone-driven visualizations that track initiatives, dependencies, and execution progressEvery output is built and managed as part of a Closed Loop Theory approach—ensuring that every discovery insight and assessment intake is turned into a structured, client-driven strategy that closes the gap between listening and execution, and makes ongoing execution traceable through the roadmap and regular reviews. This accelerates follow-through, increases client buy-in, and delivers measurable business value with minimal delay.Those outputs become execution artifacts for downstream Strategy, Health, People, and Process modules. For example, a drop in Health Score triggers a risk report and updated proposal; a new assessment insight feeds directly into a revised roadmap or budget. Because the system is fully modular, any new data source, automation rule, or template can be easily integrated, so all Customer Success workflows always operate on the latest, actionable deliverables—closing the loop from input to outcome.Why is it important?A unified, product-agnostic Deliverables architecture ensures that all Customer Success outputs—reports, proposals, budgets, strategy documents, and roadmaps—are generated from the same real-time data foundation and are systematically linked to client business goals and actions. By consolidating all inputs into a single data layer and powering an automated output engine, the approach eliminates silos, manual effort, and inconsistent follow-through.With a modular, closed-loop process, every discovery, assessment, or client request immediately triggers the right deliverable—ensuring that insights turn into visible, trackable action. Each output is not only scheduled and permissioned, but also reviewed for engagement, feedback, and measurable results. This means:? No client concern or opportunity is lost between intake and execution.? Stakeholders always receive relevant, timely, and actionable deliverables tailored to their role and business context.? Roadmaps and strategy documents make it possible to track every initiative and deliverable from insight through to execution, review, and completion.In practice, this level of automation and process integration enables MSPs to:? Deliver polished, decision-ready artifacts the moment a client’s situation changes—whether it’s a health warning, a new risk, or an emerging business priority.? Track every output for acceptance, review, and action—closing the loop on client feedback and demonstrating the value of CS activities at every stage.? Enable more productive business conversations, faster approvals, and greater trust through total transparency.Why do I need to do this as an MSP?Without a standardized, closed-loop Deliverables system, MSPs risk missed follow-up, slow execution, and inconsistent client experience. Ad hoc proposals and hand-crafted reports cannot scale with a growing client base or shifting business needs.By adopting this methodology, you can:? Instantly convert discovery and assessment notes into actionable proposals, strategies, and roadmaps.? Ensure that every output—report, proposal, budget, or strategy—closes the loop on a client insight or request, with automated reminders for review and follow-up.? Tie every deliverable to a business goal, segment, or maturity level—ensuring relevance, buy-in, and measurable value.? Reduce cycle times: from insight to delivered proposal or strategic update in days, not months.Automated permission controls and governance features guarantee that the right people receive, review, and act on each deliverable, while outcome tracking (open rates, approvals, feedback) ensures every artifact drives real change—not just documentation.What is the Customer impact?Clients receive consistent, relevant, and actionable deliverables exactly when and how they need them—closing the loop between what is discussed and what gets done.? High-maturity clients receive executive-ready roadmaps, strategies, proposals, and budgets, all mapped to business objectives and KPIs.? Lower-touch accounts get concise, operational summaries with clear next steps—never generic, always client-specific.? Every deliverable is reviewed, commented on, or approved—and clients can see that their feedback or decisions directly result in visible action and updated plans.This process:? Builds tangible trust: clients see not only your insights, but also your execution.? Accelerates decision-making and momentum, with less delay and rework.? Makes every engagement transparent, auditable, and value-driven—anchoring the MSP as a partner who truly delivers on promises, from discovery to results.
Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: Deliverables Are Execution, Not StrategyDeliverables don’t define what strategy is—that’s the job of Segmentation, Engagement Strategy, and Playbook execution. Deliverables determine when and how actions are triggered and executed. They transform strategic intent into visible execution. They respond to inputs rather than define them. They act as structured outputs when the CS Process signals it’s time to act. For example:? Drop in Health Score ? triggers governance summary report? Updated roadmap ? triggers a proposal or budget generation? Contract renewal ? triggers a renewed budget forecastEvery deliverable—report, proposal, budget, strategy, or roadmap—is always produced using structured, API-accessible data from the MSP’s PSA, CRM, RMM, and assessment tools, and enriched with automation and AI for scalability, traceability, and relevance.All deliverables are generated and tracked as part of a Closed Loop Theory approach—every output is linked to a specific insight, intake, or decision, and its execution, review, and follow-up is logged for continuous improvement.Expanded with a Practical Example: After an assessment flags a backup gap, your CS platform’s automation layer creates a risk report block, drafts a proposal for remediation, and updates the roadmap—using data directly from your RMM and PSA via API. The report is presented live at the QBR, and client approval automatically triggers the start of the backup project workflow.Impact:? Every discovery or assessment is actioned quickly, not lost in notes? Clients see rapid movement from insight to execution? Automation, AI-based relevance and follow-up is needed—everything is structured, visible, and traceableConcept #2: Deliverables Are Shareable, Visible ValueA deliverable, such as a roadmap, proposal, or budget, is a tangible artifact that can be opened, shared, discussed, or approved. It is a portable, decision-ready snapshot that reinforces the MSP’s role.Every deliverable should be presented live whenever possible (not just emailed), turning it into an interactive client engagement.Deliverables reinforce trust, increase buy-in, and become shared memory across stakeholders. They should be:? Easy to understand and relevant to the client’s current Business Goal level? Visually apparent and structured with traceable business logic? Directly linked to roadmap status, budget impact, or service risksEach output is logged, versioned, and its client engagement (opened, reviewed, approved) is automatically tracked as part of the closed loop.Expanded with a Practical Example: For a quarterly roadmap review, the reporting tool assembles a visually engaging, segment-tailored PDF or presentation—including budget, upcoming initiatives, and previous proposal status. The meeting is held live, every attendee can view, comment, and digitally sign off on next steps. The system logs who opened and approved the document, triggering any required follow-up.Impact:? Clients feel ownership of the plan and see visible progress? The MSP can demonstrate value at every meeting with shareable, trackable artifacts? Audit trail supports governance, compliance, and renewal discussionsConcept #3: Deliverables Are Triggered, Not Ad HocDeliverables are part of an orchestrated Customer Success rhythm, not one-off reports generated reactively. They are generated in response to defined CS Process triggers:? Quarterly business review (QBR) meeting cycle? Introduction of a new stakeholder? Drop in CS Health ScoreThese triggers are defined as API event listeners or workflow automation, so that every deliverable is timely, consistent, and closed loop—nothing is left to chance or forgotten. Missed reviews or ignored deliverables escalate automatically for governance or follow-up.Expanded with a Practical Example: Whenever an assessment is marked “complete” in your CS system, the platform’s workflow engine auto-generates a consultant-style report, attaches the relevant proposal blocks, and notifies the assigned CSM to schedule a review call. If the deliverable isn’t opened within five business days, a reminder is sent, and a dashboard alert is created for management.Impact:? No key deliverable is ever forgotten or delayed? CS leaders see, in real time, where follow-through is missing? Proactive, not reactive, client managementConcept #4: Deliverables Are Modular, Block-Based ReportsIn Practice for an MSP:? Stop thinking in terms of one-off, handcrafted documents. Instead, build every deliverable—report, proposal, budget, strategy, or roadmap—as a set of “blocks,” each powered by a specific data source (e.g., Health, Budget, Initiative, Third-Party Risk).? How to use it:? Use a report composer to select and arrange blocks for the deliverable: e.g., Quarterly Roadmap, Proposal Pipeline, Budget Forecast, Health Score Trend, Assessment Summary.? Integrate both native and third-party blocks via API (e.g., security summaries, compliance scores, insurance risk, productivity analytics).? Save configurations as templates by segment, goal, or scenario (“Segment B – Modernization Proposal” or “Quarterly Strategy Update”). If a stakeholder changes, you can simply swap or add blocks without redesigning the entire deliverable.? All deliverables are versioned and template logic is stored as code (YAML/JSON) for audit and continuous improvement.? Why it matters:? If stakeholders change (new CFO, compliance officer), you can simply swap blocks without redesigning the whole report.? You can respond quickly to new reporting requirements—add a new TAP block when a partner integration becomes available, or customize for a specific client’s hot topic.? Pro Tip: Ask your client which blocks they find most valuable, and use those preferences to fine-tune future reporting for higher engagement.Concept #5: Deliverables Are Automated for Both Delivery and PresentationIn Practice for an MSP:? Don’t rely on manual report assembly and email chains! Use the Deliverables module to automate both the timing and delivery format of every report.? How to use it:? Set up automated schedules (e.g., “Send a QBR summary every quarter”; “Trigger a Risk Assessment report after any major project closure”).? Decide whether to deliver by email, secure client portal, or live via Presentation Mode.? Live Presentation Mode: Use this for executive briefings or QBRs—full-screen, interactive, and synced in real time with the client’s actual LMX data.? Hide internal-only blocks (like notes or draft initiatives) from the client, showing only approved, client-ready content.Automation ensures every client receives deliverables on time, with real-time tracking of opens, approvals, and feedback. Missed or unreviewed deliverables are auto-flagged for CS or governance intervention.? Why it matters:? Automation guarantees that no client is missed and every report goes out on time, every time.? Live presentations enable more interactive, engaging discussions and make it easy to drill into relevant details without exposing sensitive information.? Pro Tip: Use open rates and client feedback to refine scheduling—if a report is rarely opened, try a different cadence or presentation format.Concept #6: Permissions, Branding, and Governance Are Built-InIn Practice for an MSP:? Control exactly what each person can see, edit, or present in every deliverable—right down to the block level.? How to use it:? Set block-level permissions (e.g., “Internal Only” for risk notes, “Client Visible” for summary stats).? Define who (vCIO, TAM, CSM) can create, edit, or approve each report template or block.? Apply your client’s branding to every export (logo, corporate colors, custom fonts).? Archive every report sent or presented, keeping a date/versioned history for compliance or audit purposes.? Why it matters:? Prevents accidental disclosure of internal or sensitive information.? Ensures every deliverable looks professional and consistent with your client’s own standards.? Makes it easy to prove what was delivered and when, supporting governance and QBR review.? Pro Tip: Use governance dashboards to track report engagement, monitor who opened each file, and follow up with feedback requests after important presentations.Concept #7: Third-Party (TAP) Integration Expands Deliverables’ ValueIn Practice for an MSP:? Go beyond just your own LMX data—make reports more valuable by incorporating best-in-class metrics from external partners.? How to use it:? Connect TAP integrations (MDR/EDR providers, insurance risk platforms, compliance or productivity analytics) via the ScalePad Hub.? New blocks from each integration automatically appear in the Report Composer; simply drag them into your next report.? Combine, for example, a native “Roadmap” block with a “Security Risk Score” from an MDR provider and a “Microsoft 365 Usage Trends” block from a productivity analytics partner.? AI-driven normalization ensures that third-party blocks look and feel consistent with your native reporting style.? Why it matters:? Offers clients a single, unified report that covers all critical business, technical, and risk data—without needing multiple tools or sources.? Helps differentiate your MSP’s QBRs and executive briefings by offering deep insights, not just basic status updates.? Pro Tip: Ask TAP partners for recommended best-practice blocks and pre-configured visuals—this can make your reporting both richer and easier to produce.Concept #8: Closed Loop Theory – Every Deliverable Drives and Tracks ActionThe foundation of the Deliverables methodology is Closed Loop Theory:? Every deliverable (report, proposal, budget, strategy, roadmap) is tied to a discovery insight, assessment intake, or client request? Each output is tracked for delivery, review, approval, and outcome? Actions (accept, reject, comment) trigger the next CS workflow; no feedback = auto-reminder/escalation? All results are logged for continuous improvementExpanded with a Practical Example: After an executive report is presented, approval triggers roadmap updates and project kickoff; rejection triggers review and proposal revision. All steps, feedback, and next actions are auto-logged and visible to the CS and leadership team.Impact:? No insight, risk, or opportunity is ever lost? CS performance is measured not just by delivery, but by follow-through and outcome? Clients see a living process, not static documents—commitment and trust are built into the rhythm of engagement
Implementation ProcessStep 1: Determine the Type and Frequency of Deliverables? This configuration step must be defined in advance by the MSP as part of their CS Strategy (segmentation, engagement rhythm, and role planning)? It is not the job of the deliverables system to decide what to send—it only executes what was designed? Determine:? report cadence (e.g., monthly, quarterly);? deliverable formats (e.g., tactical summary vs. strategic roadmap); ? stakeholder roles (who receives and presents what)Step 2: Aggregate Data from Structured Sources? Deliverables must be based on reliable, structured data sources, such as PSA (support activity, SLAs), MRR and billing tools (contract value, renewal periods), CRM (stakeholder mapping, engagement logs), RMM (device health, usage stats), assessments and roadmap history.? The data should be consolidated into a unified system or data layer to ensure accuracy and accessibility.Step 3: Select Template and Configure Components? Choose a deliverable template based on the client’s segmentation or Business Goal level and the type of CS interaction (e.g., QBR, renewal, initiative review)? Configure sections such as strategic goals and risks, initiative updates and KPIs, budget forecasts and financial metrics, CS Health summaries (Engagement, Adoption, Alignment)Step 4: Use AI to Generate Narrative and Visuals? AI adds interpretability and personalization to structured data: ? narrative (e.g., “Last quarter, three initiatives closed, risk reduced by 40%.”);? visuals (auto-generated roadmaps, budget charts, risk trends);? personalization (adjust tone and content for executives, technical users, or project sponsors)Step 5: Present or Deliver and Log the Interaction? Deliverables should be presented live during strategic or QBR sessions where possible; delivered via email or client portal with confirmation tracking; logged with metadata such as delivery date, recipient, view status, and next steps.? If a deliverable is ignored or unacknowledged, trigger alerts or follow-up workflowsStep 6: Trigger Downstream Events Based on Delivery? Deliverables should initiate action: proposals are approved or modified, roadmaps are updated, CS cadence is recalibrated, and governance escalations are launched when deliverables aren’t reviewed or presented.? These workflows must be governed by predefined automation rules that ensure follow-through.
AppendixHow does Deliverables connect to Client Business Goal levels?Client Business Goal LevelDeliverables FocusDownstream Impact1. Technology SupportDeliverables provide operational visibility and service assurance: basic ticket summaries, backup/asset status, and compliance logs.Reporting is auto-generated, lightweight, and standardized for “keep-the-lights-on” stability. Minimal meetings or presentations. Deliverables reinforce trust and SLA coverage for low-maturity, low-appetite clients.2. Technology EnablementDeliverables expand to cover project tracking, stack alignment, and milestone progress, often through quarterly QBRs and simple roadmaps.Reports start to visualize technology adoption, standardization efforts, and key initiative status. Engagement with deliverables increases, helping clients recognize progress in enablement and supporting their move to higher maturity.3. Technology ModernizationDeliverables become central to the client relationship: detailed modernization roadmaps, lifecycle assessments, and budget projections.Formal QBRs and documentation drive collaboration. Deliverables support prioritization of modernization initiatives, ensure accountability, and give clients visibility into the full range of services and improvement opportunities.4. Business TransformationDeliverables shift to executive-level, outcome-driven assets: cross-departmental roadmaps, KPI dashboards, and business impact reports.Reports are designed for multi-stakeholder use, driving strategic decisions, productivity improvements, and process optimization. Presentation mode and interactive reviews become standard.5. Business InnovationDeliverables are co-developed: innovation roadmaps, OKR-tracking reports, advanced analytics, and multi-year investment decks.Reports facilitate innovation steering, align technology investments to business outcomes, and provide visibility for executive and departmental leadership. Deliverables help the MSP act as a co-innovation partner, not just a provider.How does Deliverables connect to other CS disciplines?? Client Business Goal: Deliverables are directly tailored to the client’s business goal level and segment. Every report, roadmap, or proposal is mapped to the client’s current maturity and appetite, ensuring relevance and value at every stage.? CS Strategy: Deliverables are built from playbook-driven templates, aligned to the engagement cadence and strategic priorities set in the CS Strategy blueprint. Reporting workflows and standards become more sophisticated as clients advance in maturity and segment.? CS Health: Engagement with deliverables (opens, reviews, follow-up actions) is a live indicator of client health and engagement. Deliverables visualize Health metrics (Adoption, Alignment, Service Quality, etc.), and any lack of interaction with deliverables can trigger CS Health interventions or governance workflows.? CS Deliverables: The Deliverables module operationalizes all output artifacts—reports, budgets, roadmaps, and proposals—making them visible, actionable, and tied to playbooks and strategic outcomes. Deliverables are versioned, permissioned, and audit-trailed for full transparency.? CS Process: Deliverables are generated at key workflow milestones—after Discovery, Assessment, or Meeting steps—ensuring that every process rhythm is documented and every stakeholder receives the right artifact at the right time. Automated delivery and Presentation Mode integrate reporting into the process flow.? CS People: Clear ownership of deliverable creation and presentation is mapped by role (e.g., vCIO for strategy, TAM for technical health, CSM for initiative follow-up). Playbooks and templates enable every CS team member to confidently deliver outputs suited to the client’s segment and goal.
?? 6.4 People
6.4 PeopleOverviewWhat is the objective?Why is it important?As an MSP, why do I need to do this?What is the Customer impact?Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: The Application Process Is an Execution Engine, Not a StrategyConcept #2: Process Triggers Drive Role Activation, Not SegmentationConcept #3: API Data + AI Interpretation Powers the People LayerConcept #4: Role, Enablement, and Compensation Actions Are Triggered—not Assigned ManuallyConcept #5: Governance and Health Create the Feedback LoopImplementation ProcessStep 1: Map Available API Data PointsStep 2: Enable AI to Interpret Key Client ShiftsStep 3: Define Trigger Points for Role, Enablement, and Governance ActivationStep 4: Link Trigger Outcomes to the People LayerStep 5: Monitor System Effectiveness and Close the LoopAppendixHow does it connect to the Client Business Goal levels?How does it connect to the other parts?
OverviewWhat is the objective?The CS Technology People methodology defines a product-agnostic, API-first architecture for the Customer Success ecosystem. In this model, an average mid-tier MSP with 15–25 employees cannot rely on offline spreadsheets or manual coordination to stay up-to-date. Instead, diverse data sources—such as PSA, CRM, MRR feeds, RMM, and other IT-management tools—stream raw Strategy, Health, Deliverables, and Process information into a centralized data lake or warehouse. Once data is consolidated, AI-powered engines automatically generate core outputs in real time: role assignments, enablement triggers, compensation recommendations, and governance alerts. Those AI-generated outputs become the operational instructions for the downstream Strategy, Health, Deliverables, and Process modules.Why is it important?A unified, API-first People architecture ensures that the same real-time data foundation drives all Customer Success role activations, enablement steps, and compensation decisions. Poorly aligned roles and responsibilities can make CS delivery either too costly (over-assigned vCIOs) or under-scoped (no roadmap owner). By consolidating disparate signals into a single data lake and continuously feeding AI engines, the methodology prevents silos, eliminates manual handoffs, and accelerates operational responsiveness. In practice, this level of automation allows MSPs to assign the right CS resources the moment a client’s Health Score shifts, to launch targeted training the instant a new initiative is approved, and to trigger governance reviews before a renewal is at risk.As an MSP, why do I need to do this?Without a standardized People backbone, MSPs end up juggling spreadsheet-based role rosters, ad-hoc enablement checklists, and manual compensation calculations, making it nearly impossible to scale or maintain consistency. The CS Technology People methodology provides the reusable components needed to automate every aspect of CS operations, without rebuilding the wheel each time you hire a new CSM, onboard a vCIO, or adjust compensation targets. This means you can deploy a new enablement flow in days instead of weeks, reassign underutilized resources the moment a client’s engagement dips, and align compensation to outcomes automatically, all while keeping internal overhead to a minimum.What is the Customer impact?Clients experience a consistently intelligent, structured MSP presence that adapts to their evolving needs. Strategic clients automatically receive senior executive involvement as soon as their Health Score indicates higher maturity, while lower-touch accounts get precisely the right level of coverage without wasted effort. When a client’s roadmap stalls or their Health Score drops, an alert fires and the recommended CSM or vCIO is assigned within minutes, ensuring proactive follow-up rather than reactive scrambling. This leads to:? Consistent, context-rich engagements: Clients constantly interact with the correct CS role based on their current needs, not on outdated org charts.? Faster response to risk: Early signal detection (e.g., low engagement) triggers immediate role activation and enables, preventing churn.? Clear accountability and transparency: Every client sees that a dedicated customer success owner is responsible for their success, which boosts trust and alignment.
Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: The Application Process Is an Execution Engine, Not a StrategyThis blueprint doesn’t define your strategy—it operationalizes it. Strategic decisions, such as segmentation, role definitions, or engagement models, occur upstream. But strategy, left alone, doesn’t scale. The Application Process blueprint turns those choices into live, trigger-based execution systems. ? When segmentation places a client in Segment B, the Application Process decides when to assign a CSM and how to enable that role. ? When a roadmap is approved, it triggers governance logic and initiative tracking automatically, not manually. ? When CS Health drops due to Engagement or Adoption, escalation is triggered before a renewal is at risk. This concept repositions the People layer from static org design to real-time orchestration. It ensures that every motion in the CS Process (Assessment, Meeting, Proposal) activates the right people at the right time for the right reason. It’s not “who owns this?”—it’s “what conditions trigger this role to act?”Concept #2: Process Triggers Drive Role Activation, Not SegmentationSegmentation is essential—but insufficient. Knowing a client is in Segment A doesn’t mean they’re ready for full strategic engagement. Conversely, a Segment C client who just approved their first roadmap may now need a different role mix. That’s why role assignment must be process-driven, not assumption-based. ? After Discovery Intake reveals multi-departmental needs, vCIO activation is triggered—even for a Segment B client. ? When a Proposal is delivered but no Budget is aligned, CS Manager involvement is triggered to course-correct. ? When cadence is broken (e.g., QBR skipped), Governance may step in with escalation workflows. These transitions aren’t based on “feeling” readiness—they’re based on observed events in the CS Process discipline. This protects CS teams from over-delivery and ensures clients only receive roles and resources when activity justifies it. It creates a living segmentation overlay powered by behaviour and outcomes.Concept #3: API Data + AI Interpretation Powers the People LayerManual people management doesn’t scale—but data does. The future of CS People's execution is API-fed, AI-interpreted automation. First, you collect relevant signals: ? process milestones (QBRs held, reports delivered, roadmaps approved), ? health indicators (drops in Engagement, plateaued Technology Adoption), ? role activity (initiative follow-through logged, governance events triggered). Then, intelligent rules or AI logic interprets these inputs and recommends or even executes actions: ? “Assign CSM to Segment B client—Engagement dropped post-roadmap.” ? “Trigger Enablement flow for AM—first-time proposal delivery for Segment A.” ? “vCIO follow-up required—initiative marked stalled for >45 days.” This framework unlocks continuous alignment of people resources with client conditions. It reduces both CS overexertion and underperformance, keeping delivery lean, relevant, and automated where possible.Concept #4: Role, Enablement, and Compensation Actions Are Triggered—not Assigned ManuallyMost MSPs rely on managerial intuition to assign people, define training needs, or review bonuses. That works—until the team scales or client complexity increases. The Application Process replaces ad-hoc decision-making with triggered people ops. ? Assigning a TAM happens when Assessment Intake identifies risk in the core stack.? Enablement is deployed when a CSM is involved in their first budget conversation.? Compensation bonuses are unlocked when CS Health scores improve consistently across an account over three months. These trigger events are derived from Product (Delivery + Process) activity, not from human memory. This ensures:? Fair and timely compensation that aligns with verified client outcomes? Enablement that is targeted, contextual, and responsive to maturity growth? Role clarity that evolves with client needs, not just annual reviews In short, every part of the People blueprint—roles, responsibilities, enablement, compensation—is made dynamic. Instead of a playbook in a drawer, it becomes a responsive system triggered by measurable events.Concept #5: Governance and Health Create the Feedback LoopThe Application Process doesn’t just launch actions—it learns from them. For this to happen, you need a feedback loop powered by governance oversight and CS Health metrics. Every triggered action should generate measurable outcomes. ? Assigning a vCIO should lead to improved strategic alignment and roadmap execution.? Launching enablement should show better follow-up after meetings or proposal success.? Triggered governance should resolve process gaps before renewal risk escalates. Governance validates: Did the triggered action happen? Was it documented? Did it help? Meanwhile, CS Health metrics indicate whether the intervention was effective—providing the quantitative signal. Together, these feedback loops enable the MSP to continuously refine the Application logic by tightening triggers where actions were too late, softening them where actions were unnecessary, and calibrating resource allocation to reflect the actual CS effort. This is how the Application Process becomes self-improving—a governance-aware, data-responsive engine for delivering the proper CS engagement, role, and impact at scale.
Implementation ProcessStep 1: Map Available API Data PointsIdentify key structured data sources across platforms:?  From PSA: MRR, service types, client creation date, assigned resources? From RMM: hardware/software aging, lifecycle coverage, agent health? From CS tools: last meeting date, proposal volume, Health Score changes? From CRM: opportunity status, decision-maker rolesThis step builds the foundation for all downstream People automationStep 2: Enable AI to Interpret Key Client ShiftsUsing the API data, define interpretation rules such as:?  3 lifecycle touchpoints in 6 months ? likely maturity growth? Initiatives approved + roadmap meeting complete ? shift to Business Goal Level 4+? High ticket volume with no strategy meetings ? potential misalignmentThese interpretation models allow the system to make role and enablement decisions based on patterns, not just status.Step 3: Define Trigger Points for Role, Enablement, and Governance ActivationKey trigger events may include:? New client creation? First Discovery meeting completed? Assessment scored above a threshold? Proposal accepted / initiative approved? CS Health drops by 2+ points? QBR cadence overdueEach trigger should initiate a rule-based action, such as assigning a vCIO, launching a training flow, or initiating a governance check-in.Step 4: Link Trigger Outcomes to the People LayerEach trigger outcome maps directly to People’s actions:? Role activation: assigning TAM, AM, CSM, vCIO roles by segment? Enablement launch: sending relevant milestone training, talk tracks, or context materials? Compensation adjustment: updating targets for bonus calculation (e.g., new roadmap initiative)? Governance scheduling: logging a quarterly review or scorecard auditThese are automated, but reviewable, allowing humans to override or validate if needed.Step 5: Monitor System Effectiveness and Close the LoopUse internal reports to check:? Role coverage gaps (e.g., clients with no CS contact in 90 days)? Enablement adoption (e.g., training completed post-trigger)? Compensation fairness (e.g., reward vs. responsibility match)? Governance completion (e.g., QBRs logged, Health reviewed)Over time, refine the rules and triggers to better align with client outcomes and MSP capacity.
AppendixHow does it connect to the Client Business Goal levels?LevelApplication Focus1.1 Technology SupportNo People automation. Single-role coverage.1.2 Technology EnablementAPI triggers are used to detect TAM needs, with minimal automation.1.3 Technology ModernizationInitiatives trigger AM/vCIO assignment; roadmap pacing begins.1.4 Business TransformationAI interprets strategy depth, enabling full role orchestration and rollout.1.5 Business InnovationComplete loop between role, enablement, compensation, and governance; system adjusts in real time.How does it connect to the other parts?? Client Business Goal: Determines the segment context for automation logic.? Customer Success Health: Inputs into trigger decisions and validates role effectiveness post-activation.? Customer Success Deliverables: Ensures deliverables (roadmaps, budgets) are linked to the right roles at the right time.? Customer Success Process: Connects directly to milestone triggers (e.g., Discovery ? Proposal ? Strategy Meeting).? Customer Success People (6.1–6.5): This blueprint activates the other five by utilizing data to assign roles, responsibilities, enablement flows, compensation adjustments, and governance actions.
