6.5 ProcessOverviewWhat is the objective?Why is it important?As an MSP, why do I need this?What is the Customer impact?Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: The CS Process is an Execution EngineConcept #2: Every Event Becomes a Feedback PointConcept #3: Process Control Requires Structured DataConcept #4: AI Enhances Preparation and InsightConcept #5: Versioned, Reusable, Auditable Workflow CodeImplementation ProcessStep 1: Define Trigger Points and Timing LogicStep 2: Aggregate Structured Data InputsStep 3: Configure Event Triggers and Response PathsStep 4: Automate Execution with Templates and AIStep 5: Execute, Track, and RefineAppendixHow does it connect to the Client Business Goal levels?How does it connect to the other parts?
OverviewWhat is the objective?The CS Technology Process methodology defines a product?agnostic, API?first architecture for the Customer Success ecosystem. In this model, an average mid?tier MSP with 15–25 employees managing more than 100 clients cannot rely on offline spreadsheets or manual coordination to stay up-to-date. Instead, diverse data sources—such as PSA, CRM, MRR feeds, RMM, and other IT-management tools—stream raw information about Strategy, Health, Deliverables, and People into a centralized data lake or warehouse. Once data is consolidated, AI-powered engines automatically generate orchestration instructions in real time, turning every CS process into a reusable, versioned workflow. Those AI-generated outputs become the operational instructions for the downstream Strategy, Health, Deliverables, and People modules.Why is it important?CS process rhythm is the backbone of an MSP’s operational model. Without it, there's no consistent client experience, no scalability, and no quality control. A well-functioning CS Process system forms a closed loop: every trigger, whether calendar-based or anomaly-based, automatically results in a scheduled meeting, task assignment, or intervention.With the right combination of data, rules, and automation, the entire process chain (Discovery Intake, Assessment Intake, Meeting, Initiative, Governance) becomes executable, whether initiated by cadence or KPI-based logic.As an MSP, why do I need this?Closed-loop execution ensures that every signal leads to action, such as a meeting, initiative, or review. Versioned, code-defined workflows enable auditable, scalable execution. Automation and AI can prepare execution steps, such as personalized Discovery and Assessment forms, and extract and prepare Initiatives from meeting notes. Without a standardized Process backbone, MSPs end up with ad?hoc task lists, missed triggers, and inconsistent follow?ups, making it impossible to execute CS strategies as they evolve reliably.What is the Customer impact?Clients experience a consistent, visible, and responsive engagement:? Reliable follow?through: No signals are lost—every alert or milestone generates the appropriate process step.? Timely execution: Documentation and follow?ups are generated and delivered just-in-time, based on data-driven triggers.? Data-driven recommendations: AI-prepared materials (Discovery forms, agendas, initiative drafts) ensure each interaction is highly relevant and decision-ready.
Important Concepts ExplainedConcept #1: The CS Process is an Execution EngineDefinition: The CS Process blueprint does not define what actions should be taken—that’s determined upstream by segmentation models, CS playbooks, and strategic role design. Instead, it exists to explain when and how those decisions should be executed. It is the operating system that brings strategic intent to life.How it works:? When a QBR approaches, a Discovery Intake form and Meeting agenda are generated without manual action.? When a new stakeholder is added to the CRM, a Discovery Intake trigger is launched, ensuring they are included in context-rich interactions.? When roadmap milestones are reached, follow?up assessments or initiative updates are prepared and presented.Why it matters: Decisions without execution lead to stagnation. Once a CS decision is made—whether related to cadence, governance, or segmentation—the downstream workflows are enacted automatically, reducing reliance on memory or manual effort. Execution becomes predictable, scalable, and reliable.Concept #2: Every Event Becomes a Feedback PointDefinition: In an orchestrated CS Process, nothing is “just data.” Every event—calendar-based, metric-based, or manually entered—has the potential to initiate action. This transforms the Customer Success system into a continuous feedback loop.How it works:? A scheduled cadence (e.g., quarterly rhythm) triggers the generation of QBR meetings and pre-meeting tasks.? A drop in usage metrics automatically triggers a reassessment of engagement risk and the generation of a tailored assessment.? The onboarding of a new contact triggers an opportunity for updated Discovery, role-specific assessment, or context briefing.Why it matters: Without this kind of automation, signals are often missed or delayed, especially in lower-touch segments. Making every event actionable ensures no opportunity for value creation is lost. It’s especially crucial for early-stage, low-maturity, or less-engaged clients, where proactive outreach can significantly alter the growth trajectory.Concept #3: Process Control Requires Structured DataDefinition: No orchestration system can function effectively without a foundation of high-quality, structured data. The quality of your automation depends on the quality, consistency, and accessibility of your inputs.How it works:? Key inputs come from structured platforms, such as the MSP’s CRM (contacts, engagement logs), PSA (support tickets, SLAs, project status), RMM (device usage, uptime, patch compliance), and other IT management systems.? Financial data, such as MRR trends or budget history, provides the business context for cadence and initiative planning.? These data streams are merged into a unified layer, often via an integration platform or data warehouse.Why it matters: A process engine without structured data is like a car without fuel. Inaccurate, fragmented, or delayed data leads to broken workflows, misfires, and poor client experiences. Centralized, consistent data enables precise orchestration and agile response.Concept #4: AI Enhances Preparation and InsightDefinition: Artificial Intelligence in CS Process automation doesn’t replace humans—it enhances execution by preparing the right materials, identifying gaps, and making recommendations based on data patterns.How it works:? AI builds personalized Discovery and Assessment forms using client metadata (e.g., segment, industry, maturity level).? It transcribes and analyzes meeting notes to extract suggested initiatives and playbook actions.? It detects gaps (e.g., initiative delays or governance cadence drift) and suggests corrections (e.g., “add roadmap review to next meeting”).Why it matters: By automating the preparation phase, AI eliminates one of the biggest bottlenecks in CS execution. This allows CS team members to focus on interpretation, decision?making, and relationship management, not on formatting slide decks or recalling cadence dates. It ensures every process step is informed by the latest data and optimized for client relevance.Concept #5: Versioned, Reusable, Auditable Workflow CodeDefinition: The CS Process is more than a list of tasks—it is a codified, modular system that can be versioned, reused, and improved over time. Each process is treated as code.How it works:? Workflow logic (triggers, conditions, outputs) is stored as modular building blocks.? Each version of a workflow can be audited, rolled back, or adapted to a different client segment.? All actions are logged and traceable, providing a complete audit trail from trigger to execution.Why it matters: This approach supports standardization, quality assurance, and regulatory compliance. More importantly, it enables the CS organization to evolve its process logic over time without losing fidelity. As service offerings change or segments evolve, workflows can be rapidly updated and version-controlled without requiring the rebuilding of the entire system.
Implementation ProcessStep 1: Define Trigger Points and Timing Logic? Not defined by the Process system, but required as configuration by the MSP (based on segmentation, CS strategy, playbooks).? Examples:? Segment B ? Quarterly QBRs? Segment A ? Weekly check-ins or KPI-based alertsStep 2: Aggregate Structured Data Inputs? Unified data collection from:? CRM (contacts, engagement)? PSA (tickets, projects, SLAs)? RMM (assets, usage)? Financial systems (MRR, budget history)? Optionally enhanced by roadmap, health, and assessment toolsStep 3: Configure Event Triggers and Response Paths? Define what triggers which process:? New stakeholder ? triggers Discovery Intake? Usage drop ? triggers Assessment? Roadmap milestone ? triggers governance meetingStep 4: Automate Execution with Templates and AI? Auto-generate:? Discovery or Assessment forms (based on client profile)? Meeting agendas, next steps, summary decks? Draft initiatives from meeting transcriptsStep 5: Execute, Track, and Refine? Present deliverables live or post to the portal? Log views, openings, and interactions? AI reviews missed steps and proposes cadence changes or process improvements.
AppendixHow does it connect to the Client Business Goal levels?? Goal 1–2: Fixed cadences, basic automation. Monthly reviews, standard discovery surveys.? Goal 3: Hybrid approach. Scheduled meetings enhanced with signal-based deep dives (e.g., triggered by usage or ticket volume).? Goals 4–5: Full orchestration. Meetings and assessments are initiated dynamically, with real-time signal detection and self-adjusting playbooks.How does it connect to the other parts?? Customer Success Strategy: Implements the logic and rhythm defined by segmentation and playbooks to drive effective outcomes.? Customer Success Delivery: Automates the preparation and execution of reports, proposals, budgets, and initiatives to streamline processes and enhance efficiency.? Customer Success Health: Collects and responds to Health Score triggers, triggering governance when engagement or alignment declines.? Customer Success People: Assigns correct roles to each meeting or initiative based on scope and importance.? Customer Success Technology – Deliverables: Ensures that deliverables, such as reports and roadmaps, are triggered, prepared, and delivered in the correct cadence.
Quickstarters
Chapter: How to Start — The CS Quickstarters“Blueprints are the system. Quickstarters are your ignition.”By now, you've seen the depth of the CS methodology—the frameworks, the quadrant models, the strategic loops. It's powerful, but it can also feel overwhelming. The question we kept hearing from the field was simple:“Where do I start?”That’s why we built the CS Quickstarters.Quickstarters are focused, role-based launch kits that quickly take you from zero to value. Each one is designed to help a specific person, like an Account Manager, vCIO, or CS leader, run their first high-impact CS motion in hours, not months.What Are CS Quickstarters?Each Quickstarter is a guided mini-sprint, purpose-built to help you:? Apply the CS methodology to a real-world situation? Learn just enough theory to act with confidence? Use AI tools and templates to streamline the process? Drive a specific business outcome (not just “do more CS stuff”)They are the fastest path from intention to execution. Whether you're trying to understand a client’s goals, structure your CS team, or build your first strategy framework, there's a Quickstarter.What’s Inside a Quickstarter?Every CS Quickstarter has the same structure, so once you’ve used one, you’ll know how to approach the others:ComponentPurposeObjectiveThe clear business outcome you’ll drive—e.g., “Find one client’s business goals.”Five CoursesEach step teaches one concept or skill needed to hit the objective.Matching MethodologyThe simplified version of a blueprint that powers the execution.AI ToolGuides the user through each step, answers questions, and helps with deliverables.DeliverablesTangible outputs like segmentation docs, roadmaps, role maps, or SOPs.Each quickstarter typically takes:? ~1 hour of learning (digestible course content, self-paced or workshop-style)? ~2 hours of practice (client-facing time, team planning, or hands-on building)This isn’t just a workshop. This is execution. You’re doing real CS work with real clients—just structured in a way that builds your skill and confidence fast.Use Case: One Client, One OutcomeLet’s say you’re an Account Manager just starting to embrace CS. Your quickstarter might be:? Objective: Find and document one client’s business objectives.? Five steps: Learn segmentation, discovery questions, enrichment, how to run a discovery, and how to close the loop.? Deliverables: A real client roadmap, complete with initiatives and proposed budget.That’s not theory. That’s value delivery.Who Are Quickstarters For?Each Quickstarter is built for a specific role and CS maturity stage:? AMs, TAMs, and vCIOs ? Focused on one-client execution (Client Goals Quickstarter)? CS Leaders or Owners ? Focused on team, process, and structure (CS Strategy, Team Quickstarters)? Service or Sales Teams ? Supporting roles with clarity on impact and integration.And because an AI Copilot supports every step, users are never stuck—they always have next steps, coaching, and blueprint references one click away.Why They WorkCS Quickstarters solve the activation gap.Most CS initiatives stall because they require teams to learn everything before doing anything. Quickstarters flip that. They’re designed to get you doing real work within two hours, with just enough structure to build confidence and deliver value.This is how we scale success. One outcome. One client. One playbook at a time.
?? 1. Client Goals Quickstarter (All CS Roles)
Client Goals QuickstarterFor All CS Roles | Build Strategic Impact, One Client at a TimeWhat is it?The Client Goals Quickstarter is a focused, role-inclusive training program that helps Customer Success professionals identify and connect clients' business objectives to tailored, impactful initiatives. It’s built for MSPs ready to shift from reactive service to proactive strategy—starting with just one client.Why it matters:Too often, CS teams rely on outdated segmentation, tactical conversations, and unstructured follow-up. This course equips them to reframe their role: understanding what clients are ready for, what they care about, and how to translate insight into action. The result? Better prioritization, deeper engagement, and stronger outcomes.What You’ll LearnNew Ways of Segmentation Discover why revenue-based segmentation fails—and how Appetite vs. Maturity gives you a more transparent lens for client prioritization and strategic planning.What Your CEO Wants You to Know Learn how to research and enrich client profiles to be prepared for executive-level conversations—with insight that connects IT to growth, risk, or efficiency.How to Come Across as a Consultant Replace technical checklists with powerful business-aligned questions. Build trust, uncover goals, and position yourself as a strategic partner, not just a vendor.How to Unpack a Discovery Learn how to turn meeting notes into clear, client-aligned initiatives. Move from conversation to proposal, assessment, or annual planning with confidence.Perfect Closed Loop Follow-up Bridge the gap between strategy and execution. Translate Discovery outputs into scoped deliverables and follow-through plans that drive momentum, not just ideas.

Client Discovery - Ultimate Guide

Course Outline - CLient Goals
Client Goals Quickstarter - Course OutlineCourse #1: New Ways of SegmentationSubtitle: How to Identify What Each Client Can Do and Wants to DoOriginal ProblemMost MSPs segment clients using outdated or oversimplified criteria, such as revenue, the number of endpoints, or vertical. But this often leads to mismatched service levels, wasted effort, and missed opportunities. High-paying clients get strategic attention even when they resist change. Smaller clients are ignored—even when they’re eager and capable. As a result, CS teams struggle to prioritize their time, proposals misfire, and initiatives stall because the proper drivers of success—maturity and appetite—aren’t visible. Without a better segmentation model, Customer Success stays reactive and inconsistent.PurposeThis course introduces a powerful, practical segmentation method using Appetite for Change vs. Technology Maturity — helping CS professionals ditch MRR-based guesswork and start tailoring strategy based on behaviour, mindset, and capability.Learning ObjectivesBy the end of this course, participants will be able to:? Explain why traditional segmentation (MRR, #users, vertical) falls short.? Apply a 2x2 segmentation framework to categorize clients based on:? Appetite for Change (buy-in, urgency, momentum)? Maturity (tools, adoption, operational capability)? Assign clients to one of four Archetypes: Transform, Modernize, Educate, or Sustain? Use segmentation to tailor customer success (CS) engagement and project scope.Core Content Outline1. The Pitfall of MRR-Only Thinking • Why MRR ≠ Maturity • Why high-revenue clients often have low-impact potential (and vice versa)2. The 2x2 Client Segmentation Model • Vertical Axis: Technology Maturity • Horizontal Axis: Appetite for Change • Quadrants: ?• Transform (High/High) – Strategic champions; ready for big moves ?• Modernize (Low/High) – Ambitious, needs structure ?• Educate (High/Low) – Stable, needs inspiration and clarity ?• Sustain (Low/Low) – Minimal change, risk-managed touchpoints3. Common Pitfalls in Misalignment • Trying to “Transform” a Sustain client • Overinvesting in clients with low appetite • Using the same QBR template for everyone4. The CS Leverage Effect • How segmentation allows you to prioritize time, elevate the proper accounts, and activate the Growth LoopPractice ExerciseTitle: Archetype Mapping Sprint • Choose one active client • Plot them on the Appetite vs. Maturity matrix • Assign a primary Archetype • Write two engagement strategy statements per client: ?• “For [Client X], we will prioritize ___.” ?• “We will avoid ___ to reduce friction.”Strategic OutcomeParticipants walk away with a Segmentation Matrix and Archetype Playbook for one client of their choice, ready to guide roadmap, QBR cadence, and initiative framing.CS Toolkit:Toolkit #3 – Client Business Discovery – Use the starting page to plot the client within the Appetite vs. Maturity quadrant. This enables quick, visual segmentation and forms the foundation for downstream alignment in CS Health, Roadmap Planning, and Proposal Strategy.
Course #2: What Your CEO Wants You to KnowSubtitle: How to Prep for Strategic Conversations Like a Business Partner, Not a Tech VendorOriginal ProblemCustomer Success conversations often stop at infrastructure, licensing, or projects. However, executive stakeholders think of strategic outcomes, such as growth, efficiency, and risk. MSPs that can’t connect the dots between IT services and business priorities lose credibility, stall roadmap momentum, and stay stuck in tactical conversations. Without structured business enrichment, CS teams often appear unprepared, and clients tend to treat them like vendors rather than partners.PurposeThis course trains CS professionals to gain a deep understanding of their clients' business context, enabling richer discovery conversations and better alignment between IT initiatives and executive priorities.Learning ObjectivesBy the end of this course, participants will be able to: • Research and interpret key business indicators that influence client priorities • Enrich client profiles with strategic context (vertical, size, pressures, goals) • Identify high-leverage use cases for IT tied to revenue, risk, or efficiency • Develop a Discovery Brief that links client pain points to potential projectsCore Content Outline1. The “CEO Filter” • Why most QBRs fail to land: they’re too technical • How CEOs think: goals, risks, ROI, velocity • What they don’t want: specs, features, jargon2. Strategic Enrichment: Research Framework • Use structured enrichment tools to analyze both industry and client-specific context • For industry, extract key insights on: ?• IT-critical business processes ?• Common risk and compliance challenges ?• Industry-wide technology trends and disruptions • For a client, extract: ?• Core products, services, and target markets ?• Business model and revenue drivers ?• Recent updates (e.g., growth, hires, acquisitions) ?• Key stakeholders and decision-makers • Combine both sets of insight into a business-literate profile that informs Discovery3. Translate Business Context into Strategic Hypotheses • “If this client just acquired a new location, they likely care about…” • “If they’re in manufacturing and hiring, workforce productivity may be key…” • Link hypotheses to proposed IT initiatives or solution categories4. Craft the Discovery Brief • Write a one-page summary that includes: ?• Client snapshot ?• Key goals ?• Industry and business context ?• Strategic hypothesesPractice ExerciseTitle: Discovery Brief Sprint • Select one client from your CS portfolio • Use enrichment tools to research: ?• What they sell, who they sell to ?• Industry dynamics ?• Recent company updates or hires • Identify three likely business goals they have right now (use the Client Goal Pyramid: Support ? Enablement ? Modernization ? Transformation ? Innovation) • Write a Discovery Brief with: ?• Client snapshot ?• Key goals ?• Strategic hypothesesStrategic OutcomeParticipants complete the course with a finished Discovery Brief, which prepares them for roadmap planning, QBRs, or upcoming executive meetings, providing a clear understanding of the business context behind client needs.Toolkits or TemplatesThe CS Toolkit #3 – Client Business Discovery tool follows a structured enrichment-first approach: Step 1: Automated Enrichment 	• Client Summary – Captures company-specific context (e.g., size, location, revenue indicators, leadership, services, recent news, competitors, and technology stack). 	• Industry Summary – Captures sector-wide context (e.g., industry IT needs, cybersecurity trends, compliance risks, business models, and operational dependencies).Step 2: Strategic Hypothesis Generation • Links enrichment findings to probable client priorities • Suggests areas for follow-up or framing in future meetings • Prepares CS professionals to align recommendations with the executive mindset
Course #3: How to Come Across as a ConsultantSubtitle: Ask the Questions That Shift You From Vendor to Strategic PartnerOriginal ProblemEven well-prepared MSPs often ask the wrong questions—those that sound technical, transactional, or vendor-like. As a result, strategic opportunities are missed, and the client views the MSP as a service provider rather than a partner. Without a transparent questioning methodology aligned with business outcomes, CS professionals fail to establish executive trust or uncover the fundamental levers for growth, efficiency, or change.PurposeThis course trains CS professionals to lead with curiosity and business acumen, replacing technical checklists with strategic dialogue and informed decision-making. It focuses on how to ask powerful, business-aligned questions that elevate your role from vendor to advisor.Learning ObjectivesBy the end of this course, participants will be able to: • Distinguish between technical vs. strategic discovery questions • Lead client conversations that surface business goals, risks, and constraints • Use question frameworks that establish trust and elevate positioning • Avoid "vendor framing" by using language and sequencing that aligns with executive prioritiesCore Content Outline1. The Power of Strategic Questions • “He who asks the questions controls the conversation” — Josh Braun • From spec talk to strategic talk: Why consultants ask different questions • How questions influence perception: expert vs. executor2. Anatomy of a Great Discovery Question • Open-ended, non-leading, insight-generating • Tied to outcomes: growth, efficiency, risk, revenue • Designed to uncover what matters, not just what’s broken3. Methodology: Power Questions + 3 Strategic Discovery Areas • Power Questions – Engage executives, surface vision, create space for meaningful conversation • Business-Focused Questions – Expose goals, metrics, and department initiatives • Integrated Business–Technology Questions – Bridge pain points with IT opportunities • Technology-Focused Questions – Reveal infrastructure, service, and workflow needs • Apply frameworks like: ?• 3-Why Ladder: Why now ? Why this ? Why us? ?• PACT: Problem, Alternatives, Consequences, Transformation • Use the Goal Pyramid and client quadrant to calibrate tone, ambition, and language4. Do’s and Don’ts of Discovery Delivery Do: • Mirror language, summarize goals, probe deeper Don’t: • Pitch solutions early, talk features, and overuse acronymsPractice ExerciseTitle: Consulting Conversations Drill • Select one client (ideally using the Discovery Brief from Course 2) • Choose their Archetype and Goal Level • Use the Strategic Discovery Question Bank to write five custom questions to: ?• Uncover strategic goals ?• Surface hidden pain ?• Understand timelines and internal blockers • Role-play with a peer or manager in a mock QBR or roadmap session • Record “What we heard” and “What we should explore next.”Strategic OutcomeParticipants conclude with a personalized Discovery Question Bank tailored to real clients, along with practice in delivering them with confidence and strategic impact.Toolkits or TemplatesThe CS Toolkit #3 – Client Business Discovery tool generates tailored discovery questions automatically based on structured enrichment. After the client’s Industry Summary and Client Summary are completed (see Course 2), the tool uses the client’s Appetite ? Maturity quadrant and the stakeholder’s seniority level (e.g., owner, C-level, manager) to generate personalized questions across four strategic categories:Power Questions Open-ended prompts that engage senior decision-makers by surfacing their vision, frustrations, and executive ambitions. Example: What would success look like for your business if technology perfectly supported your strategy?Business-Focused Questions Expose goals, KPIs, department initiatives, and competitive drivers that shape the business context for technology alignment. Example: What are your top three business objectives for the coming year?Integrated Business–Technology Questions Bridge operational realities with technology opportunities, revealing how IT can remove bottlenecks or accelerate outcomes. Example: Are there workflows that could benefit significantly from automation or AI?Technology-Focused Questions Target current-state infrastructure, service quality, and process gaps—anchoring conversation in measurable improvements. Example: Are there recurring tech issues your team continues to raise but haven’t yet been solved?This automated output allows CS professionals to arrive prepared with relevant discovery questions, be business-aware, and be calibrated to the stakeholder’s mindset, so every meeting feels more like a consulting session than a check-in.
Course #4: How to Unpack a DiscoverySubtitle: Turn Meeting Notes Into Roadmaps That Clients Say Yes ToOriginal ProblemDiscovery meetings often feel productive, but then stall. CS professionals take notes, but struggle to convert them into tangible next steps. Roadmaps remain vague, proposals get delayed, and assessments fall short. The result? Clients view the MSP as a good listener, rather than a strategic driver. Discovery remains passive without a method for transforming raw conversations into focused action, and business outcomes fail to materialize.PurposeThis course teaches CS professionals how to synthesize discovery conversations into strategic initiatives, map those initiatives to client goals, and structure a next-step output that supports annual planning, proposal development, or in-depth assessment—depending on the client's readiness.Learning ObjectivesBy the end of this course, participants will be able to: • Extract relevant insights from client discovery sessions • Translate raw inputs into clear goals, initiatives, and timelines • Prioritize initiatives using the Goal Pyramid + Archetype model • Identify when to advance toward planning, scoping, or assessment • Build a structured output ready for annual strategy and planningCore Content Outline1. From Conversation to Commitment • What clients say vs. what they mean: filtering signal from noise • Spotting initiatives: recurring pain, time-sensitive issues, executive interests • Why most roadmaps and proposals fail: too vague, too technical, or disconnected from business context2. Goal–Initiative–Planning Mapping Framework • Client Goal ? “Improve remote collaboration” • Initiative ? “M365 optimization project” • Planning View ? phased effort across quarters or key business cycles3. Prioritization by Appetite & Maturity • Use segmentation to determine scope, timing, and format • Low maturity clients ? project scoping and quick wins • Moderate maturity ? annual initiative planning and budgeting • High maturity ? full funnel flow: Discovery ? Assessment ? Roadmap4. From Discovery to Deliverables • When to turn outputs into a scoped proposal (validated, contained need) • When to escalate into planning (multi-topic, medium maturity readiness) • When to move into assessment (deep dive on risk, complexity, or unknowns)5. Annual Planning Context • How Discovery outputs become the launchpad for structured annual plans • How Goals, Topics, and Initiatives carry forward into roadmaps and budgets • Why clarity at this stage improves cadence, confidence, and CS HealthPractice ExerciseTitle: From Memo to Motion Plan • Upload or reference a recent meeting memo or discovery notes • Identify and extract: ?• Key business goals ?• Repeated challenges ?• Executive concerns or constraints • Draft: ?• 3 strategic initiatives (each labelled with Client Goal alignment) ?• Estimated time/effort or delivery rhythm ?• Output recommendation: project scope, annual plan, or assessment• Submit your draft as: ?• Title, Objectives, and aligned Client Goal ?• Client segment and maturity ?• Suggested next step (proposal, planning, or assessment)Strategic OutcomeParticipants leave with a structured output anchored in Discovery, but purpose-built for strategic use at the next step. Based on the client’s maturity, this output may: • Feed directly into a scoped project proposal • Advance to structured annual planning with roadmap and budget • Trigger a focused assessment to validate deeper risk or complexityRather than leaving Discovery as “just a conversation,” this course equips CS professionals to guide clients toward the right planning path with confidence and clarity.Toolkits or TemplatesThe CS Toolkit #3 – Client Business Discovery tool supports live intake and post-meeting synthesis. It organizes insights using a five-box canvas:• Client Industry Information – Sector context, tech trends, and risk triggers • Client General Information – Locations, size, growth signals • Client Business Information – Strategic drivers, department goals • Business Technology Information – Collaboration, enablement, and process gaps • Technology Infrastructure Information – Systems, lifecycle, asset gapsAfter input is refined, the tool generates: • A draft Client Business Goal • Suggested Topics for follow-up • Candidate Initiatives based on maturity, appetite, and strategic postureThis structured output empowers CS professionals to translate insights into one of three strategic paths:1. Project Scope – For low-maturity clients ready for contained action2. Annual Plan – For mid-maturity clients with multiple aligned topics3. Assessment Intake – For high-maturity clients needing structured validation before initiative framingThe result is a confident transition from Discovery to structured CS execution, tailored to each client’s stage and business model.
Course #5: Perfect Closed Loop Follow-upSubtitle: How to Turn Roadmaps Into Action Without Losing MomentumOriginal ProblemDiscovery insights and roadmaps often sound promising, but then stall. CS professionals generate great recommendations but lose traction in the follow-through. Clients disengage without a straightforward method to translate discovery into action, through assessments, scoped initiatives, or structured proposals, and momentum fades. Strategic wins become missed opportunities because there’s no clear path from idea to execution.PurposeThis course helps CS professionals close the loop after discovery—converting strategic intent into scoped initiatives, validating needs through assessment, and preparing action-ready outputs that drive execution inside LMx or internal workflows.Learning ObjectivesBy the end of this course, participants will be able to: • Build an initiative follow-up plan based on discovery outputs • Select the right path: assessment, project scope, or roadmap-based planning • Use assessments to validate urgency and prioritize action • Draft a client-facing project scope aligned to business value and stakeholder expectations • Package discovery outputs into execution-ready artifactsCore Content Outline1. The Risk of Dropping the Ball • Why great discoveries often die in the follow-up • “Consultant ghosting” vs “Trusted advisor closure” • How strategic CS wins are lost without tight execution2. Closed-Loop Execution Framework Discovery ? Roadmap ? Scope ? Proposal ? Execution • Assessment ? Validate risk, uncover urgency • Project Scope ? Define success criteria, milestones, and stakeholders • Initiative Planning ? Link to Client Business Goals, budget, and timeline • Proposal or QBR Update ? Finalize buy-in and transition to delivery3. Choosing the Right Path by Maturity • Low Maturity: Use Discovery insights to build a single Project Scope (focused, contained, ready to propose) • Mid Maturity: Roll outputs into a structured Annual Plan (Roadmap + Initiatives + Budget) • High Maturity: Follow the whole Funnel: Discovery ? Assessment ? Initiative ? Budget4. Strategic Follow-Through Techniques • How to transition from recommendation to commitment • Framing scope in terms of ROI, business continuity, or efficiency • Anchoring initiative alignment to Client Goal and Archetype • Preparing decision-makers using phased budget thinkingPractice ExerciseTitle: Assessment ? Scope ? Roadmap Flow • Choose one initiative from your Discovery output • Select the best-fit pathway: ?• Assessment – For complex, high-stakes, or compliance-sensitive topics ?• Project Scope – For validated needs requiring proposal packaging ?• Roadmap – For multi-topic planning over time • Complete the following for your selected path: ?• Assessment Summary – Key risks, urgency, and impact if ignored ?• Project Scope – Outcomes, roles, timeline, and three high-level milestones ?• Roadmap View – Show timing and priority over the next 3–6 months • Create a presentation-ready slide or page with: ?• Initiative overview ?• Business goal alignment ?• Supporting insight (Assessment or Discovery) ?• Suggested cost/budget tierStrategic OutcomeParticipants leave with a Client Initiative Package: a scoped deliverable based on real Discovery inputs and structured for execution—whether inside a roadmap, a project proposal, or an LMx-based assessment. The outcome is traction, not just insight.Toolkits or TemplatesPrimary Follow-up CTAs (via Business Discovery Tool ? LMx integration):1. Use LMx to build the project – Transition scoped initiatives into LMx Projects2. Use LMx to build the roadmap and budget – Send Topics and Initiatives into the LMx Recommendations section3. Use LMx to send an assessment – Trigger formalized intake and scoring for high-impact topicsSecondary CTA Options (Toolkit-based extensions):1. Project Scope ? Use CS Toolkit #3 – Proposal Builder ?• Expands a selected Discovery topic into a scoped, client-facing proposal2. Roadmap + Initiatives + Budget ? (Coming soon: separate planning builder) ?• Placeholder for internal roadmap planning workflows (until complete toolkit available)3. Assessment Findings ? Use CS Toolkit #8 – Assessment Generator ?• Generates a written assessment summary for a specific business technology topic, which can be pasted into the LMx Assessment module manually

Promo Page – Why Strategic Business Discovery FailsThree signs your MSP is “winging” business discovery:? You ask the same generic questions in every meeting—no client context, no impact.? Discovery is seen as “checklist time” or awkward sales, never as a strategic conversation.? Discovery notes live in a silo: they don’t feed goals, initiatives, or CS Health.What’s Actually Broken: ? You lack industry and client-specific context, so the questions land flat.? You don’t tailor the conversation to client maturity, appetite, or business priorities.? You can’t quickly translate insights into initiatives, goals, and CS follow-ups.Here’s Your Fix: The Business Discovery Canvas This tool bridges the gap by:? Gathering deep, up-to-date industry and client intelligence—zero touch.? Connecting business discovery directly to strategic planning, so every conversation builds toward actionable outcomes and future initiatives.? Selecting a discovery style tailored to each client’s segment and strategic context.? Instantly generating segment-aware, high-impact questions—no more generic lists.? Integrating discovery notes and follow-ups directly into your CS and planning workflows.? Personalized. ? Actionable. ? Scalable.
App Cover PageMost MSPs run discovery “on autopilot.” You ask some questions, but don’t know if you’re missing what matters or if your advice is even relevant. True business discovery is more than a checklist: it’s about understanding the real-world pressures your client faces, the industry trends shaping their decisions, and the goals that drive their investments.The Business Discovery Tool fixes this by guiding you step-by-step through structured information gathering, quadrant targeting, and actionable follow-up. It connects the dots between what you learn in discovery and how you plan your Customer Success initiatives, ensuring every insight is translated into future roadmap items, strategic planning, or tactical projects.By the end, you’ll:? Understand your client’s industry and context better than their competitors.? Have a clear, tailored list of discovery questions for every maturity/appetite profile.? Document, organize, and operationalize client insights for maximum impact—not just in CS Health or QBRs, but throughout your CS planning.
Step 1: Enrich Your Client and Industry UnderstandingEvery successful Customer Success Strategy begins with a deep understanding of your clients, not just their IT infrastructure, but their business context, industry pressures, and strategic objectives. Step 1 is where we lay the groundwork for strategic business discovery and planning by gathering and organizing two key types of information:? Client Information: Specific details about the organization’s size, market, leadership, revenue, locations, known initiatives, and technology environment. This sets the stage for relevant, high-impact conversations.? Industry Information: Up-to-date research, sector trends, competitor activity, regulatory challenges, and typical pain points facing organizations like your client. This ensures your discovery is always rooted in the client’s business reality.By combining these two layers, you don’t just ask better questions—you unlock the ability to connect business discovery directly to strategic planning, assessment, and roadmap execution. The tool leverages AI-powered search to automatically gather and structure the most relevant information about each client and their sector. It gives you a proper foundation for all future CS planning and engagements.Why is this enrichment significant?? Relevance: Knowing your client’s business model, industry trends, compliance needs, and key decision-makers enables you to tailor IT solutions and advice to what matters.? Differentiation: Industry intelligence helps you stand out from “one-size-fits-all” competitors by letting you connect IT outcomes to sector-specific challenges and opportunities.? Efficiency: Automated enrichment eliminates the need for manual research, delivering structured, actionable insight that accelerates playbook preparation, roadmap design, and proposal writing.What is Client Enrichment and Industry Enrichment?Client Enrichment means using AI to collect and organize key facts about your client’s locations, size, management, value proposition, core offerings, and recent news. Industry Enrichment means pulling in up-to-date trends, risks, compliance frameworks, and business models for your client’s sector so that you can position IT recommendations in the proper context.How does the tool gather and structure this information?? AI Search & Data Aggregation: The tool queries public data, company websites, LinkedIn, news feeds, and business registries to compile the most recent and relevant information—zero manual effort required.? Structured Output: Each client and industry profile is organized into clear fields (e.g., Industry Overview, Client Locations, Key Competitors, Technology Stack), ensuring consistency and easy review.? Anti-Hallucination: If sufficient data is unavailable, the tool flags this so you can supplement it later—no speculation, only facts.What types of information are collected?Client Information (example fields):? Locations: Where does the client operate?? Size & Revenue: How big are they, and what is their scale?? Key Contacts: Who are the IT decision-makers and influencers?? Value Proposition: What makes them stand out in their market?? Core Products/Services: What do they sell or deliver?? Recent News: Any acquisitions, new technology investments, awards?? Technology Stack: What IT tools, platforms, and vendors do they use?? Partnerships: Who are their strategic partners or alliances?? Competitors & Market Position: Who are their rivals, and how do they compare?Industry Information (example fields):? Industry Overview: What are the defining features of this sector?? Trends & Opportunities: What new technologies or shifts are on the horizon?? Challenges: What pain points or disruptions are common?? Compliance: Which regulations are most critical?? Business/IT Challenges: Typical risks, standard tech struggles? Technology Opportunities: What’s being adopted (cloud, automation, etc.)?? Revenue Models & Processes: How do businesses in this industry make money, and which IT systems are mission-critical?? Supply Chain Risks: Are there any notable dependencies?What if the tool can't find all the details?? You will be prompted to review and complete any missing fields manually.? You can always add, edit, or clarify information to ensure accuracy.? The more you refine the enrichment, the more tailored and credible your Customer Success strategy will be for each client.How can you improve enrichment accuracy?? Supplement automated results with internal notes from onboarding, QBRs, or past projects.? During business discovery, ask clients to validate key data points (e.g., tech stack, compliance requirements).? Regularly update enrichment profiles as clients grow, merge, or shift focus.
Step 2: Select Your CS Strategy Target (Maturity–Appetite Quadrant)The second step in effective Business Discovery is defining the primary business context you want to uncover for the client you are about to meet. In this tool, you select a single focus quadrant from the proven Maturity–Appetite framework—clarifying whether your main objective is to identify a client ready for innovation, one needing operational stability, or another combination. This selection ensures that your downstream discovery questions will be relevant to this client's real business state and ambition.
What is the Maturity–Appetite Quadrant? The Maturity–Appetite model is a proven segmentation framework that classifies a client based on two axes:? Maturity: How standardized, aligned, and operationally advanced is the client’s environment?? Appetite: How ready and willing are they to pursue strategic improvement and invest in change?In this tool, you’ll select one of four archetypal quadrants as the primary focus for your Customer Success discovery with this client:? Transform (High Maturity, High Appetite): “Transform your client’s business with innovative solutions.” Select this if you want to explore opportunities for co-innovation, OKR-level alignment, and proactive, business-led change with a highly advanced, engaged client.? Modernize (Low Maturity, High Appetite): “Modernize your client’s technology stack.” Select this if the client is eager to improve but needs guidance to standardize, consolidate, and upgrade their IT—your goal is to help them move up the maturity curve.? Educate (High Maturity, Low Appetite): “Educate your client about the benefit of your services.” Select this if the client has a solid, standardized environment but shows little openness to change—your aim is to surface value and spark appetite for improvement.? Sustain (Low Maturity, Low Appetite): “Sustain your client’s business growth.” Select this if the client prioritizes stability, reliable service, and minimal disruption—your CS approach will focus on efficiency and maintaining trust.Why does this selection matter?? It sets the strategic tone for your Business Discovery session—defining what “success” means for this particular client.? It focuses your preparation and conversation on communication strategies that best fit this client's real business context.? It ensures that your recommendations, and follow-up are aligned to a clear, client-specific business goal.How should you select your target quadrant?? Review what you know about the client so far: Do they show signs of readiness for transformation, or are they mostly focused on stability and operational basics?? Consider your pre-meeting research: Look for clues in recent project history, assessment results, or client communications that indicate their current maturity and appetite.? Think about your meeting objective: Are you aiming to inspire innovation, remove friction, help them catch up with industry standards, or simply maintain their trust?What if the client’s situation is complex or in transition?? If your client seems to straddle more than one quadrant, start by focusing on their most urgent or strategic business need today.? You can adjust your approach as more information comes out during the discovery conversation.? As the relationship develops, you can shift the CS strategy focus to support their evolving priorities.How can you refine your choice over time?? Revisit your client’s quadrant classification after major assessments, quarterly reviews, or significant business changes.? Use feedback from this and future meetings, plus any updated CS Health metrics, to confirm your focus and fine-tune discovery questions for maximum relevance.? As you gather more data, you can reclassify the client and update your CS approach to match their new reality.
Step 3: Review and Complete Client InformationAt this stage, you review and finalize all the foundational data about your client that was auto-enriched in Step 1. The Client Discovery Canvas presents two key sections: Industry Information and Client Information. This is your opportunity to validate, complete, or adjust these fields to ensure the context for your engagement is accurate and relevant. By grounding your Customer Success process in up-to-date, client-specific information, you set the stage for high-impact discovery conversations and actionable planning.By completing this step, you create a reliable foundation for the next phase: generating highly relevant discovery questions and tailored presentations.What is included in Industry and Client Information?? Industry Information: These fields capture your client’s industry sector, common market challenges, regulatory requirements, and typical business models. The tool pre-populates this data using best-available public information and your own client database, so you get a jump start on understanding what’s likely to matter in your upcoming discovery.? Client Information: Here you’ll see specifics about your client organization, such as company size, main lines of business, geographic scope, leadership contacts, and any known technology platforms. These details are pulled from your CRM, public sources, or manually entered during onboarding.Why is this review step important?? Ensures all discovery questions and recommendations are anchored in the real client context, not generic assumptions.? Builds trust with the client, demonstrating that you’ve done your homework and understand their world.? Surfaces missing or outdated data that might otherwise derail a meeting or initiative later.? Supports compliance and risk management by making industry requirements visible up front.How should you review and update these fields?For many smaller companies—or for clients in niche or less-documented industries—it’s common that limited public information is available about the organization. As a result, some fields may be pre-filled with incomplete or outdated data, or may be missing entirely.? Compare pre-filled fields with your latest CRM records and notes from recent client conversations to ensure accuracy.? Fill in any missing information or correct errors (for example, if there have been recent mergers, changes in ownership, or shifts in business focus).? For industry-related information, check that the listed challenges, market trends, and compliance notes actually reflect the client’s current profile and priorities.? Leverage your firsthand experience with the client’s vertical or unique situation—add details from recent projects, regulatory changes, or local market conditions that may not be captured in public sources.? If the tool fails to capture a critical point, simply edit or add it directly—this is your opportunity to make the Client Information and Industry Information sections genuinely actionable and relevantWhat if you’re missing information or unsure about an entry?? Reach out internally to account managers, vCIOs, or others who know the client best.? You can always return to this page to update the information as more data becomes available.How can you improve the quality and impact of your client information over time?? Review and refresh industry and client-specific info at the start of each major initiative, QBR, or annual review.
Step 4: Get Discovery QuestionsPersonalized discovery questions are the foundation for high-impact client meetings. The tool presents a tailored set of 19 questions on this page, generated based on your earlier inputs about the client, industry, and business priorities. Each question is designed to spark meaningful dialogue, uncover pain points, and reveal strategic opportunities, going beyond generic templates.What Are Discovery Questions and Why Are They Important?Discovery questions help you understand your client’s real goals, challenges, and context. A well-crafted set of questions will let you move from surface-level conversations to a genuine strategic partnership. When you ask about the business environment, industry trends, digital enablement, and infrastructure, you show the client that you understand their world and are prepared to add value, not just push solutions.What Types of Discovery Questions Are Included? The tool’s questions are based on the six key types identified in modern MSP discovery methodology:? Warm-Up Questions: Build rapport and set the tone for an open, trusting conversation.? General Business Discovery: Surface high-level objectives, business pain points, and key initiatives.? Industry-Specific Questions: Demonstrate domain expertise and contextual intelligence about the client’s sector.? Digital Enablement: Identify opportunities for process modernization, automation, or digital adoption.? IT Strategy & Optimization: Explore how current technology infrastructure supports or limits the client’s growth.? Next Steps & Commitment: Clarify alignment, confirm priorities, and define what progress or follow-up should happen next.Each question is accompanied by a brief explanation to help you understand its intent and tailor your approach in real time.How are the Questions Personalized?The tool uses client information (location, size, business model), your team’s vertical competency, and industry data to generate context-rich questions. You’ll see not only general business questions, but also prompts tied to current market pressures, technology maturity, and compliance factors specific to the client’s sector.A short explanation follows each question in square brackets, so you understand the intent behind the question and can adapt your follow-ups in real time.What Should You Do on This Page?? Review the information: Carefully review the automatically enriched Client Information and Industry Information sections on this page. Consider if all key facts about your client, their context, and their industry are present and accurate.? Go back if needed: If you recall additional data or context—such as new client contacts, industry changes, or specific business goals—you can always navigate back to the previous step in the wizard and update the relevant fields there. This ensures that your strategy foundations are as accurate and comprehensive as possible.? Generate your summary: Once you are satisfied, proceed to the next step or use the available “Create Presentation” function to generate a downloadable PDF containing your current enriched data. This can be shared internally or used as a handout for upcoming meetings.What if the Questions Don’t Fully Fit?If you feel some questions do not match this client or this meeting’s context, you can always copy the text into your preferred editor to adjust or supplement it before use. The tool’s initial suggestions are a starting point—real strategic value comes from tailoring your approach to each client’s current situation, industry challenges, and business objectives.If, as you progress, you realize there’s more information you want to include (for example, additional details for Client Information or Industry Information), simply go back to the previous step in the wizard and add or update those details. This flexibility ensures that your discovery process is always aligned with the latest, most accurate inputs.How Can You Improve Your Discovery Approach?? If you find, after moving forward, that you want to enrich the Client Information or Industry Information further, you can simply return to the previous step to add the new details.? Track which questions lead to the most valuable insights, and incorporate that feedback into your evolving discovery sessions. This continuous improvement approach will maximize the value of every client interaction.
Step 5: Add Business Discovery Meeting NotesCapturing accurate notes during the Business Discovery meeting is essential to ensure that client context, needs, and goals are understood and reflected in the Customer Success plan. Supports auditability and continuous improvement of the CS processHow should you capture or generate notes?? Use structured note-taking templates provided by your CS platform or CRM? Step 6: Review Client Discovery CanvasThe Client Discovery Canvas gives you a structured, at-a-glance summary of everything you’ve learned about your client, from meeting notes, enriched website data, and earlier steps in the wizard. This is where you finalize your understanding of the client’s current business and technology environment before moving into CS planning, roadmap development, and playbook execution.A key advantage of the Discovery Canvas is that it brings together two previously captured inputs:1. Client Information — the client’s own business model, size, positioning, and strategic focus.In addition to these, the Discovery Canvas also integrates structured notes from your Business Discovery meeting:? Business Discovery — what’s changing in the client’s business environment, goals, and pain points? Business Technology Discovery — business process enablement, how technology supports or limits the client’s operations? Technology Infrastructure Discovery — current IT stack, key risks, lifecycle issues, and readiness for changeThis unified view ensures that Customer Success planning is aligned to both macro-level industry context and micro-level client reality. With the Canvas, you have a comprehensive yet actionable starting point for building relevant playbooks, aligning roadmap items, and setting up initiatives that truly match each client’s priorities and environment.What does the Client Discovery Canvas show?The canvas is structured to help your team prepare for high-value client conversations, especially those involving strategic initiatives or quarterly/annual planning. It shows:? Business-facing details like client size, ownership model, and growth posture? Operational readiness indicators (e.g., number of users, sites, locations)? Strategic intent, such as M&A readiness, compliance-driven initiatives, or AI ambitions? Technology posture through a simplified infrastructure viewInstead of collecting this data ad hoc, the canvas standardizes your prep work across all accounts, creating consistency, saving time, and enabling segment-specific playbook delivery.Why is this step necessary?Good CS planning starts with context. You'll default to tactical conversations if your team enters a QBR or strategic meeting without understanding the client’s business structure, vertical nuances, and technology maturity. The Discovery Canvas ensures:? Everyone is on the same page before planning begins? Strategic guidance is aligned to the client’s world, not just your stack? Playbooks are relevant, and reporting is focused on business valueClients don’t just want tech recommendations—they want advisors who understand what makes their business tick.How are these discovery topics mapped?The Discovery Canvas is broken into three areas that support the Customer Success journey:1. Business Discovery? Used to surface innovation appetite and OKR alignment? Examples: organizational growth goals, competitive positioning, key metrics, M&A activity2. Business Technology Discovery? Highlights the digital transformation potential and internal process friction? Examples: workflow automation needs, cross-departmental collaboration gaps, compliance pressures3. Technology Infrastructure Discovery? Captures operational status of the stack and signals upgrade readiness? Examples: outdated firewalls, legacy on-prem servers, poor patch hygieneEach section gives input into whether a Discovery or Assessment should trigger a roadmap initiative, risk remediation, or standardization effort.What if your discovery input is incomplete?That’s normal. The Canvas is designed to evolve as your relationship with the client deepens. You can:? Pre-fill using website enrichment, and past meeting notes? Refine during planning conversations? Update before major engagements like budget reviews or strategic planningHow can you improve discovery accuracy?? Standardize who fills in the canvas and when—ideally after Discovery Intake (4.2) and before a significant CS milestone like 4.3 Assessment or 4.4 Meeting.? Use vertical-specific templates to guide questions and validation? Assign ownership (e.g., AM, CSM, vCIO) and include updates in your CS Health rhythm? Cross-reference assessment and roadmap outputs to close any gaps over time
Step 7: Transform Discovery into Goals, Topics, and InitiativesCapturing raw notes from meetings is not enough—actual Customer Success impact comes from converting those notes into action. This step is where business discovery meets strategic planning. Step 7 operationalizes the Closed Loop Theory, ensuring that every discovery insight is turned into a structured, client-driven strategy that closes the gap between listening and execution.The Closed Loop Theory teaches that effective MSPs always transform their Discovery into three structured outputs:? Client Business Goals (what the client ultimately wants to achieve)? Strategic Topics (the key focus areas or business functions that connect goals and action)? Initiatives (the concrete, measurable actions the MSP will deliver to address those topics)This approach ensures that business-side insights from Discovery don’t get lost in a silo, but instead become the foundation for roadmap planning, initiative scoping, and client engagement strategy. By explicitly linking discovery to strategic planning, you maximize every client conversation’s value and align your Customer Success activities with what truly drives business impact.What information gets transformed here?At this step, your discovery notes are structured into three layers:? Business Goals: These are the client’s long-term, high-impact outcomes (e.g., risk reduction, expansion, or improved efficiency) that guide all future technical and business decisions.? Topics: These are thematic areas or business functions (such as “device lifecycle” or “change management”) that group related issues and context under each goal, creating clarity for discussion.? Initiatives: These are specific, actionable projects or solutions (such as “deploy UEM platform” or “standardize onboarding checklist”) that the MSP will deliver, directly tied to the identified goals and topics.Together, this structure transforms raw conversation notes into a clear, actionable framework for strategic planning and execution.Why is this step necessary?? Closes the Loop on Discovery: By parsing discovery data into Goals, Topics, and Initiatives, MSPs ensure that valuable client input is not lost or ignored, but carried through to roadmap, QBRs, and planning.? Prepares for the Meeting: Ideally, it should be done right before your strategic planning meeting. This ensures you enter with clear, validated client goals and initiative candidates.? Drives Engagement and Accountability: Clients are more committed to initiatives they helped define through Discovery or Assessment, especially when the framing reflects their own words and goals.? Builds Playbook-Ready Inputs: These outputs can be immediately used to structure roadmap reviews, initiative proposals, and budgeting.How does Discovery turn into structured goals and plans?? Conduct Discovery early—before your Annual Strategic Meeting. Ideally, schedule and complete Business Discovery 4–6 weeks ahead of your strategic planning session. This gives you time to collect, process, and organize the client’s inputs without rushing.? Use your Discovery Canvas as a foundation. Review the AI-generated Business Goals, Topics, and Initiatives produced by the tool from your Business Discovery  Canvas notes. This helps you quickly surface recurring themes and spot both strategic objectives and operational pain points.? Assign targeted Assessments when deeper analysis is needed. If a new goal, challenge, or opportunity emerges during Discovery but lacks detail, don’t guess—assign an Assessment. This could be a standardized technology stack review, a cybersecurity scan, or a digital maturity questionnaire, tailored to the specific topic. Assessments bring structure, evidence, and focus to vague or complex ideas.? Update and refine your Business Goals, Topics, and Initiatives.  Once Assessments are complete, review the results and adjust the original goals, topics and initiatives. This step ensures that every initiative is rooted in verified data and that business priorities are clearly defined.? Validate with the client during your Annual Strategic Meeting. Present the refined Business Goals, Topics, and Initiatives to your client for confirmation. Walk through each one, invite feedback, and clarify anything that’s ambiguous or off-target. This collaborative review builds alignment and accountability.? Translate structured goals into deliverables. Once the client confirms their goals and priorities, convert them into actionable deliverables—roadmaps, playbooks, project scopes, or initiative lists. These become the backbone of your Customer Success plan, turning strategy into day-to-day action.

CS Strategy Quickstarter (Owner/Leader)For CS Owners & Leaders | Build a CS Strategy You Can Actually DeliverWhat is it?The CS Strategy Quickstarter is a practical program for MSP leaders who want to move beyond theory and build a scalable, financially aligned Customer Success strategy. This course is your blueprint if you’ve ever struggled to balance high-touch service with real-world margins.Why it matters:Without segmentation logic, time capacity models, or role alignment, Customer Success stays reactive, over-committed, and unscalable—or oversized and financially inefficient, where the math just doesn’t work. Many MSPs deliver too much, to the wrong clients, with the incorrect roles, leading to burnout or bloated overhead. This course walks you through each key decision: who gets what, how often, and when, based on MRR, appetite for change, maturity, and your real team resources. You'll walk away with a working plan, not just ideas.What You’ll LearnMRR-Based Touchpoints Rethink how you assign CS time. Segment clients using MRR + Appetite/Maturity to define tiered cadences, service levels, and strategic potential.Set Engagement Time Budgets Translate MRR into time. Build a CS delivery model that balances proactive value with reactive flexibility, based on margins, cost per hour, and client tier.Match Team Capabilities to Activities Tie strategic CS work to real business value—and ensure your team actually has the skills to deliver it. Align activities with revenue, risk, and vertical opportunities.CS Team Blueprint Determine what roles you need, how many hours they can provide, and where your gaps are. Build a team structure that reflects the strategy you designed.CS Strategy & Capacity Gap Plan Synthesize it all into a Minimum Viable CS Strategy you can immediately deploy. Prioritize the right initiatives, close critical gaps, and drive consistent delivery.What You’ll Walk Away With? A segmented client portfolio with tiered touchpoints? CS Strategy - Ultimate Guide
Designing a Role-Aligned Operating System for Customer Success DeliveryAuthor: ScalePad Strategy OfficeContributor: Joe Markert, Director of CS ResearchAbstractAs MSPs evolve from reactive technical support to proactive, strategic partners, role clarity has become a critical success factor. This paper introduces the Four Quadrants of MSP Roles, a practical framework designed to structure Customer Success teams by two strategic axes: Business vs. Technology Impact and Operational vs. Strategic Engagement. By adopting this model, MSPs can reduce delivery friction, clarify responsibilities, and improve client outcomes across the maturity spectrum.IntroductionMost MSPs experience growing pains as their services diversify. Technical delivery becomes intertwined with account strategy, client expectations evolve, and internal teams struggle with handoffs, duplication, and gaps in ownership. Clients ask:“Who owns our roadmap? Who’s my main contact? Why does this keep falling through the cracks?”The Four Quadrants of MSP Roles framework solves this by mapping roles not only to job titles—but to types of value delivered.The ModelThe quadrant model is built on two intersecting axes:? Vertical Axis (Y): Impact Orientation — from Technology to Business? Horizontal Axis (X): Engagement Type — from Operational to StrategicThis results in four functional quadrants:1. Technology Operations FocusRoles: TAM, SDM, NOC, SOCImpact Orientation: TechnologyEngagement Style: OperationalKey Functions:? Service delivery execution? Cybersecurity configuration and maintenance? Backup and disaster recovery alignment? Process and best practice implementationThese roles ensure technical reliability and compliance with defined standards.2. Strategic Technology FocusRoles: vCIO, vCISO, PMImpact Orientation: TechnologyEngagement Style: StrategicKey Functions:? Building and owning the technology roadmap? Guiding strategic stack adoption? Managing the technology lifecycle? Overseeing cybersecurity strategy? Leading strategic project executionThese roles bridge execution with planning—moving clients forward across the technology maturity curve.3. Business Operations FocusRoles: AM, CSMImpact Orientation: BusinessEngagement Style: OperationalKey Functions:? Driving contract renewals and service satisfaction? Managing support interactions and follow-ups? Coordinating projects and scheduling? Facilitating general engagement and relationship management? Supporting service expansion through upsell triggersThese roles are essential for maintaining day-to-day relationships and service momentum.4. Strategic Business FocusRoles: vCIO, vCISO, CxO (external or internal advisor)Impact Orientation: BusinessEngagement Style: StrategicKey Functions:? AI adoption and productivity strategy? Aligning technology to employee and operational efficiency? Business intelligence and analytics planning? Supporting regulatory and risk compliance? Advising on emerging technologies and market differentiationThese roles speak to executives and link MSP services to measurable business outcomes.ApplicationsRole ClarityEach quadrant defines not just who does what—but why. When roles are aligned to quadrant value, team members avoid duplication and clients gain confidence in the structure.Scalable StaffingBy segmenting clients based on maturity and strategic potential, MSPs can assign roles based on the quadrant coverage required—avoiding over-servicing or resource dilution.Meeting DesignThe quadrant determines who owns and participates in QBRs, roadmap planning sessions, or tactical check-ins—ensuring every engagement is appropriate to both the audience and the intent.Enablement and IncentivesTraining and compensation can be designed around quadrant expectations—for example, strategic roles measured on maturity uplift, while operational roles are rewarded for consistency and satisfaction.ConclusionThe Four Quadrants of MSP Roles provides a practical framework for structuring Customer Success teams that match the complexity of today’s client expectations. It shifts role design from reactive firefighting to intentional value delivery—ensuring the right people show up to the right conversations with the right purpose.When implemented alongside segmentation, client goals, and health tracking, the quadrant model becomes the core of your Customer Success Operating System.References? ScalePad CS Blueprints – Discipline 5: CS People? “From Roles to Outcomes” Visual Model, 2024? ScalePad Academy: Team Builder Quickstarter and Role Enablement Matrix

CS Strategy Quickstarter (Owner/Leader)Objective: Build a sustainable, scalable Customer Success strategy using time budgets, client segmentation, and proactive engagement models that align CS to revenue, risk, and strategic value.Chapters – CS Strategy Quickstarter (Owner/Leader)1. Set Engagement Time Budgets Based on Financial Constraints How to Translate Revenue Into Realistic CS Delivery Capacity Helps MSPs create sustainable time models using investment strategy, proactive/reactive balance, and internal hourly cost metrics.3.
