Course #1: MRR-Based TouchpointsSubtitle: Rethink How You Allocate CS Time — Strategically, Not EmotionallyOriginal ProblemMost MSPs allocate Customer Success time based on habit, intuition, or relationship pressure, not financial or strategic logic. But the real issue isn’t time allocation — it’s segmentation that ignores strategic readiness. MSPs often segment by MRR alone, leading to blind spots where high-potential clients are underserved and low-potential clients are over-supported.PurposeTo build a dual-axis segmentation framework that balances economic prioritization (MRR) with strategic readiness (Client Business Goal = Maturity + Appetite), so CS time is allocated based on both value and potential.This course reframes how MSPs define CS service levels — not by gut feel or legacy assumptions, but through financial alignment using Monthly Recurring Revenue and goal-level segmentation.Learning Objectives? Segment clients using Primary (Client Business Goal) and Secondary (MRR banding) segmentation.? Define proactive vs. reactive service levels by client type? Allocate touch frequency and format based on both economic tier and strategic intent, not just size alone.Core Content Outline1. The Fallacy of Flat CS Delivery? Why “same QBR for everyone” failsi. Different Client Goals require different engagement styles, roles, and cadences. Segment D (Goal 1) needs stability and visibility, while Segment A (Goals 4–5) expects strategic co-planning.ii. Over-servicing Sustain clients vs. ignoring Transform clientsiii. Client readiness (Maturity + Appetite) should be the primary segmentation input. MRR only defines how much, not what.? Over-servicing Sustain clients vs. ignoring Transform ones2. Segmentation Inputs? Combine MRR with Appetite/Maturity segmentation? Primary Segmentation: Client Business Goal level (based on Maturity + Appetite scores)? Secondary Segmentation: MRR band (VIP, High, Mid, Low)? Define engagement tiers based on both:i. Segment A ? Strategic planningii. Segment B ? Formalized insight + roadmapiii. Segment C ? Structured enablementiv. Segment D ? Operational consistency? MRR Bands:i. VIP: $10,000+ii. High Touch: $5,000–$10,000iii. Mid Touch: $1,500–$5,000iv. Low Touch: <$1,5003. Touchpoint Design? Introduce the Four-Touch Model based on both Frequency ? Depth and Strategic Readiness:i. VIP Touch ? Weekly or Biweekly, led by vCxO/Strategic Advisorsii. High Touch ? Monthly, playbook-driveniii. Mid Touch ? Quarterly QBRs or async updatesiv. Tech Touch ? Trigger-based (CS Health alerts, reports)? Use the Client Goal segment to define the type of content (what kind of conversation) and the MRR tier to define the cadence (how often).? Also define delivery mode: Virtual, In-person, Async.Practice ExerciseTitle: CS Segmentation & Touchpoint Mapping Sprint Steps:? List all clients with MRR? Score each client’s Maturity and Appetite (1–5)? Plot each on the Client Goal quadrant (Segment A–D)? Assign MRR Band? Define per client:? Segment (A–D) and MRR Band? Touch frequency? Meeting types (Strategic, Tactical, QBR, Check-in)? Roles (AM, vCIO, etc.)ToolkitsCS Tool 4 – Segmentation & Playbook Supports both strategic and financial segmentation through:1. Primary Segmentation – Plot clients on the Maturity ? Appetite matrix2. Secondary Segmentation – Sort clients by MRR and assign Band (VIP–Low)3. Touchpoint Logic – Define cadence and format based on segment + MRRSegment Thresholds:? VIP: $10,000+? High Touch: $5,000–$10,000? Mid Touch: $1,500–$5,000? Low Touch: <$1,500This method ensures delivery aligns with financial scale and strategic potential.
Course #2: Set Engagement Time Budgets Based on Financial ConstraintsSubtitle: Design Your CS Model with Real Margins in MindOriginal ProblemMany MSPs treat Customer Success delivery as unlimited, offering engagement without constraints, leading to margin erosion and burnout. The deeper issue is the lack of a structured Engagement Strategy (7.2) that links available time to Client Segments, roles, and cadence. Without this, CS work becomes reactive and disconnected from financial reality. A scalable CS model begins with a clear understanding of what you can spend, where, and why.PurposeTo establish a financially viable and segment-aligned Engagement Strategy by translating revenue, cost, and strategic intent into time budgets that support both structured engagements (e.g., playbooks) and operational realities.Learning ObjectivesBy the end of this course, participants will be able to:? Define a CS Engagement Strategy that determines per-client CS investment? Calculate total available CS hours using revenue, cost, and margin? Split time into Proactive and Reactive buckets based on service style? Align delivery effort to client segments, MRR tiers, and business goalsCore Content Outline1. Engagement Strategy - Choose a CS Engagement Strategy based on how you intend to serve clients:? Boutique – 9% of MRR allocated to CS? Premium – 7% of MRR? Standard – 5% of MRR? Value – 3% of MRR? Cost Driver – 1% of MRRThis maps to the CS Engagement Strategy. Boutique providers invest more time in deeper relationships. Cost Driver MSPs optimize for minimal service load. The engagement strategy defines your CS operating model.2. Hourly Cost? Estimate your average hourly cost for Customer Success delivery.? Include loaded salary, tools, and operational overhead.? Weight the average across CS roles based on utilization.? This becomes your basis for time-budget planning and role capacity validation.3. Proactive vs. Reactive Effort - Determine the percentage of CS effort that should be proactively planned (e.g., QBRs, onboarding, playbooks) versus reactive support (e.g., urgent client needs, escalations, unplanned project scope work). We recommend:? Proactive: Roadmaps, onboarding, reviews, check-ins, quarterly themes? Reactive: At-risk clients, escalations, unscheduled planning and resolution The split ensures you retain capacity for strategic impact without dropping unplanned events.4. Time Budget Model - For each client tier (VIP, High Touch, Mid Touch, Low Touch), calculate:? Monthly CS Budget = MRR ? Engagement Strategy %? Total Hours = Monthly Budget ÷ Hourly Cost? Split time into Proactive and Reactive       Example: $5,000 MRR ? 5% = $250 per month budget. At $100 per hour, this client receives 2.5 hours of CS time. If 70% is proactive and 30% is reactive, that’s 1.75 hours strategic and 0.75 hours buffer. This builds a repeatable, financially aligned delivery model.Practice ExerciseTitle: Time Budget Modeller? Select your Engagement Strategy? Enter the average Hourly Cost? Define desired Proactive vs. Reactive % split? Input average MRR per client by tier? Calculate the CS Budget per client? Divide by the Hourly Cost to get the available time? Split by Proactive and Reactive, and map each result to the segment-based Playbook cadence? Identify over- or under-engagement by comparing delivery targets to actual capacity.ToolkitsCS Tool 4 – Segmentation & Playbook Supports CS time budgeting through four integrated planning tools:1. Engagement Strategy Selector – Enables MSPs to determine the percentage of their recurring revenue to allocate to CS activities, ranging from 1% (lean model) to 9% (high-touch strategy).2. Effort Split Planner – Helps structure the proportion of proactive versus reactive CS time, aligning delivery style with business risk and client expectations.3. Hourly Cost Estimator – Calculates the average blended hourly cost of CS team members based on their salary, role utilization, and indirect overhead.4. Capacity Planning Engine – Maps time investment to cadence and feasibility of Playbook execution.Why This Matters: Without a grounded time model, the Engagement Strategy fails. And without time for Playbook delivery, strategic engagements collapse. This course ensures that what you plan can be delivered at scale, with measurable outcomes and team alignment.
Course #3: Match Team Capabilities to Activities in ArchetypesSubtitle: Prove That Strategic CS Isn’t Just Nice — It’s NecessaryOriginal ProblemMany MSPs design proactive CS playbooks without verifying whether their team has the capabilities to deliver them. What needs to be delivered (topics, meetings, cadence)? Who is best equipped to deliver it? Where there are gaps in coverage that require upskilling or role sharingThis output directly supports the execution of the Engagement Strategy and ensures that the right playbooks are delivered to the right clients, by the right roles, at the right time.
Course #4: CS Team Blueprint – Who, How Many Hours, RoleSubtitle: Build a Team That Matches the Strategy You Just DesignedOriginal ProblemMany MSPs build their CS teams reactively — assigning roles to people rather than aligning people to work. This leads to burnout, inconsistent delivery, and strategic underperformance. Without a capacity-based team design, growth in CS is impossible to scale or sustain.PurposeThis course helps CS leaders align their team structure to their segmentation model and delivery strategy. Using inputs from segmentation, time modelling, and cadence planning, it calculates the roles needed, the required hours, and the available team capacity — so you can design a team that can actually deliver the strategy.Learning ObjectivesBy the end of this course, participants will be able to:? Define the necessary CS roles (AM, TAM, vCIO, CSM) based on client segmentation? Allocate hours per role by client tier and activity type? Identify coverage gaps and team imbalance risksCore Content Outline1. From Strategy to Staffing? CS isn’t scalable until you staff to your segments? Don’t build roles for people — build roles for the work2. Role Planning by Segment? Match each segment (VIP, High, Mid, Low) with a delivery model? Determine resource type (Strategic vs. Operational CS roles)3. Time Budget by Role? How many clients per AM? vCIO? TAM?? How many hours per client per month per tier?4. Identify Team Model? Shared vs. Dedicated Roles? Solo vs. Paired Coverage? Strategic Specialists vs. Generalist Flex RolesPractice ExerciseTitle: Team Delivery Model Canvas Map each client segment to required roles (solo or paired) Assign:? People & Roles Inventory – The user defines their CS team members, roles, and whether they are full-time or part-time contributors to CS work (e.g., 50% allocation = 1000 hours/year if 2000 hours is full-time).2. Client Portfolio Composition – The number of clients per segment (VIP, High Touch, Mid Touch, Low Touch) is entered.3. Capacity Planning Reference – Based on the previously defined playbook delivery cadence (from Course 2), the system calculates the required hours per client, per segment, and year.These inputs are used to generate a Capacity Overview, which includes:? CS Hours Required per Segment (e.g., VIP: 450 hours, High Touch: 810 hours…)? CS Hours Required per Cadence (Annual, Quarterly, Monthly, Ad-Hoc)? Total Required CS Hours per Year? Total FTEs Needed, assuming 1 FTE = 2000 hours? Current Team Capacity, based on declared % allocations? Capacity Gap, calculated by subtracting the current supply from the required hoursSample Capacity Overview Insight (Narrative Style): Based on your current delivery plan, your team requires 2330 hours per year to cover all CS activities across your VIP, High Touch, Mid Touch, and Low Touch clients. These hours are distributed across various cadences, with the majority consumed by Ad-Hoc and Monthly engagements. Your current team, composed of two partially allocated resources, provides only 1,200 hours annually, covering just over 50% of the requirement. This creates a shortfall of ~1,130 hours or 1.14 full-time equivalents (FTEs).Recommendations Example:? Increase Capacity – Add 1–2 full-time employees (FTEs) focused on proactive work for VIP and High-Touch clients. These segments drive the most strategic value and therefore deserve experienced customer service (CS) coverage.? Ramp Up Strategically – Prioritize capacity improvements for Annual and Quarterly activities in high-impact segments first, while deferring lower-impact cadences in mid- and low-segment activities.? Automate or Delegate – Utilize automation or internal admin support to absorb routine or Ad-Hoc workload for Low-Touch clients. This frees up strategic CS time without sacrificing responsiveness.This capacity-based role planning ensures that your CS Engagement Strategy and Playbook delivery model are grounded in realistic execution, sustainable staffing, and segment-aligned delivery rhythm.

App Cover PageMost MSPs struggle to scale Customer Success because they don’t have a clear strategy for matching effort to value. You might be over-servicing small clients or under-delivering to your best ones, not because of intent, but because there’s no system. To fix this, we need to answer four critical questions:1. How much revenue do we generate from each client segment?2. How much time can we realistically allocate to each segment based on that revenue?3. What types of high-value engagements are appropriate and deliverable for each segment?4. And critically, do we even have enough resources to support all segments, or are we overcommitted without knowing it?The CS Strategy Builder walks you through each of these questions. By the end, you’ll have a capacity-aware, value-aligned strategy that defines who gets what, and ensures your team can deliver it.

When your CS plan and vision are aligned to your organization’s top-level strategy, your team will buy in more easily and execute with confidence. You avoid a “bolt-on” feeling and instead build a plan that both staff and leadership can support.? CS TouchpointsCustomer Touchpoints represent the moments and ways your MSP interacts with clients, tailored to their strategic value and revenue contribution. Capturing and analyzing revenue by client segment provides critical insight into where your Customer Success efforts should focus. MSPs risk misallocating resources without understanding how much revenue comes from each segment, over-servicing low-value accounts while under-serving their most strategic clients.Accurate segmentation by Monthly Recurring Revenue (MRR) bands allows you to define distinct client engagement levels—from high-touch, strategic partnerships to light-touch, automated check-ins. This segmentation forms the foundation for sustainable Customer Success operations by aligning service depth with economic impact.
Step 2: Segment Your Clients by MRR BandsCustomer Touchpoints represent the moments and ways your MSP interacts with clients, tailored to their strategic value and revenue contribution. Capturing and analyzing revenue by client segment provides critical insight into where your Customer Success efforts should focus. MSPs risk misallocating resources without understanding how much revenue comes from each segment, over-servicing low-value accounts while under-serving their most strategic clients.What are Client Segments Based on MRR Bands?While this tool currently supports segmentation primarily by MRR to help MSPs prioritize Customer Success resources based on financial impact, the most robust segmentation models combine MRR with strategic readiness—meaning client maturity and appetite. We recommend using MRR as a starting point, but over time, layering in maturity and appetite data for more precise, value-driven engagement The most common segmentation model divides clients into four tiers:? Segment A — VIP Touch: Clients generate $10,000+ MRR, requiring frequent strategic engagement and executive involvement.? Segment B — High Touch: Clients generate $5,000–$10,000 MRR and receive regular, formal cadence and advisory sessions.? Segment C — Mid Touch: Clients generating $2,500–$5,000 MRR, managed with quarterly reviews and tactical check-ins.Segment D — Light Touch: Clients generating below $2,500 MRR, typically served with automated or ad hoc communications.Why is this segmentation important?? It ensures that your highest-value clients receive the time and strategic focus they require.? It prevents unnecessary over-investment in clients whose revenue or appetite doesn’t justify it.? It helps set internal and client expectations about service levels and engagement frequency.How should you assign segments?? Use actual MRR data from your billing or CRM systems.? Sort clients by MRR and divide into bands representing roughly equal portions of total revenue, not just client counts.? Align engagement strategies and Customer Success efforts according to segment assignments.What if your segmentation needs adjustment?? If you are over-serving low-value clients, consider shifting your segment boundaries upward, meaning fewer clients qualify as high-touch.? Conversely, if too many clients fall into high-touch segments and your team is overwhelmed, you may need to move clients to lower-touch segments to maintain sustainable service.? Use Health metrics such as Engagement, Adoption, and Alignment scores to refine segmentation decisions over time.How can you improve segmentation accuracy?? Regularly review and update your segment assignments at least quarterly.? As your data maturity improves, begin incorporating health signals and business goal readiness (maturity/appetite) in addition to pure MRR to refine segmentation.? Use feedback from both your team and clients to validate that each segment receives the right level of service.? If your CRM or PSA allows, automate updates to keep segmentation accurate as clients grow, shrink, or change focus.
CS CapabilitiesBuilding a scalable and effective Customer Success operation requires deeply understanding your team's capabilities and how they align with your client portfolio. The CS Capabilities block focuses on three essential dimensions that determine your ability to deliver consistent, high-value outcomes:? Engagement Strategy: How you segment clients by revenue bands and allocate your Customer Success investment accordingly. This ensures your highest-value clients receive appropriate attention while lower-tier clients are efficiently managed.? Hourly Cost: The fully loaded cost of your Customer Success resources, including salaries, benefits, overhead, and other indirect expenses. Knowing this cost is crucial to translating budget into actionable time capacity and realistic staffing plans.? Proactive Effort: The balance between planned, strategic Customer Success activities (quarterly business reviews, roadmap sessions, and budgeting meetings) and reactive, ad hoc client support or escalations. Managing this balance is critical to driving forward-looking value while handling day-to-day client needs.Without clear insight into these three areas, MSPs risk misallocating resources—over-servicing small accounts while under-serving high-potential clients. This imbalance can lead to burnout, inconsistent client experiences, and ultimately lost growth opportunities. MSPs build a sustainable and scalable Customer Success engine by quantifying engagement investment, understanding real resource costs, and managing proactive vs. reactive efforts.This capability framework supports internal resource planning and helps MSP leadership make data-driven decisions about segmentation, playbook design, and staffing. It links financial inputs to strategic outputs, enabling MSPs to confidently scale Customer Success without sacrificing quality or relevance.
Step 3: Define Your Engagement Investment ModelEngagement Strategy: How you segment clients by revenue bands and allocate your Customer Success investment accordingly. This ensures your highest-value clients receive appropriate attention while lower-tier clients are efficiently managed.Hourly Cost: The fully loaded cost of your Customer Success resources, including salaries, benefits, overhead, and other indirect expenses. Knowing this cost is crucial to translating budget into actionable time capacity and realistic staffing plans.Proactive Effort: The balance between planned, strategic Customer Success activities (quarterly business reviews, roadmap sessions, and budgeting meetings) and reactive, ad hoc client support or escalations. Managing this balance is critical to driving forward-looking value while handling day-to-day client needs.
Engagement StrategyWhat is an Engagement Strategy and Why Does it Matter?Your Engagement Strategy sets the level of Customer Success investment you’re willing to make for each client segment. This isn’t just a number—it’s a commitment to how much time, effort, and expertise you’ll dedicate to driving value for your clients. The Engagement Strategy defines the bandwidth for strategic meetings, roadmap sessions, proactive playbooks, and more.A clear, realistic Engagement Strategy ensures that your most valuable clients receive high-touch, strategic guidance, while your mid- and lower-tier segments are managed with efficient, scalable processes. It is the bridge between your financial planning and the actual client experience.Why is Choosing the Right Engagement Level Important?Setting your engagement level too high leads to overpromising and team burnout; too low, and you risk underdelivering to key accounts and missing growth opportunities. The right Engagement Strategy makes your Customer Success effort:? Predictable: You know exactly how much resource you’re allocating per segment.? Scalable: You avoid spreading your team too thin as you grow.? Strategic: You deliver the right engagement rhythm for each client’s value and potential.What Engagement Investment Levels Should You Consider?Most MSPs adopt one of five standard models:? Boutique – 9%: Deep, white-glove engagement for VIP clients. (Frequent executive sessions, heavy vCIO/CSM involvement, detailed planning.)? Premium – 7%: High-touch, regular strategy and roadmap reviews for your top growth clients.? Standard – 5%: Balanced, structured engagement for your core client base—quarterly meetings, periodic playbooks, roadmap and budget sessions.? Value – 3%: Lean engagement, with semi-annual reviews and playbooks, mostly virtual.? Cost Driver – 1%: Tech-touch or automation-driven engagement, triggered only by issues or annual reviews.Choose the investment level that fits each segment, based on their MRR, strategic importance, and maturity.How Do You Assign the Engagement Model to Segments?? Start with Segmentation: Use your client segments (A, B, C, D or VIP, High Touch, Mid Touch, Tech Touch) as defined by MRR bands and strategic fit.? Match Investment to Segment: Assign higher engagement models (e.g., Boutique, Premium) to your highest-value or highest-potential segments. Assign Value or Cost Driver to your smallest, least strategic segments.? Document Your Choices: For each segment, record the % of MRR to be reinvested as Customer Success effort.Example Table:SegmentTypical MRREngagement Model% CS InvestmentNotesSegment A$10,000+Boutique9%Executive sponsor, monthlySegment B$5,000+Premium7%vCIO/CSM, quarterlySegment C$2,500+Standard5%TAM/AM, quarterly/virtualSegment D$0+Value/Cost Driver3%/1%Tech touch, annual/reportsHow Do You Use These Percentages in Planning?? Calculate the Annual CS Budget: Multiply the chosen % by the client’s annual MRR.? Convert to Time: Divide the CS budget by your hourly cost to find how many hours you can realistically dedicate.? Set Cadence: Decide what meetings, playbooks, or touchpoints fit within this time.? Assign Roles: Ensure that the right CS roles (e.g., vCIO, CSM, TAM) are aligned to segments based on the engagement level.What if Your Engagement Model Doesn’t Work in Practice?If you find you’re consistently overspending time, or struggling to meet commitments:? Revisit Investment Levels: Reduce engagement percentages for lower-value segments.? Shift Segment Boundaries: Move more clients into lower-touch segments.? Automate Lower-Tier Engagements: Use digital reports, videos, or automated QBRs.? Prioritize Strategic Accounts: Reserve the highest engagement only for clients where it truly drives retention and growth.
—Hourly CostWhat Is the Hourly Cost and Why Is It Important?The hourly cost is the actual, all-in cost of delivering Customer Success work, including salary, benefits, overhead, technology, training, and management. This figure is critical: it translates your strategic intent (e.g., “we’ll spend 5% of MRR on CS”) into realistic, budgeted hours that your team can actually deliver.Knowing your hourly rate allows you to plan, price, and scale Customer Success sustainably—so you avoid overcommitting resources, underestimating CS spend, or undervaluing your most important client relationships.Why Does Accurate Cost Calculation Matter?? Budget Realism: You can’t allocate hours you can’t afford—knowing your real cost protects margins and prevents staff overload.? Staffing Decisions: If your average CS hourly rate is $80, you’ll know exactly how many hours each CS team member can deliver per year, and how many FTEs you’ll need as you grow.? Transparent Planning: With a clear hourly cost, every segment, engagement plan, and playbook cadence can be mapped to a tangible delivery plan.How Should You Calculate the Hourly Rate?? Include All Costs: Add up gross salary, benefits (healthcare, taxes, PTO), software and tooling, training, and a portion of management/overhead.? Calculate Total Available Hours: Typically, 1 FTE = 1,680–1,800 hours/year, but only 60–75% is available for client-facing CS (the rest is admin, meetings, internal work).? Divide Total Cost by Available Hours: This gives you a realistic, loaded hourly cost for CS delivery.Example Calculation:? Salary + Benefits + Overhead per CS FTE: $120,000/year? Available client-facing hours: 1,500? Hourly Rate: $120,000 ÷ 1,500 = $80/hourYou can select from typical benchmarks:? $60/hour (lean team, minimal overhead)? $80/hour (average MSP, some specialization)? $100/hour (specialized CS roles, high-touch segments)How to Use the Hourly Cost in Practice?? Calculate Hours Per Client: Annual CS budget for each client ÷ hourly cost = number of hours you can allocate to that client.? Set Delivery Expectations: If you promise quarterly QBRs and roadmap sessions, check if your budgeted hours can cover that level of engagement.? Plan Staffing: Sum up hours across all clients and segments; divide by each FTE’s available hours to see how many CS team members you’ll need.Example Table:SegmentAnnual CS BudgetHourly RateHours AvailableSegment A$9,000$10090Segment B$4,500$9050Segment C$3,000$7540Segment D$1,500$7520What if Costs Are Too High or Too Low?? If your real cost is higher than planned, reduce engagement intensity, automate lower-tier interactions, or adjust your CS investment levels.? If costs are low, check if you’re underinvesting in critical roles or missing opportunities for strategic impact.How Can You Improve Cost Accuracy Over Time?? Track Real-Time: Use timesheets or time-tracking to monitor real CS hours per client and compare to the plan.? Recalculate Annually: Update your loaded rate as salaries, tooling, or benefits change.? Adjust for Specialization: For advanced CS roles (vCIO, BI/AI, regulatory), use a blended or premium rate as needed.By setting a transparent, realistic hourly cost for Customer Success, you can connect your strategic plan to operational reality, ensuring every hour and dollar is well spent.
—-Proactive EffortWhy Is the Proactive/Reactive Split Critical?The proactive/reactive split defines how much of your Customer Success time is invested in planned, strategic activities (like annual planning, QBRs, roadmap sessions, and playbooks) versus unplanned, reactive work (like incident response, last-minute escalations, ad-hoc meetings, or client “firefighting”).A sustainable CS program isn’t just about doing “more”—it’s about doing the right things at the right time. The ideal ratio (e.g., 60% proactive / 40% reactive) keeps your team out of firefighting mode and ensures you have enough bandwidth for real client impact.Why Does This Balance Matter?? Client Experience: Proactive CS drives trust, alignment, and strategic results—reactive CS is necessary but can dominate if not managed.? Team Wellbeing: Too much reactive work leads to burnout, errors, and missed strategic opportunities.? Growth & Retention: Planned, proactive engagements (QBRs, roadmap reviews, playbooks) are the strongest drivers of upsell, retention, and client advocacy.How Should You Set Your Proactive/Reactive Ratio?? Benchmark Typical Split: Most high-performing MSPs aim for 60–80% of CS time on proactive, planned work (e.g., annual, quarterly, monthly playbooks).? Start with 60/40: As a baseline, allocate 60% of CS hours to proactive engagements and 40% to reactive/ad-hoc work.? Adjust by Segment: VIP and High Touch clients get a higher proactive ratio; low-touch or tech-touch segments may need more reactive coverage.How Do You Track and Allocate This Effort?? Define Planned Activities: List all recurring playbooks and strategic engagements (annual reviews, QBRs, roadmap, budgeting, executive check-ins).? Track Ad-Hoc Time: Use time-tracking to log unplanned requests, escalations, or support-driven meetings.? Review Regularly: Compare planned vs. actual effort quarterly to stay on track.Example Table:SegmentAnnual CS HoursProactive %Proactive HoursReactive HoursSegment A10860%6543Segment B5460%3222Segment C2760%1611Segment D1860%117What if Your Proactive Time Is Too Low?? Automate Reactive Tasks: Use reporting, alerts, or self-service for basic requests.? Reduce Planned Touchpoints for Lower Segments: Focus effort where it has the greatest impact.? Coach Clients: Train clients to use structured CS engagements (like QBRs) instead of requesting ad-hoc calls.How Can You Improve the Proactive Ratio?? Batch Routine Work: Group similar client tasks into dedicated sessions.? Expand Playbook Usage: Use more templates and standardized agendas to reduce prep time.? Monitor and Adjust: Routinely revisit the ratio, especially if the team or client needs a shift.Step 4. CAPACITY Result PageThis page summarizes your Customer Success team’s available capacity across each client segment—VIP, High touch, Mid touch, and Low touch—based on your engagement strategy, hourly cost, and proactive planning ratio. For every segment, you’ll see a breakdown of annual, quarterly, monthly, and ad-hoc hours, plus the total planned CS time. Use this matrix to quickly identify if your available hours align with your client commitments and to spot any over- or under-allocation before you set playbook parameters. Adjust your strategy here to maintain balance between high-value engagement and team sustainability.
CS CapabilitiesThe CS Capabilities Block helps you map out the true power of your Customer Success organization. In this tool, all three—Vertical Competency, Growth Opportunities, and Business Capabilities—are considered together under the 'CS Capabilities' umbrella. Mapping these collectively ensures you can deliver, expand, and differentiate Customer Success in a unified, strategic way:1. Vertical Competency: What industries (verticals) do you truly understand—where your team knows the client’s data, workflows, compliance, and pain points?2. Growth Opportunities: What additional services can you cross-sell, up-sell, or expand into within your current client base, using a vendor-neutral service catalog?3. Business Capabilities: What can your team confidently deliver in front of the client, from strategic planning to financial management, assessments, and more?Defining these capabilities ensures you play to your strengths, know where you can stretch, and spot the most valuable opportunities for CS-driven growth. The goal: build a living map of what you do best, what you can grow into, and how you’ll support clients at every stage of maturity or industry focus.When you combine these three lenses, you get a practical “capabilities matrix” to match your team, services, and industry expertise to the evolving needs of your client portfolio. This is the bedrock for setting realistic CS strategy, staffing plans, and growth forecasts.
Step 5. Map Your Strategic CS CapabilitiesBusiness Capabilities: This is what your CS team can confidently deliver in front of a client: not just technical tasks, but business-facing skills like strategic planning, discovery workshops, budgeting, compliance reviews, etc.Growth Opportunities: A growth opportunity is any additional service—cross-sell, upsell, or expansion—you can offer to existing clients. It’s mapped to a standardized, vendor-neutral service catalog so you can track adoption and plan initiatives across the whole base.Vertical Competency: Vertical competency means your team has real-world expertise in a specific industry or sector (e.g., Education, Banking, Healthcare). It’s not just about having a few clients in the space—it’s about understanding the business model, workflows, compliance needs, and technology stack that matter for those clients.
